content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												It's certainly novel for a game's subtitle to boast of your impending slaughter, but Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition is unusual in most respects. Its combat is abnormally precise, its narrative is largely embedded within optional NPC interactions, and its multiplayer features are unconventional and initially largely hidden. While the PC version is a shabby port, there is simply no other action RPG out there like Dark Souls, which is so good that it adversely affected my opinion of how all previous RPGs handled combat. However, I must start out with a warning: the PC port is a disappointing wasted opportunity to technically improve on the console version of Dark Souls, and it lacks many features you probably expect as standard. The resolution is locked at 1280x720 (aka 720p), the framerate is locked at 30fps, and there are no high resolution textures. There's a mouse & keyboard control option, but control is so bad that it's not practical, so you'll definitely want a gamepad to play. Fortunately, there's a must-have unofficial patch available that improves the rendering resolution. With it, everything looks much crisper, although you're stuck with low-resolution textures.That said, Dark Souls is still an amazing game. There's no hand-holding - to succeed, you need to invest time diligently exploring, learning the combat system, and developing your skills to overcome challenges. The open-world design makes it likely that you'll wander into high-level areas that'll mercilessly slap some perspective into your character. It's a tough, but fair experience. Deaths aren't cheap, but success needs to be well earned. Dark Souls – likes it predecessor – is a third-person dungeon crawl at its core. In the almost overbearingly gloomy realm of Lordran, a sizeable open-world that you’ll explore high and low, threats loom just about anywhere you look. From a few established hubs in the world, you’ll expand outward, constantly facing adversity in the endless gnarled faces of ever-dangerous creatures that stand between you and ending the calamotous period called the Age of Fire…or, if the tone of the world sucks you under, to usher in a different calamity entirely. The game’s plot is purposely minimalistic and tells its story through the limitations of its sparsely populated world. Like most everything else in the game, the flavour of the game’s lore and plot is largely left with the player’s curiousity and interpretation, which suits it just fine. Dark Souls is a game focused squarely on combat that demands precision, smarts, and persistence.Most action-oriented games place you in frenetic fights that move swiftly, and although fluidity is very much a key to success in Dark Souls, the combat here feels weighty and deliberate. Your character’s movements, burdened with heavy armour and weaponry, feel appropriately strained. You can’t make a last minute dodge out of harm’s way or just mash on the attack button, either. Every action in the game is methodical yet extremely powerful if used judiciously and properly. Each blow you land and fatal swipe you dodge is the result of skilled observation and timing, of knowing your characters strengths and limits and exploiting each to the fullest. Know your character and pull your punches wisely, and you’ll slay the toughest of foes. Attack wildly and evade flippantly, and you’ll soon find your enemies taking advantage of your every misstep.Death is swift and common in Dark Souls, though it’s never an end. In fact, your character will likely be dead – or “hollowed” – for much of your play time, complete with a decayed and eyeless face. Each time you die, you’ll lose all of the souls you accrued from enemies – which serve as both experience points to upgrade your stats and currency to purchase items – and respawn at the last bonfire you visited, which serve as sigh-relieving points of rest in the game world. Bonfires refill your stock of estus flasks – the game’s healing item – as well as recharge uses of your spells. Yet even these points of safety come with a catch; use a bonfire, and all enemies excepting bosses respawn, ready to make an attempt on your life once more.The game’s death mechanics also introduce yet another unique aspect to Dark Souls – the importance and privelige of being alive. Although your character handles the same way no matter their state, using valuable Humanity items at a bonfire to turn your character back into a living being opens up a ton of online connectivity features. Although you can’t play Dark Souls in a multiplayer setting or set up matchmaking with your friends, each individual player does slightly connect to all others. You may see ghostly images of other players appear around you, real-time feed of where they are and what they’re doing in their own game. When you’re alive, you can find and use items to summon players into your game temporarily, using them to help you clear more difficult sections. Ultimately, you get out what you put in to Dark Souls. There’s a dizzying amount of nuance and detail in the game’s setting, level design and combat, and it only gets more engrossing as you sink your teeth in further. The more you change up your fighting style and take risks, the more you learn about what makes the enemies tick, and brings possible methods for felling them to the surface. There’s no easing you into play mechanics or tips popping up on screen to give you a hand in Dark Souls. You not only need to take chances and be proactive in your approach to its many challenges, you need to remember everything that works and apply it skillfully. Equipment choices can have more than one impact - heavy armor not only blocks more damage than lighter equipment, it also makes your character less likely to be thrown off balance when hit. Large shields have great stability, which allows your blocks to use less stamina, but light shields allow you to better land devastating ripostes. Some weapons inflict damage dependent upon attributes such as Strength. If you've neglected the attributes that modify weapon damage, you can instead use elemental weapons that don't rely upon attribute modifiers, or chaos weapons that scale with consumable Humanity points. If you find it difficult to get parry timing down, ignore it and use heavy shields for blocking or rely more upon rolling. Enemies and items don't scale in strength as you level, so if you become skilled enough at combat you can complete the storyline and grab the most powerful equipment as a very low-level character. The Prepare to Die Edition also adds three new areas that provide some new insight into the setting's history: a crumbling cityscape, a forest, and an area of the Abyss that's haunted by Humanity ghosts. The cityscape is the only one that impresses, as the others feel too redundant next to the original content, but the new enemies make them worth playing, including some misshapen humanoids with headstalks that can be seen in darkness and some tough stone guardians who slam their hammer so viciously into the ground that yanking them out causes an explosion of turf. The new bosses include the fallen Knight Artorias, a key figure in the lore, and a ferocious Dragon which is so tough that he's an optional fight. All of the new bosses are frenetic and extremely aggressive combatants, making them at least as tough as those in the original areas. One of those original bosses also makes a very welcome reappearance, in a manner that both fits well with established lore and gives a different tone to the original encounter.With its high difficulty, punitive checkpoint system, and trial-and-error gameplay, Dark Souls isn't for everyone. But with the Prepare to Die Edition, PC gamers finally have a version of Dark Souls to call their own, and longtime fans of the game have some new content to work with. Graphical hiccups aside, that makes this port a success.

												One of my favourite games of all time.I originally played Dark Souls on the Xbox 360 back in the day and i absolutely hated it. The combat was punishing and i had no idea what most of the items did and i would die over and over again and eventully i said something like "♥♥♥♥ this!" and gave up on it.A few weeks later i tried the game again and something just clicked. The combat was still punshing, i still had no idea what most of the items did and i still died over and over again but i learnt that Dark Souls is the kind of game that you have to play by it's rules. Running around trying to be Rambo like you would in any other hack and slash game will do nothing but encourage you to smash your desktop in to little pieces.Pros:- A huge detailed dark fantasy world to explore and die in.- So many different character builds. Do you want to focus on using heavy weapons and pyromancy? You can do that. Want to be a fast moving wizard who can also use a samurai sword? You can do that too. How about a naked man armed only with a broken sword and wooden shield?- Weighty and responsive combat which makes you feel like a badass.- Dozens of cool weapons which all have unique move sets to suit your play style.- Unique online features where you can either choose to help other players or invade their world and ruin their day.- Massive scary, screen filling bosses to get killed by.Cons:- The PC port is hot dog♥♥♥♥♥♥but there are fan made patches which are very easy to find and install.- Blight Town exists. I won't spoil anything but you probably won't like it much either.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												If you're considering buying Dark Souls, you should ask yourself how much you really appreciate a good challenge. Dark Souls is a game that embraces difficulty, and not in a monotonous grind-y way like Ninja Gaiden or I Wanna Be The Guy. Dark Souls does not spoonfeed you victory like so many modern games: it expects you to learn from your mistakes and hopefully prevent them in the future. Persevering through From Software's epic may seem daunting, especially at the beginning, but if you open yourself to it, Lordran can be a fascinating and emotional place. Dark Souls is packed full of monstrosities and deities alike, and although its numerous bosses are not easily felled, triumphing over them will be one of the most rewarding victories you'll likely ever experience.

Posted: September 7, 2016
												Truly, the Dark Souls™ of Video Games™.+ God-tier level design. Everything loops and interconnects in ways that will blow your f*cking mind.+ Infinite replayability. The level design allows so many different experiences if you know where to go.+ Fair and satisfying combat, but it requires patience and every input has to be intentional.+ Very fun and well designed bosses (except a few, see below).+ Every level is intricately designed and detailed (except a few, see below).+ Expert enemy placement.+ Fantastic atmosphere that ranges from comfy to nerve racking.+ A great variety of weapons and armor combos.+ Stats and levels offer a lot of play variety.+ The deepest of lore, you just have to put effort into appreciating.+ Excellent voice acting for what little there is.+ The greatest DLC I've ever played in my life. - The second half (after Anor Londo) feels a bit rushed and notably weaker than the first half.- The Demon Ruins and Lost Izalith are absoulte sh*t in every way compared to the rest of the game.- The Duke's Archives are lackluster as well.- Capra Demon boss is too claustrophobic and a lazy way of creating difficulty.- Moonlight Butterfly boss is boring for any melee only character.- Pinwheel boss is laughably easy.- Seath the Scaleless boss is annoying and very shallow that makes you fight with the framerate more than the boss itself, even with DSFix.- Ceaseless Discharge boss is lazy and has a stupid cheese way of beating it.- Demon Firesage boss is literally a reskinned Asylum Demon.- Centipede Demon boss is unfun and an eyesore with all the lava.- Four Kings boss is nothing more than a DPS rush where you can't even dodge some attacks.- Bed of Chaos boss is one of the worst designed bosses in any video game ever. It's like they didn't even playtest it.Other than almost half the game feeling rushed and 9 of the 26 boss battles being either lame or stright up horrible bosses, the game's positives greatly outweigh the negatives, but they should not be glossed over. Still one of my favorite games and even at its worst it's still better than most games released today 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Dark Souls will be one for the ages to me. This is the kind of game that is completely brutal but rewarding at the same time. I raged, and raged hard at some encounters, because this game holds nothing back, but it forces you to also think on your tactics as you progress through the game. It will give you all the tools you need to get through it, you just need to think and plan accordingly. And they are completely right, the feeling of accomplishment you get upon beating a particularly hard section or encounter is unlike any most games out there can give you. I especially enjoy how big monsters actually FEEL like big monsters, as in, they can easily crush you if you're not careful. It was a thrilling and challenging ride, but I loved it and it is now easily one of my favorite games of all time. Highly replayable as well, there are tons of secrets to find here.Elaborating why I liked this game though, hell, even discussing the minimal detail on this game would actually derail and spoil you the experience, in my honest opinion. This is one of those games you're supposed to pick up and play, while going in completely blind. You'll be shafted many times, count on that, and you'll probably seethe with frustration, but you'll adapt, improve as a player, and maybe even overcome the challenges ahead. This is definitely not a game for everyone though, the difficulty is up there.The port wasn't the best, but I did just fine using an Xbox 360 gamepad and DSFix, an unofficial fix that fixes many of the problems it has - http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix. I was able to go through the game quite well, barring one single crash, and some minor framerate issues here and there. That's better than what any Bethesda RPG can really claim in terms of performance, and I love the hell out of those games too.Bottom line, if you have this game on Steam and didn't play it yet, I URGE you to finish this review, and go install it and play it right now. You may end up loving it or hating it, but either way, you won't come out indifferent to it. Even better, now that Steamworks has finally been implemented, you have no excuse. Go die lots of times, go curse that one boss who keeps kicking your♥♥♥♥♥ it'll all be worth it once you finally manage to beat him down, I promise.Praise the Sun!

number of helpful: 25 of 26 people (96%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												In a world where games are designed to give you kind of power fantasy feeling for doing jack squat, this action RPG is unafraid to punch you in the face. With an iron gauntlet. Spiked. Repeatedly. Telling you to toughen up, learn to dodge, block and/or parry, and above all, fight back.But it's fair at that - when you do learn how to block, dodge, fight back, then you truly know you do deserve that power fantasy feeling. Or deserved to die for failing to dodge or misstepping that ledge and plunging into ever so eagerly welcoming embrace of gravity.Come here if you want to know what a game designed ground up to be challenging, but fair, means. As opposed to misnaming♥♥♥♥♥♥easy difficulty as "normal" and then making "hard" just by halfheartedly upping sponginess and numbers of enemies.Beware though, this game really does not hold your hand in any way and you barely get any pointers what to do or where to go, or what various things mean or do - you may end up needing to do some research on wikis etc.The game has interesting take on multiplayer, creating peer to peer network of game worlds (citing temporal anomalies in game lore) that enables various interactions between players. But that, in terms of PvP, I wouldn't call fair, as the game is min maxer's and twinker's paradise and you *will* get totally funked up by relatively overpowered real human adversaries, which, unlike PvE enemies, will give no room to breathe whatsoever. Unless you become one of them, or play majority of game in "hollow" state which doesn't let you summon help but also prevents other players from invading your world to kill you.But yeah that summoning of help, letting willing players help you kill bosses - or trying to help others yourself - is part of multiplayer experience as well, along with getting that feeling of shared struggle, seeing various messages left by others or just their apparitions as they hang out by the bonfire or fight in their own world.. and die.The world design is really great (though I think designers had some fetish towards flying buttresses which suspiciously often feature as the only bridge forward). All in all the world is not too huge, and not too open, but is very interconnected, like a tree becoming a graph, opening up more and more, where completing one segment allows you to open a shortcut to places you already visited. It's always a great feeling, recognizing some place you've already been to, now approaching it from a different side... Or even remembering that this ruin up on the hill you've seen the other day, now you're in it, looking down at the ruins you've been into a few days back. You get this sense of adventure, exploration, cohesive but diverse world, dread, desperation, death, misery, sublime, wonder, having to decide on your own which branch of the world to explore next, until you meet a dead end, temporary or otherwise, or the local boss to defeat (and sense of accomplishment once the deed is done), and then repeat, explore, fight, git gud.Praise the sun!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game is literally all about you dieing over and over again until you know what in the ♥♥♥♥ you're doing. It's not as hard as people say but playing through the game for the first time can be really frustrating. This game doesn't hold your hand, but it doesn't try to cut off your wrist either. The story is very vague unless you take the time to dig through every description of every item or if you bother talking to the NPCs. You aren't told where to go but what you must do, its up to you to figure out what works best for you, how much you want to engage in the online play (which on this PC port it takes forever to connect to anyone without the use of mods), and how you wish to take on your enemies as you progress. There are quite a few optional places to go, lots of loot to find, and many enemies to kill along the way. Take your time and absorb all of the information the game throws at you, enjoy your first experience through the game. I recommend playing with a controller as the keyboard and mouse controls are just terrible without mods, if you want to play with a very active online community you should aim for one of the console releases of the game, though there is still a bit of a PC community for this game.

												One of the most brilliant RPGs of recent years, a legitimate heir to Severance: Blade of Darkness[en.wikipedia.org], Gothic (by Piranha Bytes) and Rune. Dark Souls makes you re-evaluate your understanding of gaming process, challenges all your skills and nerves, and gives you a rare sense of deep immersion on that very special and rare scale. Not recommended for casual gamers and kids. World of pain, tortures  and death ahead. And strange sun cults, and demons, and big snakes, and spiders, and skeletons. And Mushrooms. And lots of strange and crazy stuff.  Still, get the game and play it already! It's a rare gem you're missing. And remember - it's only possible to learn through death. TLDR: 10/10 brilliant\О/

content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												What is the best part about playing a video game? Is it the thrill of watching the visual effects of a plane crash through a building and the amazement of the graphical destruction caused by the building crashing down to pieces? Is it the Hollywood style action sequences which keep the adrenaline rush going till you eventually want to jump out from the window to try and catch that ledge? Is it the thrill of racing or playing in a football game which one might not be able to achieve in real life? All of these can qualify as perfectly valid reasons for playing video games. But for me, they’re a bit too superficial. My reasons for playing games are much more basic. For me, its all about failing and trying again to correct myself. The possibility of death and the chance of life after it really intrigue me. I love a challenge, and i love to be rewarded for playing well and punished for being stupid. And in that regard, i feel Dark Souls is one of the best games i’ve ever played.

OCENA: 10/10 (ZAJEBISTA!)Gra potrafiąca wzbudzić w nas masochistyczne zapędy. Giniemy, wściekawy się, przeklinamy i rwiemy włosy z głowy, jednocześnie świetnie się bawiąc.PLUSY:+Doskonały model walki obejmujący wszystkie potrzebne akcje+Świetnie dobrany poziom trudności, dzięki któremu gra bez przerwy stawia przed nami wyzwania. Trudność jest sprawiedliwa i zależna od umiejętności gracza, każda śmierć jest wynikiem błędów. +Zróżnicowany i świetnie zaprojektowany świat, połączony w genialny sposób licznymi skrótami. +Mimo stosunkowo małej jak na RPG powierzchni, zwiedzania jest tu mnóstwo. Projekty lokacji są fantastyczne i mimo nie powalającej jakości technicznej, robią wrażenie.+Zróżnicowani przeciwnicy atakujący na różne sposoby, walka z każdym z nich to inna bajka i należy się nauczyć ich zachowań i słabości. +Zapadające w pamięć batalie z bossami o świetnej stylistyce i przemyślanym poziomie trudności. +Świetnie dobrana muzyka, zarówno w czasie normalnej gry jak i w czasie walki z bossami (szczególne wrażenie: Ornstein & Smough)+Rozbudowany system ulepszania broni, pozwalający nawet na pozór niezbyt ciekawe przeobrazić w coś świetnego+Mądrze zaprojektowane i ograniczone do 20 eliksiry uzdrawiające, odnawiające się pod wizycie przy ognisku. Posted: January 14, 2015
Teal DeerDevelopers: FromSoftwarePublishers: Bandai Namco Entertainment Initial release: Aug 2012Genre: Action, RPG, Dark#Worth/NotWorth: #Worth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationI really like this game. It's punishing but boy is it rewarding. I never played Demon Souls so this is my first "Souls" experience. (Lets just pretend the GFWL and DSfix stuff never happened, it runs great) Going through this blind the first time, it was literally one of the most nerve racking and scary games I've ever played (scary in the sense of losing everything you've earned thus far in a single instance.) What I really enjoyed about it was that it feels similar to how rogue-likes are played but within a over-arching game. Every death you learn something new. The game never feels like it cheating you. It's always telling you to be more patient, more cautious and punishing you when you fail to heed to the lessons you hopefully learned. The in depth lore that has to be searched for and interpreted has pros and cons. I personally found  the digging to be well worth it. You could say that it could use a minimap but I would argue that having to remember the maps, item locations, and enemy traps are what gives it the essence of "Souls".I continue to mess around and play with diffirent character builds. Very satisfying experience.Follow my curation for more

Posted: December 15, 2016
												I was particularly stressed out because of work, exams at uni and issues in my personal life when I started to play this game, so this was my little island of peace where I could calm my nerves after a long day... I don't understand what's the big fuss with this game, I've only broken 2 keyboards, a table and my arm in outbursts of rage.Ok, jokes aside I've bought this game in 2014, played it for 15 minutes, got killed by the Asylum Demon, uninstalled the it and I didn't touch it for 2 years. I'm not sure why... usually I'm not a whiny little b...ch when it comes to a challange in games but I gave it another shot a few weeks ago and oh boy... I was an idiot back then. I probably still am but that's another thing.This game is an absolute beast! The scenery is diverse and jaw-dropping even by today's standards (at least for me), the gameplay gives a solid challange, and the boss fights are epic. Yes, it's hard, yes, you'll die a 1000 times (I sure did) but as you play more you'll get better and the joy that you feel when you kick a boss'♥♥♥♥♥after failing so many times will compensate you for the pain/anger/despair etc that you've felt after every failed attempt.The only downside for me was the "lack of story"... I'm a sucker for a great plot in games (normally for me the story matters the most) but here It seemed like the story is not an organic part of the game, maybe I just didn't pay enough attention but it was pretty hazy and uninteresting to me. The other thing that I missed was a badass soundtrack... especially at bosses. There are a few good scores but for most of the time it's pretty forgettable. I had to put in some rock songs during boss fights to get myself in a pumped-up state in order to beat the s..t out of them.Overall; the game is fun/hard like hell and I'll definitely pick up the sequels as soon as I can!

A blaze of fire carpeted the path from the door, and seconds later, the wooden obstacle was blown from its hinges. The Legend had arrived.Without even breaking a sweat, Giantdad grabbed the hacker by the head in mid-swing, twisting him so he looked at the face of No-Mercy right in the eyes."Wt rings u gt, bicth?" it asked, without really caring to hear the answer.The hacker squirmed under the intense grip, swinging his Crystal Greatsword madly. "You only live once, ♥♥♥♥♥," it continued, impaling the hacker with its Chaoshander +5. "Unless you're a Legend."Then, the Legend falcon-punched the hacker, slicing his head from his shoulders in less than a second. Giantdad surveyed the scene, pleased with his work, and began to walk away.Then, as if forgetting something, it turned back around, and strode up to one of the only still-functional cameras in the room, and held his arms out wide in a gesture that it could pull off successfully. Finally, it whispered something so powerful, one would need an oscilloscope to appreciate it properly."THE LEGEND NEVER DIES!"

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Dark Souls is easily one of my favorite games ever made. The gameplay is sophisticated, but it isn't too complicated once you understand the stats and what they mean. Controls are tight, and everything works as it should. The world is deep and rich with an interesting lore that isn't shoved in your face. You basically have to read item descriptions and pay close attention if you really want to understand the world From has crafted. Or you can just do what normal people do and kill stuff and move on. The story of the game is very implicit, but the direction is clear if you talk to NPCs. Multiplayer is a big part of the game, with coop existing by summoning friendly phantoms to assist you in your world. There is also Player vs. Player, which is the main draw for me, and it's fantastic aside from the occasional lag and balancing issues. One of the main problems with the game was that it used Games for Windows Live, but that's gone now and the multiplayer is better than ever. The PC Port is just god awful though. It's locked to a low resolution and framerate and the keyboard controls seem to have been designed by a monkey with half a brain. This is all fixed by Durante's mod DSFix, which is very easily installed. Once everything works as it should, the multiplayer of this game is phenomenal. The game has a reputation for being brutally difficult and unfair, but that's not really true. The game's difficulty comes from its punishing nature. If you make a mistake, you're gonna get messed up. Playing carefully is the best way forward (read: get good). Nothing about the game is intrinsically unfair aside from gravity being overpowered.The community in this game is fantastic as well, but it has its fair share of tryhards that will send hatemail at the slightest infraction of their self-imposed moral code. I've gotten death threats for not bowing before a fight before. You learn to move past these people, and you find some seriously funny and dedicated people that make this game's community great. Youtubers like VaatiVidya, Iron Pineapple, and formerly OnlyAfro (Rest in Peace good Afro) make pretty great videos that also add to the community of the game.In summation, this game is a must-play for anyone that doesn't mind fixing a small amount of issues. The game is punishing, but never unfair and the multiplayer is to die for. Get it? Also, Git Gud

content:
Posted: February 24
												Welcome to dark souls, prepare to die. This will be a review of the full experience including DLCs. You play by freely walking around in third person with full jumping abilitys, even over low railings and with them often..well death. Enemies will have a certain aggro range and once you reach this they approach you, you hit the enemy by having them be where your attack lands, akin to Skyrim for comparison, only third person.Dark souls adds a lock-on mechanic on top of this, meaning you then permanently aim at the enemy when using it, allowing you to control where you attacks are directed to, as well as making dodging a lot easyer by being able to focus where "away" is.In its essence dark souls is like other action RPGs but it doesn't hold your hand or mess around. There is no map, dying makes you lose a decent chunk of progress, "savepoints" are few in between (but you can quit and come back anywhere) and saving brings back all enemies and most importantly all enemies are OP and kill you in barely any time. This is mostly fair though once you get used to the fact that you dont slay mass amounts of enemies and level up but rather fight for dear life constantly. And pretty much all enemies are just a matter of skill, if you master the controls and learn their moveset you will barely take any hits anymore and thus the fact that you die so easyly will matter less. Speaking of controls, for the love of god do this with a controller, even on pc, it makes things a lot more managable. Also they are a bit clunky, which gets improved upon with later parts, for example you can only dodge in 4 directions, even though often you would have needed a couple more.Mastering is easyer said than done though, especially when you choose to fight the enemy close up, you will have to dodge every attack perfectly and in the right direction, know when to attack what to block etc. etc. and the game will punish mistakes by allowing the enemies powerful strikes to get you. This is where all the difficulty comes from, dodged too early twice? Often this means you are dead. This is actually even part of the charm, so a giant monstrosity successfully smacks you with a club, well you should be dead. And look at that you are. It makes you get to learn how enemies behave and to respect them. Once you are done with this you will probably never forget any of the bosses and most of the enemies will remain with you forever, their moveset, how to fight them. And that's not something most slightly more greyish orcs in other games can claim.And o boy the enemy design together with the places you find them in is probably the games strongest point, it makes monstrosities look truly twisted and evil, dragons and giants fearsome and the enemies always fit the locations, knights in castles, killershrooms in forrests, and have a reason for being where they are what they are as well as for trying to kill you. Allthough speaking of looks the game looks even older than it is, obviously no modern standard but I'd say still good enough to be very enjoyable.And once you succeed, once you get into the flow, it feels incredibly rewarding, because all together this means said giant looks like it will just rolfstomp you, and it WILL stomp you so you take all of your skill and roll away right as his giant weapon approaches and attack in the moment of breath his opening leaves for you until you have finally worn him down to death. It just feels like a "realistic" boss fight would and should play out.Also the game usually hints at danger, even though it is subtle, for example with burnt corpses, animating you to run for your life.Now a couple of difficulties are unneccesary though. For example as I said there is no map and of course that would break the immersion to a certain degree but you get so damn lost so easyly and until very late in the game you always will have to find your way by foot no fast travel and often not even obvious paths. I believe having a largely reduced map to at least help you out a little would help so much.The cameraangle can also sometimes be your downfall, luckily though this isnt common.And the worst part about the game in my opinion is a lack of guidance about what to do. Again obviously there is reasons not to hold hands and give door by door directions, however, let me just give you an example:right after the tutorial you are at a crossroads. there is many paths to choose and all look like a neat adventure. WRONG all but one of them kill you and there is no real way for you to know except for kind of not being able to beat the enemies and constantly dying. But it is dark souls, perhaps you just need to improve! No, just no, you are running against an impossible wall and dont even know it yet. This goes further with how ridicoulous the things you need to do to advance get. It is basically talk to NPC A then go back get item B at location C and then and ONLY then you can advance in a place that is nowhere near any of this and seems to have absolutely nothing to do with any of it. This is some hold the red orb and jump in a tornado type of how are you supposed to know that.Also some of the bosses are just absolutely hard even for Darksouls standards, requiring pitch perfect reactions even more than other enemies and coming at you with incredible ferocity, basically forcing you into a 3 minute cycle of perfection or death. Most of these are optional though. There is actually a lot of extra content, new enemies places bosses etc. both via DLC and just in the game in general for that extra touch of everything that makes Dark souls what it is.FInally the story: it's complicated. Aside from an absolutely amazing introduction there is no cutscenes to establish anything and while you know your general world and goal kinda, there is such an incredible hidden amount of lore. Like you kill a boss and its eh whatever, though it looked neat, but in reality this was person X responsible for event Y and major player in the history of the world, but you will never know that, because tidbits are hidden in item descriptions of all places, NPC dialogs and most importantly piecing together piece by piece and theorizing. Oh and the music is pretty neat, subtle, underlining the emotion rather than setting it and just great tracks.A final key note: multiplayer. At this very moment a revival event is happening and you can actually find people again but thats like once a year and only a few days. At all others times there is a chance you are literally the only person in the game and this kills a lot of gameplay, though not key experiences they are a defining part of what makes this game. For example in certain areas of the game another player could choose to jump into your world to fight you, because things arent already hard enough. Or the fact that there is a certain selection of texts applyable anywhere in the world for all to see. (and this is usually used to write "treasure" at the edge of a cliff) there is "covenants" basically factions in the game with their own items places rewards concepts etc and there is a LOT of them. All pretty much useless without multiplayer. So if you check this game out see when the next revival event is and then see how the entire experience changes.Tl:DR:amazing setting and design, brutally complicated, buy if you love piecing together a great story fantasy action RPGs, fast reaction based challenges.Got eaten alive by a lootbox 10/10

Posted: March 8, 2016
My Personal Score: 4.5/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]Issues: This is a very unoptimized port. Visit the PCGW page before you click the purchase button.DLC: None. Prepare To Die Edition comes packaged with the Artorias of the Abyss DLC from the consoles.Microtransactions: None.Dark Souls is a very difficult game, yet my experience with it can only be described as gratifying. It consistently challenged me and appropriately rewarded my efforts for taking risks, never treating me like a child that requires constant hand-holding, but as an adult who can assess and adapt to the situation at hand. The game forced me to be patient and calculating, testing my limits, and mocking everything that I knew about games, but all of the challenges that I came across were worth it in the end because it gave me that satisfying sigh that one gets after overcoming an obstacle which kept you in place for minutes - even hours - on end. It will be jarring at first, but if you're prepared to die (a lot) and willing to take challenges which the modern gamer would quickly deem intolerable, I'm sure you'll be rewarded with the same satisfaction that Dark Souls gave its players.And there you have it.

content:
Posted: March 20
												+Cool art design and lore that goes together.+Good combat.Slow and steady gameplay. Helps you focus to the fights and think before acting.+Good level design.+Nice enemy&boss variety.+Challenging but not unfair. It's not trial&error but rather being careful and patient enough to avoid mistakes. And trying to learn from your mistakes if you failed.o PVP and Co-op are features but they're not polished at all.o The lore is there but it is too subtle. I wouldn't mind at least some dialogues from all those characters you talk to.o The shields are too good. If you can't use them you're bad and if you have a better shield you're better.o Backstabs are too powerful. But it is not like the game is easy. You don't have to abuse it if you don't want to but this will not stop the game from killing you. A perfectly balanced game would make a dull game anyway so why not.- The port is beyond bad. It is dreadful. The resolution is low, fps drops, keyboard&mouse support is bad, you can't play with your friends. You gotta find some mods to fix those issues and they don't fix them completely. (There are mods for resolution and connectivity with your friends. FPS is still an issue and don't know about a keyboard mod.)- Netcode sucks for PVP, get backstabbed from front.- Some builds are not viable at all. You can choose to be a sorcerer but it is really easier to just go strength.- There are times where you will be frustrated because of bad AI, a weird platform that you can't stand on. But the game is about observing before acting and learning from your mistakes so it is not that bad.This game is hardly perfect, but it is a game. It let's you do your thing, find your way through challenges, it does not hold your hand. Like a game should do. This game is all about the game and nothing more. It knows what it is, it does not pretend to be a good PVP experience or a Co-op game. You have to go out of your way to use those features anyway. The good part is: This is a difficult game right? So You don't feel guilty when you can abuse the game, use your items, upgrade them, try magic, try ranged battle min/max. It is fun when you try to find your way around the game. The game is your enemy, you beat it as it beats you, but you still love it.This game is perfect in its imperfections. There are good builds, bad builds, good items, bad items, good bosses, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ enemies, and some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. But the joy you get from prevailing after all, that is a treasure.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Dark souls, My favorite game, my favorite series. I own 5 copies of this game. Why you ask? well Ill tell you. Demon souls started this new genre. Its an action rpg yes. But its more than that. It is something so new to the gaming world that was desprately needed. A game that you actually playSo many games now hold your hand so much that you are not even really playing the game, you are just clicking a series of actions to keep the game progressing. There are not many games that actually require you to learn the world, the system, the enemies and Much, Much more. Dark souls just does that. it throws you into this unknown world with nothing more that a few scribbled notes on the ground to get you started. Has you killed over and over within 2 minutes of the game, just to give you a hint on what is coming. Yes dark souls is a challenge, But you know what has kept me coming back after nearly 1200 hours over multiple consoles? The reward. The insanely gratifying feeling when you kill that boss after so many tries, Get through that area to that fog door, Finally kill that Hacker who has invaded you 30 times. Nothing, and I MEAN NOTHING   compares to that feeling, Especially no other series. Dark souls holds a special place in my heart, It has been there in the hard times in my life to take my mind somewhere new. Get my head strait. It may have an incredible reputation for being super difficult and you will probably hear someone say it is unfair. It may be difficult, but it is not unfair. Any time you die, it is your fault it is something you didn't do, maybe you did not understand it yet. But that in its essence is what dark souls is. A game to help you understand. A game to help you overcome its challenges and make you better prepared for life. Cause thats really in an essence how we deal with life, LIke a moth Flittering towards a flame.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
													I really wanted to like this game, I really wanted a hard game, What I got was a confusing mess. Dark Souls sets of to be an “Old School” game, where the term old school means confusing, unclear, vague, and downright purposefully clunky. 	I knew what I was getting into, a game that is suppose to be tough at first, but over time has solid mechanics that keep you coming back in the same way Ninja Gaiden (Xbox) was. What this game is, is a complete miss an all cylinders.	The game starts off dumping you into a jail/keep where you have to escape from. During that about 20 minutes are very very basic tutorials. Right bumper = swing, right trigger = heavy swing. Which is good, but right after if gives you the button assignments, nothing. Oh and the stats system and leveling up good luck on that, nothing helpful is said about it. It's worth noting that any time your user has to look up a walk through to understand something as central as what stats do what to an RPG game, the developer should really take a step back and ask “How and what information am I communicating to the user?” If what is needed to be conveyed is central to the understanding of the game system, and is purposefully or negligently concealed you have already made a huge mistake. Dark Souls takes this mistake and makes it a central game mechanic.  	I get the sense that at some point the developers wanted to make a fighting/hack and slash system that was consistent, in that there was no slicing through enemies (because you missed the hit box) which is a good idea. Again though the game comes to a crashing to a halt when you consistently die without any understanding of what you could have done differently to result in a better outcome. Again Dark Souls hides information from the user, you'll get combat pop-up bars that are conveying information but what that information is you are never told. Is that meter something positive or a negative? You won't know because at no point does the game ever clue in the player to what their avatar is dealing with. 	I could go on but I have a feeling I'll be drowned out by people telling me I should have played longer then I did. I'm not a teenager, I have a full time job and I get precious few hours of free time. I do not want to use them dealing with a game that seeks to make itself more challenging by keeping information from me.

												"This game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t." This was my first thought when Asylum Demon wrecked me for the 6th time... Then I saw that door there. And it took me 1 hour! Yeah I wasn't good in this game, so as other newbies, but instead of giving up I countinued because I was curious what challenges await for me. Then I spent another hour finding out that the skeletons don't want be my friends in the graveyard. *Travel in time* Ornstein and Smough (or Pikachu and Snorlax as I call them) was the first boss fight where I felt that now I need help I won't get through here without help. Then I saw a magnificently glowing sing and with that sign I saw promises for the future. Yeah Solaire got wrecked after we took down Pikachu. But then the reward was beauty and *cough* big "melons" >.> what I later found out it was a lie. Okay my review is getting longer so must short it.In short this game was painfully, hard, and sometimes I felt it unfair. Yeah we all know that feel, but it never was unfair, everytime when I died I was about to ragequit but no because then I was thinking "I'm so stupid bc I did this instead of that" the game is rewarding, the reward is that you can survive more, get better, and if you take a time you can figure out the story too. I had this dark feeling every locations in this game like in the Painted World, it was so terrifying seeing those corpses as crows biting them (and the surprise crow people was gave me shiver).And now let me talk about the community and PvP. When I first encountered a fight with another player in my second playthrough I was so scared, I ran to Queelag with my phantom and guess what? I got killed because I didn't watched my back and took a chaos stormin full. But then again community is still helpful and after that the "enemy" helped with the boss. There are a lot of player still doing PvP, there are honourable players, and there are Darkwaiths and Darkmoonblades. If you don't study your enemies they will kill you PvE experience which needs to PvP.I'm not too good  to short things but finally I can say what's wrong with the game. The only thing what it bothers me, that's the summoning faileds and failed to invade nothing else.I would praise this game untill my death and after that too, If only I could be so grossly incadescent.

cons:-Areas left unfinished like Lost Izalith.-Heavy framerate issues even with dsfix, really really bad port in general.-Areas with even more framerate issues.-In a game that encourages different builds, too much value is given to the endurance stat. Also resistance is futile.-DEX makes casting spells faster, which makes no sense-Reusing a really bad boss multiple times.-Durability is a joke.-Gravelord covenant is a messy mess that could have been very entertaining.-White Way covenant is virtually useless.-Good luck invading as a Blade of the Darkmoon (even when this game was at peak population).-Badly designed platforms in Crystal Cave, your character slides like its buttered-covered teflon in some parts.-The Bed of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t-Some rings are unbalanced, allowing to stack multiple benefits to one statistic, flippy ring is still silly.-Most spells are unoriginal, boring stuff (like the multiple soul arrow spells and fireballs).-Camera lock-on clunky at times.-Camera auto-adjust can make you fall from a platform if you're not careful.-Clunky, bad designed interface for the inventory, very limited in options.-Misleading marketing from bamco in the difficulty of the game when that never was the intention of the director.pros:-its a really good game

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												As far as the fun goes, it's the best game in Dark Souls series and one of the best games I played in general.Things I liked the most:- Amazing if not the best world design out there- Breathtaking boss fights that can leave you both amazed and frustrated at times- The whole combat mechanic is very well designed & developed- Very deep lore. You can spend hours just reading what this game is all about- One of the rare games with good Co-op- High learning curve. Even after beating the whole game you will still find yourself learning/trying new stuffThings you should look after:- The graphics are bad, but this didn't affect the overall experience for me- PC optimization is bad. During some boss fights FPS can get as low as 10.- Literally unplayable without a controller (unless you are willing to try out some mods)There is no reason to skip this game if you liked any other from Dark Souls series. The newcomers will have a hard time (that's how it goes with any other Souls game) but at the end it is definitely worth the struggle. You will hear someone saying Git Gud :)If I had to rate this game, it would be 9/10 with optimization issues being the only downside.

number of helpful: 20 of 22 people (91%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game has an incredibly cohesive and immersive world, with great level design and enemy placement. It also features a very responsive combat system, and a wide range of possibilities in character design to add replayability. Unfortuntately, its pvp system features bad netcode and no cheat prevention, but it's still fun at times. The game gets called hard because it refuses to hold your hand and no one knows how to deal with that, but it's not really that difficult--it just has an incredibly steep learning curve. It does require the extensive use of a wiki to fully understand, which is very unfortunate, as there are some mechanics that the game only gives you hints for when in reality you need a textbook, for example, weapon upgrade systems. Luckily, such wikis exist, though at times they get things wrong. Overall, a highly engaging and enjoyable game with a very deep background lore. 8/10.Bad PC port, though.

												Dark Souls, the game everyone recommended me to play, the game I tried to play a few years back, the game I couldn't play because I went in the wrong direction when I started...A year or two later I decided to give it a shot one more time. This time, I took some time to explore every bit of Firelink Shrine (starting location) and found the ACTUAL easier/do-able sarting path, with ennemies that won't one-shot my character.It's hard, very hard. Especially during the first couple of hours. The learning curve is steep but is also super entertaining. Getting your build right, upgrading your weapons and gears, fighting difficult ennemies and epic bosses, progressing through a fantastic storyline, all of these are the reasons I came to love Dark Souls. I died a lot, I sill do, but learning how the game works and how to defeat every ennemy by learning their patterns and their weak spots really helps a lot.PvP in 2016 isn't like it was back then but it still works. I recommend this game to anyone who likes RPGs for their storyline and games with a difficult learning curve.--------------------------------------------------------------Single Player: 10/10 Amazing lore, goergous ennemy design and patterns, stunning landscapeMultiplayer: 7/10 Co-op and PvP both included in the game. Could be betterGraphics: 9/10 Amazing dark theme with beautiful landscapes and interesting locations. Not the most polished graphics but still amazingCommunity: 9/10 Streamers, nice wiki and many videos--------------------------------------------------------------0 Comments	 Subscribe to thread  (?)

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Dark Souls™: Prepare to Die™ Edition (With two ™'s, it's probably trademarked) is the port everyone asked for, but no one really wanted.Prepare to die is a major tagline for the game, and is the last thing your computer will ever hear, because Dark Souls is so hard, it has the ability to manifest bosses in our world inside your machine, to destroy it from the inside.You start off by making your hero with a powerful character creator, rented straight from Bethesda's The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion team, allowing you to create any type of potato you wish.After you finish your vegetable appearing character, you can finally start the game. Owning a game controller will allow you to skip 3 of the bosses: Lord♥♥♥♥♥♥Camera, and the mentally handicapped siamese twins, Keybohd n' Mawz.The gameplay is ripped from Super Mario 64, with platforming and hopping into paintings to fight bosses, with Metroid and Zelda thrown in for good measure. The soundtrack is actually composed completely by Finnish metal band Apocalyptica, who also designed the whole game, Keeping the frames at a crisp 30 frames per second. It also takes advantage of Microsoft's revolutionary service: Games for Windows LIVE, which brings the power of Xbox LIVE right to your PC! I hope you hate playing video games, because Games for Windows LIVE sure does.Trademarked Souls™: Prepare to Trademark™ Edition is a fine edition to steam, and will compete directly with Valve's first person shooter action sidescrolling point n click adventure game DOTA 2.Awful/5

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												Dark Souls: Prepare To Die.Oooohhh, Dark Souls. You know, I actually avoided playing this game at first (but still nabbing it in a pretty good sale, but let it sit for a year or two in my library...) because of the famed difficulty of the game. I just passed it off as something that it didn't really follow it's tagline.Why did I pass this game up?I completely missed it's prime. What do I mean?This is a single player game that combines multiplayer in it's world. But how? Well, you're given phantoms of what other players are doing at random times, being able to make pre-written messages and warn others (or trick others) about the future obstacles. Some are even more friendly, extending their hand to help escort you through a zone, and even fight bosses with you! Some...will invade your world, in a attempt to take your experience points.Everyone's moved onto DS3, so this game is quieter than it should be. Invasions are rare, co-oping with random players is a complete pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥..most of the PVP groups you can join in the game is rendered useless by the quiet of the game. Thankfully, there almost always seems to be at least a handful of people on, playing the game, at any time of the day.I'm counting this against the game, as, in it's current state, the community playing it has mostly moved on to DS3. Onnnn the other hand, those who prefer to avoid the multiplayer aspect will have a alright time knowing that invasions will be far and few. But it's still something that deters from the experience.Let me adress the tagline, "Prepare To Die." Yes, this is a game where you cannot take combat as a joke. If you're unprepared, you will die. Nearly every single time I've died, I've had to blame myself for the mistakes I made. However! There are areas in the game that made me scratch my head in utter confusion and anger when I died. For example, deep within the catacombs, there's a hole you can drop down. However, before you even reach the hole, a creature under it already has locked onto you and is aggro'd against you. So, when I dropped down, there was a high chance I'd be immediately killed IN MID-AIR. While you're in mid-air, you cannot perform any actions. So, you can very well be screwed while falling down. However! There's only a handful of hiccups this game has in it's level design. Such as the example I've personally dealt with. Perhaps I'm just bad at those segments, but there are times when my deaths are constant.A fair warning to you. If you find dragons sittin' around on a bridge, multiple small dragons, do not take them as a joke. No matter what level you are, they will still pose a very serious threat.The combat in this game is satisfying. Oh my. Out of all the games in my library, Dark Souls has the absolute best. Performing Backstabs and Counters for the first time is just badass on every level. And even now, 120 hours into the game, I still find them satisfying and dropping little one-liners to myself with certain weapons. Pure magic players will find a little harsher experience than those who fit magic into their repritoire, but Pyromancers will be fine. Miracles and Sorceries will have to work harder to stay on top.The less you know about Dark Souls, however, the better. Contrary to popular opinion, I actually kinda liked having to figure out the systems and Humanity on my own. So, try to be careful and avoid spoilers if you somehow already have. I say, get this game, and praise the sun! Even despite the fact that one of the biggest aspects of the game is a quiet one now, with DS3 having came out recently...it's still worth your time and money!

number of helpful: 22 of 27 people (81%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												I'll divide this review into two sections: Game Review & PC Port Review then you can decide for yourself whether you would want to buy the PC version or look for a console copy.Game ReviewIntro:FROM Software's Soul Series first started by Demon's Souls on PS3. At the time of release, that game revolutionized the concept of difficulty. It was truly a challenging game that needed mastering. Dark Souls is no different, it is indeed very difficult and offers little to no help along the way. Tutorial is nothing more than explanation of controls and a few gameplay basics, nothing more. Dark Souls is not for the faint of heart, it takes a dedicated gamer to finish the game.Pros (+12):- Achievement through struggle, unforgiving difficulty which is very rewarding- Minimalistic plot that's open to player interpretation and fan theories- In-depth character customization and lots of equipment to choose from- Multi-player is uniquely integrated into single-player- Beautiful art design and breath-taking sceneries, visuals are great- High replay value which stems from the NG+ system- Inter-connected world and amazing level-design barring a few rushed locations- Each single step you take has permanent consequences, the game is auto-saved every moment- Epic boss and enemy designs- Even the weakest enemy can kill a careless end-game character, there is no true safety- Teaches real life lessons and is full of metaphors- No quests, no mini-map, no guidance, you are truly alone in a hostile worldCons(-4):- Audio and sound effects are boring and dull, soundtrack is uninteresting- Persistent network issues which will never be fixed- Intentional "easy mode" provided by some items or play-styles- Lousy English translation and occasional incomprehensible textGameplay = 10/10 ; Audio = 7/10 ; Visuals = 10/10 ; Story = 10/10Verdict: 9.75/10 - Almost PerfectDark Souls is truly a gem and one of the finest RPG titles of this generation, it is a game with a point to prove, lessons to teach and controllers to break. This is a must-play title for any true gamer in this generation.PC Port ReviewThis horrible monstrosity called a PC port is truly one of the worst ports in all history if not the absolute worst. This game is literally unplayable without a controller, if you're looking to play with Keyboard+Mouse you're going to be deeply disappointed. The game always displays X360 Buttons on the screen. Apart from that, the game itself is locked to 30 FPS and unlocking the framerate with mods causes several issues such as broken ladder animations and extremely short jumping distance.The port itself is borderline broken without the help of various fixes and modifications such as DSFix & PVPWatchdog. This is an utterly terrible PC Port with countless issues and problems that will never be officially fixed. If you have access to a last-generation console, I would highly recommend buying a console version instead because the PC port is plain broken.However, if you insist on playing the game on PC, use of modifications and fixes is mandatory.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												TL;DRI've been playing games since the DOS era, I really lost count of how many games I had played. If my lifespan permits, I would like to experience all the great games ever created, new or old. Dark Souls, is one of the brightest diamonds in history, easily in my top5 of all-time. But 10 years from now, what will happen to the online aspect of Dark Souls? Nothing lasts forever, even all things good will eventually come to an end. Before that happens, if you are a true gamer, do yourself a favour, overcome your own Dark Souls, and you will never be the same again. Put simply, to emerge victorious in this Trial of Mentality, you have to become a stronger person than you are today.9.7/10IF YOU HAVE MORE TIME TO READFor those of you sitting on the fence due to reviews of a bad PC port, worry not. I am playing this on Windows 7, without any controller, without any 3rd party fix, and it works just fine. My guess is they had released a recent patch to fix most of the complaints. You can always change the key bindings to something you like. My only issue is that sometimes the camera is too near, but that is more of a small annoyance since you can't really zoom out.THINGS I LIKE:+ Level up mechanic, reminds me of Diablo 2 but more extensive and better+ Choose the level of online interaction you want at any time, you can play it like Single-player, Co-op or PVP! It's like half an MMO. At minimum there are still some subtle "interference" between you and other online players (players can leave messages on ground to warn other players; bloodstains show a ghostly playback of how a previous player died; occasionally see "ghosts" moving around which is another real player)+ Variety of weapons & their associated combat moves+ Upgrading system of equipment+ Checkpoint system wil restart you at latest "touched" checkpoint when you die+ Epic Boss Fights+ Looting is easy because there is a shiny bright light over anything that is lootable+ No lengthy towning explorations or NPC conversations, just pure adventuring & combat+ 1-slot save system of no regrets+ Unlimited inventory space, take everything you want !+ Most importantly, this game makes you want to play it, you wake up everyday looking forward to your Dark Souls, and honestly, I haven't experience this kind of enthusiasm in any game for a long time

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												The game humbles you.I know of no other game series that puts you in your place better than the Dark Souls series. The only thing responsible for your deaths is your own stupidity because there is no element of randomness. It's not the AI's fault you died. You failed to predict the actions of an easily readable computer. It's entirely up to you to understand your mistakes and correct them.It's not only difficult; the game reveals itself to be a truly immersive and expansive universe. The way the maps interconnect and the atmospheric lighting and sounds make you feel as if you really are the chosen undead with the world stacked against you. The characters have interesting storylines and perspectives, and the items you pick up come with a description explaining some of the lore that would otherwise go unsaid.Well, what is it? Muster up some patience and begin a fantastic adventure.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Once the annoying GFWL piece was removed, I purchased this game on sale.  I enjoy challenging games so I wasn't afraid of the rumors I heard about Dark Souls' difficulty.  Having never played Demon Souls, the spiritual predecessor, I was completely new to this series.  What I quickly learned is that the game is very overwhelming to new people and seriously lacks adequate in-game tutorials.  Many questions people start off with is "What character should I be?", "Which weapons should I use?", and "Which skills should I spend souls on?"  The makers of the Dark Souls seemingly want you to experiment in the game to figure this out and some say this is part of the charm.Since the game can easily take at least 40 hours to complete, I simply didn't feel in the mood to play a difficult game AND not know what the heck is going on.  So what I did instead was to read a few beginner guides to Dark Souls (spoiler-free versions), and I really feel this helped the game be much more enjoyable.  Even several hours into the game I would have to go look up what a certain item is used for on a Dark Souls wiki page as well, for example.As for game play, there isn't much more for me to say that hasn't already been said 100x over.  I definitely recommend the game for those who enjoy challenging RPGs with emphasis on action fighting.  The large amount of big boss battles will give plenty of satisfaction.  The story and sense of adventure will also make you incredibly curious with each new area you enter.  When you are new to this game, it will engross you to the point that when you aren't playing, you'll be thinking about what is next and/or how to defeat a boss who has already killed you 10+ times.  This is one of those games you'll never forget.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												One of the best Co-op Games out there and the best Dark Souls Titles.Since Dark Souls Prepare to die Edition has been ported completly to Steam, it now has Steam Achievements which could off been ported over from the GFWL Version but you didn't have to. This Game is probably a the only Masterpiece in the Series. Why is that? Poise. Poise funktions and the game was not made to be difficult, it was made the way it should off been to be a game. Whilst other Dark Souls Games will Cheese you with the same copy + paste enemy, this games enemys are actually different from each other and have different attacks. This Game turned out to be difficult but fair. Unlike other Dark Souls titles that were made to be difficult and not fair at all. This Game is by far the best one they ever made and I think everybody should try it out and give it a little bit time. I took me 65 hours to like the game and 80 hours to find myself not dying around every corner, but all the struggle was worth it, since this now one of my favourite games that I play to this day.Since this Game is a bit older then the other Dark Souls Titles, the community actually made a connectivity Mod and a PVP Watchdog mod, where you can simply kick cheaters out. You also can install costum textures without getting banned.I can recommend this Game to anybody that loves challenges and Metroidvania Games for its full price, as you might spent more then 100 hours on it, however if you unsure whether you like it or not just grab it on sale or buy a cheap key.

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 7
												God damn, I love this game! I will admit that the biggest reason is because it finally showed all the garbage that's been infesting my beloved hobby for the last decade that they ain't worth♥♥♥♥♥♥(and made them beg for an easy mode which they never got), but also because the game itself is simply fantastic. I will warn you now though, the PC port is functional at best. You're most likely better off playing it on PS3 or 360 but if you're dead set on the PC version then  make sure you get DSfix, Dark Souls PVP Watchdog, the Dark Souls Connectivity Mod and a gamepad! These will make your time with the game a lot less headache inducing. STORY  This game handles its story very well. I won't go into details, but I will say that the story and lore of Dark Souls is pretty damn good, HOWEVER the majority of it you'll have peace together yourself by talking to people and reading item descriptions, so if you're one of those babies who "plays" games for the story, but also expect everything to be given to you on a silver platter, this game isn't for you. On the other hand if you don't care for story at all then you don't have to worry as you can skip every cutscene, every piece of dialogue and aside from very few exceptions you aren't technically required to talk to anyone to progress through the game.Hence why I said this game handles its story very well: If you care for story there's plenty of it, but if you just want to play the game there's nothing stopping you from doing so. muh grafix  This game came out in 2011 on consoles, so don't really expect mind blowing grafix, however from an aesthetic standpoint it looks amazing. I may get some flak for this but to me DS1 looks ten times more pleasing than both its sequels. MUSIC  Dark Souls has little in terms of music, but what little there is was composed by JRPG Jesus himself: Motoi Sakuraba and it's all fantastic. I wouldn't say its his best work, but every track fits perfectly with the place or event where it plays. Would you remember it for years to come? Eh, I don't know, that really depends on what kind of music you like. I prefer Sakuraba's rocking soundtracks so this one won't stick with me till the end of time, but that's just me. GAMEPLAY  I won't bother explaining the gameplay basics of this game, thats what the tutorial is for HOWEVER I will get this out of the way right now.Dark Souls requires you to use your brain, pay attention and plan things ahead. Going #YOLO#SWAG#SuchANerd here will only get you the YOU DIED screen over and over again. You won't believe how many times I've been called a masochist or being asked why I hate myself by people every time I launch the game, which always leaves me scratching my head. I then proceed get completely disregarded when I try to explain why the game isn't balls hard like some memers make it out to be or end up hurting someone's fee fees when I tell them they are just♥♥♥♥♥♥Now I'm not saying this game is perfect, there are things I like and things I don't like just like every single game in existence.What I like the most is how the game absolutely lets you tailor your own playstyle, because many of the weapons have their own unique movesets which makes them handle differently. You want to swing a massive greatsword like Guts: you can. Want to be a rapier thrusting♥♥♥♥♥ you can. Want to fight from a distance with a spear: you can. Become the ultimate edgelord with katana and fedora: you can. Go ranged with bow/crossbow or become the ultimate nerd (Mage): you can do it. The starting class you pick really isn't all that important as you can become something completely different by the time you reach the end.Another thing I really like is how the game handles its multiplayer component. While you're alone for the majority of the game you'll sometimes see the ghosts of other players as well as bloodstains (which indicate they died there, touching one of those lets you get an idea of what happened to that player which in turn might give you some knowledge in advance). Once you restore your humanity at a bonfire you automatically go online. While human you can be invaded by or summon other players for either Co-op or PVP, you can also invade or leave a summon sign yourself (note that co-op and PVP work only in areas where the boss hasn't been defeated yet, so for example you can't summon people or get invaded in an area where you've already slain the boss, but you can invade or be summoned by people who haven't killed him yet). There are several covenants (think something like a guild) you can join if desired. Some are focused on Co-op, some on PVP and others have PVE uses. Leveling up your rank in whichever covenant you belong to will also gives you neat rewards, so it's definitely something worthwhile. My personal favorite is the Forest Hunters aka gank everyone who dares to set foot in the forest.I also love the world you get to explore. I went in completely blind for my very first playthrough and ended up having to draw a map on paper just to keep up with all the interconnected areas. I haven't done something like this since the 90s.For things I dislike: There are a couple of moments in the game that are just cheap and while the majority of the bosses are fun to fight there are several of them that are just reskins and some (like the Bed of Chaos) that are just badly designed and are not enjoyable to fight at all. Some areas of the game can also get on your nerves: Blighttown is the most famous example of that. The zone itself isn't THAT bad but the massive framerate drops is what kills it. I really wouldn't mind if the zone was optional but sadly you have to pass through it to progress through the game. Multiplayer wise on PC you're bound to run into cheaters and sadly the PVP watchdog can't get rid of every single one of them. However 14 year olds with no skill who have to resort to cheating isn't exclusive to this game (it always makes me smile when I beat them at their own game though).Overall though, these cases are few and far between and don't detract from the overall enjoyment of the game. TL;DR Dark Souls is a game that takes me back to the good old days when both eastern and western video games were good, when games required you to work for your satisfaction instead of spoon-feeding you constantly in order to avoid hurting your fee fees and I love it for that. It's far from the perfect game but the few shortcomings it has I can overlook simply because it does everything else so well. It is in no way, shape or form a game for masochists, nor is it the hardest game ever made and to all those who keep spouting this crap, please stop playing video games and go back to facebook or whatever, you'll be making the rest of us a massive favor.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												I had heard quite a lot about Dark Souls: Prepare to Fun Edition before I went ahead and decided it was time I picked it up. I had actually heard about enough to give me the impression  that buying it would end up being a mistake because I would find myself quitting before I managed to get so much as a quarter of the way into the game because of the 2hard4me. Ironically enough I couldn't put it down because of the♥♥♥♥♥kicking I was getting initially being a lot different from the lackluster wins it seems every other game throws out.  Albeit that Dark Souls is just about as far as one can get from a walk in the park with a title made in recent times (save for the most irritating of indie games) it's nowhere near as bad as most will set it out to be. There are almost no situations where I felt that what was happening was just plain unfair and the deaths were anyone's fault but my own. Every challenge presented could be easily overcome by taking things slowly and getting the timing right. If you're used to the hand-holding of modern day pewpewbangbangbang games like I am then maybe you'll have a little (or a lot) more trouble than you should be having with whomever (Carpa, stop plis; it hurts). The animation quality is to die for, I have never once played a game where I sat in an area toying with weapons just to see what the attacks looked like before but I've spent hours doing so here. Regardless of if I planned on using it or not when I got a new weapon different from what I had seen before I was excited to see what it was like. I've now gone as far as making builds just to try weapons I didn't get to use in combat before due to stats. Voice acting is another point of interest, most characters were unique enough to actually want to talk to. On the down side the story could have been portrayed a lot better in game, I myself had to watch a countless amount of Youtube videos to get in on what was happening beyond the basic outline. If you decide to go ahead and do so then chances are you'll realize you missed quite a lot of the plot while playing through. The dreaded four letters also take a part in Dark Souls, GFWL (best system 10/10); on top of that connection is P2P so without DSCfix good luck summoning anyone, really. Although I've met a decent enough amount of people who have adapted to playing with mouse and keyboard I would still have to put down that playing without a gamepad is rather difficult. Dark Souls easily places in my top five favorite games and I cannot wait to get my hands on the next one. Praise the Sun, praise the sun, praise the sun praise the sun, praise the sun. TL;DR Gaem is gud, buy.

												First off let me tell you that this isnt a ♥♥♥♥ing game, its a MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING NIGHTMARE BRO! 5 Minutes out of the Firelink shrine i find myself greeted by what i call "The Welcoming Comitee". Composed of rotted flesh and stanky♥♥♥♥♥bones, this rag tag group of miscreants may seem like nothing more than trash mobs before the big boss, but dont be fooled. These conniving, conspiring, crestaceous mongoloids will utterly skull ♥♥♥♥ your♥♥♥♥♥♥to no end with their insane knowledge of gokus ability to falcon punch you a thousand times within the window of a few seconds with their daggers forged in the fires of mount go♥♥♥♥yourself. It took me 30 hrs to master the ways of the welcoming comitee, and since then i feel ive accomplished little to no tasks in my life that have been more gratifying. Although i did come across a foe i fear has been created just to spite me. In the cave of the giants there lies a string of beasts that no man should dare to seek. They thrive in the darkness and live only to bring you to the brink of shoving your controller up your♥♥♥♥♥ I call them RA-RA-RA's. Beware the giant skeletal canine-like beasts that will endlessly tear your character several new asses. As i reached the end of this game and entered the final room to the final boss. I felt as if my journey had been one of a kind. I had spent days, weeks, traversing this land, uncovering its secrets, and now it all ended here. I entered the room and suddenly i was blown away by the saddening music and atmosphere before me. It was almost too late to notice my foe mid air flying towards me. I set the controller down. Took a deep breathe. It was over. I won... i felt relief, then happiness. Then sadness. BUT WHY SADNESS THIS GAME TORCHERED ME TO THE BRINK?! Thats when i realized that this is more than a game, its a nightmare and nightmares become part of us, part of our souls. They define aspects of our lives, this game was the embodiment of my DARK SOUL. 100/10 would dark soul again.
