content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
A beutifully designed, unfathomably deep, and truly rewarding odyssey that feels intensely and brilliantly alive in nearly every conceivable respect.*Please be aware that Durante's 'DSfix' is an essential mod for this lacklustre PC port, so be sure to install it before even attempting to play*When industry pundits make reference to a "hardcore" game, this is exactly the kind they're talking about. Dark Souls is the game that brings roguelikes bang up-to-date, and with what style it does so.Touting a brutal learning curve and an equally chilly approach to player tutoring, Dark Souls is a ruthless RPG of peerless satisfaction once you master it's deceptively graceful combat and giddy sense of exploration.As 2010 rolled around I found myself lamenting the current state of RPGs; searching in vain for a setting and approach that would get me excited again. It turns out that this game was just the cure I needed as the failings that spoiled my experience of Skyrim were nowhere to be found in the cursed world of Lordran.Every choice in Dark Souls is a meaningful one; the game is constantly updating your save file so there's no reloading and trying again if something goes wrong. If you lose all of your hard earned souls (the game's currency) then you're out of luck. If you kill an NPC by accident or fail to save another from assassination then that's just too bad. In this game you must live with those mistakes and what a refreshing change it makes for you as a player.I instantly appreciated Dark Souls for its gritty feel, hard as nails gameplay and the simple fact that it made you actually want to go delving into the usually derivative crypts, dungeons and even sewers!The magazine reviews that extolled a huge, connected world with foreboding areas, minimal loading times and a new 'ambient' style of multiplayer seemed too good to be true. To my surprise however; they were dead right on all counts.To me Dark Souls is the game that has finally done difficulty (for established gamers at least) in the right way. Yes it's hard as it can possibly be in the beginning; the game makes no concessions for your initial ignorance or pleas for clarity, but a lot of persistence and a little experimentation goes a long way in this cut-throat realm. All the tools you need to be great in this game are there- the transparent combat is intuitive, simple and easy to get to grips with if you have patience and the tenacity to stick with it and learn the little nuances that soon become second nature.This is one of those rare titles where other games are now being compared to it. "This is Dark Souls" or "it's like Dark Souls" are things that I catch myself saying regularly, even about games much older than this one. Although it's firmly engrained in the roguelike sub-genre, Dark Souls has such a unique and identifiable feel to it that the new term "Soulslike" is starting to gain serious traction for describing any game that bears intense similarities to it.If there was ever a torch-passing moment in modern video game history then this has to be it; from Rogue to Dark Souls, the dream of an uncompromising RPG with depth, complexity and intense satisfaction has been realised all over again. And for a game to accomplish that whilst maintaining such a broad appeal across the industry is a feat that is impressive beyond measure. Read the full review at my blog »[www.celjaded.com] Read a soundtrack review at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
TLDR VERDICTDark Souls is an innovative experience that provides challenging, yet extremely satisfying gameplay and a unique twist on multiplayer. Backed up with an intriguing narrative; absolutely stellar world design; all-round fantastic gameplay driven and atmosphere. An absolute must buy or at least try, as I believe everyone should experience this game, even if it doesn’t sound like your thing.FULL REVIEW BELOW”What is bravery, without a dash of recklessness” - Hawkeye Gough You are cursed. You are destined to die, again and again. You will keep dying, until you have lost your purpose and you become nothing but a hollow mindless husk. However, just maybe, there might be something different about you.This review is written from the perspective of a fan of story driven RPG games and games with well-designed open worlds, with an emphasis on player discovery and experimentation.GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNDark Souls has fairly straightforward gameplay mechanics that are simple to understand but are supposed to be adapted to your playstyle. Contrary to popular belief, Dark Souls isn’t what I would call an especially hard game. Sure it has difficult moments, but it’s just completely different from what you might expect from an open world RPG, which throws a lot of people off. The game essentially punishes you for relying on what might be the norm in other games of its genre. You need to rely on a more practical way of thinking to get a grip of how the game plays. For example: heavy armour is hard to move around in and big swords are hard to swing.The game introduces its fundamental mechanics very concisely and they aren’t anything you haven’t seen before. You have a health bar, a stamina bar, basic attack mechanics and so on. So if the game has such a simple and unoriginal sounding framework, why does it have such a massive following and a notorious reputation for difficulty? There’s a few reasons. The first is the enemies. Every new enemy in the game is different from the last. You need to observe their movements, their weapon and their body type to find an opening. The enemies are very firm, but fair (for the most part). They all have attack patterns and every pattern is avoidable, with a weakness you can exploit. Gauging what you attacks you can dodge and block and knowing when you can get hits in is all a part of the learning curve. Mastering bosses feels extremely satisfying. There are a few bosses that are arguably pretty “cheap” that might have you fighting the camera controls or jumping mechanics, but these are blemishes in otherwise fantastic array of enemies.Weapon and item variety is also fantastic. Whilst the stats and levelling system may seem overwhelming at first, you get your head around it very quickly and start experimenting. Almost every weapon has different move sets and they all feel unique. Just like studying your enemy’s vulnerabilities, you’ll need to look out for your own and they come from the type of weapon you use. There’s a massive selection of pretty much every fantasy melee and ranged weapon you can think of, with varying designs. If you replay other RPGs for alternate morality choices, you’ll replay Dark Souls for alternate weapon builds. Different weapon types require you to employ different tactics and can make entire playthroughs seem completely fresh even though you only changed your weapons. There is also a very intricate weapon upgrade system, which adds even more depth to the game.Dark Souls also has one of the best implementations of multiplayer I’ve ever seen in a game. The multiplayer is essentially built around the idea that we’re all screwed, but we’re all in this together. You can leave notes for other players that provide hints and sometimes good laughs. You can summon in other players to help you out with tricky areas. You can also invade other players and kill them in PvP combat if you feel really mean.The world design in Dark Souls is seriously genius. A lot of the areas interlock like a maze with shortcuts in logical places that actually make sense within the space of the world. No two areas occupy the same space within the world, everything fits together perfectly and you can see areas in the skybox of other areas. The amount of detail that actually went into the world design is jaw dropping. You navigate the world by walking around and looking for bonfires, which equate to checkpoints. These allow you heal up and bank your hard earned souls, which is basically currency. You lose all of your souls when you die and need to go back to where you died to pick them up. If you die again before getting them, you have lost them forever. This naturally can lead to a lot of stressful moments, especially when there is an invading player standing between you and hours of progress. The stakes just makes triumph all the more rewarding.STORY AND NARRATIVEDark Souls adopts some very subtle story telling techniques. You get a big grand cut scene at the start, that sets the scene for the world, but all the lore after that is pretty much hidden. You can interact with quite a few NPCs, but they only offer small snips of information at most and say more about themselves than the world around them. The other main source of information is item descriptions which can reveal information about specific events or people. This is quite good for people who like to piece together the story based on hints and clues. If you prefer storytelling to be more overt and involved then you might not be a fan.Personally, I am a fan of involved and cutscene/conversation heavy storytelling, but I didn’t mind the Dark Souls approach. It essentially makes the story optional for everyone who wants to ignore it. The main downside is that those hungry for more story may not necessarily want to dig for it and will come away feeling unfulfilled. I initially felt that, as I was constantly discovering awesome looking areas and enemies and kept thinking “what happened here?” and there wouldn’t really be a proper explanation. Of course, the game has a great community and the story explanations are all on YouTube (lookup VaatiVidya after playing the game) but the fact you have to go to YouTube can be a detracting factor.GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCEDark Souls is a really rough PC port. It is essentially a complete copy and paste of the console version. It runs at 720p capped at 30fps and used to have GFWL. GFWL has now been patched out and the game now uses Steamworks which is a huge improvement. The bulk of the issues are fixed by an absolutely essential mod called dsfix, which uncaps the framerate and offers better graphics options amongst other fixes. The multiplayer elements also had some serious connectivity issues whilst on GFWL. In my experience, the Steamworks patch works well when playing the game normally. You get a good amount of multiplayer play, but may have issues trying to play with a specific friend.Dark Souls has absolutely stunning art direction. All the environments, equipment and enemies are really uniquely designed and definitely emphasise the variety of locations you’re exploring throughout the game. It also does an excellent job of conveying all these completely diverse environments, which are still seamlessly interconnected. The boss enemy designs are especially well done. Almost every boss evokes some kind of emotional reaction, whether its terror, pity or respect. The actual graphical fidelity in the vanilla game looks passable for the time (2011), but the aforementioned dsfix mod really makes the game a lot prettier, despite a pretty hefty performance cost.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
Pros+ One of the most original and unique games I've ever played.+ Tough, yet rewarding gameplay. Never know what to expect. Always feels fresh. + Amazing atmosphere and a great soundtrack to compliment it.+ Addicting and immersive. + Level design is incredible. I love how everything is interconnected.+ Game is packed with content, lore, secrets, and places to explore. High replayability.+ Wide variety of settingsCons- Some elements of the game are just plain Tedious (Curse, some platforming sections, running back to certain bosses after dying, ect.)This is a game I think everyone should experience. The constant feeling of mystery when walking into a new area and not knowing what to expect at all, the feeling when stumbling across a bosses lair for the first time and wondering how to deal with it while under an immense amount of pressure, the feeling of coming across an NPC and wondering what they're doing there or what their story is, I could go on and on and on. It may take a bit for some to get pulled in by this game, but once you do good luck getting away, as you will constantly be starving for more. This game does of course have minor flaws, but even with them it managed to completely shattered my expectations.Final Score - ★★★★★

												One of the best and most challenging games i have played so far. Not only is the game setting pretty dark and scary, Dark Souls is also pretty hard so you will most likely always fear whats behind that door or fogwall, creating a similar atmosphere to horror games.Concerning the difficulty of this game: You can beat the game pretty much naked, and without getting hit a single time for the most parts, but at the same time even with the best gear you can die in a few seconds to some easy monsters if you're not paying attention or do something stupid.Learning from your mistakes is what this game is all about. You will die because you didnt know there was someone lying in an ambush. You will die even knowing there is someone behind that door, but you havent figured out what to to. You will die even knowing a good strategy to defeat a certain boss or clear an area. The game is fair, so dont blame anyone but yourself, just try it again and try harder, you will succeed eventually.If you're searching for a nice action RPG, a dark fantasy game or just a challenge, Dark Souls is the perfect match!

number of helpful: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												I've always enjoyed this game, let it be the exhilerating moments of being in CQC, or the deep lore this game is based upon.It's frustrating, but most of the time it's your fault. MOST of the time, anyway. An area by the name of Lost Izalyth was rushed, so the boss you find there (Bed of Chaos) has a lot of artificial difficulty. There was one time, when I jumped a gap to get to the boss, the GIGANTIC arm the boss slaps you around with knocked me across the arena to my death (the developers didn't do this on purpose, they just rushed the boss). The floor also crumbles beneath your feet when you reach a certain point in the boss fight. Any unsuspecting noob can fall through, since the game doesn't warn you ahead of time.Then there's the Capra Demon, though to a lesser extent. When you walk into the arena, the space you fight in isn't that big, and most noobs die before they can react in time to the dogs and the boss. After that, the boss fight isn't that bad.This is the most artificial difficulty I remember, though some bugs are out there that can spoil the fun at times.                            TIME FOR THE GOOD STUFFThe game is open world, but in a semi-linear way. It's not the GTA V open world you're thinking of, but instead it's an open world because you can go into areas if you have the skill or equipment. It's not a level requirement, but instead a skill requirement. That's probably one of the best things about the game.The combat is done quite well. You have a light attack, a strong attack, a block, a parry (if you're not two-handing your weapon), you can two-hand your weapon, and you can roll. This means you're able to endure a fight without getting hit. When you roll, you have a part of the roll that makes you invulnrable. Don't expect to land the roll perfectly every time. It takes practice and patience to learn when to roll, and when NOT to. When you parry, there is a part of the parry that can slap aside the enemy's weapon. After doing a successful parry, you can repost the enemy for a large amount of damage. This also takes practice to land, so don't quit the game after not being able to parry successfully. When you two-hand a weapon, your strength increases by 1.5x the amount it was previously. This also adds some extra damage, so it's worth it.Most of the bosses in Dark Souls are okay. Some of them are annoying, some are just too easy. I'm not going to spoil any more bosses, since they're better when you don't know them very well.The lore in this game is extremely deep, and you can piece it together by reading item descriptions. If you need help figuring out the lore, check out https://www.youtube.com/user/VaatiVidya . He has a few videos on Dark Souls 1.That's it, I don't want to spoil the areas, so play the game yourself.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Dark Souls: Prepare to Die edition is a fantastic game. I have never thought that I will enjoy this game that much so that's why I am going to share my experience and information about this game with you.The main element of this game, as you can imagine by reading the name of the game, is DYING! You will die very often and if you are not prepared to die, do not play this game, because otherwise you are going to rage-quit or delete this game.If you are ready to die, let's continue with reading this and let's say something important about this game.DS:PTD is, in my words, single-player game mixed with multi-player. The thing is, that you feel like you play single-player, however, in a moment you realize that your world is connected to other worlds and you are kind of linked with other people. If you use your humanity (in-game item) to become a human as you were before you've died, you will "enter" the multi-player. It sounds hard or maybe I can't explain it that well, but once you are human, you can invade other worlds - it means going PVP with another Online Player, you can be invaded - somebody will come to your world to kill you OR, you can summon a player who would like to co-op with you. That's why I like this game so much. Are you bored of killing NPCs, monsters, bosses? Just invade other world and feel the power of real Player-versus-Player. Is it hard to kill the boss in your world? Try to find summoning symbols on the ground and summon player to help you and kill that big as*hole together!! If I wanted to sum up everything this game offers, this "review" would be super long. This game is in open/closed world (it means that nobody tells you directly where to go. Everything is up to you. Where to go, where have you been,(there is no map, ok? you must use your brain!) where would you like to go, which area you choose first to go to or what to use/level up. However, those areas are connected together that perfectly that you can't get lost unless you are completely brain-dead. ), containing lvling-up, modifying your weapons, learning spells and having super great time with your character. PS. Very important to say! This game IS VERY CHALLENGING and DOES GIVE YOU great REWARDS!I would hardly recommend this game to anyone who wants to play challenging/rewarding game and likes this genre of game. (I would compare it with Skyrim or games like that, but don't blame me if you feel that you can't compare Skyrim with Dark Souls, because it is completely different. Maybe..it is :D, haven't played Skyrim long enough yet )Also, I would not recommend this game to players who are used to do ONLY what they are being told, to players, who likes playing games on "easy-difficulty" (in this game, there is NO difficulty to choose. It is "Hard"-difficulty, so get used to it) and to players, who are not ready to DIE! :)If you liked my "little-review", please, rate it up or comment below to let me know if I can improve something for next time!Thanks for reading it.Kubusta

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Before you read any further let me make one thing clear- this game is very, very good. Exceptional even, so many elements of it are masterfully designed to give a totally different and amazing gaming experience. So, lets get the elephant in the room out of the way- Difficulty.Yes this game is hard- especially the start. In fact you will probably doubt that you'll get to the end of it after the first hour or so, however, it is vitally important to stick with it. You will improve your skills massively in time, things that seemed nearly impossible will become almost trivially easy, this is part of the charm. You feel yourself grow in ability so much, relying only on your sharpened skills to take on truly overwhelming challenge and succeeding. The way difficulty works in this game is masterful. The gameplay is great, what feels clunky and unusable at first becomes very smooth and responsive in experienced hands, this game above any other I've played has one of the strongest connections of your wits to your performance, which is invigorating for tough fights.  The world in which it all takes place is despiringly bleak and desperate, the story is not told to you. Instead you are placed in a world and have to make your own conclusions about it's denizens and their motivations, the events that transpire and what it all means. This again is quite different to most games and triggers the curiousity in you much more than the standard formula, it has a feel almost like the old 'Myst' on PC (although it is not puzzle based).Having the hindsight of multiple completions and nearly 300 hours play, I would rank this game as a modern classic. So much of it is a fundamentally different and richer experience than most games around these days. The more you play the more you realise the genius and originality of the design.***As an aside- one word of warning. I would research online as to how to build your character and how to make strong weapons, it is not at all obvious and the game could be made much to difficult if you don't do it correctly.***As a second and vitally important aside- Get an xbox controller for your PC if you are buying this. Mouse and keyboard was unplayable. They are fairly cheap and can be used for other games that work best with controller too. I already had one for use with a gamecube emulator.

												A soothing adventure game set in the peaceful Kingdom of Lordran, from Firelink Shrine to the Depths you'll have an interesting world to explore as you come across its kind inhabitants who will help you learn of how this once great land came to fall. Experience places like; Sen's Fortress where you will feel safe and comforted by its many guards and defenses, the shining city of Anor Londo and the vibrant and cheerful Painted World of Ariamis. Meet the ever-helpful characters; the Bell Gargoyles (be careful one lies and one tells the truth), the Capra Demon (he's more friendly than he sounds), the Dragon Slayer Ornstein and his best friend Smough. Then, before you leave don't forget to gaze upon the wonderous creatures; the Moonlight Butterfly, the Gaping Dragon and the Great Grey Wolf Sif.☼ Praise the Sun! ☼

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Despite its marketing, Dark Souls is designed to make you feel something. Rather than likening it to other games – most of which are purely about sensory stimulation – I prefer to compare Dark Souls to an album. More particularly, an extreme metal album. Like an extreme metal album, Dark Souls is incredibly inaccessible. It has no desire for mass appeal. In fact, it thrives on alienation. It wants only the dedicated, the people who will strive to understand what it is trying to convey.Also, like an extreme metal album, Dark Souls has an emotional agenda. It has one united vision. It wants you to feel isolated. It wants you to feel empty. It wants you to feel like you are nothing, and that everything around you has more right to exist than you. It succeeds. The monster design, the level design, the sound assets, the silence – all these things combine to unnerve and depress you. More than anything though, Dark Souls wants you to prove it wrong. It wants you to prove that you have a right to exist in its world, despite everything it throws at you. It pummels you to the ground, yet it gives you hope. It gives you a reason to press on, even when everything seems lost. It wants you to go in as one person, and leave as another.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Pfft, you really think you're ready for this? You think you're pro-MLG enough to handle this one? Maybe you should turn around and go back to Skyrim or Terraria or whatever other CASUL "game" you waddle around in. If you really think you're ready to step up your game and try your hand at Dank Souls, lemme give you an accurate depiction of your fate:- You will die.- You will die a lot.- You will die for basically most of your time playing.- Death will befall you.- Your life will be ended.- Your shirts will be colored red in your blood, which will ironically make you die even more.- Imagine one of those games where you estimate the number of candies or rat testes or some other small things that've been put in a jar. Now imagine all of it has been replaced with instances of your death. Okay? That's a pretty accurate description, I think. Yeah. It'll do.Basically the game is hard, or at least it is to CASULS like you. Don't even pick this game up unless you already know every enemy attack animation as well as every parry frame and weapon moveset in the game with some side knowledge of every misc item in the game and all the secret passages.Or you could learn as you go. I mean, that'd be okay I guess. I mean, that's probably what makes Dank Souls so great is that you learn as you go, no matter how many times you die. UNLESS YOU'RE PRO-MLG LIKE ME, IN WHICH CASE YOU NEVER DIE BECAUSE I NEVER DIE EVER.In PvE you will face off against BALANCED and 100% QUALITY enemies such as the "bed of chaos" and "torch hollows." The combat in Dark Souls is directly tied into user and enemy animations, so the player will have to be forced to learn patterns AS WELL AS the patterns the player will utilize and change via weapon choices, since all weapons basically have their own unique moveset and sets of strengths/weaksauce weaknesses...except for the CHAOSHANDER, which only has strengths.In PvP you will be butt-devastated by a gigantic flurry of backstabs the like of which you will never have thought could exist. Take every game in the Assassin's Creed series and then add up all the backstabs players could possibly execute at any point (possibly an infinite value due to respawning NPCs?) and then multiply it by five.Okay.Good.You're still not even close.The combat is still tied into animations, except now it's entirely based on PLAYER movesets. This means PvP is primarily dominated by those who learned the strengths and weaknesses of (at least most of) the gear in the game.AKA THEY LEARNED HOW TO ABUSE THE SYSTEM AND GET FREE BUTTSTABS.FREE BUTTSTABS!!!IT'S A TRAVESTY.Basically the backstab system in Dar- I mean Dank Souls isn't all that quality-laden. Dark Souls II (notice how I didn't say DANK SOULS II) attempted to fix this, and it did a fair job of doing so. Except for how Dark Souls II isn't as good as Dank Souls, and should be avoided.Just saying.I'm not going to go into the lore because you can just do a google search ("DANK SOULS LORE FUNNY CAT IMAGES") and see 999,999,998 "people" go "OH YES IT'S SOOOOO DEEP AND MEANINGFUL BUT SUBTLE AT THE SAME TIME LIKE OMGGGG YOU HAVE TO DISCOVER IT FOR YOURSELF."They're right, of course. It still doesn't need another reiteration though. You get the point after a while.In conclusion, Dank Souls is an amazing triumph of the game market and is more akin to an interactive work of art THAT HATES YOU.If you have any disagreements then I'll have to ask you to 1v1 me. Watch out though 'cause my zweihander don't play no games son.10/10

content:
Posted: February 8
												You're basically a detective picking up the pieces of what has happened in this world. It presents you a world that has gone to ruin. Whether you play this game actively or passively is up to your intellect as a human. Engage with the world and with your mind. Look at the world, observe the clues presented to your subtly. You have to think about what you're seeing as well as reading and listening dialogue and text. You could simply just play the game and ignore everything that's being shown to you. Killing bosses, enemies, and people mindlessly--like other RPGs. The problem with modern RPGs is that you're just doing what they tell you and va-la: exp, loot, and more quests. Some people would play DS once, but like someone stated, "It's not a game, it's a experience." People have overcome real life issues through this game. The world of Dark Souls is filled with tragedy. Love is corrupted and turned rotten, cities fall into ruin and war, kings embrace madness and fear, the Gods--forsaken, great heroes overcome by true darkness, even Solaire: forgotten and only vestiges of his exsistance remain. Dark Souls reflects our world. The greatest people are forgotten, no matter how much joy they bring to an indivisual's life, overtime, such happiness has evaporated. Nations rise and fall. The people swept away--then brought back. "Humans assuming a fleeting form." People that give up are left on the side of the road and pillaged for what they were worth. "But, what is a king?"Dark Souls' world, is a world of tragedy, sadness, betrayal, love, decay, and rebirth.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2013
												Dark Souls is not a game for everyone. It will torture you, punish you and laugh at you, all at the same. But it will never be unfair. It will always play by the rules. Any mistakes you make are entirely your own. This game is hard. Maybe not all the time, depending on your build, but you will die. Not once, not twice. Hundreds of time. And you'll probably keep playing. Because the world of Dark Souls is something that needs to be experienced. I've rarely seen a world this detailed and this well executed. It reminded me a bit of a Metroidvania game, where instead of searching for upgrades you decide what to upgrade, thanks to the souls you'll collect from killed enemies. Before moving on to that part let me say that the textures in this game are simply amazing.As I said, souls allow you to upgrade your character. But only at a bonfire. If you get killed before reaching a bonfire, you lose your souls. You'll resurrect as an undead (again) and get another chance at collecting your lost souls. But the enemies will have respawned and if you die again before reaching them, you'll never be able to recover them. It's tough and frustrating.Enemies will attack you from all sides, there's danger everywhere. You have to remember when and how your enemy attacks, detect their patterns.With humanity you can become human again. This allows you to summon NPC's or friends. These allies are extremely helpful in tough situations. The only consequence of being human is the fact that other players can invade your world. This is frustrating if you haven't saved at a bonfire or/and the other player is simply too strong. Defeat them and you'll gain plenty of souls, though.It's a choice you have to make, but just remember that humanity is hard to come by, especially in the beginning, so summoning someone isn't always the proper solution.As of today I still haven't finished the game. It should take you at least 60-80 hours to beat, and that's a first playthrough. You'll never be able to see, do and collect all the stuff you want in your first playthrough. It's simply impossible. There's so much to take into account.Dark Souls is a brilliant game that only the strong will be able to finish. It's one of my personal goals, although I doubt I'll ever be able to finish it. It requires a lot of dedication. If you're one of those persons I strongly suggest you play this game. You'll not be disappointed.(Use the Dsfix to improve the graphics and performance of the game. Don't start your first game without it.)EDIT: I managed to finish this just a few days after posting the review. I'm not going to rewrite the entire thing as I still agree with most of what I've written. Dark Souls has entered my personal top 3 of favorite games ever so it doesn't need any further explanation.[Rating: 96/100]

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												If you wanted to give this game a try because you heard it was challenging, I would advise you to look elsewhere. That's not to say it's "easy" even if you know exactly what to do, just that it's the extremely cheap sort of "challenge", like playing rock-paper-scissors with three fingers sawn off while the other guy plays with both hands. The short version is that most of the enemies have access to powers/abilities/outright hacks that you most certainly don't and you pretty  much have to look up guides and wikis to get through areas, moreso bosses, in a timely fashion. There is a bit of fun to be had here, but I feel like the game should have a South Park-esque warning label: "All combat is made to look more difficult than it rightly should be... Poorly. Due to shamelessly fake difficulty the following game should not be played by anyone."You can enjoy the game, but less so as you notice the many, many ways it plain cheats.Starting with the obvious and thus possibly taken for granted; enemies have infinite ammo and spells to throw at you. You have no such thing. Those arrows, bolts, spears, magefire, and the rest can hit you from distances the player can't even target from. Even if you could lock onto things from the distances they apparently can, your magic dissipates into nothing at what can be insultingly short ranges and projectiles lose impact before too long. Enemy fire always seems to do full damage. Finally, enemy projectiles of all sorts will arc mid-air to hit you. I can understand magic doing this, as it's magic, and the player's Soul Arrows can curve a little bit as well, but ordinary arrows fired by you do not.Speaking of curving in mid-air, most humanoid enemies seem to have some kind of leaping lunge attack that can track your position and hit you by changing the direction of the attack as they're flying, weapon raised. Once more, the player cannot do this.Quite a few foes have unblockable one-hit kill attacks, usually in the form of a grapple that can kill you from full health if you aren't pouring points into Health from the start. Some enemies (Silver Knights in Anor Londo especially, in my experience) can block damage with their shields when not blocking at all, but your weapon touches the shield before touching their bodies. The player has no such ability, even with the most powerful tower shield in the game.Fair's fair if we could do everything they could, I could understand calling that a challenge to use the AI's own tricks against them. However, they're all advantages that monsters will hold over you forever, which is pretty close to the definition of unfair. Certainly, you can strike back on some of the bosses with unfair tactics, but is that the sort of gameplay you were hoping for here?A general limitation on the combat is the inability to move while firing a bow or crossbow, because if you could there would be no reason not to kite pretty much every boss to death. Challenge lies in overcoming an obstacle, be it in the form of the environment or an enemy. It is not being told you just can't walk around it because that would be too easy and the powers that be were too lazy to place different obstacles for those that pick a different path instead of great big walls. That is to say, ranged combat is not a viable means of getting through the game for most people because there wouldn't even be an illusion of challenge if it were.Now, there's an obvious reason for these things, "It wouldn't be challenging otherwise!" That there, I think, should say everything that needs to be said about the game, without these cheap tricks, it's not challenging at all, and as challenge is not defined by cheap tricks, it follows that Dark Souls is not a challenging game as much as it is a cheap, frustrating one. I've played for over 300 hours, (cutting out what might mostly have been grinding for items or standing around waiting to be summoned as a phantom while doing something else outside the game) and in that time I found ignoring the broken difficulty more of a challenge than any of the bosses, the only remote enjoyment I derive anymore comes from helping other people kill bosses in the now-legendary feat of Jolly Cooperation. Even that wears thin when you're only getting called maybe three times an hour in the highest-traffic summoning spots.None of this is even taking into account the Invasion mechanic, in which players likely more experienced than you can jump into your world under certain circumstances and kill you for a laugh, or completely subjective things that might have just been me, like randomly slipping off cliffs when standing a good few feet away from them.I have two ideas of challenge in a game, God of War and Saint's Row. The former features some difficult combat that can be overcome through skill and determination. The latter features a bunch of rat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with rocket launchers that you're more likely to overcome through dumb luck or even cheat codes. Dark Souls falls on the Saint's Row end of the spectrum, fake difficulty taken to an artform. If all you'd like is a big, dark world to explore, peppered with bosses to kill in a romp of medieval fantasy violence... Then I'd recommend a Castlevania game instead.

content:

												Playing Dark Souls for the first time harkens back to how we played games as children. I often found myself lost - not knowing where to go, or what to expect from enemies past the bonfire. The beautifully designed enviorments, the punishing nature of the combat, as well as the little tidbits of lore scattered throughout the game all do a phenomenal job at immersing the player into the gameworld. Dark Souls is far from perfect, but it's the quintessential action roleplaying game. If you still haven't played it for whatever reason, now is as good a time as any.

content:

												I sadly cannot recommend this game. It's an Xbox port and it’s a horrible port! In game you get hints like "Press (A) to read document" but you have no idea what the A button should be on the keyboard. (by defaults it's Q instead of E) In the options there is no comparison to a controller, so you have to know what button does what on the Xbox version. I tried to play it with an Xbox controller but that thing's not working and there is no option to enable or disable or at least change key mapping of a controller. Oh and did I mention, that the default key to open the game menu is END not ESC?Graphics are pretty bad depending on the standard 1024x726 resolution that is just stretched to 1920x1080 but there is a patch that increases internal resolution and adds some fine shader-effects like more realistic lightning and so. I really recommend that patch if you want to play that game on a PC.I really wanted to give this game a chance but there is sadly no way to play it. Mouse sensitive is way too high and you cannot change it without a patch. I mostly have no idea what to press because the game tells me only the button I should press on a Xbox controller and like I said already: My Logitech Xbox controller which works in EVERY other game, does not work in Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Someone tells you to ring some bell and something will happen, so naive undead that you are, you just start wandering around to see if you find it by chance. You fight some little guys, and it's alright. Then you reach a big guy. He'll be less alright. So he pulverises you once or twice (I lied it was at least 25), but you are starting to figure it out. On your way to finally beat him, and something new pops up on your screen: Phantom NastyWasty69420 has invaded. A haunting voice, deep and coming from everywhere and nowhere at once booms "HELLO". You freeze and look around. There, a glowing, naked, red man is running towards you, holding a club the same size as you. He stops in front of you and gives a wave. So you wave back. Then he runs in circles a few times. You're concerned, but he hasn't done anything hostile yet, so you don't attack. What comes next in such an interaction? You don't know, so you wait. A glowing patch appears beneath him, an item! You pick it up, and find a set of armour that looks comedically fat. You equip it to humor him, only to find when you exit the menu, he is also wearing it. He then throws down some glowing things on the ground in a circle. The two of you stand for a moment in the circle, then he drops something and the booming voice returns, "I'M SORRY". This can't be good. You lock on and raise your shield, backing up. Can you beat him? You doubt it; that's one biiiig club. He waves once more, and runs in a little circle. You've backed perhaps 5 meters away, yet instantaniously he is behind you, his preposterously large club winding up, clipping through the preposterously fat armour. You try desperately to move, to escape, to attack, pressing every button on your controller. To no avail, his club crushes you, killing you instantly. That's not so bad, you've died plenty of times before. What really hurts is the betrayal. His fully upgraded, monstrous club could never do the damage that he has inflicted upon your heart. You spiral fast. Fueled by revenge, you destroy every enemy and boss in your path, beating the game. Then New Game +. Finally you've mastered it. Every dirty trick and cheese in the book. You start a new character, and play through the entire game at a low level. One day, you're invading pathetic newbs in the undead burg, parrying and backstabbing to your hearts content. You start lowering their defenses by giving them humanity and tossing prism stones down. One day, the terrible memory of what NastyWasty69420 did to you resurfaces. You've become that which you hate most. It becomes clear that the humanity that you give to these poor lost undead is because you no longer have use for yours. This is the downward spiral of the chosen undead. This is how dark souls will break you down. Embrace the Dark. Embrace the chaos.10/10, an emotional journey like no other.(My playtime is messed up, it's actually at least 3 times this)

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												TL;DR: A game infamous for its difficulty, but for those with the time and patience to overcome the steep learning curve, they will find themselves in a deeply detailed beautiful game with one of the most competent combat systems in gaming. Though poorly ported it is still well worth playing with a controller at the ready.Dark Souls is a game that I spent a large amount of my time with on console. Moving over to PC and experiencing it all over again, is time I don't regret spending. The fun from dark souls can be found in many different forms, though difficult as you progress through the game you can see yourself getting better and more powerful. The satisfaction of winning a boss fight, after they have crushed you countless time before is a feeling I have not found elsewhere. Though suffering from some issues such as the framerate cap and poor options this is a part of gaming history you can't miss.Positive features:-In depth combat and weapons variety that can be changed at any time-Beautifully rich and detailed world with varying areas and enemies-Difficulty harsh but fair-Unforgettable boss fights-Clever online system with active PVP community-DLC comes includedNegative features:-30 fps cap-Requires a controller for best experience-Lack of graphical options and settings-Confusing navigation at timesTo conclude Dark Souls is not a game easy to summarise. On console it was amazing and although considered poor for PC, it is still the same game only better and one that is well worth your time, a lot of your time.

												dark souls , i can't properly make a good review for the game even after playing it for +170 hours .in every "top 10 hard video games " ,you'll find it on the list  , most of the time at the top of it . it's a game that punishes you for every bad decision or move that you made , and it doesn't limit you to play at one style of gameplay , you are open to beat it in anyway , which is funny actually because if you post a random post like "tips on how to beat [x] boss or something " ... you'll get plenty of users and each on of them offers his own solution which is different that the other guys's ways to deal with the problem that you're facing . the game becomes more enjoyable once you learn how to actually correctly play it , which it took me +40 hours of learning to be honest , it may take  less for you . to make the game less boring , and as you progress through the game , at the end , you get to repeat everything but in a state where everyone is even more stronger  .still , the game has some negatif points regarding the performance and the online gameplay  , luckily the community made some tools to counter it , but as some said : the perfect game doesn't need mods at all .as a final note ? i guess even tho i gave you a negatif comment on it i'll still say that it's a 10/10 game , 100% worth the money and the time .

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Dark Souls™: Prepare To Die™ Edition is quite an easy game, perfect for kids, people with ptsd and people suffering from some sort of rage problem.The gameplay is quite simple, you have to find the hidden cookies in the bushes, but WHATS THAT? Its Grandma, You have to hurry to find all the cookies fast before grandma catches you. Once you finish finding the hidden cookies the real battle begins.So then you visit a war torn city and help out the nice but sad people who live there, maybe help an old man cross the street, donate some money to the homeless and talk to the head honcho of the neighbourhood.After a nice conversation with him you keep moving towards the religious area of this war torn city and meet many nice people, a nice little piggy and even a trusty smith, you then move towards the chapel and talk to the nice priest there, he explains that the bell has not been rung in ages because the priest's back is not that well and he cannot climb the ladder anymore, so he sends you on a quest to ring the bell, and thats about as much as i want to spoil about this lovely and simple game.Perfect port, Recommend playing with a keyboard or Racing Wheel + Pedals.Score: 6 - Perfect Score.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												The problem is not to defeat the boss, the problem is to rush the zone and get to the boss with enough Estus Flasks!This game is wonderful, and i've played it for only 16-17h. I was a noob like you when i first bought it, i was worried like you are that it was going to be extremely brutal and frustrating, but it isn't for me. Well, it has been for the first 5-6 hours, when i actually thought: "why have i installed this game, why? It's terrible, it sucks; why should i use a controller, it's not fair; why the ♥♥♥♥ should i download mods for it to play at the ♥♥♥♥ing 60 fps and 1080p?".In those first hours i kept dying also to the worst skeletons of the tutorial, but going ahead with it it became understandable what the game wanted me to do: learn from my silly mistakes and make up a strategy on my own. The combat system is the best i've tried in my life, and it became understandable the difficoulty from the developers to create good keyboard keys to reproduce it. You'll have to block at a right timing, attack at the right timing, fall back at the right timing and dodge the hit AT THE RIGHT TIMING. You fail at one of these? You're dead, simple as that. The IA is very very clever, but it's not OP at all, you just need to ask yourself "what does this boss want me to do?" and you'll get it, after 20-40 times you try it. I actually found myself dying at the same boss for more than 20 times, but each time was better, untill i finally understood WHAT i was doing wrong. The good thing is that after these 20 times i wasn't bored at all, because the possibilities you have during a fight are infinite, and you'll never get tired of trying them all out! The comparison between DS and Skyrim is stupid imho: they are both epic for what they have to offer. Skyrim for its great graphics, open world, storyline, quests, MODS and a lot more; while DS for its difficoulty, replayability, combats and strategy. What is really missing on DS are strange mods like skyrims (that couldn't even be isntalled without DSfix!).I have to admit that having to install DSfix and other graphic mods to make it AT LEAST enjoyable at 1080p and 60fps is baaahd, but come on, you'll have to work on it 20 minutes to enjoy your gameplay for ever!Come on, little newbie, buy it, enjoy it and remember to NEVER EVER look on the internet cheap ways to defeat bosses, you'll feel soooo bad after having done that, trust me! :)

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Dark Souls is the new action role-playing game from the developers who brought you Demon’s Souls, FromSoftware. You exist in a land where the bad guys have already won – society is in terminal decline and everyone is turning into undead ‘hollows’. That’s how you start the game, but some trick of fate allows you to keep your human mind. You can even transform back into a person by obtaining ‘humanity’ from dead enemies – although it’s a rare commodity and, as you may have heard, dying is a very frequent occurrence in Dark Souls.I've played the game for around 250+ hours in order to complete all the achievements and characters' side quests. It is truly a masterpiece with an incredible story, stunning atmosphere and many gorgeous views. The world is masterfully designed, the soundtrack is amazing and the boss battles are outstanding and memorable. On top of that, one of the best features in the game is the online play - I found defeating the hardest bosses while cooperating with a friend very fun. The PvP system is really well done and I was usually able to find active players who were ready to fight - despite the game coming out 4 years go, the community is still very active and friendly. The first thing you may hear about Dark Souls is how hard it is, and while it is a very challenging game indeed, the reward for completing it or for even beating a boss is the best and biggest sense of achievement you will get out of a video game. The only reason why I wouldn't give it a perfect 100/100 is the PC port which is frustrating at first, but with a couple of downloads and mods you can fix it.In conclusion, this is one of the best and most replayable games I've ever played. If you like challenging games and are prepared to die, this is the game for you. I would recommend you play it with a controller and look through the community forums for guides if you find the game too hard for you.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Dark Souls is a beautifully crafted experience in a dark fantasy setting that will challenge the player to adapt and learn from their experiences rather than be spoon fed like many modern games.The level design often creates a game of risk versus reward with the careful playcement of bonfires which serve as checkpoints where you can rest and level up your character. The question many new players will be asking themselves is weither to play it safe and go back to the bonfire and lose their progress, or to push on and risk losing their souls in hopes of finding another bonfire. Being the open world that Dark Souls is, each area connects with another logically and physically often through shortcuts opened up by the player. You can stop and look around at your distant surroundings and think to yourself, " Ah yes, I've been to that bridge before." and realise that each area of the game was perfectly placed with each other area in mind. This also serves the idea of experienced players being able to quickly build whatever character they want without being railroaded into a single path storyline creating replay value.Speaking of storyline, there practically isnt any. Dark Souls is a lore rich game which often will be missed by first time players creating an atmosphere of hopelessness as you go around and around not knowing where to go. This aids in the player exploring the world on their own with little direction, but can be frustrating at times for the new player. The NPCs you find are primarily venders and story tellers, but will come and go with their own agendas further showing that the world doesnt revolve around you. Dark Souls offers multiplayer in a few forms. Players can frequently see messages written by other players wishing to aid or hinder others as well as seeing ghosts and blood stains giving the impression of how others have died giving you a warning. Dark Souls also has optional co-op and pvp by recovering your humanity. Players needing help can summon phantoms to their world to help them progress and take down bosses, but this also invites enemy phantoms to try and stop you. The co-op and pvp however is totally voluntary and is not forced apon you at any time, however you cannot have one without the other excluding playing the game offline and summoning NPC phantoms.Dark Souls is an absolute must play for anyone looking for a challenge.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												We all know that this game is famed for being 'difficult' or frustrating so instead of justifying this or telling you to suck it up, I'll write about my experience of the game so far.'You Died'But in all seriousness, Dark Souls: Prepare to Die is a game I think everyone should play at least once. It is reminiscent of old style RPG top-down dungeon crawlers in it's atmosphere with the level design allowing you to cautiously make decisions in which way you want to explore. 'Left or right? What if I miss a shiny by going this way?' you know the feel. It's really refreshing to see a more modern game handle this so well.The combat however is what makes it really shine. You can't charge in and hope to obliterate everything by mashing a few buttons. Combat in this game, even against the 'trash' mobs, needs to be carefully planned. It's not forced like an RTS or turn based combat but if you don't think carefully about where and when to move, dodge and strike you will meet a bloodstainy end very quickly. While this probably sounds like less of a selling point, as you play the reward of overcoming a foe is that 'Awwyes' moment. Again, something a lot of modern games lack. It's also worth noting the class system is classic RPG style, with attributes that you level up so you can play the way you feel suits you. The threat of dying is always there and the game does a good job of keeping you on your toes. Death is more of a learning curve in Dark Souls and half the fun is running into unexpected situations or biting off more than you can chew, each encounter (and subsequent death) asks you to take a moment to think how you could have handled that better. A boss may take more than a few attempts to overcome but when you do, you are equipped for future areas of the game. At first you'll probably be resistant to this, as many games treat defeat as the final stop, not a fully integral part of the mechanics. Once you accept this though, death is pretty fun. The world, lore and atmosphere of Dark Souls is also some thing to mention. Without spoilers, the world is a dark medieval fantasy, which sounds cliche but it keeps a pretty unique feel and adds to the doomy storyline and mechanics. The creature and character design are also refreshing.Now for some not so good things. Firstly, this is a port to PC. A lazy one. It's so lazy even the tutorial messages reference Xbox controller buttons *searches keyboard for RT button* While I've been playing with keyboard for the time being I'd suggest you buy an Xbox controller. Keyboard is okay, but I spent a fair while in the starting area mentally mapping what key did what. They aren't intuitive. You'll have a better time with controller.The resolution can also be horrific on larger screens, which is a pity because the graphics are interesting. To remedy this there is an easy to install mod on Nexus, DSMfix. Almost a must have in my opinion. Overall Dark Souls is a brilliant game worthy of time and attention. It has that old style feel that many games lack and is almost worth it just for that. However, if you are the sort of gamer who gets easily frustrated or doesn't like to be challenged in a game you should probably look into it more before buying.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												I kwnow it could a bit pretentious, or even arrogant, but i have to say: "EVERYONE SHOULD TRY THIS GAME" Why? Because this is what every game should be:The whole PVE gameplay is perfectly balanced (except for a single boss battle) even without a "difficulty selector", so no, there is no "easy difficult"; and yes, you'll die a lot, but only when you actually deserve it,(if you find it much too hard probably you are just missing something: try to explore or try another route; or you are playing with mouse and keyboard: buy a joypad).Arts, graphic and engine good enough to make this game really good-looking, but "light" enough to work smoothly in older machine: a mid tier notebook is more than enough to make this game run(even though it WILL fall to 15 fps in particular circumstance, whatever configuration you adopt)In addition to the two previous consideration, you will have HUGE selection of weapon and magic, every single one of them has unique appearance, moveset and effect, making almost any playstyle peculiar AND potentially successfull in the game (except for some, obvious, joke and trap: SPOILER: don't use the dragonsword at your first playthrough)Multiplayer is very well done, except sometimes for latency in PVP (especially when players come from far different region).Except when you play offline mode and/or disconnected from the internet, you are actually playing in multiplayer, *always*, this mean: communication from and for other player (in form of orange message written on the floor), "ghost" appearance of other player in the same area at the same time, blood of dead players (and if you interact, you will see HOW that player is actually dead).But, before you can actually do PVP and COOP, you need to perform another operation, this secures you against unespected grief AND, at the same time, if you need external help you'll have a counterpart (BUT, if you want to HELP another players you can do coop even without "activating" the PVP, you only have to be patient)The only real downfall of this game is its PC-port: it is not so good ("awful" is the right term, to be honest),BUT the community did a set for excellent workarounds for this, the only thing you need to do is: go to "discussion" panel read the 4 pinned discussions (especially   this one ) profitPraise the sun!

												The thing about this game is that it has ruined other games for me. You know why? Because other games don't feel as engaging or...fun. So, don't be afraid to die my...son.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Simply put: One of the best games I have ever played, alongside the Elder Scrolls series. The art direction, lore and player interaction are masterfully done. The amazing artstyle alone should come as no surprise from the individuals that have been creating numerous-but-unique mech designs for over a decade.The game mechanics are simple, but satisfying. Allowing you to block, parry, dodge, light attack and heavy attack your enemies. What I like about the way the game handles itself with the combat system is how methodical it forces the player to be in unevenly matched fights. A lot of the enemies can be ran past once you understand the layout of the areas, but it can still be a rather tricky endeavor because of various environmental hazards that you'll find along the way.The only true complaint I can lodge against the game mechanics are the absurdly generous input buffering for actions that usually do more harm than help. Also, be warned that since this game uses a peer-to-peer system for its multiplayer component, establishing sessions with friends or other people can turn into a frustrating ordeal.The game itself is not nearly as diverse in terms of character creation/input as something like an Elder Scrolls game, but this is more than made up for with the gripping and unique world that From have managed to create. Obscurity is a major game mechanic theme of Dark Souls, and is what makes it so much fun to play. The joy of exploring areas that you previously had believed to be thoroughly searched, only to discover a new secret hidden within its crevices. It is this sense of exploration coupled with the very macabre atmosphere that make Dark Souls a truly wonderous experience.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												I'm not sure I've ever spent so much time on a game I've enjoyed so little. There are some silver linings, but they all come with big black clouds attached.There's something compelling here - it's vaguely Metroid-like in how you really do feel like you're venturing into the unknown. And Dark Souls passes on the common flaws of modern cutscene-laden action games, which is nice to see. But in doing so it draws on the worst parts of old-school D&D, then adds in a few terrible design decisions on top. So at the end of the day it's just a disappointing dungeon crawler, albeit one with an sometimes-rabid fanbase.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Without a doubt the most dreadful PC port I've ever seen, this should have stayed console exclusive. If you don't have a controller, there is no reason to ever buy this game, and I'm not buying an XBOX controller just to play this game. Without a controller, menus are horribly irresponsive, mouse acceleration is all over the place, and the game never looks more than 1280x720p, regardless of effects, only options are motion blur and antialiasing. Gameplay is, again, dreadful without a proper controller, developers don't bother with mouse sensitivity, so any turn will turn you 90 degrees regardless without mods and even then the game is a chore to play, you can't rebind mouse keys, game doesn't even show the computer keys, just controller keys.Even ignoring the necessity for controller (which is, frankly, inexcusable considering the game could have been much more well implemented for mouse and keyboard), the PC port is still awful, since no changes were made to accomodate PC, a painful lack of graphical options, an extremely obtuse control scheme that makes no effort to change for a PC title and instead rebinds every button in a jumble across the letter keys, badly optimized graphics, no quality change, etc. Now, the elephant in the room: Windows Live. Since June 1st, it has been impossible to go online play or save your game at all, which is, again, an inexcusable oversight for a PC port where save files can be saved on the computer. Don't trust any review before June 1st in regards to functionality, it's no longer relevant.There is no way such a slapdash port should be seen as excusable compared to a console exclusive, regardless of developer of quality, period.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Dark Souls is a fantastic and unforgettable experience with an immersive world and innovative multiplayer components. Brilliant level design and combat mechanics are what make this game great.The difficulty in this game is often exaggerated. The game is challenging, but always fair. Whenever you die, its always your fault, not because of some cheap game mechanic. The game is not so much hard as it is punishing. Choosing to give an extra greedy hit against a boss can mean the difference between life and death. Unlike most RPGs, power in this game is more than just a numerical value, actual player skill plays a bigger part. The immersive atmosphere and the feeling of overcoming challenges are great.This game is the most incredible gaming experience I have ever had. I can remember every moment of my first playthrough, from my naive first steps, to what I felt while the credits rolled. I have never before seen a game with such thought put into it.HoweverAfter spending over 200 hours on the console version of the game, I decided to buy the game on steam. I was disappointed, the PC port is a joke. The graphical settings are extremely lacking, the vanilla game won’t run in full resolution and is capped at 30fps. The store page isn’t kidding when it says that a controller is recommended, the keyboard and mouse controls are horrible.  On top of all that, the game uses Games for Windows Live, which doesn’t let you access your save file if you are not connected to the internet.   Edit: The game has been ported to steamworks, not sure how this affects the online just yet, but at least you don't have to go through all of the GFWL account nonsense Fortunately, some of these things can be fixed with mods, DSfix does a great job of fixing most of the problems the PC port has, and DSMfix fixes the problems with the controls (I still recommend a controller though).I could go on and on about what makes Dark Souls so amazing, but this review is long enough already. If you are willing to install some mods to make it work, I would recommend this game to anyone, even to those who don’t like difficult games.

												10/10This game seems to be too hard or even unfair at first, but after a few hours and the first bosses it turns out to be super fun and it rewards you for for learning its combat. + amazing combat system+ world completetely connected+ can be played multiple time due to different possible ways/ covenants+ skill-based pvp system, almost no lucky wins+ coop play gives you the opportunity to summon help if you have trouble with some areas+ great lore, although in the background (room for interpretation)+ NG+ gives you the opportunity to collect a lot of the items- almost unplayable with keyboard (only gamepad)- VERY hard to play coop/pvp with a friend, needs up to 2h to summon each other, even then no guarantee- pvp works with p2p, meaning that heavy lags can occur (lagstabs...)All in all an amazing game, completely worth buying, challenging but never unfair, hard beginning but huge learing curve!

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Dark Souls is that one must play for any hardcore gamer (or even average gamers) for several reasons, one of them being challenging yourself to go as far as you can into this game before quitting in rage or frustration, except the game still has fine design like to make you come back.This is surely one of the hardest games out there, and simply playing it without focusing on cheesing the heck out of the game would be brag worthy.Both the PvE and PvP for this game are really good, it has always had an active community even after further installments (3 other installments, 2 if you don't count Bloodborne). You'll always find people to do co-op with or PvP against. Of course, keep in mind there's the malicious players at very early game that abuse the Soul Level system for matchmaking, and would stay at a low enough level to where they would be able to invade newbies, while they have mid-game gear, solely for the sake of picking on the newbies.More onto the PvE, this game's bosses aren't the only difficult thing, even the weaker enemies are dangerous if you think you can just rush through everything without proper gear or knowing what you're doing. The atmosphere gives you a feeling of being alone and maybe even helpless in this dark setting. Overcoming the dangers Dark Souls throws at you gives an extremely satisfying feel, for good reason, as you have managed to become good enough to just push away what used to destroy you, even if you may not have the gear to do so yet and you manage either way.Skill and patience is everything in Dark Souls. Taking the strongest weapon you have available early game through some gimmicks will not help you win. Finding a good weapon with a comfortable moveset (and is atleast the strongest or second strongest of it's weapon type) is what you need instead, so that you can kill enemies without worrying about messing up, specially since you've gotten attatched to your weapon.Replayability is also something big in Dark Souls: you'll always end up coming back at some point, and have between dozens of builds possible for your character, all dependant on what you'd prefer your playstyle to be like. All character ''classes'' can be anything in this game, the classes only determine your starting gear and stats to give you a headstart for your build. There's just a few things bad about this game and it's the networking. The game used Games For Windows Live up until some point, and has been updated to use Steam instead for the connectivity, roughly a year ago. Even then, there are clear issues with the online play like suddenly losing connection with all other players, making you unable to see other players' blood stains (death points), or not even be matched for PvP at all. There's fortunately a mod out there to fix this, and I'll provide a link for it and a few other things to improve the game's rough spots.Recommended Mods:DSFix:http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/19/?You *need* to get this mod if you wish to improve your framerate (even unlock from 30 FPS to 60), resolution, and overall graphics level for Dark Souls. You should get it even if you do not wish to upscale the graphics, the built-in FPS lock for Dark Souls is actually unoptimized, and simply unlocking it but then using this mod's own FPS Lock on 30, grants a major performance boost. Be aware that unlocking to 60 FPS will cause animation and hitbox issues.DSCM: Wulf's DS Connectivity Modhttp://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/1047/?Will improve, as the title says, the connectivity in dark souls allowing you to not simply lose connection with other players and give you the ability to connect to someone in specific like a friend of yours for co-op.Dark Souls PVP Watchdog:http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/849/?This mod will improve the matchmaking in a way that it will make sure you do not get matched with people that cheated their way up into the game, like being at Soul Level 5 but having 99 in every single stat, making them insanely overpowered. Those players will be blocked out from your connection with this mod.Another thing you could look for is SweetFX, but be warned that most presets for this kind of graphics mod mess up brightness in a way that places that are already dark will end up *pitch black* and give you a lot of trouble just to try to see what's there. And there are a lot of already pitch black areas in Dark Souls before this mod, so keep that in mind.Overall Rating: 9/10:Gameplay Rating: 9/10Music Rating: 9/10Graphics Rating: 8/10Replayability: 10/10- Nominated for ''The Test of Time'' Award. -

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Verdict:Buy now!Buy on saleSave your money Overall Score:8.5/10Summary:I feel like Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition has been taunting me for 4 years - waiting for me to play it. I'd heard a lot about it and the hype so thought I'd experience it first hand.To critique this game is not so straightforward. There are major issues. It's a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port and you will spend your initial time downloading the DSFix 'mod' just so you can get it into a reasonably playable state. Forget about playing it on Keyboard and Mouse, unless you like extra punishment, a controller is a MUST (Steam controller worked well for me as an aside). The graphics are pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (even for 2012, but remember at its core this is a last-gen console game). The absence of a tutorial or tooltips will have you alt tabbing and searching YouTube just to try and find out even the most basic of info that will be crucial to your game.Yet despite all that the game rises to be head and shoulders over the sum of its parts. Once you accept the basic premise that you are there to die and learn from your mistakes (the game even has a mechanic where you can watch other people’s death, via a ghost, by clicking on their bloodstain to help learn from their mistakes). Then you will practice and practice and finally get it right - rewarding you with extremely satisfying moments, a feeling not often found in today’s games. There is something to be said for taking on a boss 6 or 7 times then finally defeating him. It's not just a matter of doing the boss fight, it's clearing the trash every single time, occasionally losing your XP in the process, which will serve to both destroy your soul and have you punching the air in triumph when you are finally successful.Overall the game is akin to flawed genius, you know something is not quite right, the game will brutally punish your mistakes and yet it is almost because of it that you will find yourself coming back for more. I'm pretty sure this is the only game I have actually Rage Quit in the last 5 or so years.I've recommended picking up On Sale because the game has been around long enough and on sale enough times that you can save your money, add it to your wish list and then grab it at the next sale (unless of course you have a burning desire to play straight away).The Good:Brutal and satisfying gameplayCommunity support Good old fashion boss fightsSound is greatThe Bad:Can feel lost as a new player, with very little information to go onThe graphicsYou need to fix the off the shelf game (DSFix) before playing it to avoid a suboptimal experienceThe Ugly:A terrible console port, NOT supported after releaseCamera can be frustratingPro TipAlthough you may need to go to the Wiki / YouTube to get some of the basics of the game, I highly recommend you stay away from watching boss fights and reading guides - the most satisfying experience will be making your own way through the game.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
Genre: Hardcore Action RPGGame Time: 60~70+ hoursThe PC port is passable. The game itself however boasts a solid combat mechanic ahead of it's time, which even in 2015 is one of the best on the market. The dialogue is minimal and the story itself isn't presented like traditional RPGs but the atmosphere just reeks of heart-crushing despair and helplessness. You can genuinely feel the fall of a civilization as you progress through the levels and see the destruction of monuments and countless fallen soldiers turned hollow.The level design is a brilliant display of craftsmanship although in the later levels you acquire the ability to warp through specific checkpoints.The colorful bosses will repeatedly destroy you until you get good to the point of not needing to rely on cheesy exploits. Fitting music too. You will scream in terror at your first encounter with the Taurus Demon while the orchestra and chorus enhances the fear of being crushed to death.Dark Souls has a crazy amount of content and great ideas executed perfectly, if not for the age of the game the full-price of $20 is a massive steal. It's multiplayer and co-op despite being released on the PC in Q3 2012, is still well alive. Of course not as lively as what it used to be but not dead to say the least.Sometimes the player count can exceed what Evolve got on average during it's free-weekend, and that game came out this year.There are so few criticisms for the game I would be nitpicking if I were to make one up. Besides it's obvious that the game had a limited budget and time constraints, but the fact that FromSoftware managed to create a game of this magnitude, is just inhuman. Seriously amazing job guys.Oh, and don't forget to install DSfix![www.nexusmods.com]

												I don't know what to say about this game, so let's start from the beginning.I bought this game on a humble bundle just for fun and I kinda wanted to play the game for a long time.Bought a cheap controller and started playing. content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This is without a doubt one of the laziest and most poorly made PC ports I've ever seen. I have a little over two hours of playtime on this port and the entirety of that time was spent trying to get it to run above 15 FPS. And that's indoors - once it gets into an open area, the framerate drops even lower. I don't have the greatest machine, true, but neither do many people - and this game isn't pretty enough to justify the demands it makes on your computer.That being said, Dark Souls remains an excellent game. Having played through the first two games I can without a doubt recommend it - just not the PC version. If you have a high-end PC with a strong CPU and don't have another system that can run this game, then maybe this is for you. Even so, you'll definitely want to get DSFix just to make the game's resolution worth it.9/10 game, 1/10 port.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												"It's not hard, but hard to get into" - VaatiVidyaIs Dark Souls a hard game? Yes. Is it unfair? Mostly not. Is it impossible? Not at all. The main difficulty is how it is unfriendly to new players. You may have troubles understanding where to go, what to do, how to defeat some tough enemies, how to upgrade equipment, etc. Not gonna lie, I consulted some guides once in a while. But if you actually listen to NPCs, look at your environment, and use other players' help, everything gets much easier. The reward is astonishing. Dark Souls features unforgettable action-RPG experience, a grim but beautiful world, violent combat, unique designs, original online features (both coop and PvP), an excellent soundtrack by Motoi Sakuraba and high replayability. There are still enough players online, so you won't feel alone. The story is not a main point in the game, but it still has some great characters and side stories, however you need to look carefully not to miss them. Framerate issues at some locations and bad mouse/keyboard controls may spoil your gameplay, so a mod called DSFix and a gamepad are indispensable.Overall, I liked the game very much. To tell the truth, it took me several attempts to get used to it, but it was worth it.9/10
