												Seriously, this is one of the best games I ever played. Maybe /the/ best, so far. Why? I have no idea, I started playing, but I gave up, rather quickly, it was just too damn hard.  But then, I tried again and I made progress, where I failed the last time. What a satisfying feeling. And there the fever got me, I wanted to keep playing, to level up, to get the best equipment, or to just see how the next level looks like.But on my way to the End, I cried, I danced in joy, or I was just happy I survive, with my heart racing like I've been running for miles. No game, I ever played, got me so tied up and made me want to play again, no matter how often I died.Some people say, this game has no story, well. On the first glance, there is none. But one of the strengths of Dark Souls, is also it's Story Line, it's hidden. You need to find piece of a puzzle, that you never will truly complete, it gives you hints and you have to make your own story from it. You are in a hostile world, you against everybody else, this just get's underlined by it. Seriously, who can take to die some times and is willing to play a game, where you aren't the Literal God of War, slaying everybody after a while without any problems. You should give Dark Souls a try. This game is really a jewel in the RPG scene and a title, you shouldn't miss.

												If you are prepare to die this game is for you. You will die alot but each death will teach you something, If you like the challanging gameplay this game is one of the best. This game is hard when you first play it because lack of instructions for beginers but as you go on game will become easy.Pros:- Lots of unique enemies. Each area has its own type of enemies. I should say these normal enemies will kill you more than area boss. Great Level Design. All the areas in the game are interconnected.  Some of the best boss fights I ever seen. It feels very satifying to kill some bosses.  Great sound design. Ambient music when you fight with boss feels great. Sound when boss hit their weapon and you block it with your shield feels real. Lots of weapons to choose from. Every weapon has its own unique move set. You can build your character anyway you like. Great DLC content. Coop and PVP battles.Cons:- Pyromancy feels over powered. Most of the bosses in dark souls are weak to fire, Even some of them are good against fire they still die easily with fully upgraded pyromancies. Very bad PC port. One of the worst port I ever seen. Frame rate some times drops at certain areas not much but you can feel it. Although game's art style is great graphics doesn't feel that great.This game is not perfect. It has its flows. I give this game 8/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												This is obviously a very late review of Dark Souls so why review it now? Well to start things off simple, the big sales are coming around so if you feel the urge to buy it from Steam but not sure about it? Well here's a review you may or may not find helpful. The other reason is...Dark Souls II is just less than four months away and what better way to prepare than to review its predecessor for newcommers! Combat:The combat in Dark Souls is very basic, you have your left hand equipment for blocking and right hand equipment for attacking of two types, standard and strong attacks. Keeping this in mind that it can and might apply to all classes you may use, there are different classes you can make so you might be a sorcerer, cleric, strenght, dexterity, or mix. Also keeping this in mind, each weapon has a certain stat that scales and is required to use. This adds to the combat of what you can and can't use. Now onto the actual combat sequences: the actual combat is well designed and very fluid. Any time you die it is always your mistake of how you approached an enemy. It's no hack and slash game that's for sure, that is how you get yourself killed. Combat in this game is all about timing and approachment and it's glorious.Story:Now I will not get much into this, not that there is much surface story for you to absorb from just plowing through but, the story starts you off in a place called the Undead Asylum. After you escape you learn of these two bells and from there on out your journy continues There is a bit more of the surface story that can be hand fed to you but like I said, not going to spoil much. The lore or backstory of this is what links everything that may seem confusing together. Through From Software's brilliant design they have made it like a broken puzzle to find it all out. You learn everything through item descriptions, dialgogue, and even some times just by the looks of the area if your observant enough. It's hard work but the results will not dissapoint. Bosses & Common Enemies: To start this seciton off, we're going to start with common enemies, yeah those guys. The enemies in Dark Souls are of interesting nature, unlike in games like the First Person Shooters where they stand around like lost children, these enemies are aggressive and persistent. They are stupid enough to beat but smart enough to punish. Now when I say stupid I do not mean fit the shapes stupid, I mean they are trimmed down just enough to where they are not some diety sent form the gods to punish you, they are very much beatable. Some enemies may be smarter or tougher than others but all are beatable. The trick is they all know how to punish you for screwing up. Mistakes in Dark Souls are not forgiven. This paragraph will all be for the details of the most epic fights you will face, even if the boss seems...eh. Okay, skipping the obvious known fact of Dark Souls being known for its intense boss fights, lets discuss WHY they're intense.  Music only plays on very few occasions outside of boss fights but when these boss fights do ensue, music starts that captivates the feel of your character's challange ahead of them, the terror that they are fighting. With that included you can even tell by the way the boss fights. If it's sad or depressing music, it is a story of tragedy or sorrow. Vice versa if it's loud and fast, you get the feeling the boss is  full of rage or beast-like properties that knows no mercy. These boss fights are something that are more than just a challange, they have a story behind them and are masterpieces, each and every one of them...except Bed of Chaos.Graphics & performance:Now this is a subject I usually leave alone but in Dark Souls's case, it must be adressed. Not because it truely matters if you played it on PS3 or Xbox 360 but because of how atrocious of a port this game was. Locked in at 30 frames per second with a very poor graphic quality locked in that wasn't even 720p made it look terrible on the stretched screen of the PC. It was an exact copy paste of the Xbox 360 version, no modifications to optimize this baby. Now before you start getting freaked out and shy away, there is a mod to fix this. It is called the DSFix mod and it unlocks the frame rate and graphics settings. If you don't got the mod the game will look muddy and not play smooth, with it installed you got a pretty, dark atmospheric game and have a smooth frame rate that doesn't murder your frames in the cruel area of Blighttown.Final Verdict: I know this review seems a bit short and very rushed and it is, 2:36 in the morning is not the ideal time to do these things. I am going to give it 2 scores, one w/o the mod and one with it. This is being done so you can get an idea of what  experience you will get. WIthout the mod:  6/10. This game is nearly unplayable without the mod. The keyboard bindings are not so hot, the frame rate is locked in at 30 which for a PC game is not the ideal setting to be playing at, and very muddy, stretched graphics from the locked in graphics setting of something less than 720p stretched out onto a monitor. With the mod: 9/10If you got the mod installed you will not regret it at all and you are in for a masterpiece only obtainable by the skills of From Software and the publishing efforts of Namco Bandai. After notes:-It is highly recommended to use a gamepad for this game. Keyboard bindings like I said are not that good and this is a straight up console port. -Installation of the mod is easy, follow the files in the order below in whichever program x you haveSteamSteamAppsCommonDark Souls Prepare to Die EditionDATANow drop the files you have extracted from the DSFix compressed into here and follow any remaining instructions.Find DSFix and edit the game settings there.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												If you are prepare to die this game is for you. You will die alot but each death will teach you something, If you like the challanging gameplay this game is one of the best. This game is hard when you first play it because lack of instructions for beginers but as you go on game will become easy.Pros:- Lots of unique enemies. Each area has its own type of enemies. I should say these normal enemies will kill you more than area boss. Great Level Design. All the areas in the game are interconnected.  Some of the best boss fights I ever seen. It feels very satifying to kill some bosses.  Great sound design. Ambient music when you fight with boss feels great. Sound when boss hit their weapon and you block it with your shield feels real. Lots of weapons to choose from. Every weapon has its own unique move set. You can build your character anyway you like. Great DLC content. Coop and PVP battles.Cons:- Pyromancy feels over powered. Most of the bosses in dark souls are weak to fire, Even some of them are good against fire they still die easily with fully upgraded pyromancies. Very bad PC port. One of the worst port I ever seen. Frame rate some times drops at certain areas not much but you can feel it. Although game's art style is great graphics doesn't feel that great.This game is not perfect. It has its flows. I give this game 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Seriously, this is one of the best games I ever played. Maybe /the/ best, so far. Why? I have no idea, I started playing, but I gave up, rather quickly, it was just too damn hard.  But then, I tried again and I made progress, where I failed the last time. What a satisfying feeling. And there the fever got me, I wanted to keep playing, to level up, to get the best equipment, or to just see how the next level looks like.But on my way to the End, I cried, I danced in joy, or I was just happy I survive, with my heart racing like I've been running for miles. No game, I ever played, got me so tied up and made me want to play again, no matter how often I died.Some people say, this game has no story, well. On the first glance, there is none. But one of the strengths of Dark Souls, is also it's Story Line, it's hidden. You need to find piece of a puzzle, that you never will truly complete, it gives you hints and you have to make your own story from it. You are in a hostile world, you against everybody else, this just get's underlined by it. Seriously, who can take to die some times and is willing to play a game, where you aren't the Literal God of War, slaying everybody after a while without any problems. You should give Dark Souls a try. This game is really a jewel in the RPG scene and a title, you shouldn't miss.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												This game truly is a masterpiece!That said, let´s begin with a more "reasonable" review.Dark Souls  is a hard game, not always because of the cruel, hard enemies that will let you scream "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T!"more than once, but because of the lack of direcrion.But because of that dieing isn´t a shame but a mean of progress. It shows you your enemies move sets and potential traps so that you can do better with your next life.That might seem like a bad thing in an RPG, but for this RPG it really sets the dark feeling of isolation and beeing "lost" in the very hostile world of Lordran. The world is nearly completely free to explore right from the begining, yet you won´t progress much if in the wrong areas. There even are areas that aren´t needed for the story at all, which is a thing most games don´t do anymore.All this may result in a playtime of 60-100Hours on the first playthrough if played blind. (I admit, i didn´t play completely blind :( )Also lore is handled very differently than in everything i´ve seen so far, there´s an intro video telling you a tiny bit and the rest is up to you to find and combine through conversations and item descriptions. That may mean that you really have to "work" to feel immersed, but it weirdly doesn´t make the lore any worse but  better since your imagination takes a Huge role.Gameplay wise Dark Souls  is one of the best games I´ve played so far, it doesn´t have any complex or fancy combos, but it has a wide variety of weapons, shield, spells, pyromancies and miracles to fit everyones playstyle in some way.Added to that is the harsh management of your stamina that is more than limited, a great counter and parry mechanic, sneaky backstabs and a working, yet a bit unfair and broken PvP and Co-op mechanic. The multiplayer sadly is a bit hard to manage because of the GFWL.Did i mention GFWL? That brings us to the bad sides of this version of Dark Souls.It is a bad port, like REALLY bad. You need to install a mod called DSfix to make it work, and even then GFWL could cause some trouble, which really is a shame.These are severy problems that can be fixed easily though. There are a ton of Videos on Youtube that show you how to install DSfix and the steam forums are always nice if you ask there too, so don´t be scared even if you´ve never inbstalled a mod before.When the mod is installed the game runs well and even looks far better than console versions, and that really is worth the modding.All in all this concludes to me telling you that this is probably the best ActionRPG you could (and should) buy.And as always:Prepare To Die!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												While I dislike consoles and most games that are tailor made for them, this has been a pleasant surprise.Even though the control scheme is a nightmare without a controller, it can be mastered.The game itself is very interesting, the graphics are nice (even today they are impressive) and the settings are truly grand. At its core it is an action rpg, where you get to fight overwhelmingly powerful enemies at all turns. Even at higher levels you can end up dying to monsters that seem trivial, when careless. The bosses are all powerful, some to the point where they seem impossible to beat. Don't despair, there is always a way... unless you attack something totally out of your depth (haven't had the experience yet). Having said the above, don't be mistaken you have to die over and over and over to figure out the tactics and hone the skills that will be needed to dispatch of certain enemies.The plot line is ok, nothing tremendous, but it is supported by a setting of such grandness, that ends up lifting it to great heights.For me the true strength of the game is the freedom it gives you to explore your own play-style and build your character the way you want. I have heard that this can lead to some unplayable character builds, however I don t see that happening past 1 or 2 characters (I abandoned my first character too - however after going further with my next character I realized it was more a matter of inexperience and lack of knowledge, rather than character abilities).One thing that is both a strength and a weakness is the lack of information... it is so easy to miss things (important things mind you) that it can become frustrating. If one thing is for certain, it is that the player needs to be very alert and explore all corners of each area. The main problem with searching everything, is that there is very little to find (extra/semi hidden stuff), but still it is there to find and you should look for it.In terms of openness, it does have a slight linearity at first, but soon you get the choice to explore at your own leisure. Now a warning... (this falls under the no information problem) you may be exploring an area where you have no way of continuing further (with very little indication that there is anything further) without first completing something in another area and while at the end of the day it may seem logical and aligned with the plot, it is extremely easy to miss it (one thing to keep in mind is always pay attention to the npc dialogs and talk to them often).While dying is a integral part of the game, which you get used to after a short while, it can still be frustrating... mostly when you die because you fall of an edge, or get pushed off one or you press the wrong button... at the end of the day anything in the world can kill you, not just the actual enemies.I play this on my (older) laptop, which kind of sucks (the laptop), but it still can cope, thus anyone with a decent rig can play it.The multiplayer aspect of the game is a bit peculiar, where (under specific conditions) other players can invade your world and attack you (you have no choice in the matter), something that can be frustrating. On the other hand you can call other players for a bit of coop or be summoned (if you are willing) to help others.Overall its a great game (not just good) even with all the minor problems and frustrations - it just consumes you... so be careful.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Though it seems a poor framework game at the start, with a little tweaking, you are thrown into one of the most challenging and satisfying games you will ever play. Not for the faint hearted or those who give up easily, but those who like to smack giant demons around with weapons larger than your character and triumph over seemingly impossible odds. No other game cries out manmode like this one. This game cries out versatility in almost every aspect be it customizing your character, fighting style, appearance and even how you wish to play the game and progress. There are nearly no boundaries to stop you, only your skill and knowledge. Not to mention a fun pvp system that could be highly improved. 9.5/10 for offline play, a little less speculation of the story would be nice and a bit more concrete lore. 8/10 for pvp play. The online needs much more regulation to stop all the cheating. Otherwise, I would probably give it a 10. I haven't had this much fun duelling other players in a long time.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												So i guess what they say is right. This game is not for the masses. It's hard in its own way. You have to master your character's every ability to go on. As an old-school RPG player, i found this difficulty "weird". It's not about riddles, puzzles or tactics. It's about consistency. You have to perform good every time you lose and start anew. And you'll lose a lot! So from my point of view, i found it boring instead of challenging to dispatch EVERY time 20 "weak" enemies in order to reach and fight again the boss that just kicked my♥♥♥♥♥(boss fights are a whole different story, they are fun). Most stories that you 've heard about broken controllers/keyboards are exactly because of getting "salty" and not really of the original difficulty. Also another thing that made a great (negative) impression on me was the TOTAL absense of lore! Never before in a so-called RPG game i have searched on the internet to find clues for even the basic plot! Anyway, i finished it, i enjoyed it but it's not what i expected. Nevertheless i strongly reccomend it.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												In 1987, my older brother and I asked for only one thing for Christmas - The Legend of Zelda.  Ok, fine, we also asked for TMNT action figures, but that's a separate review. In any case, I can still remember tearing open the packaging and pulling out the magical golden cartridge.  As all younger brothers, I took the instruction manual as my brother got to play first.  The game starts, of course, with the story of Hyrule and Zelda's abduction.  You then name your character (a first!) and are dropped into Hyrule with nothing but a tiny shield and three measly hearts of life.  Except for finding the wooden sword in the nearby cave, nothing was obvious.  You could travel any cardinal direction, monsters attacking at every turn.  My brother wandered west, a big mistake.  Somehow surviving monsters far above his life/equipment level, he found the third dungeon.  What kind of twisted, depraved game allows a brand new character to enter a high-level area?  The monsters assailed poor Link and his nano-shield. His feable wooden sword only aggravated most monsters and split the chu-chu into more pieces.  Badly wounded, game beaping (still gets my pulse up) we stumbled out of the dungeon, bewildered. After exiting, and breathing a sigh of relief, the nearby tektite promptly killed us. We choose to continue, but our character now had a scarlet letter (number) by his name. With each death, and there were many, the number grew, a grim reminder of how many times we had met a horrible demise.  With persistance (and yes, a bit of help from Nintendo Power), we eventually defeated Ganon.  This was the greatest accomplishment in the first ten years of my life (judge me if you will).  The victory was richly rewarding, and I continue to replay Zelda to this day, trying to win the game in under 90 minutes with all items and no deaths.  My point, beyond reminiscing, is that Dark Souls is the actual sequel to The Legend of Zelda.  Yes, Ocarina et al are technically the sequels, but they have betrayed the essence of the original game.  Zelda has become cutesy, easy, and the amount of hand-holding and tip-giving led me to stop playing the series altogether.  Dark Souls, on the other hand, drops you into a deeply engrossing, unforgivng world with measly weapons and no direction (sound familiar?).  Fine, they tell you to find two bells, but in my original game, I somehow ended up in Drake Valley on my first foray after leaving the asylum.  I walked up to a drake, thinking it was a cut-scene, and he torched me into ash.  I could only think of my brother wandering into the third dungeon.  And like Zelda, the game punished my character with shame for dying, returning me to humanless form.  I'm half-way through (I think), and find myself completely absorbed.  Like Zelda, victory will be sweet and replay will be wonderful.  I hear some people can beat it in a couple of hours. I can't wait to try.

content:
Posted: January 19
 DARK SOULS: Prepare To Die Edition  More like "Prepare to Cry". But Seriously this is a great production with an amazing atmosphere and history. The game is set in different locations after which you can move around freely, because the game does not hold us by the hand. Locations that we will explore is large and visit such places as the catacombs, dungeons, castles, dark forests without any loading but also painted world or sent back to a past of world of Lordran. The currency is the souls of fallen enemies. Thanks to them, we can improve our character and weapons and buy armor from merchants, however, with every death we lose souls but still you can retrieve it if you get back there and notif you won't die a second time. The game also has a great sound design. Optimization instead is broken so much that in some locations the game is just not playable and the finish it was torture for me. This game has a great climate but it also offer a very high level of difficulty. The fight is an arcade, we have light and strong attacks, blocks and dodges and magic items. Each location has a boss that you will be forced to continuous attempts to change tactics. With this production I had a lot of fun, the game has its flaws but it have something in itself that attracts us.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												If you're looking for Skyrim move on. This game doesn't let you easily go through it. There is no restarting, you leave off where you exit and death restarts at your last checkpoint. The game saves everything you do and every action you take so you can't cheat around it. When you defeat a boss, you will have a great feel of accomplishment.Your playstyle is very customizable. You can be all sorts of things such as an archer, warrior, mage, or even a jack of all trades all based on how you wish to level up your skill.There is also a multiplayer aspect of it. You can help others by leaving a summon sign and wait for them to summon you to help their world and vice versa. You can also enter their world with a purpose of killing them and taking their souls (currency). The multiplayer is a great addition. If you successfully help someone, you will get Humanity, which increases your item drops, allows you to make stronger flasks(hp pots), etc.Dark Souls isn't an easy game, but if you want one that will reward you for goals that you accomplish, with epic bosses and a emphasis on gameplay (not story), then this will be for you.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Качественный и интересный проект, который не боится идти в разрез с трендами.Враги бескомпромиссны, дизайн локаций великолепен и даже затмевает средненькую по современным меркам графику. В кои то веки сюжет не разжевывается и засовывается игроку в рот. Сюжет рассказывают сами локации, боссы и вещи.Мультиплеер так же уникален и что саме главное - тонко вплетен в сюжет. Пока второсортные разработчики просто пихают несколько сетевых режимов, оторванных от одиночной кампании from software разработали систему где кооперативный и соревновательный мультиплеер органично вливаются друг в друга и создают ощущение монолитного и продуманного геймплея.Конечно игра немного потеряла актуальность на фоне выхода второй части, но все равно обязательна для прохождения, ведь сиквелам никогда не удается затмить оригинал.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Dark Souls is an 'open-world' game in the vein of 'Metroidvania' titles, which is to say it's open ended but not as open ended as Western titles tend to be. The map design is such that areas are generally linear, but paths branch out at points into other linear areas, which either lead to dead ends  or to connections to previously explored areas, or a new area altogether. This design in linearity with branching paths and backtracking is synonymous with 'Metroidvania' titles. Ultimately all linear areas connect and its your duty to explore them thoroughly and keep a mental note of places you've yet to visit due to a present task, since its completion will then lead to yourself asking, ''where to next''.''Oh right, there were those two areas that I didn't explore, time to get to it''The old school comparison goes further, as the game also has a ton of secrets. This game's secrets can be divided into three categories: alternative paths in levels (self-explanatory); illusory walls (walls that, when struck, disappear thereby revealing a path); and item-environmental interactions. alternative paths and illusory walls typically contain items behind them, sometimes unique items and weaponry not attainable otherwise. ''item-environmental interactions'' are best described as items that are used/equipped in conjunction with being in a particular area. These are fewer in number, but lead to optional boss fights and optional areas to explore. There's a lot to love in a game that has a lot to uncover in addition to just straight up exploration.Dark Souls is also an infamously difficult game, a reputation that isn't entirely merited. If you die you keep everything in your inventory minus Souls and Humanity; Souls being currency for weapon upgrades and levelling up whilst having more Humanity means better resistances and more item drops from enemies. Dying even once sounds bad, but the bonfires (which work as respawn locations and checkpoints) are always spaced apart evenly and you never lose much progress when you die since, in general, you can always get to where you previously were after death in as little as 1 minute or less. As for Souls, in general losing them doesn't matter since enemies respawn everytime you rest at a bonfire, and you can easily grind them back again. Typically if you're in an area that gives you more than a third of the souls required for a level-up with each death then its beneficial to grind the area for levels rather than constantly dying and losing all those souls. With all the deaths you could've stopped dying and levelled up a bit more rather than wasting time. The idea is to not carry around a ton of souls because you will often die, but you will also often have a checkpoint just a few seconds away from your place of death anyway.It's the type of challenge that is fair and welcolmed, but also highly overrated. There were a few spots that were difficult to get past due to enemy placement and level design, but typically if the area is hard to the point of causing rage inducing deaths, then either you shouldn't be there yet or you should but are slightly underlevelled and therefore can easily grind a few levels and upgrade weaponry and armor. Don't let talk of this being THE HARDEST GAME EVER dissuade you from trying it, because it's challenging but also fair and has levelling, which can, if EVERYTHING ELSE fails, just lead to you theoretically being level 100 with perpetual grinding and beating whatever area you're presently in. Not that grinding matters anyway, you get the majority of your damage and defense from upgrading weapons and armor. Unlike most RPG's, your stats don't matter as much as you'd like them to. Weapons generally have stat requirements to wield them (typically in dexterity or strength), so your initial points will be to meet these requirements. But weapons also scale off those stats, so that mid to late game when you have a significant number of points into whichever stat said weapon scales off of, it does a lot more damage than before. So you have a dual system whereby weapon damage is dictated by its upgrades, but also by your stats. Different weapons scale differently as well; there's a rating system from S to E, where the higher the rating a weapon has on the spectrum for a particular stat the more damage it gets off said stat. This system dictates which weapons you wish to keep and wish you'd do away with (along with their attack animations), so the RPG elements and item management make this a sort of action-RPG/Metroidvania hybrid.Speaking of 'Metroidvania', I'll harken back to the point and say that just like the first few Metroid titles Dark Souls also starts with as minimal a narrative as possible, and it's to its detriment. One of the hardest things in starting the game was giving a damn about it. You get a 4 minute cutscene in the beginning vaguely talking about Gods, and are then thrust into the gameworld with a very vague, ''go ring bells plz'' objective. It's very difficult for me to really get into something when there's no plot to it. I understand that no one wants an experience that sacrifices atmosphere for 100 NPC's and 500 cutscenes with PC's strung about the land detailing 10 pages of the game's plot in each. But it's not a scenario whereby you have to sacrifice one to get the other. Dark Souls supposedly has a considerable amount of lore but good fuc*ing luck getting it all in-game in a comprehensive fashion. It's the type of lore that was pieced together by the fanbase after multiple playthroughs and really analyzing item descriptions. I assume the rest was either in developer interviews and artbooks or stuff that came in the later titles. Some is fan conjecture. It's such a shame because you can weave a narrative that takes advantage of the groundwork laid but if, for the majority that played the game, it dwindles down to, ''I gotta google it'' then you've failed to convey a story. The game's narrative is akin to walking into a room mid-conversation with three people talking, or watching the last 20 minutes of a movie; you can understand it by the end of it if you piece it together, and if you were to view it again you could understand it all moreso but it's a REALLY bad way of relaying a story. It's one of those games that starts with the assumption that you already know what's going on, and talks about what's going on here and there. In other words, something that would require multiple playthroughs and rewatching and re-reading cutscenes/dialogue scenes to understand what the creators made. Like I said, it's a failure in story-telling and what prevents something from being damn close to perfect.Plot aside everything else in the game is awesome, and if you're into the exploratory nature of Metriod titles (old and the Prime series) and are looking for an action RPG then you can't go wrong with this game. Very few games merit the praise they typically get, but Dark Souls lives up to expectations. You'll need to google the upgrade system as it pertains to weaponry, but otherwise the barrier to entry isn't as steep as you might imagine.

												Totalling more than 1200 coupled hours between PC and PS3, this definitely is my favourite game.While, in my opinion, the settings and the athmosphere are slightly inferior to its predecessor Demon's Souls, Dark Souls fills the gap with efficient mechanics, deep lore and a feeling of loneliness and despair that accompanies you throughout the entire story. As for the PVP aspect of the game, the community is still very alive and populated by skilled players roaming Oolacile Township. GFWL is a big detriment, but with the Steam patch coming soon all will be forgotten.Remember kids: if you're getting front-stabbed it's only your fault for not anticipating your opponent's network latency. Stop complaining and come get #rekt with us.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Things I had to learn from this game without being explicity told aka artifical difficulty padding to prolong it. 1) Fight bosses in the nude to dodge all their attacks OR in the bulkiest max poise armor to be slow, get hit, but not be stunned and interrupted from your attacking and healing animations. 2) A small group or even just two of any generic enemy can be stronger than any boss when their hitstuns combo you from full hp to zero. High poise heavy armor shrugs off this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.3) Since bosses will kill you frequently, you'll spend much time going from bonfires to boss fights. 4) There's a hidden bonfire at the top of seth's funhouse and somewhat close to the boss bed of chaos (hidden behind an illusory wall) 5) IMPORTANT: If you input a jumping slash attack (right bumper plus up) but can't start the animation immediately (you're blocking an attack) the game will eat your input and use the thrust attack (right bumper) with horrendous cooldown and start up. The game dropping that input killed and frustrated me more than anything by far. 6) You will get one or a couple black knight weapons. Upgrade it with twinkling titanite and it will carry you to the end of the game.You will be lost, you will learn how to die, and eventually you will learn how to NOT die.

There is yet another mod for connectivity, but I'm personally sick of jumping through hoops to play this game the way it was meant to be played. Its been years now since this version dropped and From Software isn't doing anything fix it. They dont intend to. They're just content with their most popular game being broken on pc. I do recommend it, because it is Dark Souls 1 and we dont have a choice for playing on pc, but I'm giving it a thumbs down because this is unacceptable.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												It baffles me that people find this game difficult.Anyways, as someone who's neither into RPGs, the medieval setting, or even difficult games, I was pleasantly surprised by how amazing this game is. The lore based story is amazing (at least if you have the observational skills to discover it.) The combat is simple yet deep with intuitive controls, timing, and telegraphs. Additionally, this is possibly the only game I've ever played where the PvP can live up to the expectations set up by the PvE (but wow do I wish there was less lag.)There are a few common complaints I hear about this game, and here are my opinions on them."The game is too hard." : No, the game is not too hard, it is in fact rather easy. If you find the game difficult, then it is possible that you haven't figured out what the game expects of you yet. More likely though, you need to drop the keyboard and mouse controls and get a controller."The game is all trial and error." : It is entirely possible to beat this game exclusively through trial and error, but wow you'd have to be pretty dull to play through this game like that. The game gives plenty of hints to warn you about what's coming up, you just need to be observant enough to notice them."The game is clunky." : Well, that one's just an outright lie. Unless you don't understand the concept of management (i.e. stamina management is one of the most common things players seem to struggle with even though it's one of the most important skills for this game) or are playing with a keyboard and mouse, you'll find that this game plays beautifully.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Genre: RPG/Open World If you're the person who loves challenge, and who don't mind dying a lot and also want to try new things, then you're gonna love this game. Otherwise if you're the person who plays games at easy/normal just so you can experience the game and move on avoid this. This game takes time, and to get better you need to die a lot.Gameplay(+)Gameplay is different than in other games and it doesn't feel that smooth in the beginning. Some people find it slow at first, but that's cause Dark Souls is one of the games that tries to be more realistic as far as the gameplay is concerned. Weapons/Armors: You have two slots in each hand, for weapons or shields(you can put weapon or shield in whatever hand you want). You also have armor. You can combine parts of armor sets however you want. Game offers a big variety of weapons, armors, shields etc. There are many classes of weapons: Straight swords, Greatswords, Ultra Greatswords, Axes, Katanas, Hammers, Whips, Bows and many others. When choosing armors and weapons you need to worry about their weight and your equip load. Other than weight weapons and shields also have stats requirements. Usually you need certain amount of points invested into Strength or Dexterity, or both, and sometimes you need to invest into magic, miracles etc. Some weapons scale of strength, some of dexterity, and some of both, which means that increasing those stats increases weapons damage, and also weapons have different types of scaling. You can also upgrade weapons, shields and armors with some materials and souls(souls=Dark Souls money and exp points). Magic/Miracles: Game also offers a big variety of magic spells and miracles. They have their stats requirements too. You need to invest points into intelligence/faith to increase magic/miracles attack and defense, and to be able to use those spells/miracles. There are  additional items that improve magic or miracles attack or defense. Enemies: Enemies are very creative, there are many type of enemies and a lot of them are hard to kill at first. Boss fights are absolutely amazing, and killing a boss in Dark Souls feels like great accomplishment. Game has plenty of bosses, and many of them are optional. After killing the boss you'll get souls. Some bosses also drop boss souls which you can either eat to accuire more souls or save them for later, so you can craft boss weapons at blacksmiths. Every time you die enemies will respawn at same places, but bosses won't. Once you kill them, they're dead till the next new game + cycle.New Game +: After you finish the game, you'll automatically progress into new game +, with everything that you've collected in ng. You can play ng+ endlessly, and the game's difficulty increases every time untill you reach ng+7, where it stops increasing.Some other things about gameplay: Bonfires are checkpoints in this game. Every time you rest at bonfire, all enemies will go back to their place, and all enemies will respawn, except from killed bosses. Every time you die you lose all souls you have and you need to find that same location to pick them up before you die again, unless you want to lose them forever. After dying you'll respawn at last checkpoint you had been rested. Multiplayer(+)This is one of the things that makes Dark Souls games pretty unique. You can invade worlds of other players with special items and fight them there, or get invaded in your own world. You can also call other players from their worlds by activating signs on the floor with purpose to either fight them or play co-op with them, and you can post your own signs too. This game would be a perfect game for me(10/10) if not for instant backstab. This technique ruined pvp of this game, and it's very broken, since people are constantly fishing for backstabs. Also backstab escape bug.Atmosphere(+) One of the things that makes Dark Souls so great is dark and gloomy atmosphere, that makes you feel lonely in that cruel world. Not knowing what's behind the next corner, it forces you to have your eyes wide open all the time.Story/Lore(+) Story in Dark Souls is not told in the classical way. To find explanation of the story you must listen to what NPCs have to say, and read descriptions of items, and still after that you're not gonna be able to understand a lot of things, so you must create your own theories about what happened. There are good theories on internet from youtubers like VaatiVydia, Silver Mont, Dave Control Live, TerraMantis,etc. Bad port(+-)This is really a bad port, and it's almost unplayable without DSfix which can be found here: http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?p=684 .You can't get banned for using this, and almost every Dark Souls player uses this. Port by default is locked at 30 fps, but DSfix lets you unlock fps, and it also makes game pretty stable with improved graphic. Still some people complain that they have dips with unlocked fps and set on 60, but I really can't help you with that since I am playing on 30 fps since beginning without any problems.Note: Controller is not necessary, use what you want. Never used it in DkS series and I am pretty good in both pvp and pve.Verdict: This is an an amazing, very challenging game, and that combined with an amazing gameplay, atmosphere and lore makes it a masterpiece. Sadly it is an awful port, but there is a mod that fixes most of the issues.Personal rating: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												--DISCLAIMER--first of all, in my review the thumb doesn't matter. I could also pick a thumbs down rating, Only the text review represents my oppinion about this game, nothing else.The other thing is: I'm not someone who purely says that the game isn't possible. I'm just pointing out, what was enjoyable for me in an objective way. If you don't agree with my critics to this game, then it's fine by me. I'm not telling you what to enjoy and what not and if you actualy enjoy the things I don't enjoy, then have it your way. But then I ask you to respect my oppinion aswell as I respect yours.--DISCLAIMER END--Dark Souls is an interesting experience indeed. It always keeps you on your toes but it also gives you a break if needed.It is a challenging game without being unfair to the player, at least overall to a certain point. It is an action RPG game to my liking but, unfortunatly, it has also alot of downsides.First of all, and I'm sure everyone agrees with me is, that this is a very poor port of a game. It is a shame that there was no effort put into porting this game or even optimizing it in general, since a constant and high framerate in this kind of game is the most important aspect (timing in general). Now luckily, I have an Xbox controller for my PC and I highly recommend a controller in general for this game, since the controls on the keyboard are messed up. Now there are mods out there which help making this game playable, but I am talking about a product the developers delivered to us, not the fix that the community came up with without the developers giving a crap about there game and doing it themselves.Now the most thing I enjoyed in this game was the first playthrough. I created 2 characters and managed to play through the game with both of them with 2 different playstyles. The first character was a more tanky character with a greatsword. My 2nd character was a high lightweigth build for pure dodge and counter with a katana. The game provided me with a decent challange and, although the game has it's frustrating moments, it never made me quit the playthrough.NG+ (New Game +) on the otherhand is something I don't recommend to anyone searching for an enjoyable playthrough, simply because the difficulty scaling is to dull. Giving them more Healh and higher damageoutput doesn't mean difficulty, it just tests your patience with the game. I'd rather have smarter enemies with different attackpatterns instead of just heavylie based "trial and error" enemies. This counts especialy for dodge builds. In most cases, if you happen to stagger from an attack, you will die because you'll get stunlocked untill you die. While this alone is not a problem, some enemies will be more of an annoyence because of their high hitbox detection (4 Kings for example) where it doesn't matter if you dodge their swing or not you'll get hit anyway.Another positive thing about this game is that it doesn't hold you on your hand, like most games do nowadays. The game doesn't point out, where you should go now or what you should do. You have to figure that out yourself. Now the game does have a somewhat linear pattern you have to follow, but that's only at the beginning of the game and to a certain point. If you are 1/3 through the game, the whole game is open for you to explore. You can get the idea of what to do in order to progress by talking to certain NPCs, but you have to actually listen to what they say and you still have to think for yourself where you should go to do your task. The game my have cutscenes, but all of them are skipable and are not regular at all (mostly an introduction to a certain boss or if you did something significant for the story).The combat system is great overall. It is easy to learn, but hard to master. Dark Souls doesn't make you rely on the abilities of the characters (like certain MMO's or even RPGs where you just have to spam their individuel abilities and wait for their cooldown) all actions depend on the player himself and you'll get more then enough variety to that. You can for instance do a light attack, a heavy attack, a guard break kick, a jumping heavy attack, parry, block, backstab, dive attack. Most weapons also have their own move sets, giving you a large variety to pick from for you to use to your liking.But the obvious thing is that the combat system is almost purely made for 1v1 encounters. That means, if you have to deal with alot of enemies at once without having a weapon which can hit multiple targets, then you'll notice the downsides of the combat system or rather to certain enemy/ boss encounters (Ornstein and Smough are only considered to be one of the hardest bosses purely because, if you don't have any help, then you'll have to deal with 2 heavy hitting bosses at once. if you atleast get help from Solair, an NPC character, then the boss is manageable without big problems)The good thing is, that these kind of encounters are not that often and you are most likely able to lure them out 1 by 1.But areas like New Londo with ghosts, atleast on new game+, they will be a hard time if you are not able to 1hit them because they will swarm you and they have a decent range with their attack and the fact, that they can attack you through the wall makes it unnececary hard and you'll most likely be forced just to sprint your way through this area.The bosses are both the things you will enjoy the most but they will also be the most frustrating thing in the game. The statisfaction after killing a boss is very pleasing and you will feel rewarded for that aswell combined with the combat system. Most bosses are also unique in their own way, although that doesn't always mean that it's something positive. Some bosses are very easy and don't provide a challenge at all while other bosses have a huge difficulty spike and require certain strategies to work with. And some bosses are just downright tedious. The best example for that is Gwindolin. It may be an optional boss, but if you seek to play all of the game's content, then you'll be forced to one of the most tedious bosses of the game. I'm not saying that the boss is hard the boss is in fact one of the easiest bosses the game has to offer. This boss fight in particular just stretches in it's lenght in a very artificial way (you will always have to run up to the boss while avoiding it's projectile attacks and if you are in close range, you'll be able to land 1-3 strikes before the boss teleports away where you just repeat the process). I think the most enjoyable boss fight for me was Sif, the Wolf. It wasn't to difficult for me even on NG+ and it wasn't to hard either. Overall, I say that bosses are one of the best things the game can possibly offer. It is in fact one of the only reasons to why you should play the game, atleast when you are not into pvp, that's a different story.While I like the idea of being connected to different "nodes" and being able to see different phantoms of players who play the game aswell, this system stands in it's own way if you consider to play this game in coop. The problem is just that if you try to play with a friend, you have to hope for you and your friend being connected to the same node. If you are not, you cannot play together. Now for that there also exists a mod to help you out with and certain configurations but, that's not an excuse for such a design for online playing. I'd rather have a traditional, more working way to play the game online rather then what it has to offer now. For me, it's not a big downside for the game but for those considering buying this game to play coop, be prepared to either do alot of things to be able to play effectivly or be prepared to be patient.OVERALL: I recommend this game to those who want an action RPG with a decent and overall enjoyable experience and for those, who dare to play the game's NG+ mode for extra frustration.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Praise the Sun!Fantastically hard experience that offers little to no hand-holding both in and out of game.  The PC port is full of issues resolved in round-about ways by community mods.  If you don't go mad trying to get a resolution above 1024x720 (Tip: google DSFix), you'll wish you would have just bought a console instead when you try to get your mouse and keyboard to work (Tip: google DSMFix).  After you wade through a SEA of options hidden away in .txt files, and troubleshoot a dozen additional problems you may encounter, you're finally off to the races!Of course, the races are probably going to punch you right in the mouth because this game can be so hard the metaphors don't even make sense.  The game doesn't tell you much, other players tell you even less, and you can throw yourself at an impossible cemetary of skeletons for hours without the game even suggesting there's an easier path.  You need to learn from your deaths quickly.  If you don't seem to be doing much damage, you're NOT going to survive so turn back and try another path!  Once you finally get on the slow, purposeful drudge to success, you'll meet all sorts of FANTASTICALLY designed monsters, see AMAZING set peices, and discover a deeply burried treasure-trove of lore.  Just keep in mind that if you want to experience the full effect of multiplayer, you have to stay human.  You can always see the fleeting ghosts of other players, and you'll find their cryptic orange messages scrawled all over the world, but if you want to meet them in the flesh you have to be living yourself.  Summon your white and golden allies whenever they offer to help.  Be wary though, others may come as an agent of chaos, as your righteous executioner, a collector of souls, or even as a guardian of nature.At least it's not using Games for Windows Live anymore!Above all, PRAISE THE SUN.

												This is one of the best games I played so far. It's not easy, actually it is one of the (if not THE) most difficult games I played. Every step of your path must be chosen wisely, you can't undo a mistake in most situations, so beware of your decisions. Every single battle is a challange and will put your patience, skill and timing to the test. Even situations in which you already excel normally might be the end of you if you're not carefull or rush too much. There are some minor setbacks, like the fact that the controls' explanations are not adapted to the computer version. Nevertheless, the game is awesome. Unlike other games, the storyline won't be given to you, except for the introduction, so be ready to find out what's happening on your own. Time to grab a sword and face the journey that will change Lordran as you know it... that is... if you're ready to die.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Atrocious port, one of the best games ever made. 'Prepare to Die' is pretty accurate: the first half of the game is brutal.GameplayPretty much requires an Xbox360 controller. Mouse & keyboard controls are incredibly bad, and feel terrible even with a mouse fix mod.DkS has the best melee combat outside Mount&Blade. Every swing has weight, every hit counts. Attacks are always telegraphed well in advance: everything can be dodged with proper timing. This works both ways, and it might take some time to get used to the player's attacks not being instant, but requiring a similar wind-up that the AI has. Excellent weapon variety, with nearly every weapon having at the very least some minor unique quirk, and most weapons having full, unique movesets. The player's equipment choices are mostly personal preference: the weapons feel different and they're all perfectly viable when upgraded. Armour variety is also great, but what you wear doesn't make a huge difference. Resistances from armour are good, but dodging and blocking are far better tactics than eating hits.The magic system is a bit intimidating at first. Highly limited amount of casts, and very long casting times. Three different schools of "magic", all of which feel powerful and interesting. Playing a sorcerer does make the game significantly easier, especially later on when items that increase magic damage are easily available.The player character levels up by spending souls ( currency, essentially ) to level up individual stats ( strength, dexterity, etc. ). A single character can, in theory, be a master of everything. Leveling up gets more expensive every time, so most of the time it's more advantageous to plan a build in advance and stick to it. At character creation, the classes only really determine the starting equipment: the classes don't lock a character into a single path. Incredible freedom in the character development system; encourages replayability by having a massive amount of perfectly viable builds to come up with. Enemy design is, overall, excellent. They range from undead knights to giant mushrooms and clams. They all have unique movesets, and despite the AI being very basic (run at player, try to kill), the combat feels fresh when you move through the levels and encounter new enemies.The levels are (for the most part) designed masterfully. A maze, with shortcuts available everywhere. The world feels real: all the areas are connected perfectly, and highly encourage exploration. Huge variety in the design of the levels: Duke's Archive is a huge library, Tomb of the Giants, a pitch black cave full of skeletons. Some areas, like Lost Izalith, were clearly rushed and lack the complex geometry and intelligent enemy placement of levels such as Undead Burg.StoryHighly unconventional storytelling in this one. Most of it is delivered through item descriptions accessed in the inventory. If you never read them, all you'll really know is that there's a prophecy, and you killed a bunch of dudes. The story hidden in the descriptions, environment and NPC "quests" is absolutely brilliant, however. Having to dig for it makes figuring things out so much more rewarding than being told everything in cutscenes. There are 'holes' in the story, and those are filled by the player, and his actions. Everything in the game exists for a reason:  nothing is randomly just 'there'. I found the main storyline and the NPC stories extremely interesting, but it definitely takes some effort to be able to really enjoy.Graphics & AudioThe graphics are terrible. Looks like a console game, because this is literally a 1:1 port from the xbox360. Locked to 30fps, 720p, relatively with low res textures. All of these can be fixed on PC, though: I run the game at a 4k resolution, 60fps and with fan-made HD textures. DSFix by Durante has a bunch of variables that vastly improve the way the game looks. Well worth installing. Weapons and armour  look pretty good, but that's mostly due to their brilliant design, not graphical fidelity. The environments range from beautiful (Painted World, Ash Lake) to hideous (Lost Izalith).Sound design is ♥♥♥♥ing incredible. Very little music: only plays at a central hub area and boss fights. The rest of the time, all you'll hear is footsteps, monsters and other environmental sounds. The lack of music gives the rare times it does play so much more impact. Hearing the Firelink music after a raid on the Catacombs is very comforting, and hearing boss music gets the adrenaline pumping as you face Smough & Ornstein.In conclusion,  Dark Souls is one of the greatest games ever made. It is a terrible PC version, but most of the issues can be fixed, and the result is an experience no gamer should miss.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												PC port quality aside, this is a VERY well made game no matter which platform you play it on.  With that in mind, let's get down to the dirty details :)For starters, one thing I love about this game is that it is relatively noob-friendly (at least it was for me having never played Demon's Souls).  Its initial linearity helps new players learn the mechanics against increasingly difficult obstacles without necessarily having to worry about navigation *most* of the time.  While the enemies are by no means easy, for Dark Souls they are very primitive and therefore, make a good introduction for the kinds of attacks you will face throughout the game.  Enemies that are initially big bosses become plentiful regular enemies later on in the game, giving a massive feeling of personal growth and achievement to the player when the enemies that used to kick♥♥♥♥♥are getting cut down one by one.The art direction in this game is extraordinarily well done.  By this, I mean how its sound design, visual style, and character design work with the underlying themes of the game to completely immerse the player.  Much of the world is filled with hulking structures worn down or destroyed, giving the player the sense that they are scavenging a once great civilization come to ruin.  There is almost never any music in the game, save for the boss fights and one area that is so awe-inspiring that it requires fitting music.  In many of the boss fights, the music is hectic and rushed, simulating the players' emotions when they just walked into a room with a giant behemoth eyeing your supple body for tenderizing.  Everything in this game looks and sounds like it wants to tear out your intestines with all manner of sharp or blunt object and wear them as various pieces of clothing.  Many of the NPCs in the game have very subdued voices and seem to be only sometimes be aware of your presence.  As the game title states, you will die and you will die a lot.  Caution is the word of the day and not paying to the environment later on in the game will prove very deadly indeed when many of the game's traps are introduced.  The story is told almost entirely through the environment, with some details being vaguely provided by NPCs.  As the story picks up with the player's journey beginning, the world has already fallen to ruin, with many of the once great heroes and gods of the time either dead or driven insane by the coming darkness.  Many (ignorant) people claim the game has no story whatsoever but paying attention to the environment is key to discovering the backstory and motives for many of the other characters ever coming to Lordan.  Some youtubers like VaatiVidya have very strong explanations for many of the characters in the game and they are incredible.The combat in the game has a very weighted feel to it.  This game doesn't have a combat system like Call of Duty where everything happens at breakneck speed.  When the player swings their sword, the character has to quickly wind up for the swing.  It isn't slow by any means depending on your weapon of choice but it definitely requires deliberate action.  The combat is very much about decision making: when to block, when to counterattack, when to dodge, even when to run away to regroup.  Don't run into the game flailing around expecting to fight like Bruce Lee, it's just going to end with your death.A topic on everyone's mind when talking about this game is obviously the difficulty.  While the game is very hard, it isn't for the reasons many people state.  As hard as it may be to understand at first, YOU are what makes dark souls as hard or as easy as it is.  Your ability to observe your environments and predict the actions of your enemies will determine how successful you are in Lordran.  Overcoming difficult boss fights is a result of your very own hard work and determination to succeed.  The game never hands you a victory, it puts your prize on the opposite end of a room filled with traps and deadly foes and tells you to take what is rightfully yours.Don't go into Dark Souls thinking you will know how everything in the game works, even after playing for a while, without consulting online information.  While the game takes a hands off approach to educating the player about the mechanics of the game and how everything works, it isn't equipped to give *any* information on some things like how invasions and coop works, as well as some stats like poise.  This is my biggest problem with the game especially when it comes to new players.  There isn't any explanation for what being human does or what benefits you gain from consuming humanity without spending it.  Without consulting online information, your experience will be much more difficult especially later on when the level design becomes less intuitive.This review is written while Games For Windows Live is still functioning and as such, I have no idea if the online will still work after the shutdown (probably not).  The game's online component is a mess, barely functioning for PvP and almost nonexistent for Cooperative play.  Thankfully, there is a brilliant mod that branches off the DSFix mod that makes coop way better than originally and that is very much appreciated especially if playing with friends.  PvP works but the amount of lag is unforgiveable in a game where losing to an invader can mean losing all your souls (currency) and a lot of progress.  98% of the time, I don't feel like anyone bested me in combat out of sheer skill, but because the latency with the servers condemned me from the start.In short, the game is incredibly well put together and while a few things need improvement and the PC port DEFINITELY could have been made better, that doesn't make the game itself bad.  Especially with the community fixes for resolution, framerate, coop, mouse and keyboard, etc. the game is downright beautiful to play.  For sure, the game is VERY difficult, but it is by no means as hard as people make it out to be.  If you want a game that can bring you immense satisfaction as a player, you absolutely must buy this game.  One of my favorite game series of all time and I would recommend it to anyone who has the balls to overcome real challenge.  Incredibly deep and immersive, this game is a MUST BUY

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Great game, buy it and give it a try.There are so many things to love here. Let's get into it.The Story/Lore:Very open-ended, you have to piece it together bit by bit from item descriptions and bits of dialogue from NPCs. But the world that Miyazaki created is really cool. Each area in the world has its own story and every character has his/her own adventures. It is quite beautiful.The Looks:Each seperate area in the game has its own unique feel. Different areas are populated with different enemies and scenery, and every area does feel quite unique. The graphics are quite good, nothing groundbreaking, but will make you stop and stare sometimes. The character models and enemy design are fantastic and really help you immerse yourself in the world.The Sound:The music is very fitting and certain tracks really do stand out. But for the most part I find myself more or less ignoring the music in the game. The sound effects are fitting and immersive, and are really useful for being aware of your surroundings. Nothing really to rant or rave about here. The Gameplay:This is where this game really shines. The gameplay is very polished. The combat feels very plausible. There is a give and take, a flow to the combat. For the most part, you can't just go in flailing your sword around or spamming spells out the wazoo. You have to be careful, take calculated risks, and know when to fall back. The leveling system is fantastic. 1 or 2 levels won't really make a difference, so grinding is unnecessary. Besides hitting weapon or spell requirements, level is not a huge indicator of power. This makes pvp interesting and low-level runs possible. The wide variety of different character builds has kept me playing this game for so long. From a pure caster to a tankish wall to a dexterous fighter with the support of miracles, you can have fun with a wide variety of playstyles.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												The famously difficult Dark Souls has the ability to burn images into my head and conjure up powerful emotions with its carefully-presented story. It is both bleak and beautiful, and is one of the most impressive games made in recent years. Thematically, Dark Souls is about death and perseverance in an unforgiving world. This is echoed in the gameplay by a near-complete lack of guidance; for example, techniques critical for success go completely unexplained, like how to kindle bonfires (and what that even means). Thus, community involvement such as reading guides or walkthroughs is a must. The online elements within the game are also helpful, but the game is just as much fun to play offline.If the inaccessibile presentation wasn't bad enough, it turns out that Dark Souls really is too hard. I'd probably enjoy playing it more often if it weren't so repetitive (dying and repeating the same segment over and over again). Frankly, I have the most fun late in the game, when I've powered up enough to explore new territory and take on bosses with relatively few deaths – you know, like a normal game. On the whole, I still can't deny how absorbing and satisfying the whole experience is. There are so many fascinating details hidden away that are exciting to uncover. I love the powerful images, tense moments, and sense of accomplishment that comes when my perseverance pays off. Dark Souls is not for everyone – not by a long shot – but for those who can get past its steep learning curve and cruel difficulty, it can be a wholly unique and inspiring experience. (Rating: 9/10 “Great”)Notes: I played this PC version with an Xbox 360 Controller for Windows. It is nearly identical to the PS3 version of the game I played before, and comes packaged with the Artorias of the Abyss DLC.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I bought this game out of curiosity during the last Steam Winter sales for less than 6€, after having read many reviews over the years, and I must say that it is well worth the money. Let’s get straight to business: DS – PTDE is a 3rd Person Fantasy Action-RPG, directly ported from the Xbox360 and PS3 version. The setting is a standard high-fantasy medieval world with lots of undeads, demons, lizardmen, dragons, knights in black or shiny armors of all sorts, but the lore and plot is rarely mentioned at all throughout the playthrough, as you mostly play alone (or with friends/other players in online co-op) with very rare encounters with sentient NPCs which can offer a little bit of insight on your mission and objectives. Game progression is almost non-linear: after having beaten the first obligatory “tutorial dungeon” you character reaches the first (and only) main quest hub and is given the generic mission to “fulfil the prophecy and ring the two Bells of Awakening”, with absolutely no clue on how to proceed: it is the player’s duty to start exploring the world and find a way to progress and clear a path, and this is where the real fun begins. Even if you have been living under a rock for the past 2 years and have read no other review of DS – PTDE, you will understand one basic concept during the first 10 minutes of gameplay: as the name itself implies this game is INSANELY HARD. The developers have intentionally designed it to challenge the player at every turn, with absolutely no mercy even for beginner’s mistakes (even in the tutorial dungeon you will die A LOT during your first playthrough). Some examples, just to give an idea:-          No save-load mechanic is implemented: the game autosaves your position and progress basically after every action you perform, causing every gameplay choice to become instantly PERMANENT. Did you just killed a NPC with a fireball by accident due to him being too close to a menacing skeleton? That NPC will be permanently DEAD, even if this means losing access to his wares (in case he was a merchant) or to a side quest. You will have to find another way around the locked door or find someone else to sell you those precious arrows you were looking for… The good news is that the developers have literally thought of everything, so an “unwinnable” scenario is virtually impossible to achieve (without cheats), even if you mindlessly slaughter every living and undead being in sight (including merchants and questgivers)-          Even if your character is cursed with the undeath and technically cannot die, every single hostile monster or NPC can single handedly♥♥♥♥♥♥you and send you back to the spawn point with little effort. Even the least menacing zombie, armed only with a broken sword, can AND WILL kill you a dozen time if you do not remember to dodge his attacks or keep your shield up the whole time. Underestimating any encounter, even when overgeared, will lead to the usual YOU DIED screen in few seconds-          If you are so lucky and brave to reach one of the various checkpoints placed at various strategic locations, and use it to rest and replenish your forces before proceeding EVERY SINGLE MONSTER YOU HAVE KILLED UP TO THAT MOMENT WILL RESPAWN (with the exception of bosses and minibosses), leaving you stranded in the middle of a dungeon with no way to get out without fighting your way back to the beginning. There is no turning back in DS – PTDE, sorry-          Is it also worth mentioning that being killed will result in the same effect: respawn at the checkpoint and a horde of fresh monsters to fight all around you. Oh, did I mention that spawn points are usually very far from bosses, punishing the player even more for deaths during boss fights?Although the above points could be interpreted as lazy or poor design, the reality is that DS – PTDE is one of the best balanced games I’ve played in many years of PC gaming: every encounter and situation can be easily won by using the correct strategy and taking advantage of the weakness of the enemy; if you are rushing through an area while swinging your sword or throwing fireballs without any care for the surrounding environment you will soon be overwhelmed and the familiar YOU DIED screen will be shown. A tactical approach, with perfect knowledge of the surroundings (to avoid the frequent ambushes) and the correct gear combination will increase your survival chances immensely, and some boss fights will even become trivial with the correct strategy.Of course this implies a trial-and-error process, but there is a reason why this game is called “Prepare to Die Edition”.Unfortunately this game has also blatant flaws, and the most important lies in the graphic engine: being a direct console port (made by a SW house which was specialized only in console titles with no PC experience) you can forget about HD resolution, smooth framerates and all the eye-candies of a typical PC AAA title. But it is even worse: the PC version of DS – PTDE is locked to 720p resolution and 30fps, IN 2014! You know that 3500€ gaming rig that you just bought and that runs BF4 at ultra in Surround on 3 27” monitors? It is completely wasted since you will experience the same resolution and detail of a 2005 console anyway.And what about mouse and keyboard controls? Forget about them, as all the menus and in game text refer to Xbox360 control layout and using a M+K combo will be a frustrating experience (Steam even has a warning on the store page claiming that a 360 controller is strongly recommended for this game).Luckily for you, my friends, the modding community has solved this issue since a long time with two brilliant an small pieces of software: DSFix and DSMfix (http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix and http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/864979455329386779/). After a very simple setup process you will be able to enjoy the game on your PC as it should have been since release, with full HD graphics, 60+ constant fps (with the possibility of downsampling to push the detail even further, if your rig can take it), SSAO, MSAA, FXAA, smooth mouse controls and customizable keybindings. Last but not least, there is also a co-op fix called DSCfix which improves the experience of online co-op play over the standard GFWL junk (http://sdrv.ms/128mNwY).TL;DR version:PROs-          Very challenging gameplay, but never too difficult to become unbeatable. If you die too much, it is generally your fault-          Longevity (50+ hours of gameplay for a single playthrough, with the possibility of New Game+ with increased difficulty!)-          Endless combinations of character growth and gear allows for very different approaches, all equally rewarding, to the game-          A sequel is in the works!CONs-          Direct Xbox360 port: use of unofficial mods is mandatory to make the game playable-          Awkward game controls with M+K (also fixed by a mod)-          Absurdly steep learning curve-          Some gameplay mechanics are obscure unless google is used (e.g. crafting)-          Even with mods the graphic engine does not take advantage of all the possible features of a modern gaming PC

												I like this game. Good lvling system, story is simple but same time epic. Lore is shrouded to mysteries. Many weapons, armors and spells. Also different kind of covenants are fine. Also those player made "dueling rules" are not what this game was supposed to be. This is supposed to be Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition not Gentle Souls: Prepare to Bow edition.I would rate 10/10 but with "shadows" i will give 8/10I recommed this game to those with patience and are really prepared to die.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This is one of the best games I played so far. It's not easy, actually it is one of the (if not THE) most difficult games I played. Every step of your path must be chosen wisely, you can't undo a mistake in most situations, so beware of your decisions. Every single battle is a challange and will put your patience, skill and timing to the test. Even situations in which you already excel normally might be the end of you if you're not carefull or rush too much. There are some minor setbacks, like the fact that the controls' explanations are not adapted to the computer version. Nevertheless, the game is awesome. Unlike other games, the storyline won't be given to you, except for the introduction, so be ready to find out what's happening on your own. Time to grab a sword and face the journey that will change Lordran as you know it... that is... if you're ready to die.
