content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												PC port quality aside, this is a VERY well made game no matter which platform you play it on.  With that in mind, let's get down to the dirty details :)For starters, one thing I love about this game is that it is relatively noob-friendly (at least it was for me having never played Demon's Souls).  Its initial linearity helps new players learn the mechanics against increasingly difficult obstacles without necessarily having to worry about navigation *most* of the time.  While the enemies are by no means easy, for Dark Souls they are very primitive and therefore, make a good introduction for the kinds of attacks you will face throughout the game.  Enemies that are initially big bosses become plentiful regular enemies later on in the game, giving a massive feeling of personal growth and achievement to the player when the enemies that used to kick♥♥♥♥♥are getting cut down one by one.The art direction in this game is extraordinarily well done.  By this, I mean how its sound design, visual style, and character design work with the underlying themes of the game to completely immerse the player.  Much of the world is filled with hulking structures worn down or destroyed, giving the player the sense that they are scavenging a once great civilization come to ruin.  There is almost never any music in the game, save for the boss fights and one area that is so awe-inspiring that it requires fitting music.  In many of the boss fights, the music is hectic and rushed, simulating the players' emotions when they just walked into a room with a giant behemoth eyeing your supple body for tenderizing.  Everything in this game looks and sounds like it wants to tear out your intestines with all manner of sharp or blunt object and wear them as various pieces of clothing.  Many of the NPCs in the game have very subdued voices and seem to be only sometimes be aware of your presence.  As the game title states, you will die and you will die a lot.  Caution is the word of the day and not paying to the environment later on in the game will prove very deadly indeed when many of the game's traps are introduced.  The story is told almost entirely through the environment, with some details being vaguely provided by NPCs.  As the story picks up with the player's journey beginning, the world has already fallen to ruin, with many of the once great heroes and gods of the time either dead or driven insane by the coming darkness.  Many (ignorant) people claim the game has no story whatsoever but paying attention to the environment is key to discovering the backstory and motives for many of the other characters ever coming to Lordan.  Some youtubers like VaatiVidya have very strong explanations for many of the characters in the game and they are incredible.The combat in the game has a very weighted feel to it.  This game doesn't have a combat system like Call of Duty where everything happens at breakneck speed.  When the player swings their sword, the character has to quickly wind up for the swing.  It isn't slow by any means depending on your weapon of choice but it definitely requires deliberate action.  The combat is very much about decision making: when to block, when to counterattack, when to dodge, even when to run away to regroup.  Don't run into the game flailing around expecting to fight like Bruce Lee, it's just going to end with your death.A topic on everyone's mind when talking about this game is obviously the difficulty.  While the game is very hard, it isn't for the reasons many people state.  As hard as it may be to understand at first, YOU are what makes dark souls as hard or as easy as it is.  Your ability to observe your environments and predict the actions of your enemies will determine how successful you are in Lordran.  Overcoming difficult boss fights is a result of your very own hard work and determination to succeed.  The game never hands you a victory, it puts your prize on the opposite end of a room filled with traps and deadly foes and tells you to take what is rightfully yours.Don't go into Dark Souls thinking you will know how everything in the game works, even after playing for a while, without consulting online information.  While the game takes a hands off approach to educating the player about the mechanics of the game and how everything works, it isn't equipped to give *any* information on some things like how invasions and coop works, as well as some stats like poise.  This is my biggest problem with the game especially when it comes to new players.  There isn't any explanation for what being human does or what benefits you gain from consuming humanity without spending it.  Without consulting online information, your experience will be much more difficult especially later on when the level design becomes less intuitive.This review is written while Games For Windows Live is still functioning and as such, I have no idea if the online will still work after the shutdown (probably not).  The game's online component is a mess, barely functioning for PvP and almost nonexistent for Cooperative play.  Thankfully, there is a brilliant mod that branches off the DSFix mod that makes coop way better than originally and that is very much appreciated especially if playing with friends.  PvP works but the amount of lag is unforgiveable in a game where losing to an invader can mean losing all your souls (currency) and a lot of progress.  98% of the time, I don't feel like anyone bested me in combat out of sheer skill, but because the latency with the servers condemned me from the start.In short, the game is incredibly well put together and while a few things need improvement and the PC port DEFINITELY could have been made better, that doesn't make the game itself bad.  Especially with the community fixes for resolution, framerate, coop, mouse and keyboard, etc. the game is downright beautiful to play.  For sure, the game is VERY difficult, but it is by no means as hard as people make it out to be.  If you want a game that can bring you immense satisfaction as a player, you absolutely must buy this game.  One of my favorite game series of all time and I would recommend it to anyone who has the balls to overcome real challenge.  Incredibly deep and immersive, this game is a MUST BUY

												Listen here.. since i have played this game.. i have not put it down in almost a year. EVERY day. I would play. over and over. no game compares. all new games are♥♥♥♥♥♥ ALL. its insane. this is game is very simple in mechanics but it is so intricate also.. Have fun.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The Good: Unique difficulty, unique setting, and unique gameplay.Difficulty relies on skill in combat and evironment awareness, unlike modern games that rely only on damage modifications, and, or enemies with infalable aim. The setting doesn't rely on set pieces or glorified hollywood cutscenes to sell itself. The Bad: Lackluster PC port, and Games For Windows Client requirement.Low resolution textures riddle the game, mouse and keyboard support is nonexistent, or at the very least horrid, resolution render is capped at 720p, and framerate is capped at 30fps. Conclusion: Install DSFix mod, DSCFix mod, and High-res textures from Nexus website, and I'll guarantee you'll have a damn good time with this game!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												The famously difficult Dark Souls has the ability to burn images into my head and conjure up powerful emotions with its carefully-presented story. It is both bleak and beautiful, and is one of the most impressive games made in recent years. Thematically, Dark Souls is about death and perseverance in an unforgiving world. This is echoed in the gameplay by a near-complete lack of guidance; for example, techniques critical for success go completely unexplained, like how to kindle bonfires (and what that even means). Thus, community involvement such as reading guides or walkthroughs is a must. The online elements within the game are also helpful, but the game is just as much fun to play offline.If the inaccessibile presentation wasn't bad enough, it turns out that Dark Souls really is too hard. I'd probably enjoy playing it more often if it weren't so repetitive (dying and repeating the same segment over and over again). Frankly, I have the most fun late in the game, when I've powered up enough to explore new territory and take on bosses with relatively few deaths – you know, like a normal game. On the whole, I still can't deny how absorbing and satisfying the whole experience is. There are so many fascinating details hidden away that are exciting to uncover. I love the powerful images, tense moments, and sense of accomplishment that comes when my perseverance pays off. Dark Souls is not for everyone – not by a long shot – but for those who can get past its steep learning curve and cruel difficulty, it can be a wholly unique and inspiring experience. (Rating: 9/10 “Great”)Notes: I played this PC version with an Xbox 360 Controller for Windows. It is nearly identical to the PS3 version of the game I played before, and comes packaged with the Artorias of the Abyss DLC.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I bought this game out of curiosity during the last Steam Winter sales for less than 6€, after having read many reviews over the years, and I must say that it is well worth the money. Let’s get straight to business: DS – PTDE is a 3rd Person Fantasy Action-RPG, directly ported from the Xbox360 and PS3 version. The setting is a standard high-fantasy medieval world with lots of undeads, demons, lizardmen, dragons, knights in black or shiny armors of all sorts, but the lore and plot is rarely mentioned at all throughout the playthrough, as you mostly play alone (or with friends/other players in online co-op) with very rare encounters with sentient NPCs which can offer a little bit of insight on your mission and objectives. Game progression is almost non-linear: after having beaten the first obligatory “tutorial dungeon” you character reaches the first (and only) main quest hub and is given the generic mission to “fulfil the prophecy and ring the two Bells of Awakening”, with absolutely no clue on how to proceed: it is the player’s duty to start exploring the world and find a way to progress and clear a path, and this is where the real fun begins. Even if you have been living under a rock for the past 2 years and have read no other review of DS – PTDE, you will understand one basic concept during the first 10 minutes of gameplay: as the name itself implies this game is INSANELY HARD. The developers have intentionally designed it to challenge the player at every turn, with absolutely no mercy even for beginner’s mistakes (even in the tutorial dungeon you will die A LOT during your first playthrough). Some examples, just to give an idea:-          No save-load mechanic is implemented: the game autosaves your position and progress basically after every action you perform, causing every gameplay choice to become instantly PERMANENT. Did you just killed a NPC with a fireball by accident due to him being too close to a menacing skeleton? That NPC will be permanently DEAD, even if this means losing access to his wares (in case he was a merchant) or to a side quest. You will have to find another way around the locked door or find someone else to sell you those precious arrows you were looking for… The good news is that the developers have literally thought of everything, so an “unwinnable” scenario is virtually impossible to achieve (without cheats), even if you mindlessly slaughter every living and undead being in sight (including merchants and questgivers)-          Even if your character is cursed with the undeath and technically cannot die, every single hostile monster or NPC can single handedly♥♥♥♥♥♥you and send you back to the spawn point with little effort. Even the least menacing zombie, armed only with a broken sword, can AND WILL kill you a dozen time if you do not remember to dodge his attacks or keep your shield up the whole time. Underestimating any encounter, even when overgeared, will lead to the usual YOU DIED screen in few seconds-          If you are so lucky and brave to reach one of the various checkpoints placed at various strategic locations, and use it to rest and replenish your forces before proceeding EVERY SINGLE MONSTER YOU HAVE KILLED UP TO THAT MOMENT WILL RESPAWN (with the exception of bosses and minibosses), leaving you stranded in the middle of a dungeon with no way to get out without fighting your way back to the beginning. There is no turning back in DS – PTDE, sorry-          Is it also worth mentioning that being killed will result in the same effect: respawn at the checkpoint and a horde of fresh monsters to fight all around you. Oh, did I mention that spawn points are usually very far from bosses, punishing the player even more for deaths during boss fights?Although the above points could be interpreted as lazy or poor design, the reality is that DS – PTDE is one of the best balanced games I’ve played in many years of PC gaming: every encounter and situation can be easily won by using the correct strategy and taking advantage of the weakness of the enemy; if you are rushing through an area while swinging your sword or throwing fireballs without any care for the surrounding environment you will soon be overwhelmed and the familiar YOU DIED screen will be shown. A tactical approach, with perfect knowledge of the surroundings (to avoid the frequent ambushes) and the correct gear combination will increase your survival chances immensely, and some boss fights will even become trivial with the correct strategy.Of course this implies a trial-and-error process, but there is a reason why this game is called “Prepare to Die Edition”.Unfortunately this game has also blatant flaws, and the most important lies in the graphic engine: being a direct console port (made by a SW house which was specialized only in console titles with no PC experience) you can forget about HD resolution, smooth framerates and all the eye-candies of a typical PC AAA title. But it is even worse: the PC version of DS – PTDE is locked to 720p resolution and 30fps, IN 2014! You know that 3500€ gaming rig that you just bought and that runs BF4 at ultra in Surround on 3 27” monitors? It is completely wasted since you will experience the same resolution and detail of a 2005 console anyway.And what about mouse and keyboard controls? Forget about them, as all the menus and in game text refer to Xbox360 control layout and using a M+K combo will be a frustrating experience (Steam even has a warning on the store page claiming that a 360 controller is strongly recommended for this game).Luckily for you, my friends, the modding community has solved this issue since a long time with two brilliant an small pieces of software: DSFix and DSMfix (http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix and http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/864979455329386779/). After a very simple setup process you will be able to enjoy the game on your PC as it should have been since release, with full HD graphics, 60+ constant fps (with the possibility of downsampling to push the detail even further, if your rig can take it), SSAO, MSAA, FXAA, smooth mouse controls and customizable keybindings. Last but not least, there is also a co-op fix called DSCfix which improves the experience of online co-op play over the standard GFWL junk (http://sdrv.ms/128mNwY).TL;DR version:PROs-          Very challenging gameplay, but never too difficult to become unbeatable. If you die too much, it is generally your fault-          Longevity (50+ hours of gameplay for a single playthrough, with the possibility of New Game+ with increased difficulty!)-          Endless combinations of character growth and gear allows for very different approaches, all equally rewarding, to the game-          A sequel is in the works!CONs-          Direct Xbox360 port: use of unofficial mods is mandatory to make the game playable-          Awkward game controls with M+K (also fixed by a mod)-          Absurdly steep learning curve-          Some gameplay mechanics are obscure unless google is used (e.g. crafting)-          Even with mods the graphic engine does not take advantage of all the possible features of a modern gaming PC

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Gentlemen, I love PVP. Gentleman, I... love PVP. Gentlemen, I so love PVP.I love parrying. I love riposte. I love backstabs. I love havels. I love buffs. I love fast roll. I love drinking estus. I love invasions. I love hosts losing.On the bridges, in the anor londo, in the archives, in the forest, in the Oolacile, in the Depths, in the Painted World, in the Lost Izalith, in the Catacombs, in the Undead parish.I cherish each and every pvp can be waged in this game.I love the thunderous roar of asses, when casuls lose to the giant dad.My heart dances when the asses of enemy troops are hurled into the air in pieces from pursuers.I love it when a Havel smashes gankers with its giant club. It left a warm feeling in my chest when hosts would jump screaming from the blazing Giant Dad only to burn down lava.I love it when the gankers overrun the enemy , while hitting him with a staff. It moves me when I remember the sight of a cheater in a state of panic, stabbing an already dead enemy over und over with infinite stamina.I can hardly contain myself thinking of hanging the scrubs. And it is superb when the enemy undeads screams in time... with the roars of infested barbarians that smash them with boulders near Quelaag's domain.And those newcomers from sales that fought us, even though they used ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Drake Sword. I even remember how I one shoted their entire group with dark bead.I love russian players thrown into disorder. It is a very sad thing when their beloved npc's they should have protected to the death are killed by none other than them.I love the English and American builds being crushed and annihilated. Their creeping about on the ground like vermin, chased by the Magic spammers, is the height of humiliation.Gentlemen, I wish to see a war worthy of one in Hell itself.Gentlemen, gravelords, darkmoons, darkwraiths... Pray tell, wat do you wish for? Do you wish for PVP as a matter of course? Do you wish for a merciless, shitlike PVP? Do you wish for a stormlike conflict which runs the gamut of blowing steel and striking flame, killing every host in 3000 worlds?"Invade! Invade!Invade, invade, invade!Very well. Then let it be PVP. All our strength is held in a chaos zweihander, poised to strike. But for we who have continued to endure a whole year in the depths of mom's basement waiting for a PC release of Dark Souls... a simple PVP is no longer enough!! A GREAT PVP!! One born of our single-hearted devotion!!We are merely one gank battalion, no more than a thousand troop invaders. But each and everyone of you has min/maxed to match hardened veterans and count as a thousand. So gentlemen, together we are an army as powerful as a million and one regular invader. Let us rouse those slumbering ones who drove us into the realm of forgetfulness. Let us seize them by the hair, drag them down, open their eyes and make them remember. We shall make them remember the taste of terror. We shall make them remember the sound of our var boots. We shall remind them that something in the interval between heaven and earth they don't even recall with their own philosophy does indeed exist.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Oh my god, I think I'm gona die..... Dark Souls is undoubtedly the hardest game (and in my opinion, harder than Demon's Souls) of this generation. The gameplay is great, the game involves strategy and thinking to beat the powerful enemies, taking one hit can cause lots of damage and sometimes instant deaths if your not careful. You WILL die alot, and you will have to restart on parts you have gone so far... but completing the area will reward you greatly and you will become stronger. Bosses are a highlight of the game, they are like no other in other games, they are very challenging. This game is amazing in every aspect, challenging and rewarding. I have problems with the PC version thought...First, it is a port, this game runs terrible and laggy without using a mod called DSFix. With DSFix, you can do many game adjustments with it.Second, without DSMouse fix, you can't play with mouse and keyboard.Third, since it uses GFWL, it has ENORMOUS amount of hackers, making its multiplayer features extremly risky to use.I still recommend it thought as most problems are fixed using mods and its obviously still controller compatible.Get this game if you want to start a challenge :D

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												After playing this game whole, dying alot, enjoy it on some parts and raging unendlessly i have come to a point where everytime i meet someone new i'll ask them if they played Dark Souls, and if they haven't i'll just recommend it to them.It's one of these games that everyone is talking about, you take a look, hate a first but give it a second try and you'll treat it like a cup of coffe, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ afficionado.The first thing that you'll be noticing are the awkward controls that function awkwardly well, if you aren't playing this on the PC of course.Press R1 for light attack, R2 for a heavier strike, Y to dual-wield that may look useless at first but heck this is necessary as f*ck. Press B to roll and hold B to run.I have left Dark Souls for quite a long time, bought it in 2012 and only came to finish it in 2014 and dude, i have not forgotten what any of the buttons do.People say Dark Souls's story is crap, that it has no story, well tell that to Hidetaka Miyazaki you little piece of♥♥♥♥♥ you wouldn't trust yourself.Infact, the Dark Souls story is so well designed it gives me cancer, and look, a story has never given me cancer before.The characters itself tell the story, the bosses, heck, even the monsters do! Everything make sense if you explore further in the game, NPCs will tell stories and some monsters will be different, many secrets to be found, not something that was written on a book and making it easy to read, i'd even say Dark Souls is a interactive book where you write your own path, with circumstances if you kill an NPC or on the choices you make, they will come hit really hard later like electricity bills.The combat is realistic in its kind, it's not realistic in real-life realism level.Let's say, how do you attack with a spear in this game? you just f*cking rush with it at an enemy, i have seen a video on youtube that judges Dark Souls' combat and he tells only the truth.With many different weapons to wield, each weapon with a different skillset, different moves and abilities, it feels like every single weapon is different, let's put it like that, you are in a pet shop and can't decide which kitten to take home!The graphics are artistically beautiful, not photorealistic beautiful, with some photobumping that got my eyes stuck in amaze and how the armour is really shiny too, shields reflect light and your armour just feels like gold. The scenary is quite the thing too, but not that beautiful too, though since the PC-port was so poorly optimized, the community makes everything better, goddamit From Software i hope dark souls 2 will come out decent as journalists say.Dark souls is a one-in-a-kind game with unforgiving difficulty, if you do a mistake on combat ur dead m8. Ratings would give it a 10/10, i'm giving it my own personal score you swine, i'm giving it the 'Dark-Souls level score', that means it's good, yes.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												I originally played Dark Souls on the PS3 back in 2011 at launch, coming from Demon's Souls after about 100 hours or so, I was quite excited and avoided a lot of pre-release material, and all I could say was wow, and I still feel that way, if I were to add up the amount of time I've spent playing Dark Souls on PS3 and PC, I would estimate that I've put 1,000+ hours into the game, I also obtained the Platinum Trophy on PS3 for the game.Nowadays, it seems a lot of developers are getting more scared to take risks, particularly the bigger guys making AAA titles, this is understandable as these companies will either stick to a winning formula, or follow the trend of what people are buying and liking, From Software on the other hand, has strived to make games that they find fun, rewarding, complex, varied and memorable, in this regard, Dark Souls 1 is a gem, and one of my all time favourite games.There is absolutely a learning curve if you've never played the game(s) before, but once you get past this, you'll be surprised at really just how easy it is, knowledge is power when it comes to the Souls games, and as you obtain knowledge about the world, the weapons, the crafting system, the magic, general equipment, enemies, bosses and environments, you will be asking yourself "why is this game considered so hard again?", just as I ask myself at this point when I play through it.There is fantastic level of variety in all aspects of the game, when it comes to the enemies and bosses you encounter, the weapons you can use, the different armour sets, the spells and miracles you can obtain, the locations and environments you come across and travel to, it all adds up to make you want to push on and master the game, and once you do obtain that level of skill, you'll understand why this game has such a hardcore, passionate fanbase, and one of the most dedicated in gaming as a whole.In terms of character variety, Dark Souls has a system we calls "builds", basically there's different starting classes to choose from, each of which starts off with different stats and equipment, frankly, this only matters for the beginning of the game, typically I will personally start off with a Knight, and then level my stats in other areas to make a highly proficient Spellsword character, I have made other builds as well, but stat investment is VERY important, weapons in the game also have what is called "scaling", and as well as leveling up weapons with the brilliant crafting system, this scaling aspect will affect the damage you can do with a particular weapons based on your stats, so for example, a "Dexterity" or "Dex" weapon, like a Scimitar, will have a high "Scaling rank" (Like "A") when it comes to the Dexterity stat, meaning that the more you level Dexterity, the more damage you will do with that Scimitar, scaling ranges from S (the best) all the way to E (the worst).As far as the story goes, mainstream reviewers criticized this part of the game for being non-existent, and this is not the case, the basis of the story is explained in the opening cutscene, but the story and lore in general present themselves in a more mysterious way than most games out there do, they present themselves through item descriptions, NPC dialogues, and through emotion and general feeling, by simply paying attention to what is going on while playing the game, it's a superb way of telling a story and uncovering the rich lore of the game, you'll find yourself making connections from one item description to another, and coming up with your own theories for what may have happened, if you look at VaatiVidya or Epicnamebro on YouTube, you'll see that the story and lore are extremely deep and interesting, and we all certainly had a lot of fun putting the pieces together back in 2011 and beyond, even today, we continue to come up with new theories and we continue to discover new things about the game, which is incredible.The Multiplayer of the game is incredible and super unique, it hosts a realtime MP system which can be accessed without the need to go to another menu, the MP relies on the use of in-game items including a "White Sign Soapstone" (in order to place your personal "sign" down and be summoned to help another player in their own world), and a "Red Eye Orb" which will allow you to invade and attempt to kill another player in their world, there are other items in the game that allow for MP interaction, and co-op of up to 3 players can take place, the MP system can make for some extremely fun scenarios and some epic and fun battles.The general sound in the game is amazing and perfectly fitting, everything sounds just as it should, the music that plays during boss battles is incredible, emotional and very varied, I have nothing to complaint about in regards to the soundtrack, it is amazing.As far as the PC version goes, it was disappointing at launch in a lot of regards, for technical reasons mind you, it lacked a lot of the basic features a PC version of a game should have, such as high resolution and framerate support, however, a brilliant modder named Durante has since implemented a modification called "DSfix" which allows the game to run at higher resolutions and 60fps (albeit with a few issues when it comes to the higher fps), and also support for texture mods, some of which I use, anyone has access to this tool and it's simple to download and install.Overall, I cannot recommend Dark Souls enough, if you are a fan of Fantasy Action RPG's with a dark tone, mysterious story, incredible enemy, boss, level design, beautiful visuals, amazing art design and style and insane variety in weapons, armours and just about everything else, you owe it to yourself to play this game, continue to get better at it and master it, and just have a whole load of fun while doing so, experiencing a new world that doesn't herald YOU as its omnipotent master from the get go, but forces you to earn that spot, should you want it.If you are quite intimidated and would like a pretty understandable rundown and tips regarding the game, I suggest looking at Rurikhan's video "Dark Souls for Dummies, 10 Tips" on YouTube, which you can find right here - 


YouTube™ Video: Dark Souls for Dummies, 10 Tips 

			Views: 555,321		

			Dark Souls for Dummies For more information on upgrading weapons: http://darksouls.wikidot.com/upgrade DON'T SPOIL YOURSELF! Share, Like and leave a comment!		

I myself have also done a full YouTube Playthrough of Dark Souls on PC fairly recently, with some of the mods mentioned above for a higher framerate and resolution, if you are interested, you can check that out here - 


YouTube™ Video: Dark Souls PC Playthrough - Part 1 - Humble Beginnings 

			Views: 210		

			Finally doing a recorded playthrough of one of my favourite games of all time in 1080p 60fps, hope you enjoy! Playlist - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDpyH4QA1-TyyepVjEKaqJm6CwEKvtEGl Part...		

Thanks for reading!

												A game well worth the frustration. Sure, the PC port may not be that good, but with a bit of searching and some mods it'll work fine. content:
Posted: November 15, 2012
												As the game title says, prepare to die. And when the developer says, you should really do that, because you're going to die, big time. Death in this game is like one of the main characters: you're going to encounter it as much as you possibly can imagine. The game is as straight as an arrow, but the level-design left me speechless. Bosses are hard, enemies are smart, riddles are tricky, death is around every corner almost every time. The game overall could be too hardcore for your average casual gamer, but it's certainly worthwhile. One of the best action-RPGs of the 2012. I'd give it 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												It reminds me of games from my childhood. Enemies are tough, resources are limited, and you need to be able to get from point A to point B without dying. I spent 4hrs at Capra Demon, defeating him only with the help of a kind soul (that soul later invaded me and tried to kill me, but I shut that sucker down). If you die, you have to restart at the last checkpoint and kill everything all over again. If you use a resource and you die, you don't get that resource back. Enemies are tough enough and fight well enough that you actually have to know how to fight and how to defend yourself in order to survive. As frustrating as this game is, it's extremely satisfying and fulfilling to overcome a challenging enemy. Remember that game from your childhood where you spent so much time trying to get through one area? Remember how you felt when you finally beat it? You'll get that same feeling in Dark Souls.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												I’m fairly late to the Dark Souls party however once I started playing the game I could not stop playing, from the clumsy yet once mastered combat, it is extremely fun. I did a lot of research into the game such as weapons, armours and so on but a lot of the discovery of the game has to come from just actually playing the game. I read that “so-so” weapon was great and “this was terrible” but learned that I loved this weapon for its ability to do this, and hated that weapon because it was too slow and so on.  The story:The Story in Dark Souls is interesting, like many RPG games the lore is very deep with a strong and rich backstory to almost everything. You have to dig for all this however, searching online for the lore is the easier way to go about doing that so that’s what I did. The main story in the game however starts with you, whatever you are, man or woman and you can choose a class of a Mage all the way to the Knight, or a poor naked scrub. These affect how your character starts and how to can effect the work around you. You start in a cell, and are allowed free by grabbing a key from a hallow. After escaping you are thrown into the jaws of Dead Souls pretty violently though if you have any experience with games like this before you should easily grasp the ropes of the game. The rest of the Story is mainly about you completing quests and overall to beat the main boss. That’s all i will really say on this however.Gameplay:The gameplay is a classic RPG structure with Dark Souls combat system that is designed to be tricky but with trickery, come mastery, and once you master the combat in Dark Souls nothing can stand in your way.Many times you will encounter enemies, countless huge bosses and even real players who invade your lands and try to take your souls, however if you beat them, you can take their souls so the game has some gamble in it. Please be aware however the game has a scaling system that in my own opinion doesn’t really work. Sometimes I was thrown against high-levels who I was skilfully better than, however due to armour and weapons were no match for. Then I was thrown against enemies that didn’t know how to block and were cut down faster than wood so the imbalance was annoying however extremely exhilarating. When a player joined my game to duel I got a very high rush of adrenalin, will he be good, will he be bad and fights were often extremely intense and amazing. I’m not a very big PvP person but this game has the perfect combat system for such a PvP system.My only issue with the game it’s self is guiding. The game is open world however that’s all you are told, you must pay attention in all cut scenes to know what to do and even then sometimes it’s a guess so yeah, I don’t like handholding, but this game is a bit like those mothers who leave there children and supermarkets and drive all the way home, make dinner and then realise, however by this time the child’s already been beaten to death &♥♥♥♥♥♥♥several times and found his way back home already. But welcome to Dark Souls is the common reply hahaha. Graphics:This is when I can start getting picky with the game. The graphics are nice however the game is locked at 30fps and I believe is still locked at the rendering limit and is upscale. Please note however you can download a mod that fixes both issues. For the experience I chose against that but I’m going to download them now and play the game again at 60fps and non-up scaled res.The art style of the game is very well done. The game is very dark however (again you can download a mod to fix that) one of the greatest things about the game is the Physics system however, a lot of destructible environmental objects is always fun for some known reason and sometimes event he buggy corpse ragdolls when you run past them and they get stuck to your foot and fly in the air as you run always brings a smile to my face.So overall, I loved Dark Souls. The game is not the hard-case I’ve been told but the game has its challenges (Just saying. ♥♥♥♥ the Crystal section, invisible platforms can die in hell. They are cheap deaths and I find them to be a very lazy developer’s way of adding difficulty to the game.) Apart from the 30fps lack, 1024xsomething up scaled res and that specific level I have literally nothing to bad to say about this game I absolutely love it so much I actually played the game for 12 hours straight.I will give the game a strong 9/10 - It lost that extra 1 for been a poor port. Mainly in the eyes of 30fps, it may not bother some, and in this game it's not a ballache to watch however more is always better. Oh and it looses points for Cheap deathts, even in very hard games, its lazy and unwanted. *puts up middle finger*Pro’s:-	Great combat system once you get it down-	Strong lore, great RPG roots-	Great weapons and armours along with designs of them are incredible -	Great built in physics system and large amount of bosses and enemies-	Good PvP system, still needs some tweaking however.Con’s:-	30fps Lock and up scaled res-	Cheap deaths-	Reused bosses (only some, I don’t mean mini-bosses either)-	The game is sometimes very confusing.

												This is not a PC game. It's a console game someone has coded so that it'll run on a PC, without taking any changes into account. It may be great on a console, but it's not a PC game.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Dark SoulsThe game Brings me nostolgia back from Playing Megaman and or Castlevania, its a taste of Mastering mechanics and levels to Progress. The world is full of lore,Misery and Despair. Every NPC you meet is either fooling you or on your side, and their stories unfold as you progress, for better or for worse.Though Dark souls is hard, you may only need to  learn mechanics to play, pay close attention to the armours you pick up, the Weapons you find and build a character that Suits you. The game does not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you, if you die you know why you have died.The Integration of Invading/summoning mechanics with Story or lore is a awesome part of the game! either summon a friend via Online to help or Invade players to duel them or Stop thier Progression...PvP is really really Fun and is a great End game.THough Sadly the Game is a bad port and DSFix is needed to fully enjoy the game along with the Online Fix and a 360 controller, But honestly it is worth it. IT IS A CRIME that the game was a bad port for the art work and imagination of the game is Wonderfull.I can see my self putting in another 300-500 hours into this game if i was not 1 year late to the party and if Dark souls 2 was not around the corner, though i will be PvP'ing to pass the time ;D 9/10 would Praise the SUN!

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												wt r u, a casul?...On a more related note, with Games for Windows Live dead and this being on sale for 5 bucks, it's worth the pick up... as long as you don't count the half-dozen controllers you are liable to destroy in the process... The graphics are rather poor for 2011, but don't let that get you down. Dark Souls is a carefully crafted experience that you can only really fully grasp the first playthrough. Many players wish they could go back and re-experience their first time playing.  The replayability of the game comes in the diverse weapon choices and character builds, as poking enemies to death with a dagger is way, way different than swinging around a gigantic two-handed blade and, well, crushing them, I suppose. If you want the intended experience, I suggest starting your first playthough as the Warrior, as its a well-rounded character with a decent starting equipment set, and choosing nothing (or the Pendant... don't talk about the pendant! Please!) as your starting gift, as the items, which you can acquire in the game itself, are really powerful at the start of the game. So, what are you waiting for? We only want your precious Humanity...

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												So I bought this game for $6 a few months ago just to see what all the fuss was about.  70+ hours later I can say this is one of the most challenging and rewarding gaming experiences I've had in a very, very long time.  The game's not for the weak-willed and can be very frustrating at times, but that's a part of the experience.  If you're looking for a game that doesn't hold your hand, that beats you down with no mercy but makes you feel like you've truely accomplished something great give this game a try.I can also say a couple of months ago Dark Souls 2 wasn't even on my radar.  Now it's one of my must-own games this year!

Posted: February 18, 2014
												A great game that brings back a nostalgia of retro games where your not hand held or pampered with helpful tips, equipment or directions in the beginning. All you understand is to move forward and expect the unexpected. On a side note, the freaking tutorial is a boss fight that I did not understand how to beat until I saw the opening to an exit to get a sword and shield. An appreciation on not just on what it delivers, but for the players who traverse through the undead burg or  through the sewers of the depths and onwards to blighttown or Anor Londo, the experience is like no other. Each environment is a unique set piece with its own enemies and pathways to take. I remember reaching the firelink shrine the very first time and unknowingly heading down towards the New Londo Ruins only to be demolished by ghosts. This gives you a fair warning that your not equipped to travel through the area yet, but a bit sight seeing of what to expect later in the game can always help your conscience.Finally, the boss battles are some of the most exciting and frustrating thing about playing this game. Patience is key and learning the patterns and weakness of the enemy can go a long way. I've found sometimes even the mini bosses can be a handful because they can surprise you when entering a room and rush you unknowingly. Although I may have started playing this game at the latter end of its release (not even a quarter of the way through), I will definitely be looking forward to preordering Dark Souls 2 for the PC. A video for people who are interested in getting into the game at Dark Souls 2 -

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												One of the best games I've ever played. When this came out on the 360, I had no media knowledge of it (I recommend this for most hyped games) and came in completely blind. I got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked up and down because I thought it was a hack and slasher, obviously there is that but its much more controlled and precise. Pros:Level design - There are hardly any loading screens during the entire playthrough of this game, maybe a handful. The first 75% of the game is chock full of beautiful interconnected environments, and you will not get tired of running through them when you inevitably die :)Combat - Very visceral and precise. You will be punished harshly for using the last of your stamina and missing that risky shot. There is dodging and rolling which give you the tools to dance around your enemies if you are skilled, but even a skilled player can easily be overwhelmed by an over aggressive group of enemies. One of the best parts of the game.Enemies - Great variety of enemies and bosses, both challenging enough to not get tired out quickly.Online play - Theres nothing besides boss fights that gets my heart pumping like my world getting invaded. These invasions keep you on your toes and give you such a rush when you kill your invader as well. The messages and summoning are also great aspects of the online play, with overused and sometimes witty messages popping up to describe the levels around you. If you find an area to hard, summon a friend! Unfortunately summoning in some places is hard because there simply aren't enough players to find (especially within certain level ranges) to summon for a boss. Each boss is definitely killable via solo, but O&S boss will be tough if you cant find a co-op partner.Dying actually matters in this game as well, so the sense of riskiness is always present when holding a large amount of souls and youre trying to decide whether or not to cash them in or save up more.Cons:Framerate - The framerate can get a little bogged down sometimes, especially in Blighttown. It was way worse on the 360 though.The last sections of the game feel rushed and are not nearly as good as the rest (75%) of the game. This is not a huge con though because for the most part its great.Lack of summoning in some places due to lower player counts is somewhat of a negative, especially if youre having a hard time with the boss.All in all this game is a must buy for RPG fans, if you dont own it and youi call yourself one then please revoke your badge until its in your library :)

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Dark Souls is a splendid realization of an action RPG, beign well refined under both the aspects. Action gameplay includes dodging, parrying and blocking, while every weapon - and there are a lot - has its own moveset, multiplying the fighting possibilities against many different enemies.The ambientation is dark and criptic; a deep and imaginative creature design builds a stunning dream-like atmosphere, while short npc dialogues and hidden plots clothe the adventure in a curtain of indifference. The map is like a Rubik's cube: hidden connections and intricate geometries enrich every area, and at the end of the exploration, the whole path scheme is elegantly resolved. The game is hard to master and requires a high level of concentration, because mistakes and superficiality are punished, in 99% of the case, with instant death. In addiction, no kind of help nor indications are ever provided to the player, which have to try and learn by his own. Controls and camera are unfortunatly badly developed, eventually leading to some gameplay obstructions, while hitboxes needed a better precision.New game plus and lots of way to customize characters extend the game experience to hundreds of hours, as every game run might have a different evolution.Beign a true and solitary challenge, with little rewardings and tons of game over, DS is made for real gamers.90/100

Posted: June 27, 2016
Dark Souls: Prepare To Die EditionThis is by far the best game I have ever played in a long time, everything about it is perfect and keeps me playing for hours.  But it didn't start like that.  When I first got this game, I was bad and it was frustrating.  Death after death to the first boss made me want to stop playing, but I didn't, I kept trying and trying until I found out what I was doing wrong.  And when you finally beat a boss after 20+ failures, you get an overwhelming feeling of accomplishment, it drives you to keep playing to find out what's next.  You will spend the whole game dying, learning from your mistakes, and feeling proud of yourself once you've mastered a fight and beat a boss.  All I can say is don't get discouraged, the game will get easier the more you play, trust me.  I used to suck and now im on NG+8 and I don't suck as much anymore. :D10/10 Dark Souls Best Game

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												NOTE: Get DSFix to change the game's internal rendering resolution to whatever you like and unlock the FPS to 30 or 60. Oh, Dark Souls. The hardest game ever to hear some people talk, but in all honesty, the game's difficulty is vastly overstated. Yes, it can be brutal, and yes it's going to drop you into a big mean world full of intimidating uglies that want nothing more than to paint the walls with your warm red fluids, but NOTHING in Dark Souls is insurmountable. It's a game that merely plays on some of your worst habits as a player of games and will punish those who think they can rush things their first time through. It's tough, but fair. Combat comes down to analyzing your enemies, knowing your weapon and defenses, and managing your stamina. You don't need an overpowered build to win any encounter, just awareness and the ability to react. Nearly every piece of equipment in the game is viable and allows the game to be played pretty much however you wish. (Just don't put ANY POINTS AT ALL into Resistance. It's pointless.) This is definitely not the kind of linear stat progression and equipment system most RPGs present players with, and the game feels much more satisfying overall since you have so much of a say in how you want to defend yourself.Being dropped in fresh will be overwhelming at first since the game provides no real direction on how you need to progress, but exploring the dreary and imposing world of the undead is rewarding in itself. You'll never know what's around the next corner, but that's part of the fun. It's hard to think of many other games so focused on atmosphere and discovery these days in the same ways that Dark Souls is. I can get why the game may not necessarily appeal to everyone, but those who can tough out those initial few hours are in for an immensely rewarding experience. One of the generation's best, right here.

												Easily one of my top 5 favorite games of all time. Challenging, but well worth it. Every victory feels extremely awesome. Some pretty interesting customization in fighting, play style, magic, weapons, armor, etc. Really incredible lore - if you manage to pay attention. Every item/area/piece of equipment/enemy/boss builds on the lore in the game, none of it is just spoon fed to you. Definitely 10x better with a controller. All in all it's an amazing, well worth game that will have you pushing yourself to beat each new boss. Also, the open world is pretty awesome - you can do the game in almost any order you want. Great graphics as well, especially if you download the free DS Fix mod.10/10 for this game.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												This game is dated, slow, and can't run properly without installing a mod. That being said, this game great. It's a fun ARPG that puts your skills to the ultimate test. Yes, this game is hard. Yes, you will die. Yes, it's kinda the point. Every death you learn about the game. That boss that dunked you with his buttslam attack you didn't know he had? Now you know he has it. That well-hidden boulder trap that rolled down the stairs to crush you? Now you know where to find it, and when to run. The challenge is there, but so is the knowledge and learning to overcome it with your own power.Any RPG character you want to make, you can probably make it here. Poison Fist Monk? Spell slinging Magic Knight? Zweihander Champion of the Giants? Fire breathing, ninja flipping Dragon-Ninja hybrid? Check, check, check, and after grinding to get Dragon Scales, check!The visuals in the game are awesome. The enemy, level, and boss design feels unique and original in each area you visit. Blighttown is a toxic swamp of gloom and despair, Anor Londo is as prestigious and clean as it is controller breaking. The lighting bolt spitting snake people in Sen's Fortress. The greataxe wielding Taurus Demons of Lost Izalith. Gravelord Nito is terrifying, Ornstein and Smough are badass and powerful, and Artorias of the Abyss is one of the best bosses I've ever fought in a video game. They're all there to kill you and look cool doing so.The game rewards exploration as well. There are tons of side paths and secret areas that lead to weapon upgrades, new spells, and extra souls to level yourself with. If a boss is too hard, try another path in the area. Grind up some souls, maybe you'll find a new weapon to bash their brains in with!If the game really is too hard, try some Jolly Co-operation with a friend! I actually find the game more fun (and less brutal to my blood-pressure) when I tear down a naked-demon-spider-queen together with a friend.I've finished three playthroughs of the game (two co-op, one solo). My two major complaints are the lack of dual wielding and the game not running at 60fps (Dark Souls HD Remaster Fromsoft please please please). You CAN dual-wield weapons, but it's not very good in this game. Thankfully the sequel fixes that.TL;DR: Game is hard. Game is fun.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
“I just wanted to see the plot” - kasuparuBRIGHT SOULS: Prepare to Smile Edition1. I am a casualI don’t play games because they are challenging. I want games to have the plot, thoughts or feelings for me. After 100 hours of play I discovered that Dark Souls is about overcoming own inability and impatience. Player character power depends on player’s ability and skill. You learn to be calm and try again. This reminded me of the race mission in Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven before the patch came out. I learned how to drive in 2 weeks. The patch lowered the difficulty, and added the Skip button. Casuls.2. “Do it with a RockBand controller, then we’ll talk”I played using mouse and keyboard. Developers of DSFix and DSMFix made it possible, huge thanks! It is much more comfortable for me, and allows to control the camera at the speed and precision I want to. I almost never used camera lock-on on an enemy. Lock-on makes you move slower, and the camera messes up if the target dashes or jumps. If there is anyone telling you to use the controller, disregard, and play the way you want.3. Check or FoldI did not like how the game increases stakes by promoting to be human. I was hollow most of the times, soloed all bosses. On the bright part, I was never invaded. I used guides a lot. Did not spoil anything for me, the game is still challenging.Top-3 hardest bosses (NG): Capra & Dogs, Ornstein & Smough, Artorias & RNG.Top-3 locations I hate: Tomb of the Giants, Blighttown, Duke’s Archives.I blazed through New Game+, enjoying New Game++ or another run.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												So I was walking around the burg when a van drove up next to me.  The driver stopped the vehicle and spoke to me, asked if I would like to earn some souls through what he called 'jolly co-operation'.  Being new, and in desperate need of the SL, I graciously accepted the offer.  He gave me some white key and told me to go around to the back of the van and unlock it.  Upon doing so, he suddenly burst out and attacked me.  I jumped away, trying to strike back, but the man easily parried my blow, riposting back with a hard fist to my gut.  Crumpling to my knees, he then kicked me down and rolled me onto my stomach, then proceeding to backstab me over and over again with his estus flask, arms outstretched above his head, shouting out PRAISE THE SUN! between ragged breaths.  It was the worst experience of my life.10/10

content:
Posted: October 7, 2013
												Much have been said about this game's difficulty, and while it is hard, it's not impossible and is rarely unfair. It has a deep combat system that's precise, easy to pick up, but takes time to master. It's set in one of the best designed worlds in video games; Lordran. A mysterious and often beautiful world that at the same time can overwhelm you with fear. How the areas in this world interconnects is just mind-bending genius. There are so many ways to play this game that it never gets old no matter how many times you play through it. A masterwork.

number of helpful: 20 of 34 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I played this game all the way through the first non-tutorial boss. this includes a big detour fighting some skeletons in a graveyard for about an hour before my friend told me that those things should have been killing me and I was supposed to go the other way. Basically the whole thing is a giant patience test, where the only way you ever die is by being greedy and wanting to end an encounter sooner by getting more hits in. When the only way you can lose is if you're anxious for the central gameplay to be over with sooner, there's something seriously wrong in the game's design.If this game is challenging, it's after the first boss, who I beat on the first try because he telegraphed everything like mad.If this game is atmospheric, it's after the first boss, because I just had generic medieval castle to go through.If this game is rich or deep in story, it's after the first boss (and an NPC who talks to you a while afterward), because I still have no idea what the series is about or how anything is supposed to work (including a lot of gameplay elements, for which there is no written information anywhere - wiki walks are fine for sandbox games but just annoying in a beat 'em up).If a game doesn't give me a reason to play it by the end of the first real area, then either it has nothing to offer, or it's stringing me along instead of respecting me as a customer. Either way DS1 was a huge letdown and I really don't get all the hype.In a word, the game is "tedious", and I'm amazed at how many people seem to confuse that with "difficult". It's difficult to force yourself to play in a way that will win, because you'd rather play in a way that seems fun but gets you killed. This is not the kind of difficult that a video game is supposed to be.Pick it up on sale as a casual time-killer but look elsewhere if you want a game that actually wants you to have fun. If you're looking for a challenge in the same general genre, I recommend Rogue Legacy.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Before I begin, I would like to point out that I bought this game originally a couple years ago on Xbox 360, before I decided to get into PC gaming. I easily have over a thousand hours in this game on Xbox, and although I come back to this game often on PC now days, I have played it SO much that there is nothing new left for me. This game is, in my opinion, probably the BEST aRPG ever made.......EVER!There are many amazing things about this game, that I will list here:* The amount of character customization is staggering.* The fighting mechanics are arguably unmatched by ANY other game.* The story is very deep and full of lore. It is in NO WAY thrown in your face, in fact it's quite the opposite, in that you will need to literally search through every item description and NPC conversation, in order to figure out what is happening in this decrepit land known as Lordran.* Monster Design is arguably unmatched by any other game* After you have played through the game multiple times, Dark Souls' PvP adds a whole new layer of replayability to the game, easily adding many more hours of enjoyment to the game. * PvP is actually mixed in with PvE, in that other players can 'Invade' your world if certain conditions are met, and this greatly adds to the feeling of hopelessness and despair that the Developers have masterfully crafted into this game. There's so much more about this game that is literally too hard to put into words. I just ask that if you give this game a chance, (you better!) that you ACTUALLY give this game a chance. It will seem awkward, or hard at first. You will die, but if you can push through the first couple areas in this game, you will become addicted, I guarantee it. The only Cons that I see PC gamers taking issue with would be:* KB/M controls are broken, making a controller strongly recommended. However, there are mods that help fix this. * If you buy and install this game, it will NOT run correctly on any PC unless you also download and install DSFIX. [www.nexusmods.com] You MUST download and install this, and the 5 minutes it takes to do so fixes the game. * There are not many options for graphics in the game itself, however, exploring the .ini files included in DSFIX will provide any PC gamer with many of the graphics options that we are used to. Please do not take these cons as a reason not to buy and play this game, you would literally be missing out on the BEST aRPG ever made. Seriously, just buy it already! :D

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Dark Souls will be remembered as a masterpiece that dared to go back to gaming’s roots and doing so perfectly. Away with regenerating health, minimaps and other forms of handholding. Lordran is an unforgiving world that wants you to take risk and learn from its brutal nature. The game will kill you… a lot. But as you die you will learn and eventually die a little less and overcome its obstacles giving you a fulfilling feeling of accomplishment. In other words Dark Souls is a hard game. But that’s due to its unforgiving nature that punishes every mistake if you don’t play by its rules. I played it on PS3 and even though the port has some obvious issues, I have enjoyed it just as much. This game is still a gem, and I can only encourage anyone to give it a fair try.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												One of the most intimidating games that i played so far. Dark Souls is an interesting game that its praised for its difficulty, but thats what makes it a great game, since overcoming those obstacles that the game puts you constantly makes you feel overwhelmingly satisfied. The most interesting thing about this game is its meaning since its very similar to real life and it has very interesting philosophical concepts. Its hard to pinpoint what truly is since every player experience it differently and its open for interpretation, and the story is hidden. Though the most common philosophy i can find is existentialism. By that i mean that not everything has meaning in Dark Souls. The player starts as a hollow, which is a state that a being is cursed and will not die and the Undead slowly lose their mind and consciousness. In order to become human they need humanity or else they delve deep into madness and pain. Humanity makes you into a human form but every time you reverse the hollowing you lose some part of your self (existence). For me the hollow-human state resembles a lot with Albert Camus "The Myth of Sisyphus", since how much you try to escape or in this case to die peacefully you can't, and then comes the realization of the absurd. Just like Sisyphus you are destined to progress through the world (Lordran) and discover some kind of meaning if there is any. Another thing about hollow state or rather Dark Souls itself is an allegory for depression. Dark Souls in general is a very depressive and sad game but the hollow state is a resemblance to it since the more you go hollow (feel pain, sadness, sorrow, misery and not doing anything about it) the more you lose your self in depression. The game makes a good example on how you should progress and fight this state of mind just like in real life to overcome all the difficulties and hard times that we are faced.The NPC's in this game have all really sad stories(and most of them die and you are unable to save them) which makes you feel very compassionate, and understand their suffering. To dwell more on my interpretation a good example is a NPC called Solaire which has a quest to find the Sun(The Sun as a metaphor for hope and meaning), but the more you progress in the game you will see that Solaire is losing his hope and will to fulfill his quest to find his Sun and slowly becomes hollow(you can save him but he is still affected). The story is hidden in Dark Souls and you have to read item descriptions to learn something about the lore of this game. The design is one of the best aspect in this game since everything is interconnected and that makes it to be a more immersive experience. Also the game has a PvE and PvP aspect hence becoming a human will activate the PvP and you might get invaded more often in your game world, but another interesting thing is that by playing the game your character feels lonely and everything is against you, helping someone in PvP for a boss or from an invader is very satisfactory and the game encourages cooperation more. Though the most interesting aspect i find for this game is that it doesn't make you important(rarely for a video game to do that), rather you are there like many others who ventured in that unwelcome world to find their meaning or to simply don't go hollow.This game was a present surprise and i really enjoyed it, i recommend it to everyone who wants to play a meaningful game. In short:Pros:+Gameplay +Design+Immersion+Difficulty+SoundCons:-Capped 30 fps (Needs DSFix)-For those using mouse (Needs dsmfix)

												Dark Souls brings back the toughness in games. Remember playing Zelda on the NES? Remember how hard it was to find everything as a kid? It's not like your typical game like Skyrim where you can save 4 seconds before dying and just come back to life and fix your mistake 2 seconds later. You die, you cry. Everywhere you go, you're absolutely terrified and nearly♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself at the slightest change in atmosphere. But when you achieve whatever it was you were trying to do, you seriously ♥♥♥♥ your pants and punch your baby in the face in joy. You scream at your wife and tell her you want a divorce. Thanks Dark Souls.

												You will loathe yourself for playing this game. Let me explain: it is the most sadisticly addicting games ever created. Let me furher explain: This game will test your skill as a gamer and you patience as a human being. Its challenges are numerous and seemingly endless. You will die and die and die again then, probably, hurl your remote (or keyboard, I'd highly recomend a remote though) across what ever space you are playing in and swear that you will never play it again... But then like Rihanna you come crawling back begging for more. The worst thing about all of this is that even though it will make you want to rip your teeth out, you'll love every second of it. The feeling of finally figuring out how to beat a challenge is so amazing at times you might feel like throwing a small party in celebration, and the rush you get when beat the game (your tormentor for the past many hours of game play) is even more so. You will be hard pressed to find a gaming experience as thrilling and rewarding as sDark Souls, as soon as you start playing it will become your most hated addiction.

												One of the "harder games" in recent years that was put into limelight. This is not atypical easygoing role-playing adventure. Your health means little, your armor and weapons can break, and death comes real easily if you careless. Learn to defend, dodge, and parry to protect yourself against dangerous enemies that will stand in your way as you travel through the dark world of Dark Souls.  If you plan to go online, others may invade your world and hunt you down, but you can do the same as well. You may also meet up with friendly strangers to engage in jolly co-op, if you are into it.8/10 Will die again.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I deleted my old review because I gave it unjustly more than likely due to rage. I've played a good amount, the part i was stuck on was the Tarus Demon and the part after that where it involved a knight and some random hallowed in a pincer attack. After taking a break for many months and then retrying it. I've progressed to the first bell. I don't know what the other reviews state when they ran into bugs, problems and etc. I have an unmodded version and it runs just fine. Sure the mouse/keyboard should be fixed but to be honest I don't mind using a 360 controller. Regardless here is my review.The game will in fact not hold your hand. The will game anally ravage you over and over again over a picket fence. The game is unforgiving. The game will destroy you.But do you know what the good thing about it? Every time I finally over come my rage, calmed down adn thought about it. Thought about how I could improve. Thought about how I was doing something wrong. The more times I tackled it. I got better and better at parrying especially when I went to kill Havel. I felt pride and joy. I feel so happy and better than I even got to the first bell. Now supposely that was the "easy" part of the game as my friends have stated but you know what? I am waiting for the challenges. I played all day on 12/16/2013 perhaps I only made it pass the butterfly moth, the belfry gargoyles and even rang the first bell.I will tell you the game is very hard but can easily overcome with patience and it pays off. You'll feel very accomplished at every victory. If you like a challenge then please get this game and play it. I await for DS 2.The only part I don't get is why you have to follow the laws of physics(aka if you use a long sword and hit a wall while attacking your sword bounces off and your attack doesn't land) but yet the AI can ignore it. Sure it makes it difficult especially since the AI for basic minions can be very stupid and I can see why they would set them to ignore it but perhaps they'll make better AI and you can use your terrian to stop a black knight from swinging while you keep prodding at him or even that he choses not to swing but prod at you rapier style instead of full blow swings. But regardless this part doesn't matter because I usually get a spear and one sword on hand so I can switch as needed rather it's a narrow hallway or not a narrow hallway.Beat the game.... Kinda disappointed at few bosses and kinda disappointed at the ending.... Still a good challenge and I still enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												It may be tough, and it may make you cry, but between the scenery and the difficulty, it is a beautiful and challenging game. The detail on the buildings, Anor Londo specifically, is to die for (since the things in the place might kill you anyway!). It is a tough game, for sure, and should not be sat down with while in a mental state that says "I will be good at this, better than anybody else, and I will beat it." You will more than likely end up frustrated in the end. The pc port is iffy, albeit playable (but makes the game a lot harder), but with a controller it's equal to playing the console version of the game. The major downside to this game is that when trying to either invade or summon, it is a hit and miss. You can either get lucky and summon/invade on the first try, or anything that isn't lucky, and be sitting for 30 minutes to an hour trying to summon your friends. (I'm not sure if this also happens when trying to invade.)Overall, the game is great and I can't wait for the second one, which will have better ports!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Dark Souls.... doesnt the name just make you cringe?! Well, it shouldn't! People will play games forever, whether it's marbles or Dark souls, but either way, somebody is gonna rage quit! some people will play a video game just to 'Beat' it. However, this game does it a little different.... instead of giving you a choice of beating it or not, it decides for you - and it's never in your favour! This game beats you.... to a pulp.... then runs you over in it's car.... and gets it's mates to help beat the crap out of you.... not even exaggerating a little bit! But why should that scare you off? It's just a game right?Wrong, ♥♥♥♥♥♥!This is more than a game, it's an achievement, an accomplishment, a challenge and a test for all gamers out there!This game is not reccomended for those who are prone to rage quitting, and it's definately not for the faint at heart!'But what's the point if im just going to die all the time?'Shut up, you're adopted! let me tell you what's in store for you!The rewards may be a few souls and a weapon.... but thats in game! Inside your head you have just played the same part of the game about 500 times, and you've died equally. You were about to walk away when you gave it one more shot! finally, you got the SOB down to its last bit of health and you stabbed it right in the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ You stood with your head held high when you finally killed that boss and you made it known that you owned it and you had intercourse with it's mother while shouting at the screen. The satisfaction levels are over 9000, and you could even say that you smiled after so much anger and frustration.... and trust me when i say that THAT very smile feels amazing!this game will take you a LONG time to finish..... the first area..... let alone the whole game! but it's not about time, its about how much you want it! it's about your desire to accomplish something! You can say to your weaker friends 'Hey look noob, i finished Dark Souls! what did you do in the last 600 hours of your life?'having said that, this game IS NOT a waste of time at all! if you play for an hour and dont even get to a new bonfire (Checkpoint [Very Rare]) dont decide it's no use, just keep trying.... there are more secrets in this game the illuminati dont even know whats going on!! Look for shortcuts, try new areas dont get caught in a rut!So yeah, thats what i think anyway! please consider playing this game (If you can get it working on steam [Need a games for windows account]) Dark Souls..... You are worthy of nothing less...9.3/10Dylan Burton

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I deleted my old review because I gave it unjustly more than likely due to rage. I've played a good amount, the part i was stuck on was the Tarus Demon and the part after that where it involved a knight and some random hallowed in a pincer attack. After taking a break for many months and then retrying it. I've progressed to the first bell. I don't know what the other reviews state when they ran into bugs, problems and etc. I have an unmodded version and it runs just fine. Sure the mouse/keyboard should be fixed but to be honest I don't mind using a 360 controller. Regardless here is my review.The game will in fact not hold your hand. The will game anally ravage you over and over again over a picket fence. The game is unforgiving. The game will destroy you.But do you know what the good thing about it? Every time I finally over come my rage, calmed down adn thought about it. Thought about how I could improve. Thought about how I was doing something wrong. The more times I tackled it. I got better and better at parrying especially when I went to kill Havel. I felt pride and joy. I feel so happy and better than I even got to the first bell. Now supposely that was the "easy" part of the game as my friends have stated but you know what? I am waiting for the challenges. I played all day on 12/16/2013 perhaps I only made it pass the butterfly moth, the belfry gargoyles and even rang the first bell.I will tell you the game is very hard but can easily overcome with patience and it pays off. You'll feel very accomplished at every victory. If you like a challenge then please get this game and play it. I await for DS 2.The only part I don't get is why you have to follow the laws of physics(aka if you use a long sword and hit a wall while attacking your sword bounces off and your attack doesn't land) but yet the AI can ignore it. Sure it makes it difficult especially since the AI for basic minions can be very stupid and I can see why they would set them to ignore it but perhaps they'll make better AI and you can use your terrian to stop a black knight from swinging while you keep prodding at him or even that he choses not to swing but prod at you rapier style instead of full blow swings. But regardless this part doesn't matter because I usually get a spear and one sword on hand so I can switch as needed rather it's a narrow hallway or not a narrow hallway.Beat the game.... Kinda disappointed at few bosses and kinda disappointed at the ending.... Still a good challenge and I still enjoyed it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												It may be tough, and it may make you cry, but between the scenery and the difficulty, it is a beautiful and challenging game. The detail on the buildings, Anor Londo specifically, is to die for (since the things in the place might kill you anyway!). It is a tough game, for sure, and should not be sat down with while in a mental state that says "I will be good at this, better than anybody else, and I will beat it." You will more than likely end up frustrated in the end. The pc port is iffy, albeit playable (but makes the game a lot harder), but with a controller it's equal to playing the console version of the game. The major downside to this game is that when trying to either invade or summon, it is a hit and miss. You can either get lucky and summon/invade on the first try, or anything that isn't lucky, and be sitting for 30 minutes to an hour trying to summon your friends. (I'm not sure if this also happens when trying to invade.)Overall, the game is great and I can't wait for the second one, which will have better ports!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Dark Souls is one of the greatest games ever made.  The game manages to excel in terms of mechanics, atmosphere, immersion, lore, design and replay value.  All of this is achieved through tense dungeon crawling impressive enemy encounters, a seamlessly intertwined world, extremely rewarding challenges, complex weaponry and magic, and the flexibility to play the way you want through character customisation.  The online component is an improvement over its 'spiritual' predecessor Demon's Souls, though perhaps at the expense of the dread and feeling of loneliness that Demon's Souls provided.  You are able to aid or hinder other players as well as take part in a thriving community of duel based combat. The world is massive and seamless.  Doors open shortcuts to areas you previously visited hours before and the further you explore, the more hidden areas await.  The game encourages deep exploration with challenging gameplay simply being a consequence of the setting instead of a focus (something the sequel simply failed at understanding). The game is not perfect though and I do still believe that Demon's Souls is better.  The game requires some modding to improve performance and despite an impressive online system, it simply fails to work 100% of the time and can be frustrating.  I still highly recommend the game.
