content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												   Lots of people complain about this game being hard. Some of them even say it's too hard, but this game is like any other game in terms of dificulty. The only job you have here is learn the game: you need to learn enemy movesets, and your own, parry times, when to dodge or when to tank, if you can tank, and you need to learn enemy placements. Never just run into a place thinking you can dodge and speedrun first time.    I've played this game on the 360 for a lot longer than 140 hours, and my time on PC just adds to it. The game developers knew just where enemy placement would be perfect, and in what amount so that when you lost it was your fault. Not all areas and bosses feel this way, "Bed of Chaos", but the majority of the game is fair. I've personally seen people get stuck at the tutorial boss. It's not unfair difficulty, it's just a lack of Dark Souls skill.   Thanks to steamworks the multiplayer is a lot [less confusing than GFWL's, ]albeit a little bit slower.Most of the time I can connect to my friends with little to no downtime, but there are those times when it feels like you are in offline mode.   This game has PvP, and it's everywhere. There is a forest where invasions are a regular thing, and there is an arena in the DLC area. Red Sign soapstones are things for honorable physchopathic murderers.  Almost any place you can encounter a boss you can get invaded. PvP is really great in this game because it requires all the knowledge i previously mentioned. If you get invaded, never underestimate your opponet, or you will not survive for long.     People really like the story of this game. I do as well, but it's not just told outright to your face. It's scattered everywhere, from item descriptions to NPC dialouge. Descriptions and NPC dialouge is also a great way to discover the lore about bosses or enemies.   I definitely recommend this game. It's got all the things I love. Great PvE, great PvP, and most of all it allows you to either make new friends or meet hiliariously bad trolls.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												Dark Souls é um RPG Dungeon Crawler Hardcore de Hack and Slash de uma jobabildade excecional. O design e arte dos inimigos e masmorras bem como o seu combate são as estrelas deste jogo. Que é díficil mas justo, com um ambiente de fantasia medieval profundo, encantador e mortal. Onde a morte nos espera em cada canto mas que mesmo assim nos convece a ficar lá. É um dos melhores jogos do género. Possuí também uma história mistoriosa e complexa mas coerente e muito bem feita (que tem uma ligação forte ás sequelas). E também um modo de Multijogador (Co-Op e PvP) bastante divertidos.Simplesmente um clássico e uma peróloa de jogo.Dark Souls é suberbo, profundo, encantador, perigoso, dícifil, justo, poderoso, glorioso, coerente, inesquecivel, indispensável e épico!

It takes a few deaths getting used to, but once you see that's what makes this game great and is how it teaches you, you'll always want to play more.Unfotunately the games main downfall is the lack of time the developers put into finishing this port to PC, so it's VERY IMPORTANT that you install DSfix to resolve the graphical and game issues. You'll be very glad you did. DSfix doesn't affect any capabilities of the game besides improving just about everything and even the delevopers even recomend it. Get it now!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Dark Souls is a very difficult 8/10. The underlying game is genius, truly wonderful that eggs you on to discover what lays around the next corner. The fusion between Fighting game, Adventure, RPG is almost magical. But it is let down by it unforgiving personality. Some of the bosses I beat first time round (so it's not a skill problem), and nearly all of the bosses (up to the Lordvessel) were destroyed within a handful of attempts. However, this game really shouldn't take 50-60 hours to complete! A lot of that is wandering around trying to figure out what to do next, or trying to figure out the game logic. This game would be 10/10 if it was designed so that the same content (main) would take the average user 30 hours at most to complete. The first 30 hours were amazing for me, but it just became a plod and some of the later bosses felt like boring trial and error until something worked. Some of the challenge was not real "challenge" either. It was bad level design (even though overall the level design was rather superb), bad bonfire placement, glitchy and unpredictable collision boxes. I wanted to just love this game, and although I do truly see the brilliant glint in Dark Souls eye, it's still a Diamond in the Rough. Sort out all those shoddy hitboxes, clipping and dodgy bonfire placements and lessen up on the bulking up game time via over repetition.Stop allowing AI to hit through stone walls, where my blade fails, but then on the other hand let a dragon be shot slowly to death by an arrow because he hasn't detected you are slowly killing him. it feels cheap because it is.Still I can recommend this game to anyone that loves Dark fantasy, a deep challenge, and very wonderfully created world (even if thin to non existent on plot). But that kind of makes it even more mysterious.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2012
												Dark Souls, like Demon's Souls before it, treats the player to hostility not seen in video games since players started expecting to see the end. Dark Souls is not hard, simply fair - it even lets you come back an infinite number of times to try again. Enemies and their location decide the tactics a player should use, infinitely adding to their survivability. The game does not want you to win.When you win however, it accepts defeat.There are no Resident Evil style "IT SURVIVED #OMG fight it AGAIN" moments.They even held back the JRPG "You gotta die" thing, with one exception. They replaced them with "You're not going to survive if you don't pay attention" tests.Atmosphere-wise Dark Souls is a Survival Horror pretending to be a Fantasy RPG. Sure, it's got Fantasy elements, but they're all warped into a world where you, an Undead (marked with the ability to return to life at the last spot he sat down for a bit) are charged with deciphering a unreliably narrated world filled with plot and counter plot, where metaphors are blurred with reality. You're even perpetually attacked by alternate versions of yourself who hunt you for sport.On the negative side, the PC port was put together by taking the Xbox disc, grinding into thin paste and feeding down an ethernet cable. The button promts are still Xbox! PC controls are so badly implemented it's like they only playtested with the 19 fingered Chernobyl Bloodsucker that designed it. Get a controller, it does not matter which kind. You'll need a third party program to use a PS3 controller though.You'll also need "DSfix", a program that allows tinkering with many settings, and even helps the game run better. Optional are "DSMfix" for diehard mouse and keyboard battlers, and "DSCfix", which is fairly crucial to co-op with buddies.Multiplayer is woven into singleplayer with "Humanity" which turns your Undead self into a Human form fit to call living. Then people can kick your door down and take your stuff.Co-op is done through White Summon signs. which people leave around the place hoping to be summoned to your world. They will help you until you kill the area's boss.PVP is done through several methods, the basic is Invasion. One player will use an item in their own game, which will allow them to invade your game world in an attempt to kill you. Since all parallel undead are the same person, this guy is an alternate you who wants you-you dead. Fight. Overall Dark Souls is a game that will pretend it hates you until you realise it just wants an equally skilled opponent. It will make that opponent of you, or you will quit the game.Papa Nito loves you all.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												Great game! There is a fairly steep learning curve, and it is a difficult game, but success in the end is very rewarding. There are a wide variety of spells, weapons, armors, and techniques at your disposal; and there are unique pros and cons to each. The game also looks great, especially if you are using DSfix.The storyline is pretty fantastic as well. There are several sub-plots as well and they will differ based on your actions.Gameplay is absolutely wonderful. Truly a skill game, there are very few points where you feel like there was nothing you could do, or that you got cheated by the game into dying.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												You awaken in a prison cell, hollowed and stripped of all humanity. You are an Undead, a cursed being trapped within the purgatory that is the Undead Asylum. Who you are and what brought you here are a mystery. The curse makes one forget it seems. As you break out of your cell messages written with soapstone start to appear. Slowly you will make your way through the Asylum, heeding the cautionary tales written by those who came before you. You will seek comfort in the warm embrace of the bonfire, an oasis amidst the rubble and death. Before long however, you will be faced with insurmountable odds in the form of the Asylum Demon. This is where you will most likely die. However death isn't the end of things, you're an Undead after all. Soon you'll feel the warm embrace of the bonfire once more. At this point you will try again, again and again. Until at long last you slay the beast and are liberated from this place. This is where Dark Souls starts and your journey begins. That journey will be beautiful and engaging. The world you'll explore, the characters you'll meet are all lovingly crafted and will stick with you until long after. The gameplay is brutally unforgiving and exceptionally rewarding. Every bit of progress you'll make in this game will be a personal victory. It is incredibly captivating, challenging and simply put fun. If you are looking for a lengthy hands off narrative with compelling, tense action orientated D&D style gameplay. Then do yourself a favor, pick this game up and praise the sun!That being said, it is not without it's faults. The port of this game is sloppy to say the least. Natively it runs at sub par resolutions and has it's gamelogic locked at 30fps. This means that out of the box this game is practically unplayable for most PC gamers. Luckily there are ways to fix these glaring issues in the form of DSFix. (V2.4 at the time of this writing) It is a third party injector created for Dark Souls Prepare To Die Edition that enables you to alter render settings at the engine level.All in all I can not recommend Dark Souls enough.Praise the sun!

												Dark Souls is the very definition of a game. It has action, it has stats evolution, it has an intrisic rich lore and universe that's there for those who wish to dwell into the story, but it also has one of the best and most beautiful level designs of all time. It's highly dificult, it's ruthlessly punishing, it's highly rewarding. One of the few games I can't get enough and keep replaying over and over again,  and even doing countless attempts of (utterly failed) speedruns. Possibly the most perfectly structured game of all time. One of my all time favorites.Always remember:1. Be patient.2. Don't get greedy.3. Study your enemies and surroundings.4. Persevere.(PS: ♥♥♥♥ Bed Of Chaos. Just ♥♥♥♥ it.)

												This goes high on the list of games that are truly my favorites, and that surprises me because I have yet to defeat the whole game! Endless deaths and trial somehow push me through wanting to collect my souls for a level up and move on through a tough boss battle. The game is very punishing but rewarding in all the right ways, making me come back for more each time. If you like a challenge, are prepared to die many times, and enjoy unique level designs then this is the game for you. I don't just recommend this game but i highly recommend it. I've become addicted to it and I am an overall BAD player. I suck. If I can do it so can you. I can promise that its well worth your time. Practice makes perfect in a game like dark souls. The lore is rediculously interesting and the amount of replayability is high as well. There is a lot to do in this game and every time you move forward you will feel relief and happiness before the despair of realizing the next area you are about to go to seems to be an even bigger trial than before. Its all part of the fun!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Dark Souls is fantastic blah blah blah, I get sick pleasure from pain and am a complete masochist, etc.  If you want a real review, there are plenty of them available.  Rather than a true review, this is a wakthrough on what you need to do to get Dark Souls working on PC.  When From Software ported Dark Souls to PC, they felt it was too easy to get into the game and decided to screw up the graphics and controls so that the player would have to do a quest before they even opened the game (/sarcasm).  The reality is, From Software had no idea what they were doing in regards to PC programming and game design, and only ported the game because there was large fan demand (so don't hold the crap state of the vanilla game against them).  The result was the game can't display HD resolutions and the keyboard and mouse controls are awful.  Fortunately there are some fixes available.  (One more thing: If at all possible, use a gamepad.)First off, after downloading and installing Dark Souls, right click the game in your inventory and click on properties at the bottom.  A box with several tabs will open.  Click on the last tab that says BETAS.  In the tab, there's a scroll down box with something like dspdte-2.0.  Make sure the box displays the dspdte-2.0 line and hit the close button.  You don't need an access code or anything, it just automatically downloads the beta.  What this does is it makes sure your copy of Dark Souls interacts with Steam for online activity instead of GFWL.  It also ensures compatibility with the most recent DSFix (see below).  Note: Supposedly copies purchased and downloaded after Steam integration default to dsptde-2.0 but having never tested it, I don't know if it's true.DSFix is the mod that fixes screen resolution options and rendering and less importantly if you are using a gamepad, key bindings.  DSFix can be downloaded here:  http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/19/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nexusmods.com%2Fdarksouls%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D19&pUp=1Just follow the instructions in the description.  If you experience crashing or FPS drops, there's a good chance that your copy of Dark Souls and DSFix are not the most recent versions.Before talking about the mouse fix, I really urge you to just use a gamepad.  The controls are pretty complex as far as keyboards go and it's a bit difficult to press several buttons at a time on the keyboard, something that will happen often in Dark Souls.  The game was designed for controllers and it really shows, especially in button combos.  If you are using a gamepad, congrats!  You can go die now!  By which I mean play Dark Souls.If I somehow failed to convince you to use a gamepad, then you need to get DSMFix, the Dark Souls mouse fix.  It is built to work with DSFix and can be found here:  http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/28/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nexusmods.com%2Fdarksouls%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D28&pUp=1Disclaimer:  I have not tested this mod out having never used keyboard and mouse controls, but I hear good things about  it and it probably can't make mouse controls any worse than they are.So yeah that's how you make Dark Souls playable on PC.  With any luck this will get upvoted enough to be displayed on the Steam store page.  The pain of setting it up is absolutely worth it.  The game is definitely one of the most well designed RPGs ever made.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												I told myself I would write a review once I was done with Dark Souls. And so here it is.Dark Souls. I am late to the Souls party, since it is 2015 and this game came out... what? 4 years ago? It's an action RPG with a story hidden behind dialogue and item descriptions where you can die numerous times and come back at a nice bonfire. The RPG part mostly comes from increasing your skills and joining a covenant. The game does not really provide you much options to be a character, but that didn't stop me from being Knight Benedict of Astora, Blessed by the First-Born. Most dialogue is also just "Yes or No, mutafugger".The game's popularity comes from being "hard" or "difficult" with many of the fans of the game telling newcomers who are having trouble "Git Gud". I had to hear that myself as I was starting out and when I died a pathetic number of times to certain bosses (Here's to you, Knight Artorias), but would I say the game is hard? No. I don't believe this game is hard. I believe this game is frustrating, with a lot of mechanics that I question each time I encounter them. Questions like "Why can this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sancutary Guardian hit me 4 times in a row and keep my stunlocked and oh god damn it no, not the lightning again" as well as "Wait, these ghosts in New Londo can phase through walls and floors, because they're ghosts, but I can't roll away from them? How does that make- Oh no, now I'm surrounded and they're looking at my butt."Perhaps the only difficult part in this game comes from the early game, when bosses like the Asylum Demon and Taurus Demon can be plunged attacked but (for Asylum) you can only plunge once or (for Taurus) you can plunge multiple times, but its a fight to climb up the ladder without him killing you. Then you realize that the "git gud" part comes from running into a specific part of the boss and just wailing on them because they can't hit you there (under Sif's legs, or against Seath's crotch and tentacle leg, for example). So the game is not hard. It's very frustrating, especially when you first start out, and when you encounter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like the ghosts that you cannot roll through, despite them being GHOSTS.The lore in this game, however, is very good. It's not all up in your face like certain games, and you got to dig to find your answers to certain questions, though only some will be answered (Who was Gwyn's Firstborn? Was it Solaire? Was it Andre of Astora?). I'm always a fan of world building, and FROM did some great world building with this game. Not much to say beyond that. It's good. It's really damn good.The online community is small, but that's to be expected. Dark Souls 2 is out, Bloodborne is coming, and the community is split between the GFWL players and the Steam beta players. There was also the Region Lock that was only killed a few days ago. The game, for me, got -much- better once I was getting randomly invaded. Was fun. Managed to kill me a Spirit of Vengeance and Dark Phantom back-to-back before I got my final achievements today. Made me feel like I was gud, unlike the bosses, which just made me feel like I was cheesing all of them. Like the Ceaseless Discharge. He is so easy to cheese.So the game is good? Yeah, it's good. The combat is decent enough, though you should learn to parry, even though all but one boss cannot be parried. The lore is good. The online is still there, even if they can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (thanks to the two guys who left messages on top of the summon sign for the Manus fight). Is it hard? No. It is not a hard game, it is only a frustrating one, and there is a HUGE difference.Buy it if it's on sale, though I suspect I'm probably the last person in the world who got this game, and I didn't even buy it for myself. Thank you, my friends.

Posted: December 19, 2014
												You have to learn the moveset of every boss in order to beat him - let's take knight Artorias for example - the boss fight is so good you have to experience it to know what I am talking about. You will die maybe 4-5 times and then you start changing your tactic. After you learn every move the knight Artorias has, you can kill him if you are careful. It took me over 18 tries. I died 18 times trying to kill him, and I was HAPPY about it. The feeling of dopamine and endorphine flooding your brain after you finally beat the boss is the greatest feeling I ever had in gaming.I wish I could erase my memory of playing this game, forget absolutely everything about it (beacuse at this point I probably know almost everything, even that the Ingward returns to Firelink Shrine after you talk to him after beating Four Kings, I found this information after 3 years of the game being out) and play the game all over again. The Best game I have ever played, I have the sweetest memories about the time I first played Dark Souls.I love Dark Souls. So should you, if you give it a chance.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Review in one sentenceA very fun and challenging game, a one of its kind and a must-try.Gaming BackgroundI'm a PC gamer who predominantly plays FPS games, but has played a bit of MOBA and RTS too. Before I picked up Dark Souls, the only games I had ever played with a controller date back to the 6th generation consoles. I decided to give Dark Souls a go seeing as I finally got myself a controller and my friends were insisting I did.Index of this review Difficulty is Fun  Lore & Level Design A port of a console game Unnecessarily secretive Final wordsDifficulty is FunThough this game is notorious for its difficulty, it's challenging in a fair way; there isn't any RNG that determines whether you live or die. This game is hard because it's skill based.In a lot of RPGs, your character becomes stronger through leveling. Often this means you can both dish out and sustain orders of magnitude more damage than before. In Dark Souls, while you can definitely level your character to some extent, the real difference between you at level 1 and you at level 80 is raw skill. That's what makes this game so uniquely fun. You overcome the opponents not because your stats say you do; you overcome them because you've died to them a couple times and you now understand what you've been doing wrong all this time. This is where the phrase "git gud" comes from. Proof of this is that some players have been able to beat the game with a lvl 1 character, or without healing a single time.The always-on autosave feature in this game means that mistakes are permanent. Although this sounds hardcore, it's important to understand that dying is an important part of the game, and you lose less on death than in most games. Your "souls", which is both the in-game currency and the unit of XP you can use to level up and upgrade weapons, are dropped on the spot where you died.Lore & Level DesignDark Souls is made by FROM software, a Korean game developer, and it shows. The lore is akin to Asian folklore rather than the Greek, Norse, or Biblical stuff we're used too. This makes the lore unique and refreshing. Personally, the lore hasn't been able to rub off on me that much. It's hard to understand and hasn't really succeeded in giving me a sense of purpose, or part of something huge.That said, there's something uniquely captivating about Dark Souls. Its level design deserves an honorable mention, because it has somehow succeeded making 90% of the game contingent on each other. This means you can walk from the starting area to the rest of the world without loading screens or cutscenes. But it doesn't stop there; they have managed to meticulously interconnected their world in a brilliant way. Time and time again you will find yourself bewildered, exclaiming: "This elevator leads back here!? Holy crap!"In another stroke of genius, they decided to leave music out of the game almost entirely. They mean to make the atmosphere feel solitary and desolate, which they've done a pretty decent job at. On top of all this, it looks pretty decent for a 2011 game.A port of a console gameIn this part I'll be talking about some technical downsides that I feel stem mostly from the fact that this game is a PC Port from a 2011 console game. By default the framerate is capped at 30fps. Popular community made mods allow you to bump this up to 60, but at certain costs. This is the type of game engine where the graphical framerate is linked to the game's calculations. This means that the game will behave slightly differently at 60fps, yuck.The online connectivity is can be finnicky and might require community mods to work to your liking as well. It's not the most stable or reliably built game in the world, basically.Unnecessarily secretiveMy biggest gripe with this game is how it doesn't bother explaining new players a lot of their complicated mechanics. Don't get me wrong! The fact that this came doesn't spam you with popups saying "Press R2 to parry!" is mostly a good thing. The game's minimalistic HUD and GUI contribute to its unique atmosphere, but this is a double-edged blade.It takes most players a good while to figure out what Humanity is, how it works, what the number in your top bar means and what it means to be hollowed. To tell you the truth I still only understand how it works, but not why it works. I could go on and on listing bits of information or entire game mechanics that remain poorly-, mis-, or even unexplained throughout the game. This would all be fine in 1999, where the kid next door would tell you how to unlock a cool sword. But alas, we're in the era where extensive libraries of this type of information is at your fingertips. Sadly, at times this game almost beckons you to whip up the wiki, because decisions are permanent and you might not want to make any mistakes.The best way to play this game is by having an enthousiastic friend you can approach for specific questions, but will not tell you all of the ins and outs of the game.Summary and Final Words- Very enjoyable and rewarding gameplay- Looks decent, with great character & level design- Unique and myserious, sometimes to a faultNo matter what kind of player you are, you would be doing yourself a disservice by not at least trying this game. If you have any comments, questions, or critiques, feel free to add me on Steam. I'll even help you with the game if you want.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is one of my favorite games and does many things extremely well, but does suffer from some flaws that will cause many people to miss out on experiencing the game.My criticism is that the PC port of this game is awful and you must resort to outside fixes to make the game playable. The DSFix mod and the recent switch from GFWL to Steam for the online component of the game both allow you to play the game, but shouldn't be necessary in the first place. There are also some glaring flaws in the game design that are an added annoyance in the already frustrating game (looking at you Bed of Chaos).Now for everything that I love about Dark Souls. The amount of work that FromSoft put into the level design is astounding. Everything just seems to flow perfectly, your eyes are drawn to (or away from) things that you are supposed to find. Unlocking a shortcut or finding a new path can sometimes stop you in your tracks and blow your mind. The characters, the lighting, and the scenery all come together to immerse you in the world, every playthrough I find myself pausing from time to time to just stop and gaze at everything around me. You get the sense that you’re a part of something so much bigger than yourself (literally in a lot of ways). The lore is deep and rich, but you only scratch the surface in game, everything else is mystery or up to your interpretation. The frustration and feeling of accomplishment that follows. Getting stuck in an area and subsequently beating it is so satisfying.I can only recommend Dark Souls to someone that is not only willing to face the difficulty of playing the game, but also the difficulty of making the game playable.Good luck to all the Chosen Undead out there!Praise the Sun!   \[T]/

content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												I am pretty sure you're gonna be able to find a reasonable enough review above me, yet there is an important thing that is not being mentioned often enough. This is NOT a difficult game. It's not about dying all the time and not about raging all around. It is a marketing trick that worked for some reason, but you should not fall for it. Keep it in mind.Just like some of you, my sweet audience, I skipped this game when it came out. It was a weird idea for me to buy the game just because it's difficult. The one and only reason you'll be forcing this hardcore part is because the rest of them are not worth it. Right? Nah. Marketing team failed. It's not about deaths, not at all. It is the most fair game I've ever played. As long as you're paying respect to it, not trying to rush the whole location or avoid those fights in any way, you'll be going through this dark world as a hot knife through the butter.You'll die, of course, a  couple of times, but you'll know perfectly what happened. You'll adjust your strategy and try again. It's never about location being bad or monsters being strong. It's always about you making silly mistakes due to your arrogance or ignorance.  This is a thing that is capable of bringing back your thirst for gaming if you've lost it as I did. It is an absolute masterpiece in terms of making something complex with a very basic parts. It is something you definetly should try if you're fond of gaming. It doesn't even matter if you're filthy casual. Eventually you'll git gud.

												It's not the most graphically pleasing, not the most optimized, not the best UI, not the smoothest combat feel, but it is the best Dark Souls game.The level/world design, enemy design and story/atmosphere are all top tier. The game mechanics can feel slow and clunky, but they are the most fair and balanced of the souls games.After 300+ hours with friends and alone, on new characters and in the highest levels of NG+, this is still one of my favorite games.Since they've removed the windows live stuff from this game, it's gotten a lot better. Install DSFix from the Nexus for all of your graphics/bugs/FPS problems. Use DSCM from the Nexus to connect and coordinate with friends and you'll have no problems doing full co-op runs or friendly duels.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Would you even survive the Tutorial?Yes, we all know that the main thing of Dark Souls it's the difficulty, with actually a lot of game mechanics to understand and test. It will make you try a lot and it's actually not that easy for beginners. It can be quite frustrating sometimes if you are not in the right mood, as it can offer some big challenges in certain areas or bosses.The Dark Souls world is huge and quite open, will take some time to get oriented and follow the story at first. But once you get the hands on it I assure this game will give you a different experience than any other games out there.On the technical aspects you should install DSFix and use a controller to play this game smoothly, if you don't have a controller then I recommend DSMF(Dark Souls Mouse Fix) to get better and smooth mouse inputs. Forget about graphics options too, the game lacks of any important one, that's when DSFix come to save us, it offer some internal resolution and graphicals tweaks to optimize the game visually or performance-wise. I believe they had to rush the PC port due to a lot of people requests to bring it to PC. But please don't throw away this game because of that, it will take a few minutes to install those plugins.So to conclude, I would say that even if you are not a fan of medieval games like I was and as I mentioned early, this game will give you a different experience from any other game, I would say that it can even change your mind about what you see from videogames nowadays. It will actually make you live the feeling of progressionist and completionism.Totally recommended!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												The level design is just about one of the best from recent years. RPG-elements are minimal and the fighting, atleast as a warrior, was pretty boring. Dodge/block slash was the way to beat the game. The game has been said to be hard, but as a bad player I didn't find it that hard. Most bosses I beat with 1-3 tries(two of the lordvessel bosses fell in first try, final boss in three). Towards the end, bosses became easier and easier as the charachter got better gear. Only the "dark" areas gave me a lot of trouble, but they were surprisingly few for an fantasy-rpg. Comparing these to a generic MMORPG bosses, I found that these were a bit too easy to learn and bit too generic to actually make the learning part essential.The game had some frustrating parts, but I fast realised that they were frustrating because I wasn't supposed to be there yet difficulty-wise, again another nod to the level design. When approached later, those areas became pretty easy too.The game has some flaws, mostly dealing with shoddy PC-convert(fixed with mods). Also the in the game I think there was too much running through areas already ventured, better fast travel system could've been implemented earlier in the game and allow much less boring grinding.Also I didn't much appreciate the fact that the flames were always after the boss, not before. So taking 3 tries, meant that one must also beat all the minions between boss fight and the flame which usually was more of a nuisance than an actual challenge.The game gives too little information which is a quite normal for a RPG. I wonder what is the major problem actually explaining game mechanics in game instead of having to find out about the with either trial-and-error, manual or using a wikipage.Nonetheless, the game felt like a breath of fresh air that got just a bit too stale in the end. The "difficulty" theme didn't quite carry to the end and rest of the atmosphere was therefore lost. I still highly recommend everyone atleast try the first 10-20 hours, as one starts to respect level design in a whole new level(badum tsh).

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Don't get fooled by my playtime... I used to play this off steam way back when, shortly after it came out, and just now got it on Steam to have it in my collection there... playing DSIII now.This is the game that began the legendary DS-franchise. Yes, there were other games by the same company before that which were like the ancestors (Demon's Soul for example), yet this one, I think, was what got people in the West into these games.You can tell from the graphics that this is a couple of years old, but most likely, you'll soon download the popular mod that improves graphics anyway. I can't tell you whether you should start with this one and go to DSII and III from there... some people think it's important, others say you can start with any of them. What I can say is: It still can be quite challenging. Compared to DSIII, it's a bit slower-paced (the actual combat), as DSIII adds some elements of the popular Bloodbourne, so combat is faster. Still, it IS challenging, and if you're new to the franchise, you will die. A lot. But, here is the deal: That's part of the game, of the philosophy behind it. It's not like in other games, where dieing is rather uncommon or a really big deal once it happens. Dieing in DS is part of learning the game, of learning the controls, mechanics and fighting style of each boss and trash mob. Once you digest and accept that idea, you hopefully will stay calm once it happens. If you really really get ticked off when you die, yyou might wanna stay clear of this. However, for all the frustration and "pain" you endure, there is a big payoff - mastering the game, beating the bosses feels so very satisfying, is so rewarding. Other games afterwards might feel sluggish and too easy.Also, there IS lore in this game. Yet, it is not shoved into your face with big arrows and question marks and markers. You have to explore, take your time to look around, read item descriptions etc. Even then, things will be...dubious, but I find this mystery and the fact it's not "read to you in a loud voice through a PA system" quite fascinating.PLEASE take your time. Accept dieing as a big part of the learning curve. Practice with the controls. Try strategies. Don't spoil yourself too much with guides and walkthroughs. Dive in, explore, learn, and enjoy.I can't tell you whether this is the BEST DS game to get into the series as the graphics are a bit outdated, but it's a damn good starting point, so check it out, it's still a challenging, rewarding and exciting game!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												The Dark Souls series is famous for its gloomy atmosphere, the creative, sometimes grotesque, but always impressive art style and its very intense combat system. The player has to concentrate constantly, as almost every mistake might be punishable by death. In comparison to Dark Souls II, Dark Souls is a bit more welcoming to beginners because deaths do not cause the maximum health to decrease here ("hollowing"), so that the same nasty boss can be taken on without that additional disadvantage. For me, this was a frustrating turn-off in DS2, and I enjoy DS1 more. Also, unlimited enemy respawns in DS1 make farming and upgrading easier than in DS2, a significant factor for starters who prefer a lower difficulty.However, it is still crucial to study the game in order to advance. You need to know how stronger enemies and bosses can be beaten, either by your own observation or by watching tutorials. And you have to optimize your stats, at least as a new player, in order to gain some wiggle room for the inevitable mistakes. Basically, by optimizing your stats, you determine the difficulty of your game: Running around naked with a dagger and without levelling up is one of the highest "difficulty settings". If you want to have an easier first run, you watch tutorials and read wikis in order to - find the best locations to farm souls (= xp points and currency) in repeated killing sprees and subsequent zone resets (=enemy respawns) at a Bonfire- understand how the basic stats determine secondary stats (e.g. strength and physical damage, or encumbrance and roll speed) - get tips how to upgrade both your character and your weapons and armour- learn where to find or buy pieces of equipment that suit your playstyle and match each other.One example for matching equipment at the beginning of the game would be: - Zweihänder, a heavy and slow weapon that deals high damage and gives you a good chance to stagger enemies, but consumes a lot of stamina with each attack- Grass Crest Shield, a special item that boosts your stamina regeneration even when worn on your back, while two-handing your weapon- Elite Knight Armour, which is relatively heavy, but gives good defence values and poise, enabling you to take hits from quicker enemies while you build up your slow two-handed attack without being staggered or killed- Havel's Ring, a magical ring that increases your load capacity, meaning that you can still run and dodge roll relatively fast despite of heavy equipmentThis example should give you an idea how complex building a character can be, as there are so many interacting factors to consider.Due to the number of equippable items and viable strategies, all the DS games invite players to try out different combinations and find out what suits their taste most - not only regarding tactics and weapon movement sets that "feel good", but also the looks of your hero (the internet created the term "Fashion Souls" for a reason). I am quite fascinated by this game and give it a 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Truly one of the best Action Role-Playing Games of all time.From Software combined realism and RPG elements for one of the most unique and satisfying combat systems ever created. Enemies and bosses alike based around this combat system creates the most fun I've ever had killing anything in any game EVER.Pros: Well designed enemies, weapons, bosses, armor, you name it. The world is immersive, the gameplay fun and challenging, the characters believable, and the lore interesting. Fun enough to outweigh all the cons.Cons: Bugs, faulty physics, anything below Lower Undead Burg, Duke's Archives, difficulty spikes, hackers, Windows Live, and some enemies (Bonewheels, Torch Hollows, etc.) feel cheap, the mouse controls are absolutely horrific (thank god you can use an Xbox controller, with one the controls are great and responsive).Overall, the good parts of the game completely outweigh the bad. Sometimes you just need to consider the cons a necessary challenge so you don't smash your controller. I give Dark Souls an 87/100. To put things into perspective, this is my favorite game of all time.

The obstacles presented are challenging, but always fair and more importantly always give a sense of accomplishment after overcoming them. content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Let's see.. are you the kind of gamer who's into... Looking for a very challenging but fair game? Something that allows you to play any class or style you want to? A game in which has amazing lore that isn't upfront about it? An experience that will leave you unable to play games like Skyrim ever again? NPCs and characters that will impact you even after you have turned off the game? Jolly co-operation? Holds a DLC that is without a doubt mind blowingly fantastic? Serves you with replay value up to several runs or completely new runs?If any of these clicked with yah, than may I introduce you to Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition as the best candidate for the job. Seriously a masterpiece of a game that at first glance... seems like a hard game. You'll probably die often which will rustle your pants, but when you really pay attention and look into the lore... my god, it's REALLY deep. Apart from games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age, along with Elder Scrolls series- this game holds a record for most hidden lore in gaming history.Mechanics are so well done, that I can't enjoy games like Skyrim anymore without thinking back to how well Dark Souls plays out with the fighting, the classes, how weapons function, ect. I must admit, the co-op needs better support for the servers lack good connection plus how the leveling system works with co-op is flawed. Apart from that, I sincerely pray everyone gives this game a chance. It's one of my top 10 favorite games of all time!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												If there's a modern video-game series that can be considered "Balls-to-the-wall hard" or "Nintendo hard"(NES era, mind you), then most people will think of Dark Souls. That being said, after you've finished this game, you'll probably be thinking that The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is for pre pubescent girls. But let me get a little more in-depth on why you should (or shouldn't):Gameplay 8/10: A few MMO/RPG elements are involved in Dark Souls; mainly with stat allocation that includes upgrading strength, dexterity, endurance, etc. with the immensely versatile souls. However, there's quite a few factors that make Dark Souls vastly different than a standard third person hack and slash fantasy. The souls work as both a source of experience points and currency, as well as magic that oddly enough does not rely on the use of mana but rather a predetermined quality that can be used between safe points (Bonfires) are good example that there's a lot of fantasy elements that are changed to the point where Dark Souls can be its own unique thing.Covenants are also a rather unique factor in Dark Souls, as they are the only source of direct online interaction. Like weapons or attributes, covenants can also determine depending solely on your play-style. Do you like PvP and being an evil butt? Try the elusive Darkwraiths. Prefer to have jolly cooperation? Try out the Warrior of Sunlight. Or maybe you just want more honourable duels? Consider Path of the Dragon. All of these alliances play major roles within the PvP/Co-Op scene, and allows for further character customization.There are a couple of flaws with gameplay though, the main issue being the port from Console to Personal Computer systems. Though a lot of bugs with online play and other PC issues have been fixed, the usage of keyboard+mouse is almost always surpassed by using a controller due to the poor controls, making it feel like Dark Souls was never intended to be a PC game. If you have a controller (Playstation brand can work but Xbox is much more suitable), then this issue won't be a huge problem for you.Graphics 7/10: Nothing's really changed significantly between the ports, so Dark Souls loses points for that, along with the lack of mouth movement when people talk, and that Xbox controls are still used within the game (ie. press "B" to evade, when it's space on the Keyboard or triangle on Playstation controllers). All these little factors urk me to no end, but I'm not all negative about the graphics (I gave it a 7 after all).On the flip side, the designs of a majority of the creatures and armors are very creative compared to quite a bit of fantasy titles, yet still adds a couple of very cliché monsters (namely: rats and skeletons) to change it up. PC specs are not super demanding, so a lot of people can play Dark Souls without much lag or FPS drops. Some NPC designs are outright deceiving (Petrus of Thorolund is a great example) and it may surprise some players that silly looking characters may be very useful.. Or possibly the opposite~Difficulty 8/10: Ah yes, the most controversial topic. I'm not going to judge this on glitches/exploits or faulty controls, just full on, pure difficulty within the game. You essentially begin the first 5 minutes fighting a 30 foot demon with a broken, rusted half of a sword. That alone should set in what the game has in store for you. Dark Souls' difficulty is fairly consitant and does gradually get more hard up until the halfway point. A lot of bosses initially seem difficult, but when you know of a strategy against them, they become a lot more tolerable with your newly found MLG strats.But then, you'll come across the infamous duo, Dragonslayer Ornstein and Executioner Smaugh. Arguably the most difficult bosses in the game, these two will be the deciding factor on whether or not you can win Dark Souls or completely give up. So why mention these behemoths of boss battles? After this point, the difficulty fluctuates, but never really gets harder than this point. This is a fairly severe flaw in my opinion because of how early on this occurs, and these two should appear much later-- even second-to-last bosses of the game. After you deal with them, you can probably just take on any boss/enemy from that point on, which can be a little grating.Story 8/10: It's vague. Not as vague as say, Five Nights at Freddy's, but it's up there. This does the whole "Chosen One" cliché but with a little more finesse; as a majority of people in the game are simply unaware of it and you simply have no idea who to trust and who not to. This can create a sort of isolated feeling, which is very strange when it is your generic "Chosen One" story. People'll either treat you like dirt or as a simple friend, but nothing really outside of that with the exception of deities and alike who are aware. There's also a nice mix of personalities: You've got the Crestfallen Warrior and Merchant who's shady and pessimistic respectively, but characters like Solaire of Astoria or Siegmeyer of Catarina are a few who are jolly, humble and optimistic about their undeath makes you want to keep going or like them a lot more than most. A blend of characters, although limited, is well done in this title.Overall: I can ramble on about this game for hours upon hours, but I'll leave it as that. Dark Souls is one of those games that is truly unexpecting. You think you're going through a game that is just meant to tear your butt a new one, but has some hidden strategies, fairly good characters and story. If you want a challenge and have that special little high of accomplishing a difficult level or killing off a hard boss, this is the game for you.If you're susceptible to rage, short-patience, or hit things and hope for the best, you might want to stick with Skyrim.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is hands down one of the absolute best games I have ever played. Don't let my 36 hours on the PC version fool you,I spent hundreds of countless hours on this on the PS3 originally and beat the game, but when I saw how good of a deal it was for the Prepare to Die Edition (Which includes all of the DLC and is actually cheaper than the PS3 DLC purchased alone) I couldn't resist.The combat system in this game is so spectacular that when you go back to play a more "traditional" rpg like Skyrim or Guild Wars 2, you almost can't enjoy yourself due to the mundane combat systems. The fluid game mechanics include great timing with stabs, slashes, blocks, and parries. Moreover, there is a great dodging system where you can perform critical hits with backstabs.  Yes, it is difficult at first, but that's an essential part of the game, the learning curve, and the sense of reward that you get once you finally beat that boss, or finally succeed in that PVP encounter. This brings me to my favorite part of the game, the multiplayer aspects. The online connectivity in this game is one of the most integrated systems that I've ever seen. Players can summon each other for help in spectacular coop play, or fight to death in exhilarating PVP battles. Moreover, they can post signs and messages to warn (or trick) other players about obstacles ahead, and bloodstains can be left so future players can see where their peers died. It is a blast to play this game online, as there are always new challenges with PVP. Additionally, there is a large replayability factor in this game, because when you beat the game, you can move onto New Game + and further, where bosses and enemies are harder and new challenges arise.I know that many people give up at first because of it's initial difficulty, but after you play for a couple of hours and get accustomed to the combat mechanics, it will be the most rewarding game you have ever played. I would recommend this game to anyone, 10/10.NOTE: Some people complain that PTD is a bad PC port, and I can see where they are coming from. However, if you use a great and simple-to-use program called DSfix, you can configure your graphics and tune them to your liking. If you have a high end PC, you will find that you actually achieve smoother gameplay and framerates than in the consoles with proper configuration. I personally have a low end PC, and have managed to play the game on very playable framerates. All of the small issues that people report are solvable, so don't let that prevent you from buying this great game.

content:
Posted: January 7
The Good Amazing combat system, which makes overrated RPGs (which I will not list here, the game itself will make fanboys of such games butthurt enough) look like the♥♥♥♥♥♥they are Unique character building, no particular "class" restriction leaves a lot of room to experiment with different spells and weapons Impeccable world design and overall "flow" of the game - areas are all connected via various means, it truly is an open-world experience Some iconic boss fights you won't soon forget Great soundtrack Ways to die you never even dreamed of A co-op system that will both leave you frustrated and restore your faith in humanity (pun intended) No handholding of any kind, no "difficulty" sliders or similar ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to ruin the fun Last, but no least, the story is what makes it all come together. You can progress through the game, have fun killing everything and moving on after you're done or get bored of it, but if you really get into it, try to comprehend what the authors are trying to tell you, you'll realise that Dark Souls is a lot more than just a game.The Bad The PC port is pretty bad. There's a framerate restriction and some other annoyances, the developers were even too lazy to remove console tags for controls that pop up everywhere in the game, Luckily, there are mods to fix this, most important one being DSFix, by Durante. There's also a common misconception that a controller is required to play this game, but seeing that I beat DS1 and DS2 with keyboard and mouse, I have to say that's simply not true. In addition to DSFix, you get DS Mouse Fix (requires DSFix), set it up and you're good to go. Adding to the previous point, the controls are pretty bad. It's something you get used to, but it gets quite annoying when you have to press "Light attack" and "Move forward" at the exact same moment, if you want to do a kick. Again, this is something you can get around in various ways, but there's still no option to simply have this function (aswell as some others, requiring similar actions) bound to a single button. Additionally, binding anything to numbers requires manually editing the key bindings configuration file and there's many keys you can't even bind anything to. There's quite a lot of "you have to reload the game for this to work" moments. You have to exit and reload the game every time you want to trade an item to Snuggly the Crow, you have to exit and reload the game every time a Crystal Lizard doesn't spawn where it's supposed to, but more importantly (annoyingly) - you can actually avoid certain deaths in boss fights if you simply exit the game during the fight. There's no way to re-spec your character after allocating stat points (which happens when you level up). This is probably the single most annoying thing on this list, as fulfilling stat requirements and hitting certain breakpoints is what makes or breaks a character build. I cannot stress how crucial this is in the game. If you make a mistake early on in your stat allocation, which you inevitably will, you'll be stuck with it unless you start a new character from scratch. There are several boss fights which are completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, One of them is unfairly difficult, unless you bug it out and trivialise it (like 95% of people do, whereas the other 5% post threads on forums complaining that bugging the encounter out does not work for them) and the other has some basic platforming in it. That jump, that one jump almost makes the game fall apart completely. Some quests require that you have read several different Wikis / watched videos on Youtube on how to complete them, as there is literally no way you'll get them done if you rely on the game to work as intended. In fact, you most likely won't have fun getting through the game for the first time if you don't read Wikis or watch videos, or both.Closing ThoughtsIf you haven't played this game, you're really missing out. There is the hassle of getting it to work as it should, with setting up mods, dealing with the controls and whatnot, but if you're tired of formulaic games that spoonfeed you the same watered-down experience in different packages and want to get into some real action and ruin other people's lives (and yours), this is definitely the game for you. Prepare to die.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
***Spoiler-Free Review***Dark Souls is by far, the most immersive, addictive, and well-rounded RPG I have played in many years. I recommend true RPG afficionados to play it. That being said here is a brief run-down of the most common quesions I have received from early adopters:-The Difficulty - While it is a game that is willing to punish the player, it does not do so unfairly. If you are the kind of player who expects to run headlong into an ambush of 12 undead skeletons and live to tell the tale, this is not the game for you. You gain no special status by being the player, other than your ability to learn. If you like that, you will LOVE this game. If you dislike having to learn how to play a game properly, you will dislike this game. It is that simple. The immense sense of accomplishment you gain from learning more about this game is what keeps players coming back again and again.- Level Design - Dark Souls understands something that I think Bethesda has missed with Skyrim, and that is that the immensity of a map does not equate to content. Dark souls is by no means a monster of a game, but the number of things to do and places to explore is quite overwhelming. Every nook and cranny of the game is jam-packed with new characters, invisible walls, diverse weapons, and extensions of the storyline. Another thing that is to be applauded is the masterful connectivity between areas. You may not know where you are until you find a shortcut to some previous area you had been. Learning about these shortcuts makes the map a bit easier to traverse, but also puts on display the genius of the game designers. Everything is connected and makes perfect geographical sense. The use of depth to create distance and elevators to reduce it was a stroke of pure genius. It makes it all the more satisfying to travel to an area using the shortcut you found.- The Story - There is as much story in Dark Souls as you want there to be. That is not cryptic language or market-speak either. If you so wish, you can completely ignore the story of Dark Souls and kill everything in the game. For a lore-lover like myself, that would be a travesty. Through dialogue of the NPCs as well as item descriptions, you can gain insight into this deep, rich, and intriguing universe full of betrayals, discovery, wonder, and of course darkness. Many of the NPCs who aid you in battle have motivations, hopes, and backstories of their own which give them reasons to help you along in your quest. Discovering these relationships and motivations is part of Dark Souls' charm.- The Combat - Dark Souls uses a very deceptively simple combat system. Without going into too much detail, melee combat consists of timed attacks and blocking as well as some critical attacks, while the various magics are mediated through their respective "wands". When you kill enemies, you acquire souls, the world's currency. These can be used for leveling up, buying items at vendors, or improving items at blacksmiths. Dark Souls rewards players greatly for specializing early, but does not punish those who choose to spread their experience points around. Upgrading weapons and armor encourages you to try many different configurations to find the one that suits you as well as the different enemies you are fighting. For example, you may want to have high fire-resistance for a dragon fight, if you intend to take the flames head on. Another major factor is that Dark Souls contains dynamic weight for your character. Want to wear 120 lbs of armor? That's fine, but you will have to accept that your character is going to move around like a sloth until they are strong enough to move around in it comfortably. All of these factors combined make battles in Dark Souls different every time you play them.- The Bottom Line - So is Dark Souls good? I would go beyond saying Dark Souls is good. It is masterfully simple, rewardingly addictive, and unbelievably rich. If any game this decade was worth full retail, it is this one. And you won't even have to pay that anymore! So buy it!

Posted: January 9, 2015
												Let's see.. are you the kind of gamer who's into... Looking for a very challenging but fair game? Something that allows you to play any class or style you want to? A game in which has amazing lore that isn't upfront about it? An experience that will leave you unable to play games like Skyrim ever again? NPCs and characters that will impact you even after you have turned off the game? Jolly co-operation? Holds a DLC that is without a doubt mind blowingly fantastic? Serves you with replay value up to several runs or completely new runs?If any of these clicked with yah, than may I introduce you to Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition as the best candidate for the job. Seriously a masterpiece of a game that at first glance... seems like a hard game. You'll probably die often which will rustle your pants, but when you really pay attention and look into the lore... my god, it's REALLY deep. Apart from games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age, along with Elder Scrolls series- this game holds a record for most hidden lore in gaming history.Mechanics are so well done, that I can't enjoy games like Skyrim anymore without thinking back to how well Dark Souls plays out with the fighting, the classes, how weapons function, ect. I must admit, the co-op needs better support for the servers lack good connection plus how the leveling system works with co-op is flawed. Apart from that, I sincerely pray everyone gives this game a chance. It's one of my top 10 favorite games of all time!

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												If there's a modern video-game series that can be considered "Balls-to-the-wall hard" or "Nintendo hard"(NES era, mind you), then most people will think of Dark Souls. That being said, after you've finished this game, you'll probably be thinking that The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is for pre pubescent girls. But let me get a little more in-depth on why you should (or shouldn't):Gameplay 8/10: A few MMO/RPG elements are involved in Dark Souls; mainly with stat allocation that includes upgrading strength, dexterity, endurance, etc. with the immensely versatile souls. However, there's quite a few factors that make Dark Souls vastly different than a standard third person hack and slash fantasy. The souls work as both a source of experience points and currency, as well as magic that oddly enough does not rely on the use of mana but rather a predetermined quality that can be used between safe points (Bonfires) are good example that there's a lot of fantasy elements that are changed to the point where Dark Souls can be its own unique thing.Covenants are also a rather unique factor in Dark Souls, as they are the only source of direct online interaction. Like weapons or attributes, covenants can also determine depending solely on your play-style. Do you like PvP and being an evil butt? Try the elusive Darkwraiths. Prefer to have jolly cooperation? Try out the Warrior of Sunlight. Or maybe you just want more honourable duels? Consider Path of the Dragon. All of these alliances play major roles within the PvP/Co-Op scene, and allows for further character customization.There are a couple of flaws with gameplay though, the main issue being the port from Console to Personal Computer systems. Though a lot of bugs with online play and other PC issues have been fixed, the usage of keyboard+mouse is almost always surpassed by using a controller due to the poor controls, making it feel like Dark Souls was never intended to be a PC game. If you have a controller (Playstation brand can work but Xbox is much more suitable), then this issue won't be a huge problem for you.Graphics 7/10: Nothing's really changed significantly between the ports, so Dark Souls loses points for that, along with the lack of mouth movement when people talk, and that Xbox controls are still used within the game (ie. press "B" to evade, when it's space on the Keyboard or triangle on Playstation controllers). All these little factors urk me to no end, but I'm not all negative about the graphics (I gave it a 7 after all).On the flip side, the designs of a majority of the creatures and armors are very creative compared to quite a bit of fantasy titles, yet still adds a couple of very cliché monsters (namely: rats and skeletons) to change it up. PC specs are not super demanding, so a lot of people can play Dark Souls without much lag or FPS drops. Some NPC designs are outright deceiving (Petrus of Thorolund is a great example) and it may surprise some players that silly looking characters may be very useful.. Or possibly the opposite~Difficulty 8/10: Ah yes, the most controversial topic. I'm not going to judge this on glitches/exploits or faulty controls, just full on, pure difficulty within the game. You essentially begin the first 5 minutes fighting a 30 foot demon with a broken, rusted half of a sword. That alone should set in what the game has in store for you. Dark Souls' difficulty is fairly consitant and does gradually get more hard up until the halfway point. A lot of bosses initially seem difficult, but when you know of a strategy against them, they become a lot more tolerable with your newly found MLG strats.But then, you'll come across the infamous duo, Dragonslayer Ornstein and Executioner Smaugh. Arguably the most difficult bosses in the game, these two will be the deciding factor on whether or not you can win Dark Souls or completely give up. So why mention these behemoths of boss battles? After this point, the difficulty fluctuates, but never really gets harder than this point. This is a fairly severe flaw in my opinion because of how early on this occurs, and these two should appear much later-- even second-to-last bosses of the game. After you deal with them, you can probably just take on any boss/enemy from that point on, which can be a little grating.Story 8/10: It's vague. Not as vague as say, Five Nights at Freddy's, but it's up there. This does the whole "Chosen One" cliché but with a little more finesse; as a majority of people in the game are simply unaware of it and you simply have no idea who to trust and who not to. This can create a sort of isolated feeling, which is very strange when it is your generic "Chosen One" story. People'll either treat you like dirt or as a simple friend, but nothing really outside of that with the exception of deities and alike who are aware. There's also a nice mix of personalities: You've got the Crestfallen Warrior and Merchant who's shady and pessimistic respectively, but characters like Solaire of Astoria or Siegmeyer of Catarina are a few who are jolly, humble and optimistic about their undeath makes you want to keep going or like them a lot more than most. A blend of characters, although limited, is well done in this title.Overall: I can ramble on about this game for hours upon hours, but I'll leave it as that. Dark Souls is one of those games that is truly unexpecting. You think you're going through a game that is just meant to tear your butt a new one, but has some hidden strategies, fairly good characters and story. If you want a challenge and have that special little high of accomplishing a difficult level or killing off a hard boss, this is the game for you.If you're susceptible to rage, short-patience, or hit things and hope for the best, you might want to stick with Skyrim.

I highly recommend buying this game!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												First: yes, the port isn't really good. It's pretty much a straight port from Xbox 360 without much work done to accommodate the game for the PC. Second: modders fixed the greatest problems with it, which makes this game far more enjoyable.You are the Chosen One. Destined to save the world. You know, like always. The twist? You are undead. Dying isn't something you need to be really afraid of. You actually shouldn't be afraid of dying, because you will die. A lot.It's a tough game. Even your standard enemies might pose a threat to you.And then come the bosses. Not only can they be quite big and hit REALLY hard, simple attacking them won't do you any good.Learn their attack patterns. Learn when to strike. And after you've learned, die a lot and try again until you get it.Afraid to face the bosses alone? Try jolly co-operation! Turn into a human at a bonfire, summon a player and try to tackle the boss together! But beware of invaders! As soon as you turn human, other players can invade and attack you. And believe me, they will.You also may find some messages left by other players; warning you of great danger, pointing you to amazing chests or tell you to roll down a cliff (don't do that).Be aware that there might be cheaters around, so if you wanna be save from other players, stay undead, but keep in mind that you won't be able to do co-op that way.The story may not be the greatest, but the lore is quite extensive, albeit mostly hidden behind conversations (with some really messed up people) and item descriptions. You want to know something about the world you're in? You'll need to work for it.This also isn't your typical medival fantasy world. There are no populated towns or cities filled with NPCs, shops and quests. It's a post-apocalyptic world, where death and destruction reign supreme.You will encounter the odd friendly NPC here and there, but don't♥♥♥♥♥♥them off or they will try to kill you. Again and again.Beat the game without breaking a sweat? Try New Game+! Done that? Try New Game++! And that gets one for a while.Imo an absolutely fantastic game with a great art direction and lots of challenges to conquer.I'm really glad this game came to the PC. And it did so because of a petition! Isn't that amazing? How often does something like that work?In this regard: Praise the Sun and prepare to die! A lot.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												PREPARE TO DIE.It's not often when a game's subtitle not only warns me of what lies ahead, but is in fact accurate in such words. You should prepare to die before you start playing this because you will most certainly die. Quite alot. But you probably knew this already, since this game has developed a reputation for itself for being very difficult... and very good. Both are deserved. I'm not going to dig too much into the gameplay and story for this review though, but rather just clearly lay out some things that I feel are worth mentioning:First, you do not need a controller to play this game. You do not need a controller to do well at this game. You do not need a controller to beat this game. My achievements page is living proof of this. You do need mods, specifically dsfix (get this anyway, controller or not), Mouse Fix (or dsmfix), and probably some sort of graphic thing so that you will get keyboard buttons displayed instead of controller ones (You can get all of these mods on the Dark Souls Nexus site: http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls ). Mouse sensitivity will be a problem even with it set to its maximum, but you can manage through with a mix of scrolling and good use of the "targeting" button that either forces you to look at a enemy or the direction your character is facing.Is it easier with a controller? No idea. Don't have one. People say it is, but for someone like me who hasn't played console games since the PS2 and therefore would probably do worse with a console simply due to lacking familiarity, I decided to take my chances - and it paid off.You will die alot, but only a few times did I actually start getting frustrated, and that had more to do with my poor execution than the game itself*. Dark Souls is hard, but not cruel. The approach I ended up taking with this game was putting my years of WoW raiding experience to use and treating the bosses in this game much as I did in that smelly MMO. Namely, to figure out what the boss can do, what patterns it might have and recognize them, then kick its♥♥♥♥♥when you are comfortable and know what the foe can do.And that leads to my last thing to bring up: the old saying 'knowledge is power' is very much key here. The more you know, the better you will do at this game. Whether through game experience, going over the excellent wikis, or a combination of the two, figuring out how to deal with the countless lethal situations you will end up in will be of great value. Really, the hardest parts of the game are in the beginning, when you still are just messing about and are not really sure how everything works just yet. Once you do, the game becomes, if not easy, then at least easier to progress through. And when you do finally beat the game, you can be happy that you took the best this "super hard game" threw at you and that you were able to overcome it...and then you can do New Game+. Woohoo for more madness! :DAnyway, it's good. Play it because I said so... or something.*(Except for the Bed of Chaos. ♥♥♥♥ that boss.)

content:
Posted: November 8, 2012
												One of the best games i have ever played, period. This action RPG has everything. Including a very high difficulty level. Which is a good thing. As when you finally down a huge boss that has killed you numerous times the sense of satisfaction is immense. If you choose a ranged, magic or melee character (or a mix) the combat is perfect. Every fight is an epic battle. And the bosses are awesome. All 24 of them (give or take 1). The world is huge, varied and non linear. And the PVP/Co-op is unique and fun.Right then now the important part. The standard vanilla game looks awful. It's a straight up port and runs in a muddy 720p @30fps. AND the sound is broken!However all 3 are easily fixed by mods. The textures are so detailed when you crank the res up (you can go way up and downsample to 1080p) it looks beautiful. The 60 fps mod runs like a dream and the quick sound fix restores the entire sound to what it is supposed to be like. It really does make a difference to the atmosphere.EDIT. The sound bug has now been fixed in the last patch :)

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												What can I say? The game was absolutely incredible. I recently beat Bloodborne when it came out, and it was my first real experience with a "souls" type game. I couldnt stop playing it until I finished it, and thats what led me to start seeking out other games made by From Software.So my first choice was this, dark souls. Once you get past the intimidating learning curve, the game opens up to be one of the very best action rpgs out there. My first play through clocked in around 100 hours. The reason being is I took my time and did quite a bit of PvP as well as finishing the DLC before continuing with the main story. The one thing I absolutely love about this game, is that I feel that 99.9% of the time, when you die its your fault and not the game cheating you. The more you die, the more you learn about the enemies. Its a game that requires you to learn the entire map and enemy placements like no other game. Its crazy, when I think in my mind I can map out pretty much the entire game in my mind as well as which enemies are where, and its because its a game that requires you to pay such close attention to detail. All in all, incredible game. Cant wait to get into dark souls 2 scholar of the first sin :D

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This is an edit:At first, I didn't really like the game that much, I tried to speedrun it, only killing the necessary bosses dying all the time, didn't see why that was fun. Didn't enjoy killing bosses, so I quit the game.But then, over 3 years later, I decided to give it a try once more. But this time with a different approach. This time, I would take my time exploring, but also killing every boss. Not only that, but I did some research on what weapons I should use for my style of playing, and for the type of character I created, also I found out what I should spend my souls on.This was a gamechanger for me, because first I just wanted to finish the game, therefore I didn't get the amount of souls that was necessary for me. Now I managed to get further than ever before, because I explored, I picked up items I had never seen before, I got loads of souls to level up, bosses actually became a lot easier than I originally expected them to be.I went for full heavy massive attacks, heavy armor, loads of Vitality, Endurance and Strength.Suddenly I started to appreciate the game, the world and the mood. I still don't feel anything special for killing the bosses, but I appreciate the bosses in a different way, they are actually kinda awesome!If you keep dying forever, then maybe there is something you are missing? Maybe you are rushing too much? Take a step back and observe, even do some research if that's more your style ;)

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Dark Souls has a reputation for being a hard game.  I write to clarify that.  Unfortunately, Dark Souls is not difficult because of inventive game mechanics, difficult puzzles, extremely tight hand-eye coordination requirements, etc.  This game is difficult because it is broken out-of-the-box and unplayable without some DIY patching, and otherwise generally poorly coded. Upon loading it for the first time, you'll notice some things:  Resolution doesn't match your settings, the mouse is jittery, the keyboard layout makes zero sense, etc.  God help me, is this a PC game where ESC doesn't open the menu!? Yes!  I have to push a different button to cancel out of a menu depending on which menu it is?  ♥♥♥♥'s sake, guys.  This is a♥♥♥♥♥♥pile beyond all imagining.  Let's say you fix it with some patches, push it to something resembling a professionally made PC game.  Now you get to experience the atrocious bow aiming system, the inability to actually hit a target where you're aiming (target reticle alignment is off for range beyond 25 feet), etc.  Collision is trash - don't bother trying to aim from the left side of a cover wall, you'll have arrows getting stuck in the middle of nowhere.  Backstabs?  Roll the dice if you must, but you're better off not counting on them given the inconsistent nature.  If you find a way to be cheap, you can sneak your way through, taking pot shots at enemies to kill them, resorting to cheesy techniques like abusing the poor walkable terrain mapping for AI (looking at you, crystal giants at Darkroot Basin.)  Still, you'll find yourself at boss battles which are, again, tests in your ability to abuse the poorly-refined fight mechanics rather than tactics and execution. All in all, I killed a lot of bosses and explored most of the game's areas.  Through every minute of it, the nagging feeling that I was pressing on out of stubborness rather than fun made it impossible to continue.  I quit after killing the bellkeepers and the hydra, upon realizing that there was no true challenge in this game - no test of skill, no trials of quick thinking and twitch.  This game is about banging your ♥♥♥♥ing head against the wall until you make a dent - and hoping you don't get randomly invaded by a PVPer upon finding yourself a nice cache of souls. Pass on this trash.
