content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game. This ONE game.This game sits as a must-have for those who love a challenge. Those who want to explore any path, at any time, in any fashion, this game is built for you. It's difficult to say just WHY It's so good, it just is. From the open world freedom to the player flexibility, It's hard to tell which is better.While most RPGs will have you choose a class and that'll be that, restricting items you can use based on your chosen class, this game abolishes that. You can start a Mage character, but turn it into a tank of Rage and Destruction. The level design is Incredible, enemes are challenging and there are plenty of secrets to find, from weapons to places. The multiplayer is the most innovative and unique experiences I've played, with Singleplayer and Multiplayer seamlessly intertwined with one another. Within this game there are two states that affect your Online experiences: Hollow and Human. Whilst Hollow, you cannot Summon other players to aid you, Invade other players (unless using specific invasion items) or Be Invaded yourself, like a limited online mode. Human form allows you to Summon other players to help you, Invade other players and Be Invaded yourself, the Full Online experience.Again, if you Love challenges, Amazing Game Design and piecing things together yourself (I forgot to mention how much of a minimalistic game this is), then this game is a mmust have.Praise the Sun, and Prepare to Die... Alot!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Dark SoulsPrepare To Die EditionGenre : Action-RPGRating: 10/10Comment : It's the best game I've ever played. It deserved a better pc port'Dark Souls' is a complex dark fantasy action role-playing game that is played from a third person perspective. It has a direct combat system similar to games like the 'Zelda' series. Unlike those it comes with a multiplayer feature: You can cooperatively take on bosses or fight other players to the death. The game is challenging and very rewarding once you achieve something. There are tons of secrets to discover be it gamplay- or story-wise. All these things add up to a high replay value.In my humble opinion 'Dark Souls' is a masterpiece and should be seen as a milestone of videogame history. Edit : Now that Dark Souls works with steamworks I played the game again. Arriving at the 'Firelink Shrine' felt like coming home and I realized that Dark Souls is my all time favourite game. So I changed the rating from 9,5 to 10 although the game still has its technical issues.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												It's hard to put into words why I like Dark Souls so much. Well let me just say that you're going to need the patience of a saint, fast reflexes, and the ability to adapt to any situation at any given time if you want to get through this game in it's entirety. Now moving on to the gameplay itself, it's just wonderful. To put it simply, melee combat is the base of this game. You posess a wide variety of swords, bows, sheilds, and magic to defeat the many deadly mobs of enemies that you'll meet in the game. There are many game mechanics that make this game different from other melee focused games, but for now, let's just start with the basics. For starters, there are many ways you can swing and control your weapon. You can attack in light basic swings, or you can go for more damaging and slower attacks. Either way, you'll need to figure out which set of attacks is needed for the current situation. Then there is the ability to parry and riposte. Sure, you can sit there and swing your sword mindlessly, which will most likely get you killed, or you can parry your foes attack, leaving them wide open for a riposte, or counter attack, dealing massive critical damage. Another game mechanic that changes up the playstyle of the game, is the ability to dodge. Sure it doesn't sound so impressive at first, but Dark Souls puts a lot of emphasis into dodging. You could just go through the entire game with a sheild, (wut r u casul m8?) but before you know it, enemies are becoming so strong, that they're able to blast through your sheild like it's nothing. That's where dodging becomes essential. You have the ability to roll through enemies attacks thanks to the use of invincibility frames. Dodging takes a considerable amount of skill, timing, and practice and is one of the game mechanics that really challenges your ability to memorize attack patterns and really take into account how easy it is to screw up and die, which is why I think it's a mechanic that really spices up things in Dark Souls. Anyway these mechanics and so much more really add to why this game's combat is so rewarding and satisfying. Imagine just dying over and over to a boss that you're trying so hard to kill. Then you start to memorize his attack patterns, the way he swings his weapon, how he swings his weapon, how he telegraphs his attacks. You then start dodging all his attacks flawlessly, using patterns of light and heavy swings to take him down with each dodge. The feeling of absolute victory and triumph is what will keep you wanting more. With that being said, I will move on to the environment and world itself. Dark Souls does not have a very linear path or objective, in fact, it encourages you to go in different paths and learn what the objective is for yourself. The game will not hold your hand, and if you die, then that's on you. All the mistakes and deaths are made by you and created by you, so don't blame the game if you're sucking. The most reasonable solution is to just git gud and stop being a casul scrub. Honestly, the environment really supports the vibe of complete loneliness and helplessness. You won't be having much social interactions in this game, save for a few NPC's and most of the time your only company is going to be the mobs of enemies around you. Overall, Dark Souls is a very unforgiving experience that will only get worse with your impatience and lack of skill and know how. If you manage to get past all that, however, and actually learn from your mistakes and manage to not get fed up with the amounts of death and stress you'll have to deal with, then it becomes one of the most memorable and rewaring experiences you could ever have in gaming, ever.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game. This ONE game.This game sits as a must-have for those who love a challenge. Those who want to explore any path, at any time, in any fashion, this game is built for you. It's difficult to say just WHY It's so good, it just is. From the open world freedom to the player flexibility, It's hard to tell which is better.While most RPGs will have you choose a class and that'll be that, restricting items you can use based on your chosen class, this game abolishes that. You can start a Mage character, but turn it into a tank of Rage and Destruction. The level design is Incredible, enemes are challenging and there are plenty of secrets to find, from weapons to places. The multiplayer is the most innovative and unique experiences I've played, with Singleplayer and Multiplayer seamlessly intertwined with one another. Within this game there are two states that affect your Online experiences: Hollow and Human. Whilst Hollow, you cannot Summon other players to aid you, Invade other players (unless using specific invasion items) or Be Invaded yourself, like a limited online mode. Human form allows you to Summon other players to help you, Invade other players and Be Invaded yourself, the Full Online experience.Again, if you Love challenges, Amazing Game Design and piecing things together yourself (I forgot to mention how much of a minimalistic game this is), then this game is a mmust have.Praise the Sun, and Prepare to Die... Alot!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Three-hundred hours in I guess it deserves a review...If you just start playing this game blind without watching four or five "How to play Dark Souls" videos on youtube, this is a terrible game. Dense, dense, dense. It doesn't tell you how to move, how combat works, or what the game is even about. You've heard that the game is hard, and it is, but before you get over this hump it is technically impossible to play. Some say this is horrible game design, some say it's dense on purpose because it's for "hardcore gamers." I'll leave it up to you to decide whether not explaining the mechanics of the game is terrible or hardcore.Ok, now you know how to actually play the game. Now it's no longer impossible, it's just rage inducingly difficult. It almost seems unfair. I mean how are you supposed to fight three enemies one once? This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t! Then, on the fifth or sixth time you reach that encounter you realize that if you just strategically take them out, have a plan, think it through, you can take them all out. Sneak up and backstab this guy. Parry then riposte that guy. Roll, block, then strong attack the other guy. This is starting to work. I'm gittin' gud a this!Wait! What in Zeus' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is that giant thing!? It's 28 feet tall! It just one shot me!Five or six tries in you begin to see a pattern. Around fifteen to sixteen attempts you start actually getting it down near half health.  On your eight-millionth attempt you are like Neo in the Matrix, rolling out of the way of huge one-shot capable attacks. Dropping two handded attacks on it that take a fifth of it's life off.  You get it. You are in The Zone. You now understand how to play this game. It dies. A luminescent beam streams onto your silhouette as dust motes dance in the ribbon of light around you. A chorus of angels sing. You are God.Then you find the next area and you begin crying.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Abandon the notion that you will  - Play this with the gaming keyboard you spent hundreds of dollars on.-This game will be easy-This game will tell you where to go or give you any indication This is something of a new game, the first of its kind for PC.To enable 60 FPS you will need to get an easy to access yet moderately difficult to optimize mod. This is an action game with hack and slash action. Now, the thing is? It punishes a simple idiot who just berserker slashes his way across the world, because you are gonna run out of energy and get cut.You have an HP bar, magic uses (depending on your job) and an endurance bar. You get tired, yoru character is vulnerable, and the weapons he can use depend on his or her stats. This game epitomizes the word "difficult" to newbies. It is uncompromising, unfair, and in a lot of ways it is like life. When I say it is like life, imagine this. You are going into a bad neighborhood, and you are a normal guy with a weapon. And you know what's in a bad neighborhood,  a bunch of normal guys with weapons. If these guys manage to kill you, tough. Restart from a bonfire that somehow bothers to heal you, pick up your dead corpse and raise you from the dead. The game gets harder. Soon you go up against elite soldiers : Pikachu and Snorlax, "The man" who is the CEO of a hoarde of ♥♥♥♥in ugly deads,  a blind dragon who is also a scientist who betrayed his own kind, an angry woman who ♥♥♥♥ed herself up, and the old grandpa who won't let go of the past because he was the warrior who built this town from dust.You have to kill them all and become the next lord of the world. Now, let me put that in perspective. You're a normal joe and this game throws you at things that are stronger than you, but you will preservere and advance. You will absorb their essence and you will become stronger than a CEO. You will build something, and you will either martyr yourself for a small change or be the next big CEO who runs this♥♥♥♥♥♥with a bunch of evil snake things bowing before you. What the hell does all of that mean? Find your own answers, fuccboi.

												I'm only 5 hours in and I haven't gotten anywhere. It's tough. It's addicting. I recommend it! This is coming from someone who rarely plays RPGs. I almost didn't buy this game cause of the things I read about its shoddy conversion to PC, but I took the leap. Installed DSfix, applied a texture upgrade pack, applied a nice SweetFX preset and off I went ...into the brutal world of Dark Souls. At the rate I'm going, I'll be done when I'm 50.There are reports of glitches with 60 fps, so to avoid them, I set a fps cap of 59 in Rivatuner. On a G-Sync monitor, there really is no difference between the two framerates. Smooth at all times.Alrighty then, back to playing Dark Souls...EDIT: I have given up. I'm not gonna play till I'm 50 and jeopardize my marriage for this sh!tload of föck. Neeewwwwwp! Bye bye! Dark Souls, welcome to my "Just don't bother" games list. :P

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												I would describe myself as very new to Dark Souls having not played any of the sequels yet either. With almost 80 hours into DS:PTDE I can say that this would already make it into my top 10 easily.This game can be as deep or superficial as you like depending on your preference and time available to you. On the surface it is a difficult and challenging explorative action game with a decent fighting system that requires patience and strategy, and an intriguing world that provides a looming, fantastical backdrop. Dig deeper and you find that every NPC has a deep backstory and the world is dark and full of a sense of disparing melancholia that speaks thoughout the entire narrative. The level design is among the best I've have seen in recent years as every part of the world feels connected and is cleverly and thoughtfully conceived. The first playthrough (which I still have not completed by this point btw) makes this even more rewarding as you discover how the areas are linked to one another.If you've been thinking about giving the Dark Souls a try the answer is yes and the first one is - as you'd expect - an excellent place to start.*Xbox Controller (or steam pad) recommended!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												There has never been, and I wonder if there ever will be, a game that has had me so immersed and invested. Everything in this game is deliberate, and while hard as nails, there are very few occasions where you feel that the game is unfair. Going into a new area sword swinging and expecting to win will get you slaughtered. Going slow and studying ones surroundings will save you from said death.Unlike many modern titles, Dark Souls never forces the story down your throat, but there is a wide array of lore and detail that an observant eye and an inquisitive mind can discover. And while certain set-pieces are unavoidable, you can play through the game however you want.The replay value is amazing as well. A character based on strength and heavy weapons will play completely different than a nimble and fast character, and all three approaches to magic are distinguised and unique from one another, demanding different playstyles and creating a new experience every time. I have likely made over 50 characters so far, and I still find new and interesting combinations and approaches that I have yet to try, or challenges and limitations to truly test my skill.I would go so far as to say it is my favorite game of all time, and I have been gaming since the Commodore 64.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Firstly this is the Marmite of PC games you will love it or hate it, it will make you rage, you will get frustated and you will alt+F4 thats the game, but once you begin to realise the basic mechanics and the concept of patience you begin to enjoy it, and get into it, the sense of satisfaction of beating a boss after it has crapped all over you for hours is why you keep playing, the game doesnt hold your hand your taught basics and the rest is up to you.  To find your way around and where to go you need to read item descriptions and talk to the NPC's you encounter, which draw you into the lore and story of the world.Artistically the game looks and feels great it isnt too over the top and everything looks glorious, from the fires of lost izeleth to the sunny city of Anor Londo things look and feel different and the enemies encountered will have you saying WTF!? at points.Theres hundreds of secrets and hidden things lots of different ways to play no this is best build, this is how you beat this boss easy, you do what you want to overcome the challenge so much depth and variety in character and weapon upgrades you can make truly unique combinations, this however also has its downsides as after 80+ hours played i still dont know anything about the differnt weapon upgrades and the differences between a Raw Weapon and a Normal +15 weapon, fire lightning curse and divine are all modifiers for diff enemy types but not required to defeat them.i could go on for ages but i will just score itgraphics 9/10 DSfix makes it look glorious but loses points because its a mod u have to downloadsound 9/10 no real problems but no real stand out iconic soundtrack, its sets the atmosphere and draws you in which is what they wanted i guessCombat 10/10 once you learn what each stat means poise stability etc, and work out how to fight effectively its a realistic enough system and feels good, backstabs parrys feel extra satisfying.Story 7/10 I love the story but feel its told in a way that leaves you with too many gaps to fill in, guess thats the intrigue and why you play more to see bits you missed before or find out what happens if you do something different, I really like this way of story telling but just feel it could have been done in a more conclusive way, you are left assuming too much by the end, a little clarification of what happens and why would have been welcome. To enjoy the story, and to get it you NEED to talk to everyone and listen to what they say and read item descriptions even on armour, wepaons, and items you use they all add extra layers to your understanding or extra questions that you seek answers for, its Awesome how it makes you think, but for some i feel the lack of a conclusive ending or a Clear end may put them off.Overall a mighty 9/10 from me, you will need patience and you will get mad, but just turn it off and keep coming back, dont try to play it like diablo you cant take everything on at once, one at a time learn the enemies learn the parry points if you want to show off and feel real good but mostly just Take your time look around and ENJOY it.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I am an avid gamer, especially for RPG's, and I must say, first time I played Dark Souls, I got brutally murdered, over and over. However, it is a major learning game that the more you play and die, and learn the environment, the more it rewards you with the knowledge from the countless deaths and time spent learning. Expect to die. Expect to die a lot, the game developer, FromSoftware, even tells you "Prepare to Die", but don't let that deter you from this amazing and immersive game. The evironments are rather different and will allow you to learn each one.When you feel you know the game well enough, make a new character with new fighting styles, go full Dexterity, handling fast, but light hitting weapons, or go heavy, hard hitting with Strength, or balance the two out. Melee not your thing? Make a pyromancer, mage, or cleric, calling upon the powers of the fire, magic, or miracles. Mix and match your character and find a build that feels fit for you. I say nearly infinite replayability with the sheer amount of possible builds, as well as challenge builds/runs you can set for yourself (I currently and going through the game as a level 1 character).As for tips, the best I can offer would be to explore and focus on learning everything you can from every death. Oh, and I highly recommend getting a PS3 controller or Xbox 360 controller to play this, since the mouse+keyboard controls are complete sh*t.As of right now, PvP is kind of dead in most areas, but it still can be rather active, especially with the hype for Dark Souls 2 coming right around the corner, people are coming back.To help further your online experience, I would highly recommend downloading the DSfix and DSCfix mods, for better graphics and FPS and allowing you to connect to people on your Games for Windows Live friends list much easier and faster. Do not worry however, DSCfix does NOT affect random summonings or invading, it simply helps team you and friends up.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I've recently completed this game upon knowing Dark Souls III would be coming out on April 11th. Probably the best game to experience for the decade in my opinion. It has challenging boss fights with gorgeous music and unique stage designs that all tie into one area, Firelink Shrine, the main bonfire... With such a mysterious story, speaking in things such as metaphores most the time, the game is very hard to understand on a first playthrough. That being said, if you read into each item and piece of equipment you picked up, it contains minor info that you can piece together into something amazingly interesting. A very challenging game it is, not being friendly to new players and unoptimized to all ♥♥♥♥. I've successfully added HD texture mods, as well as an ENB, max settings and all, and I recieve around 75 max fps (capped, it breaks the game engine beyond 60fps most the time) and 30 at the lowest. This game is really worth the time and effort if you enjoy rewarding games that are ceasing to exist in this modern era of gaming. My score? 8.5/10 There's always something that needs to be improved, but this game? It wasn't the content that made me look away for a couple of seconds... as it was how broken the game was for pc upon release. GET A CONTROLLER IF YOU WANT TO PLAY

content:
Posted: September 18, 2012
												Lets get the bad stuff out of the way first. Out of the box, the game only renders at 720p, then upscales and has prety poor mouse and keyboard controls.Both of these were actually fixed by modders either right after release or shortly before. The game does look amazing with downsampling, SSAO, and SSMA after the Durante fix. And from what I hear the mouse patch is great, though I use a controller which works perfectly.With that out of the way, the game actually runs really well and plays even better. Already one of my favorite games of all time, with serious replayability.  The game is incredibly deep and has a great multiplayer online system for co-op and pvp. I get a constant 30 fps as well, which rarely dips and only about a 40-60% gpu usage even with the higher fidelity settings.I'm a first time player, but the new content was some of the best in the game. Definitley a great pickup.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, plain and simple.However, I think the fact that it's known for being difficult really undersells what this game is about. Yes, it's got a rather steep difficulty curve. Most players that start off may only play the first hour and turn it off because they have no idea what's going on. Fewer still will power through and break the wall that is the first area. The game is hard... but that's not what makes this game amazing. Not even close.What really sells this game for me is the atmosphere and the enemy/level design. This is high fantasy at its finest, and this isn't something you want to miss if you enjoy things such as magic and swords. Each area is unique and plays wonderfully off the themes commonly found in Tolkein-esque fantasy.And yet it's something all its own.Also, the swordplay is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing and the combat mechanics are really deep and involved. You'll have difficulty finding a game like this where combat mechanics actually work as well as they do without being overly complicated.10/10, come play it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Firstly, Dark Souls for PC is a terrible port, but I believe a patch solves many of its problems. You need to install a patch for PC (http://uk.ign.com/articles/2012/08/24/upgrade-dark-souls-pc-version-visuals) which counters the limited resolution. Just make sure you disable anti-aliasing or the game window will not be fully visible. Recommended for fans of challenging games. This isn't achievement in the form of random steam achievements, but learning how to fight each individual enemy. The sucessful player dispatches their enemies through correct timing of blocking, attacking and dodging. Weapon types are numerous and actually matter, especially the balance between thrusting and slashing attacks. However, once you have selected a weapon or two, it is hard to change due to commiting to weapon upgrades. Also, I would have liked to have seen more variation in combat (more attack combinations). The dark, gritty atmosphere of the game with views stretching long into the distance really make the game for me. While not as open world as I expected, each zone looks flawless and varied compared to the last. The world reminds me a lot of Soul Reaver's Nosgoth. In the same way, the world is fairly unoccupied creating a feeling of bleak lonliness. You, the player, know that the only way out is defeating boss after boss. Acting as a major negative point against the game is the multiplayer. Really, it is terrible both in design and balance. As an avid PvPer used to high level WoW arena and League of Legends, I found the PvP similar to a max level player ganking a lowbie in Stranglethorn Vale, totally devoid of any skill. Whilst you are meant to be matched to players of similar level, every player coming to my world has been a twinked pyromancer (imbalanced pvp) with an array of bombs. Once they're in your world, they can and will attack you during mid-combat. You can mostly avoid the ganking but some points in the game require you to be very vunerable. If you want to enjoy a vastly difficult co-op campaign together with one of your best buddies, then this isn't for you. But as a single player title, it's fairly solid. 7/10

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game. This ONE game.This game sits as a must-have for those who love a challenge. Those who want to explore any path, at any time, in any fashion, this game is built for you. It's difficult to say just WHY It's so good, it just is. From the open world freedom to the player flexibility, It's hard to tell which is better.While most RPGs will have you choose a class and that'll be that, restricting items you can use based on your chosen class, this game abolishes that. You can start a Mage character, but turn it into a tank of Rage and Destruction. The level design is Incredible, enemes are challenging and there are plenty of secrets to find, from weapons to places. The multiplayer is the most innovative and unique experiences I've played, with Singleplayer and Multiplayer seamlessly intertwined with one another. Within this game there are two states that affect your Online experiences: Hollow and Human. Whilst Hollow, you cannot Summon other players to aid you, Invade other players (unless using specific invasion items) or Be Invaded yourself, like a limited online mode. Human form allows you to Summon other players to help you, Invade other players and Be Invaded yourself, the Full Online experience.Again, if you Love challenges, Amazing Game Design and piecing things together yourself (I forgot to mention how much of a minimalistic game this is), then this game is a mmust have.Praise the Sun, and Prepare to Die... Alot!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												A masterpiece. This game is fabled to extremely challenging, and to any new player, it is. The difficulty in Dark Souls is masked as a lack of knowledge: Once you try something new (be it take a different route, use a different weapon style or talk to a certain npc), you gain KNOWLEDGE. As you play, you learn more and more about the game, arming yourself with the know-how and the strategy to succeed. Dark souls rewards those who are curious enough to try something new, or creative enough to solve problems a different way. If you are willing to think outside the box by learning from your mistakes rather than repeating them, the payoff is huge. That 100th attempt to kill that boss where you succeed makes the 99 times you died seem like it was not so bad, although by death number 20 you were probably ready to smash your controller. The boss fights are all unique, challenging in their own way, and most impressively of all: completely fair. If you died, it was because of your fault. Not the game. The combat in this game is clean cut and impartial. And the mistakes? You will make many. My first playthrough took probably about 50 hours (If I were to guess) and that was with help from a couple of friends giving me some minor hints along the way. You will have to put in the time, serious undivided attention, to get past some areas without external help. Getting your feet wet is the hardest part; once you start swimming (ie understand the basic mechanics of the game) it's a blast. The actual campaign, for an experienced player, does not take very long (4-8 hours, speed-runnable in under 2 hours by experts) once you're armed with all that knowledge in your first rodeo. The game has good replayability (that's a word now!). The single player restarts itself each time you beat it, allowing you to keep all your level ups+equipment, but the monsters get much more lethal. There's a great player vs player system in the game, with almost balanced combat allowing for a huge variety of PvP character builds to be explored. Let's talk about the bad. It's a port - it was made for the Xbox 360. The controls suck for PC, you'll NEED a controller. Seriously. Don't play with a Mouse+KB. Just don't. Get a PS3/Xbox360 controller and MotionJoy software to use it (it's not the greatest piece of software, but it'll do). You'll also need to download a community-made fix, for your resolution unless you enjoy calculator-quality graphics. There are a few minor to not so minor bugs in the game that you may come across. One particular section of the game is very laggy, even on a good computer. Lastly, the connectivity is horrid. It relies on Games for Windows Live, which is terrible for PC gaming. When trying to hook up with a friend to fight a boss, or trying to invade someone to fight another player, you will spend A LOT of time waiting around, failing to join. It sucks, but it does work eventually. A fix exists to better allow players that are friends with each other on GFWL to connect to each other much better, though. I would recommend this game to anyone who has the patience to stick with it and keep trying new things until they succeed, anyone who has the willpower to keep playing without seeking external help to pass an area (that's just cheating yourself; it's seriously not worth it in the end! Your first play through is your most memorable, without a doubt), or to anyone who is looking for a RPG unlike any other modern game available. All in all? The only gaming experience I can compare this to is playing an old Zelda game where you find a new item (say, Flippers) that all of a sudden opens up much of the world that was previously inaccessible to you before. That feeling is Dark Souls - only the you don't have to open a chest to get this empowerment in the form of a new item, you just have to open your mind and explore this masterpiece of a game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Close to one hundred hours and four characters later, I cannot recommend Dark Souls enough.A game that does not hold your hand and tests your patience and tactics, Dark Souls is the first game that I have played that gives you a deep sense of accomplishment. Landing a reposte, even after the thousandth time, fills me with satisfaction.+ Fantastic and rewarding combat+ Many weapons, shields and armor sets to mix & match+ Excellent use of multiplayer (invasions, co-operation and PvP)+ Gorgeous enviroments and ambiance+ Interesting enemy design, each with their own specific attack patterns+ Great level system and statistic allocation+ Deep and enticing lore once invested in+ Lautrec's voice actor ;)- Poor console port; suffers from a locked frame rate, no graphical options, low quality textures and text- Games for Windows Live (From Software has stated they will be changing the infrastructure when this system shuts down July, 2014)- Corrupt save data/no cloud storage (this always happened to me after formatting my computer)This game receives a 9/10 and should not be overlooked even if Dark Souls 2 is slated for release in a couple months.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												(Before reading the following scenario, be aware that the last paragraph is about how awesome this game is and you should get it)_______________________________________________After spending 10-30 minutes crafting a unique character to portray your identity, you find yourself already dead at the beginning of the game, or undead so to speak. This is probably for the best, because if you were to start alive, the game would be more than willing to kill you as many times as it needs to until you've become a bloody conglamerate of what appears to be flesh.For the first 40 hours of gameplay, you are given these instructions; ring two bells. Where? How? Why? Well if it told you, where would the fun be? Instead of having a fluffy NPC tell you "Oh Bob, you should probably turn around and head to undead burg" they take the obviously more effective approach and rather place a prowling demon with 2000 health or a lake of lava containing 7 bosses to kill you, implying the message in your head "Hm... I'm gonna go somewhere else!" Bliighttoown iis graaphiic iinteensiivee aand wiill sloow doown thee fraameeraatees oof thee feeeeblee coompuuteereed.......... Fraameeraatee..... Sloowiing..... DOOOOOOOOWN.......... Get Gamebooster and close chrome :P Oh, and be careful if you have a slower computer. lag likes to cause you to just, kinda... go through elevators, and fall to your death, so when you travel vertically hold REALLY STIILL................... Okay we're at the top alive you're good. Nevermind a knight just stabbed your heart you're dead.If you're new, I can assure you, you should not fight ghosts or skeletons until you have the Lordvessel, and the forest is really just sorta there for you to do whenever you don't die when you try to get in. Oh right, did I mention you'll die a lot? I mean, Prepare To Die Edition, you've been warned. You will lose a lot of souls. It happens. I lost 126,000 once. I didn't care, 'cause Dark Souls bro, duh. Knight Solaire is your friend to assist you in some jolly cooperation for bosses if you're human. Remember that.PRAIIIISE THE SUUUUN!!!-*Cough* ahem, I mean, This game is amazing. I have 5 characters, thief on New Game+ Just remember, when you see the 12 headed dragon of death, you've gone too far. Fight thing's your own strength, and you'll end up in the right place. Prepare to die. Die happy, of course. As long as you have an xBox controller. Keyboard will make you rage quit, the suggestion is actually mandatory. Then... Die happy. \m/

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I am an avid gamer, especially for RPG's, and I must say, first time I played Dark Souls, I got brutally murdered, over and over. However, it is a major learning game that the more you play and die, and learn the environment, the more it rewards you with the knowledge from the countless deaths and time spent learning. Expect to die. Expect to die a lot, the game developer, FromSoftware, even tells you "Prepare to Die", but don't let that deter you from this amazing and immersive game. The evironments are rather different and will allow you to learn each one.When you feel you know the game well enough, make a new character with new fighting styles, go full Dexterity, handling fast, but light hitting weapons, or go heavy, hard hitting with Strength, or balance the two out. Melee not your thing? Make a pyromancer, mage, or cleric, calling upon the powers of the fire, magic, or miracles. Mix and match your character and find a build that feels fit for you. I say nearly infinite replayability with the sheer amount of possible builds, as well as challenge builds/runs you can set for yourself (I currently and going through the game as a level 1 character).As for tips, the best I can offer would be to explore and focus on learning everything you can from every death. Oh, and I highly recommend getting a PS3 controller or Xbox 360 controller to play this, since the mouse+keyboard controls are complete sh*t.As of right now, PvP is kind of dead in most areas, but it still can be rather active, especially with the hype for Dark Souls 2 coming right around the corner, people are coming back.To help further your online experience, I would highly recommend downloading the DSfix and DSCfix mods, for better graphics and FPS and allowing you to connect to people on your Games for Windows Live friends list much easier and faster. Do not worry however, DSCfix does NOT affect random summonings or invading, it simply helps team you and friends up.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I've recently completed this game upon knowing Dark Souls III would be coming out on April 11th. Probably the best game to experience for the decade in my opinion. It has challenging boss fights with gorgeous music and unique stage designs that all tie into one area, Firelink Shrine, the main bonfire... With such a mysterious story, speaking in things such as metaphores most the time, the game is very hard to understand on a first playthrough. That being said, if you read into each item and piece of equipment you picked up, it contains minor info that you can piece together into something amazingly interesting. A very challenging game it is, not being friendly to new players and unoptimized to all ♥♥♥♥. I've successfully added HD texture mods, as well as an ENB, max settings and all, and I recieve around 75 max fps (capped, it breaks the game engine beyond 60fps most the time) and 30 at the lowest. This game is really worth the time and effort if you enjoy rewarding games that are ceasing to exist in this modern era of gaming. My score? 8.5/10 There's always something that needs to be improved, but this game? It wasn't the content that made me look away for a couple of seconds... as it was how broken the game was for pc upon release. GET A CONTROLLER IF YOU WANT TO PLAY

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Firstly this is the Marmite of PC games you will love it or hate it, it will make you rage, you will get frustated and you will alt+F4 thats the game, but once you begin to realise the basic mechanics and the concept of patience you begin to enjoy it, and get into it, the sense of satisfaction of beating a boss after it has crapped all over you for hours is why you keep playing, the game doesnt hold your hand your taught basics and the rest is up to you.  To find your way around and where to go you need to read item descriptions and talk to the NPC's you encounter, which draw you into the lore and story of the world.Artistically the game looks and feels great it isnt too over the top and everything looks glorious, from the fires of lost izeleth to the sunny city of Anor Londo things look and feel different and the enemies encountered will have you saying WTF!? at points.Theres hundreds of secrets and hidden things lots of different ways to play no this is best build, this is how you beat this boss easy, you do what you want to overcome the challenge so much depth and variety in character and weapon upgrades you can make truly unique combinations, this however also has its downsides as after 80+ hours played i still dont know anything about the differnt weapon upgrades and the differences between a Raw Weapon and a Normal +15 weapon, fire lightning curse and divine are all modifiers for diff enemy types but not required to defeat them.i could go on for ages but i will just score itgraphics 9/10 DSfix makes it look glorious but loses points because its a mod u have to downloadsound 9/10 no real problems but no real stand out iconic soundtrack, its sets the atmosphere and draws you in which is what they wanted i guessCombat 10/10 once you learn what each stat means poise stability etc, and work out how to fight effectively its a realistic enough system and feels good, backstabs parrys feel extra satisfying.Story 7/10 I love the story but feel its told in a way that leaves you with too many gaps to fill in, guess thats the intrigue and why you play more to see bits you missed before or find out what happens if you do something different, I really like this way of story telling but just feel it could have been done in a more conclusive way, you are left assuming too much by the end, a little clarification of what happens and why would have been welcome. To enjoy the story, and to get it you NEED to talk to everyone and listen to what they say and read item descriptions even on armour, wepaons, and items you use they all add extra layers to your understanding or extra questions that you seek answers for, its Awesome how it makes you think, but for some i feel the lack of a conclusive ending or a Clear end may put them off.Overall a mighty 9/10 from me, you will need patience and you will get mad, but just turn it off and keep coming back, dont try to play it like diablo you cant take everything on at once, one at a time learn the enemies learn the parry points if you want to show off and feel real good but mostly just Take your time look around and ENJOY it.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Three-hundred hours in I guess it deserves a review...If you just start playing this game blind without watching four or five "How to play Dark Souls" videos on youtube, this is a terrible game. Dense, dense, dense. It doesn't tell you how to move, how combat works, or what the game is even about. You've heard that the game is hard, and it is, but before you get over this hump it is technically impossible to play. Some say this is horrible game design, some say it's dense on purpose because it's for "hardcore gamers." I'll leave it up to you to decide whether not explaining the mechanics of the game is terrible or hardcore.Ok, now you know how to actually play the game. Now it's no longer impossible, it's just rage inducingly difficult. It almost seems unfair. I mean how are you supposed to fight three enemies one once? This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t! Then, on the fifth or sixth time you reach that encounter you realize that if you just strategically take them out, have a plan, think it through, you can take them all out. Sneak up and backstab this guy. Parry then riposte that guy. Roll, block, then strong attack the other guy. This is starting to work. I'm gittin' gud a this!Wait! What in Zeus' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is that giant thing!? It's 28 feet tall! It just one shot me!Five or six tries in you begin to see a pattern. Around fifteen to sixteen attempts you start actually getting it down near half health.  On your eight-millionth attempt you are like Neo in the Matrix, rolling out of the way of huge one-shot capable attacks. Dropping two handded attacks on it that take a fifth of it's life off.  You get it. You are in The Zone. You now understand how to play this game. It dies. A luminescent beam streams onto your silhouette as dust motes dance in the ribbon of light around you. A chorus of angels sing. You are God.Then you find the next area and you begin crying.

Dark souls rewards those who are curious enough to try something new, or creative enough to solve problems a different way. If you are willing to think outside the box by learning from your mistakes rather than repeating them, the payoff is huge. That 100th attempt to kill that boss where you succeed makes the 99 times you died seem like it was not so bad, although by death number 20 you were probably ready to smash your controller. The boss fights are all unique, challenging in their own way, and most impressively of all: completely fair. If you died, it was because of your fault. Not the game. The combat in this game is clean cut and impartial. And the mistakes? You will make many. My first playthrough took probably about 50 hours (If I were to guess) and that was with help from a couple of friends giving me some minor hints along the way. You will have to put in the time, serious undivided attention, to get past some areas without external help. Getting your feet wet is the hardest part; once you start swimming (ie understand the basic mechanics of the game) it's a blast. The actual campaign, for an experienced player, does not take very long (4-8 hours, speed-runnable in under 2 hours by experts) once you're armed with all that knowledge in your first rodeo. The game has good replayability (that's a word now!). The single player restarts itself each time you beat it, allowing you to keep all your level ups+equipment, but the monsters get much more lethal. There's a great player vs player system in the game, with almost balanced combat allowing for a huge variety of PvP character builds to be explored. Let's talk about the bad. It's a port - it was made for the Xbox 360. The controls suck for PC, you'll NEED a controller. Seriously. Don't play with a Mouse+KB. Just don't. Get a PS3/Xbox360 controller and MotionJoy software to use it (it's not the greatest piece of software, but it'll do). You'll also need to download a community-made fix, for your resolution unless you enjoy calculator-quality graphics. There are a few minor to not so minor bugs in the game that you may come across. One particular section of the game is very laggy, even on a good computer. Lastly, the connectivity is horrid. It relies on Games for Windows Live, which is terrible for PC gaming. When trying to hook up with a friend to fight a boss, or trying to invade someone to fight another player, you will spend A LOT of time waiting around, failing to join. It sucks, but it does work eventually. A fix exists to better allow players that are friends with each other on GFWL to connect to each other much better, though. I would recommend this game to anyone who has the patience to stick with it and keep trying new things until they succeed, anyone who has the willpower to keep playing without seeking external help to pass an area (that's just cheating yourself; it's seriously not worth it in the end! Your first play through is your most memorable, without a doubt), or to anyone who is looking for a RPG unlike any other modern game available. All in all? The only gaming experience I can compare this to is playing an old Zelda game where you find a new item (say, Flippers) that all of a sudden opens up much of the world that was previously inaccessible to you before. That feeling is Dark Souls - only the you don't have to open a chest to get this empowerment in the form of a new item, you just have to open your mind and explore this masterpiece of a game.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2012
												Prepare to die, more like Prepare to fix.Be warned, this is one of the worst PC ports I've ever seen.Before you play you'll need to download the resolution fix, because the game locks at 1020x720 regardless of what you pick and just stretches the screen, thus the grahics look blocky and blurred. The resolution fix... fixes that.The screen sensitivity is also absurd, moving way faster than what you may have set. As well as that, when you move the camera it shakes and wobbles for whatever reason.The most unforgivable is the fact that the control prompts (such as 'press mouse 1 to attack') are not properly intergrated. At all. Meaning the game will prompt you to press A, B, X, RB, LB, Move right/left analog stick etc as if you were using a controller... even when your not.Luckily you can change the keys in the option menu, but even then it's clunky.And to top it all off the game uses Games for Windows Live. Great.The game itself is amazing. I'd suggest buying a gamepad.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, plain and simple.However, I think the fact that it's known for being difficult really undersells what this game is about. Yes, it's got a rather steep difficulty curve. Most players that start off may only play the first hour and turn it off because they have no idea what's going on. Fewer still will power through and break the wall that is the first area. The game is hard... but that's not what makes this game amazing. Not even close.What really sells this game for me is the atmosphere and the enemy/level design. This is high fantasy at its finest, and this isn't something you want to miss if you enjoy things such as magic and swords. Each area is unique and plays wonderfully off the themes commonly found in Tolkein-esque fantasy.And yet it's something all its own.Also, the swordplay is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing and the combat mechanics are really deep and involved. You'll have difficulty finding a game like this where combat mechanics actually work as well as they do without being overly complicated.10/10, come play it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												A controller will greatly benefit your experience in this game. I also recommend the DSfix Mod. This is one of those games that feels good to beat. Winning feels like an accomplishment because the game rarely pulls its punches. The world is dangerous and filled with horrible things that want nothing more than to kill you, again and again. But almost everything in the game feels fair. I never truly found myself dieing because the game was unfair. I found myself dieing because I didn't play with a plan, because I rushed in without caution, because I became impatient. It's not a game for everyone. If you don't enjoy the taste of accomplishment that comes from wallowing in defeat you may not enjoy this game. If you don't like putting the story together yourself by collecting bits of story from exploring the world you may find the narritive lacking. If you don't care to learn about the mechanics of the combat you will hit a wall in terms of progress. In terms of cost to enjoyment ratio, it's a great deal. I believe my first playthrough took ~60-70 hours.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game feels EXACTLY like War of the Roses, another game that takes place in a similar medieval setting with realistic physics (meaning the jumps aren't like those videogames where you can literally jump higher than your own height etc) You roll and you feel the weight of your body as your armor smashes into the stone floor of some underground ruins. You could even say it is the RPG version of that game, since that game is only for purely PVP.This also reminds me alot of Monster Hunter, with all the big boss battles etc. Expect epic Hydra and Dragon fights. The game becomes easier by several folds if you have a party, so try to do some side line soloing too if you wish to truly enjoy the intended difficulty of the game. I tend to let my friends walk ahead of me in our parties, so that they may also enjoy the fun of being tricked into chasing a naked zombie and then realizing it was a bait to an ambush, and that all too famous black knight one-hit-kill with his huge sword as soon as my friend climbs unsuspectingly to the top of the tower stairs and pops his head up seconds before it gets split into two. My rating: 9 / 10 (Very much recommended)

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												-----------------------------SPOILERS--------------------------------------The Dark Souls series is probably my favorite series in gaming. I spend quite alot of time in these games and they helped me through the hardest time of my life. Most people probably try to cheer themself up íf they are depressed when i was depressed i played a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of Dark souls (Most of the time in offline mode) so i thought that i am going to play through every game i own which is: Dark Souls: PTDE, Dark Souls II, Dark Souls II: Scholar of the first sin and Dark Souls III and write a review and say my overall opinion about the Souls series probably no one cares but neither do i if someone will read this.So without talkin much more lets get to the first game: "Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition. For me and probably most people this was the first souls game i ever played. I played it after getting hyped from seeing dark souls II on youtube but i couldn't play it so i decided to play the first game instead until it's released for PC and... i got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked. The first boss i troubled with was the Taurus demon (pathetic) to beat that boss for the first time i had to try it about 10 times. After i beat him and got to the Gargoyls and... just stopped playing after i wasn't able to beat them. So by that time Dark Souls II was released for PC and after playing through the entire game i went back to the first game. I started over and... had a rather easy time. I killed the Taurus demon and the Gargoyls in under an hour. I didn't know where to go after that tho so i ran around for 2h without getting anywhere in the game but after that i discovered that i can now open a door after the Taurus Demon which lead me to the lower area of undead burg i found the Capra Demon and i hate him until today the boss is just bad designed the 2 dogs make it more harder than it needs to be and the small arena is just not very nice to deal with but after finally slaying the beast i went further on my epic adventure. So  i could tell about the entire game but i don't have to please instead of reading this review just get this game and play it if you have a xbox controller (you really need one).The Graphics are fine for the time. But WTF were they thinking when designing the area before Seath the Scaleless... looks more like grass textures from 2000 when some of the first 3D games came out.Gameplay is just... Perfect. Thats something that is special about the first game it's so easy to be either OP or Weak. If you are going to get a Black Knight weapon this maybe is the easiest game in the series because they are easy to upgrade and do a ton of damage i can advice you... don't use them if you want the full experience. Sadly the coop is not that play able anymore because almost no one is playing this game for it, it's a buggy mess with summoning being very unreliable and most of the time it doesn't work. PvP is a laggy mess nothing else to say about it. The bosses are the best part of the entire game just forget about the♥♥♥♥♥♥fights like Bed of Chaos and tbh every fight in lost izalith is just there but the rest of the bosses are really great i will just point some of them out: Smough and Ornstein,  Gwyn, Sif and the legendary Knight Artorias.At the end of the Dark Souls III review i will say what the best Game is in my opinion and the best boss etc. So can i recommend this game? Do you really need to ask this? Get this game play it LOVE.Thx for reading have a nice day. ^^

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This game surprises with so many never before seen ideas in my gaming lifetime. Something I love most is that you really need to learn how to navigate and control your character, no invisible walls to keep you from diving off the edge into that lovely sunset, nope. You take a bad step and it's pahnkake(unenforceable copyright pending) status for you. And surprisingly a stroll across a small ledge over a deep chasm gives a great adrenaline rush and satisfaction when you succeed in defeating a ledge boss, also being wary of elevator bosses is necessary too. If you block or parry someones attack, you'd better time it right, because it takes perfect timing. However you will be surprised at how proficient you can become at anticipating peoples attacks with practice, and you can use regular computer controlled enemies for that. And if you parry them, it leaves them open for a riposte (meaning an undefended attack that allows for a great finishing attack) which in most cases is an insta-kill, or at least a huge hit. And the killing blow for backstabs and riposte' are always fantastic to watch.The game is for a majority of the time a Single Player experience but has an integrated PvP system divided into "worlds" or "dimensions" if you will, meaning that people can invade your world to kill you, or join your world as a cooperative help to make difficult area's less punishing and more enjoyable, but not easy. Note that the age of the game and it's use of Games For Windows Live have allowed for somewhat of a cheating infestation, it doesn't by any means make the game unplayable though.I haven't before gone into details because I'm really just that lazy, but I'm editing this review because it deserves a more clear description so that it really is helpful. I have never written a review for a game but this game inspired me to do so. I duely appoint this game to be the most likely game to prepare you for death and also a great way to prepare for Dark Souls II (and happy fun elation too! Maybe! hmm, maybe might be a slight exaggeration). Newcomers to the franchise shouldn't be too discouraged, the game won't hold your hand, and you'll improve drastically because of it. And you won't have a very hard time progressing through the game as a result of not knowing what to do next, wherever you go you can progress and you'll navigate the main storyline without too much difficulty.Updated 3/28/2014. This review welcomes suggestions and criticism so that it can be improved.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Dark Souls One is my most beloved game of all time, even beating Ultimate DOOM and Metroid Prime which were among the first and greatest games I ever played. It's a Dark Fantasty styled RPG that doesn't hold your hand through the game, hell not even the story, leaving you to fill in the blanks which created one of the biggest lore communities for a video game that's ever been made. It's easily my favorite game of all time, and is a godly title, throwing you into a dark curse world that'll tear you apart over and over and is heavily inspired by my favorite book/comic series ever made, Berserk, and if you know what Berserk is then you'll see all the inspiration and love for it in this game. While you'll need the DSFix mod to even make the game playable in terms of frame rate and bugs, and another mod for the online connection and PVP to even be close to stable, it's the greatest game I've ever played. The huge variety of enemies, the level design, the soundtrack, the characters, the lore, the story, everything besides the games sadly unstable fps and bugginess is damn near perfect, and is one of the very, very few games I'd ever give a 10/10 rating too (There's only 6 others out of every game I've ever played) and the replayability for this game is at a high level as well, and that's not even including the still very active community in the PVP part of the game. The Souls series itself is a beautiful collection, and this is simply the greatest of all of them, and my favorite RPG I've ever played.

I have played this game and i have tried most builds. They have their strengths and weaknesses from pyromancy being almost useless against smaug and his friend. To enemies who are very vulnerable to flame. I would rate this game a straight 10/10 for how challenging, fun, and its great co-op system, i am very proud of this game and can never get bored of it. PRAISE THE SUN

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												A controller will greatly benefit your experience in this game. I also recommend the DSfix Mod. This is one of those games that feels good to beat. Winning feels like an accomplishment because the game rarely pulls its punches. The world is dangerous and filled with horrible things that want nothing more than to kill you, again and again. But almost everything in the game feels fair. I never truly found myself dieing because the game was unfair. I found myself dieing because I didn't play with a plan, because I rushed in without caution, because I became impatient. It's not a game for everyone. If you don't enjoy the taste of accomplishment that comes from wallowing in defeat you may not enjoy this game. If you don't like putting the story together yourself by collecting bits of story from exploring the world you may find the narritive lacking. If you don't care to learn about the mechanics of the combat you will hit a wall in terms of progress. In terms of cost to enjoyment ratio, it's a great deal. I believe my first playthrough took ~60-70 hours.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game feels EXACTLY like War of the Roses, another game that takes place in a similar medieval setting with realistic physics (meaning the jumps aren't like those videogames where you can literally jump higher than your own height etc) You roll and you feel the weight of your body as your armor smashes into the stone floor of some underground ruins. You could even say it is the RPG version of that game, since that game is only for purely PVP.This also reminds me alot of Monster Hunter, with all the big boss battles etc. Expect epic Hydra and Dragon fights. The game becomes easier by several folds if you have a party, so try to do some side line soloing too if you wish to truly enjoy the intended difficulty of the game. I tend to let my friends walk ahead of me in our parties, so that they may also enjoy the fun of being tricked into chasing a naked zombie and then realizing it was a bait to an ambush, and that all too famous black knight one-hit-kill with his huge sword as soon as my friend climbs unsuspectingly to the top of the tower stairs and pops his head up seconds before it gets split into two. My rating: 9 / 10 (Very much recommended)

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This is probably one of the most aptly named games I've ever played - you will die. You will swear, you'll shout and wake your neighbours, you may even break your controller (really do follow the store page advice, a gamepad is really the only way this game can be played). I bought this game having heard how challenging it was - I gave up after getting destroyed repeatedly by the tutorial boss!!! But several months later, as the buzz for Dark Souls II began to grow, I gave it another go. And it was still brutally tough.  However as may have said before, it's (mostly) fair. This game strikes an amazing balance that means conquering each area, taking out every enemy, earning each piece of equipment, is HUGELY satisfying. Seriously, the immense satisfaction derived from beating a tough boss in this game is near unbeaten by anything I've ever played. And if ever the going gets too tough, there's no shame in turning to the internet for advice, because that alone won't get you through, the best it can do is steer you in the right direction.   Adding to this, it has a great combat system, each weapon has it's own unique move set, each move recorded in motion capture to make it feel smooth. Because of this you grow a much more natural preference to weapons you feel more comfortable with, not just the regular "Imma get the hardest hitting motherf**ker and stick with it". I never had much use for magic myself in the game, it has however appeared very effective from what I've seen other players do.    That does bring me to a minor problem howerver - other players. I played this just before Dark Souls II came out, so the player base had emptied by then, therefore most of the time I was alone save a few NPC buddies the game grants you if you need some help (you can summon the spirits of other people you meet on your journey to help with bosses in exchange for the boss being a little tougher). The thing is though next to nobody seemed to be around to be summoned, nor did anyone ever summon me for help at any point in the game save a couple of rare occasions. It's a very cool mechanic, and is well used in the sequel, but I guess if you don't know any better you don't really miss it - and it makes it all the more fun in Dark Souls II. Also, people often mention the terrible performance of the game on PC, but that's long since been fixed through modders which make it playable, not really an  issu unless you "MUST" play all your games at 60fps, as I believe the fix makes the game run fine but at 30fps (basically console level)   Other than that, and the difficulty that may not be to everyone's taste, this is an outstanding challenge to play, and if you can work it out (or just watch the lore videos on Youtube) it has a fascinating story, that can add genuine emotion to some battles as you discover how the land of Lordran became so twisted.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Don't let my "4" hours in this game fool you. I played this for upwards 300-400 hours back when I used to play on consoles, and another 200 or so hours on PC before it even came to Steam, so I can say without a doubt, that this flawed masterpiece is my favorite video game of all time. I may have been introduced to the series thanks to Demon's Souls (I even have many more hours logged into that game as well), but I feel like this is where From really "got" where to go. Demon's Souls was incredible, but also somewhat of a mess, in that it didn't really know where it wanted to be as a game. It tried to create backstory and lore, but fell short in comparison. The PVP, while great (This is where I spent most of my time with it), played a much smaller part. The bosses, while epic, weren't terribly intricate or creative (Dragon God? Cool boss idea, but super generic). Dark Souls 2, another game I love to death, is very much a mess. It tries far to hard to be the best of Dark Souls 1 and Demon's Souls, but falls short, capturing very few, *real* Souls moments. It's Lore is a massive disappointment compared to the first Dark Souls, and the game itself is just a mash of zones thrown together (Go into a windmill, end up in a lava-surrounded castle? Or when you go through Aldia's Keep, you end up taking a tall elevator and end up in the Dragon Aerie? Where the hell did that come from? Outside of Aldia's Keep looks NOTHING like where you suddenly end up. There are no massive spires all throughout the area around Aldia's Keep, then suddenly there are? Meh. Whatever.) Now, Dark Souls 2 does shine in one key area; the most important in fact. The GAMEPLAY. This is where Dark Souls 2 succeeds and allows me to forgive all of its shortcomings. The combat is slick, the PVP is addicting and rewarding, and the bosses/enemy designs are creative and fun to fight.Dark Souls 3 is now the big deal in the Souls universe, and while it is currently my most enjoyed game as of the last couple of years, and a better Souls game than Dark Souls 2, I can't really talk about what makes it as special as it is without first talking about the game that makes this series itself what it is...Dark Souls. Not 2, not 3, not even Demon's Souls (In my opinion, and I still love the hell out of that game). Just Dark Souls. Where to even begin? This game is HUGE, yet very compact. It nails level design, weapons/armor, enemies/bosses, and the lore especially. I'm still to this day, trying to uncover its secrets, and speculating on all manner of things within this universe. Odds are, the developers themselves don't even know the answers to a lot of my questions, but you know what? I'm fine with that. Sometimes it's better to be able to craft my own theories and formulate my own opinions about certain characters or places based off of what I *think* is true or untrue about them. It makes it feel like I'm played a gigantic, epic campaign in D&D, and I love every moment of it. Sure Dark Souls 3 is a better game from a gameplay and storytelling (but not story itself) prespective, and it's surely the game I would suggest someone play if they wanted to get into the series, as it's a much better representation of how great the series is for this modern age of gaming, there is no denying that Dark Souls 1 is where the true heart of the series lies.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Dark Souls Prepare to Die edition is one of the best games you will have the pleasure to suffer to play it. The game places you at the end of the age of fire, in which the great lords of Lordran have begun to fade in power. You, the undead, has begun his/her journey in the Undead Asylum, were you are taught the basics of combat and given your starting equipment. You are able to choose from various different classes going from warrior to deprived (meaning with only a wooden shield and a wooden club.)The game centers around exploration and combat which is very easy to learn and apply in the different situations. You must quickly learn that you arent the superpowered heroe that you are in most other games. You can die from the most basic of enemies, and you will have to get used to this. You will die. A lot. Four things you must have to enjoy this game: Persistence, patience, perseverance and stubbornness.Controller smashing fun!! Ulcer bringing happiness!! Spincter clenching moments!! And much more can be yours for the low, low price of your sanity!!Some of the best boss fights I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing, along with solid combat and a deep system of blocking, evasion, armour, magic, and pyromacy which forces you to think ahead of the fights or be cursed to live them over and over and over again. The name says it all: Prepare to die.The story isnt told in narration or is blasted into your face like other games. The rich and deep lore from the history and NPCs is told mostly by item descriptions and sometimes in dialog and actions of these NPCsThe music is amazing. Some of the boss fights will be accompanied by some of the most beautifully crafted and immersive music that will stay with you even after you finish the game.Pros: Story, gameplay, replayability is basically infinite, weapon variety, class variety, musicCons: You will get frustrated at the beginning as you learn the gameplay and weapon varietiesgit gud 9/10Priscilla best waifu

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Dark Souls 1 is not an easy game, but it also isn't a game that tries to be unfair. DS1 is a game that rewards patience, curiosity, and allows the player to go through the game how they wish. The tutorial is optional, the story is optional, talking to NPCs is 90% optional, however, ignoring these optional things will make the first play through for a virgin Souls player extremely confusing and feel like this game has nothing to offer other than death.It is true that death plays an important role in the game as both a mechanic as well as part of the plot of the story. The player that will enjoy this game is one that not only enjoys a challenge, but also one that isn't afraid to fail. You will die. You will lose your Souls aka experience more than once. Each time is a chance to learn more and and grow as a Souls player and a gamer in general. I can't recommend this game enough. It has one of the best stories and game designs I have had the privilege to enjoy. You will miss a lot your first play through, but I still encourage people to play without help the first time. Talk to NPCs, read item descriptions, get lost, die, learn. But don't you dare go hollow.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I'll be the first (or one of the first) to admit that the game is not without its flaws; the port has some issues, ranging from some wonky collisions right down to stuff that not only doesn't make sense, but can't be reproduced even if you try.But despite all of that, it's a solid piece of work and easily one of my favourite games on any platform. It takes a mechanic that would usually be seen as absolute BS (trial and error gaming) and turns the negatives on their head - you're rewarded for taking things slowly and trying out different ways of attacking problems. The game has its own rules and doesn't break them - just like you, the enemies you face can't endlessly spam attacks and just like you their guard will break if you hit it enough times. EVERYTHING you meet operates within the game's constraints, and so if you take a methodical approach, there's pretty-much NOTHING in there that you can't beat in a one-on-one fight.The RPG mechanic of "Linear Warrior, Quadratic Wizard" doesn't apply - while using magic is more or less the closest thing the game has to an easy mode, if you don't like using pyromancy, sorceries, or miracles, you can dump a few levels in your physical stats and start beating the snot out of things with a greatsword to see if that tickles your fancy. The reverse also applies - if having to get within bad-breath range of the undead cast is getting you down, scratch up a couple of levels in Faith or Intelligence, work on Attunement to open up some spell slots, and start nuking things.The most important thing to come to terms with is not that you will die frequently (and believe me, you will die frequently, especially if you're as bad at the game as I am), it is that you're not playing for the grinding hours of frustration and swearing at your screen; play for the relief and joy of finally finding the key to a situation and pushing through it.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												People will say you should play Dark Souls because it is like TEH HAREDST GAM EVA!!!111Or avoid it because it is punishingly hard.My recommendation is to ignore all those claims about the difficulty, the game is just retro-difficult and actually has quite a good challenge curve once you pass the 2-3 first bosses for the first time.And you should play Dark Souls because it is a great game. The level design is superb, as you explore through twisting paths, switching floors and opening shortcuts to where you were hours ago. The graphics are well designed (but dated) and the sound design is great. There will be moments you will be straining to hear if those footsteps get closer to you.As for the gameplay, the combat in Dark Souls is the star. This is an action RPG and it has a very responsive and precise combat system, perhaps a bit too gamey (with the occasional hitbox/animation exploit)  but once you get the hang of the game it becomes very satisfying. Control-wise, the keyboard setup is a bit awkward and the game is better played with a controller.The port is decent but poor, with too few options, some mods are almost required to enjoy.Oh, and about the difficulty: you will die. A lot. But dying is not losing, you are undead and you instantly respawn, making dying part of the game. There will be times you will kamikaze to get an item or off an annoying non-respawning enemy, making it an effective tactic. And the game will remain constantly challenging, forcing you to replay each and every segment of it till you learn how to handle it, then it will through you another, much different challenge. Most of the times the difficulty is fair, but there are some cheap bossfights (I am looking at you, stray assylum demon) and the fabled obscurity about game mechanincs that can end up becoming frustrating (unless you read a walkthrough and lose some of the fun exploring the game - but noone is perfect).Overall, a great game everybody must play, assuming (s)he can take the time and effort to master it - it is a highly satisfying experience

												Truely you must prepare to die... Alot.Dark Souls is the follow-up / spirtual successor to Demon's Souls which is essentially the same thing,the main difference that being it finally became a PC and Xbox title. Dark Souls places you in the world of Lordran land of lords as the Chosen Undead the supposed decendent of the easily forgotten Furtive Pygmy (or Manus if you believe the theory). content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												I would describe myself as very new to Dark Souls having not played any of the sequels yet either. With almost 80 hours into DS:PTDE I can say that this would already make it into my top 10 easily.This game can be as deep or superficial as you like depending on your preference and time available to you. On the surface it is a difficult and challenging explorative action game with a decent fighting system that requires patience and strategy, and an intriguing world that provides a looming, fantastical backdrop. Dig deeper and you find that every NPC has a deep backstory and the world is dark and full of a sense of disparing melancholia that speaks thoughout the entire narrative. The level design is among the best I've have seen in recent years as every part of the world feels connected and is cleverly and thoughtfully conceived. The first playthrough (which I still have not completed by this point btw) makes this even more rewarding as you discover how the areas are linked to one another.If you've been thinking about giving the Dark Souls a try the answer is yes and the first one is - as you'd expect - an excellent place to start.*Xbox Controller (or steam pad) recommended!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												(Before reading the following scenario, be aware that the last paragraph is about how awesome this game is and you should get it)_______________________________________________After spending 10-30 minutes crafting a unique character to portray your identity, you find yourself already dead at the beginning of the game, or undead so to speak. This is probably for the best, because if you were to start alive, the game would be more than willing to kill you as many times as it needs to until you've become a bloody conglamerate of what appears to be flesh.For the first 40 hours of gameplay, you are given these instructions; ring two bells. Where? How? Why? Well if it told you, where would the fun be? Instead of having a fluffy NPC tell you "Oh Bob, you should probably turn around and head to undead burg" they take the obviously more effective approach and rather place a prowling demon with 2000 health or a lake of lava containing 7 bosses to kill you, implying the message in your head "Hm...
