content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												People will say you should play Dark Souls because it is like TEH HAREDST GAM EVA!!!111Or avoid it because it is punishingly hard.My recommendation is to ignore all those claims about the difficulty, the game is just retro-difficult and actually has quite a good challenge curve once you pass the 2-3 first bosses for the first time.And you should play Dark Souls because it is a great game. The level design is superb, as you explore through twisting paths, switching floors and opening shortcuts to where you were hours ago. The graphics are well designed (but dated) and the sound design is great. There will be moments you will be straining to hear if those footsteps get closer to you.As for the gameplay, the combat in Dark Souls is the star. This is an action RPG and it has a very responsive and precise combat system, perhaps a bit too gamey (with the occasional hitbox/animation exploit)  but once you get the hang of the game it becomes very satisfying. Control-wise, the keyboard setup is a bit awkward and the game is better played with a controller.The port is decent but poor, with too few options, some mods are almost required to enjoy.Oh, and about the difficulty: you will die. A lot. But dying is not losing, you are undead and you instantly respawn, making dying part of the game. There will be times you will kamikaze to get an item or off an annoying non-respawning enemy, making it an effective tactic. And the game will remain constantly challenging, forcing you to replay each and every segment of it till you learn how to handle it, then it will through you another, much different challenge. Most of the times the difficulty is fair, but there are some cheap bossfights (I am looking at you, stray assylum demon) and the fabled obscurity about game mechanincs that can end up becoming frustrating (unless you read a walkthrough and lose some of the fun exploring the game - but noone is perfect).Overall, a great game everybody must play, assuming (s)he can take the time and effort to master it - it is a highly satisfying experience

												Truely you must prepare to die... Alot.Dark Souls is the follow-up / spirtual successor to Demon's Souls which is essentially the same thing,the main difference that being it finally became a PC and Xbox title. Dark Souls places you in the world of Lordran land of lords as the Chosen Undead the supposed decendent of the easily forgotten Furtive Pygmy (or Manus if you believe the theory). You may either rekindle the flame for the new Age Of Fire, or walk away to become the Dark Lord for the Age Of Man as the Furtive Pygmy desired to have.This port is mediocre in quailty and could've easily been improved severely ( BlightTown, 30fps lock, non 1080p graphics, and crappy UI I mean it still uses the Xbox Buttons for prompts. ),Nontheless it defintely holds up to it's other more superior ports given that it still plays the same way, with the samepainful and scary invasion, and it's noted hard difficulty.This game is known for it's insane difficulty, however it really although harder than most games this kind of skill is easily accumulated over gameplay hours. One hour you can't fight a hollow, the next you just kill Seath The Scaleless.Also if you thought the challenges ended by beating the game, there is New Game + (up to 6) which essentially increases difficulty, and trust me it will make things very interesting, that first Taurus Demon might not be as easy as a few leap jabs now is it? number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												All arguments about whether or not video games are art cast aside, Dark Souls might aptly be called a masterpiece. The game is an aesthetic triumph in its use of light, sound, and setting to create a distinctive atmosphere, and more importantly, it's fun. Dark Souls strikes a great balance of challenge, reward, and utter bull♥♥♥♥♥♥to create an experience that is simultaneously harrowing and satisfying. Is it the perfect game? Not by a long shot. It's the laziest port to PC I've seen since Saint's Row 2 (although this can be fixed with a fanmade patch), and there are some gravely serious weapon balance issues that are most apparent in player versus player interactions. The game's difficulty is also vastly overstated both by its fans and its detractors, the product of a generation that sucks at video games being confronted at last with a game that refuses to hold the player's hand. Ultimately, though, Dark Souls is all about the journey. It's about overcoming relentless enemies, ceaseless problems, and suffering without end. The presentation, as a whole, greatly overshadows the myriad shortcomings in design.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
About The GameDark Souls tells the story of your hero trying to save an intriguing world which, by every possible metric, fell long ago. Abominations make their homes in the forgotten nooks of a lost civilisation. A handful of enigmatic survivors are all that's left, but you're as free to talk to them as kill them, and they're as liable to help you as to lie. Best of all, the game literally kills you off somewhere between character creation and the first cut-scene. Above all, Dark Souls seems to thrill at escaping expectations.Generaly in Dark Souls you're not completing levels, or even doubling back in the Metroidvania style. You're exploring, taking step after nervous step through a foul wonderland that oscillates between great cruelty, and moments of sweet relief. Its great achievement is in not feeling like a game world at all, much as Minecraft didn't, and it's a similar joy to explore. This simply feels like a place where you really, really shouldn't be, where every step is heavy with dread.Pure Controlsll of this survives, totally intact, in the PC port, with a single caveat - you must own a Xbox 360 pad, or suitable equivalent.The mouse and keyboard controls in the Prepare to Die edition are a war crime. Losing the gentle acceleration of analog movement would have been bad enough, but the mouse doesn't control the camera so much as wrestle it around on a rubber leash. Meanwhile, the GUI's adaption to the keyboard is just awkward. All told, you could be playing on an emulator. If you don't own a pad but somehow end up with Dark Souls running on your PC, remove the power cable from the back with a barge pole.But if you do own a pad, and quickly grab this 80Kb fan hotpix, which unlocks the game's resolution from 1024x720, you'll be able to enjoy the definitive edition of Dark Souls until the Artorias of the Abyss DLC arrives for consoles this winter. That content's packed in the PC version for free, and we're pleased to announce that it's... fine. It's just fine.Overall i definitely reccomend buying this game if you own a XBOX 360 Controller !9.2/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This game surprises with so many never before seen ideas in my gaming lifetime. Something I love most is that you really need to learn how to navigate and control your character, no invisible walls to keep you from diving off the edge into that lovely sunset, nope. You take a bad step and it's pahnkake(unenforceable copyright pending) status for you. And surprisingly a stroll across a small ledge over a deep chasm gives a great adrenaline rush and satisfaction when you succeed in defeating a ledge boss, also being wary of elevator bosses is necessary too. If you block or parry someones attack, you'd better time it right, because it takes perfect timing. However you will be surprised at how proficient you can become at anticipating peoples attacks with practice, and you can use regular computer controlled enemies for that. And if you parry them, it leaves them open for a riposte (meaning an undefended attack that allows for a great finishing attack) which in most cases is an insta-kill, or at least a huge hit. And the killing blow for backstabs and riposte' are always fantastic to watch.The game is for a majority of the time a Single Player experience but has an integrated PvP system divided into "worlds" or "dimensions" if you will, meaning that people can invade your world to kill you, or join your world as a cooperative help to make difficult area's less punishing and more enjoyable, but not easy. Note that the age of the game and it's use of Games For Windows Live have allowed for somewhat of a cheating infestation, it doesn't by any means make the game unplayable though.I haven't before gone into details because I'm really just that lazy, but I'm editing this review because it deserves a more clear description so that it really is helpful. I have never written a review for a game but this game inspired me to do so. I duely appoint this game to be the most likely game to prepare you for death and also a great way to prepare for Dark Souls II (and happy fun elation too! Maybe! hmm, maybe might be a slight exaggeration). Newcomers to the franchise shouldn't be too discouraged, the game won't hold your hand, and you'll improve drastically because of it. And you won't have a very hard time progressing through the game as a result of not knowing what to do next, wherever you go you can progress and you'll navigate the main storyline without too much difficulty.Updated 3/28/2014. This review welcomes suggestions and criticism so that it can be improved.

												Dark SoulsPrepare To Die EditionGenre : Action-RPGRating: 10/10Comment : It's the best game I've ever played. It deserved a better pc port'Dark Souls' is a complex dark fantasy action role-playing game that is played from a third person perspective. It has a direct combat system similar to games like the 'Zelda' series. Unlike those it comes with a multiplayer feature: You can cooperatively take on bosses or fight other players to the death. The game is challenging and very rewarding once you achieve something. There are tons of secrets to discover be it gamplay- or story-wise. All these things add up to a high replay value.In my humble opinion 'Dark Souls' is a masterpiece and should be seen as a milestone of videogame history. Edit : Now that Dark Souls works with steamworks I played the game again. Arriving at the 'Firelink Shrine' felt like coming home and I realized that Dark Souls is my all time favourite game. So I changed the rating from 9,5 to 10 although the game still has its technical issues.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												It's hard to put into words why I like Dark Souls so much. Well let me just say that you're going to need the patience of a saint, fast reflexes, and the ability to adapt to any situation at any given time if you want to get through this game in it's entirety. Now moving on to the gameplay itself, it's just wonderful. To put it simply, melee combat is the base of this game. You posess a wide variety of swords, bows, sheilds, and magic to defeat the many deadly mobs of enemies that you'll meet in the game. There are many game mechanics that make this game different from other melee focused games, but for now, let's just start with the basics. For starters, there are many ways you can swing and control your weapon. You can attack in light basic swings, or you can go for more damaging and slower attacks. Either way, you'll need to figure out which set of attacks is needed for the current situation. Then there is the ability to parry and riposte. Sure, you can sit there and swing your sword mindlessly, which will most likely get you killed, or you can parry your foes attack, leaving them wide open for a riposte, or counter attack, dealing massive critical damage. Another game mechanic that changes up the playstyle of the game, is the ability to dodge. Sure it doesn't sound so impressive at first, but Dark Souls puts a lot of emphasis into dodging. You could just go through the entire game with a sheild, (wut r u casul m8?) but before you know it, enemies are becoming so strong, that they're able to blast through your sheild like it's nothing. That's where dodging becomes essential. You have the ability to roll through enemies attacks thanks to the use of invincibility frames. Dodging takes a considerable amount of skill, timing, and practice and is one of the game mechanics that really challenges your ability to memorize attack patterns and really take into account how easy it is to screw up and die, which is why I think it's a mechanic that really spices up things in Dark Souls. Anyway these mechanics and so much more really add to why this game's combat is so rewarding and satisfying. Imagine just dying over and over to a boss that you're trying so hard to kill. Then you start to memorize his attack patterns, the way he swings his weapon, how he swings his weapon, how he telegraphs his attacks. You then start dodging all his attacks flawlessly, using patterns of light and heavy swings to take him down with each dodge. The feeling of absolute victory and triumph is what will keep you wanting more. With that being said, I will move on to the environment and world itself. Dark Souls does not have a very linear path or objective, in fact, it encourages you to go in different paths and learn what the objective is for yourself. The game will not hold your hand, and if you die, then that's on you. All the mistakes and deaths are made by you and created by you, so don't blame the game if you're sucking. The most reasonable solution is to just git gud and stop being a casul scrub. Honestly, the environment really supports the vibe of complete loneliness and helplessness. You won't be having much social interactions in this game, save for a few NPC's and most of the time your only company is going to be the mobs of enemies around you. Overall, Dark Souls is a very unforgiving experience that will only get worse with your impatience and lack of skill and know how. If you manage to get past all that, however, and actually learn from your mistakes and manage to not get fed up with the amounts of death and stress you'll have to deal with, then it becomes one of the most memorable and rewaring experiences you could ever have in gaming, ever.

												At this point everyone's heard of Dark Souls, so I'll keep it short.This is an amazing game if you're in for a challenge. It has great characters, music, bosses, areas, a very interesting story and way to tell it and, best of all, fantastic combat. The combat is simple yet complicated, easy to learn and hard to master, and it is VERY addictive. I have finished this game start to finish 17 times so far (9 on 360, 6 on PS3 and twice on PC) and every once in a while I'll still play it for some time, and that is all due to the brilliant combat that provides endless hours of fun.If you're in for a challenge, I highly recommend this game. My one advice is: Don't give up and be prepared to die. Death is not failure in Dark Souls, it is knowledge. Learn from each death and keep going.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												I guess I might as well write one of these after 100%-ing the game finally. Did not know that I was gonna end up doing this, considering that when I first played the game, I hated it (purely out of my incredible bad-ness). But after playing a lot more, over several different playthroughs and weapon usage (my personal favorite was squashing everyone with the Zweihander), I gained a lot more respect for the game.I don't really know what to say that the many other reviews haven't already said, honestly. The story/lore/whatever is well constructed (even though I don't really care about it), the gameplay is very solid (even though backstabs are incredibly silly), the bosses are varied and interesting (except for the Lost Izalith bosses and having to fight the Stray Demon 3 times), and the immense replayability speaks for itself with the large amount of weapons and self-imposed restrictions you can put on yourself. Although trying to 100% it is a huge trial, since at BARE MINIMUM you have to go to NG+2 (screw you Sif!), so fighting a handful of the bosses with even more HP on NG+1 can be really tedious. If there's one problem I have, it's that NG+ is just one of those "amp up the enemy stats" difficulty modifiers that I'm not a huge fan of. But that's not a huge deal in the grand scheme of things.So good on you Dark Souls, despite being a not-so-great port on your own (seriously, get DSFix), you have a ton of content and quality for most people to be satisfied with.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This is probably one of the most aptly named games I've ever played - you will die. You will swear, you'll shout and wake your neighbours, you may even break your controller (really do follow the store page advice, a gamepad is really the only way this game can be played). I bought this game having heard how challenging it was - I gave up after getting destroyed repeatedly by the tutorial boss!!! But several months later, as the buzz for Dark Souls II began to grow, I gave it another go. And it was still brutally tough.  However as may have said before, it's (mostly) fair. This game strikes an amazing balance that means conquering each area, taking out every enemy, earning each piece of equipment, is HUGELY satisfying. Seriously, the immense satisfaction derived from beating a tough boss in this game is near unbeaten by anything I've ever played. And if ever the going gets too tough, there's no shame in turning to the internet for advice, because that alone won't get you through, the best it can do is steer you in the right direction.   Adding to this, it has a great combat system, each weapon has it's own unique move set, each move recorded in motion capture to make it feel smooth. Because of this you grow a much more natural preference to weapons you feel more comfortable with, not just the regular "Imma get the hardest hitting motherf**ker and stick with it". I never had much use for magic myself in the game, it has however appeared very effective from what I've seen other players do.    That does bring me to a minor problem howerver - other players. I played this just before Dark Souls II came out, so the player base had emptied by then, therefore most of the time I was alone save a few NPC buddies the game grants you if you need some help (you can summon the spirits of other people you meet on your journey to help with bosses in exchange for the boss being a little tougher). The thing is though next to nobody seemed to be around to be summoned, nor did anyone ever summon me for help at any point in the game save a couple of rare occasions. It's a very cool mechanic, and is well used in the sequel, but I guess if you don't know any better you don't really miss it - and it makes it all the more fun in Dark Souls II. Also, people often mention the terrible performance of the game on PC, but that's long since been fixed through modders which make it playable, not really an  issu unless you "MUST" play all your games at 60fps, as I believe the fix makes the game run fine but at 30fps (basically console level)   Other than that, and the difficulty that may not be to everyone's taste, this is an outstanding challenge to play, and if you can work it out (or just watch the lore videos on Youtube) it has a fascinating story, that can add genuine emotion to some battles as you discover how the land of Lordran became so twisted.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Don't let my "4" hours in this game fool you. I played this for upwards 300-400 hours back when I used to play on consoles, and another 200 or so hours on PC before it even came to Steam, so I can say without a doubt, that this flawed masterpiece is my favorite video game of all time. I may have been introduced to the series thanks to Demon's Souls (I even have many more hours logged into that game as well), but I feel like this is where From really "got" where to go. Demon's Souls was incredible, but also somewhat of a mess, in that it didn't really know where it wanted to be as a game. It tried to create backstory and lore, but fell short in comparison. The PVP, while great (This is where I spent most of my time with it), played a much smaller part. The bosses, while epic, weren't terribly intricate or creative (Dragon God? Cool boss idea, but super generic). Dark Souls 2, another game I love to death, is very much a mess. It tries far to hard to be the best of Dark Souls 1 and Demon's Souls, but falls short, capturing very few, *real* Souls moments. It's Lore is a massive disappointment compared to the first Dark Souls, and the game itself is just a mash of zones thrown together (Go into a windmill, end up in a lava-surrounded castle? Or when you go through Aldia's Keep, you end up taking a tall elevator and end up in the Dragon Aerie? Where the hell did that come from? Outside of Aldia's Keep looks NOTHING like where you suddenly end up. There are no massive spires all throughout the area around Aldia's Keep, then suddenly there are? Meh. Whatever.) Now, Dark Souls 2 does shine in one key area; the most important in fact. The GAMEPLAY. This is where Dark Souls 2 succeeds and allows me to forgive all of its shortcomings. The combat is slick, the PVP is addicting and rewarding, and the bosses/enemy designs are creative and fun to fight.Dark Souls 3 is now the big deal in the Souls universe, and while it is currently my most enjoyed game as of the last couple of years, and a better Souls game than Dark Souls 2, I can't really talk about what makes it as special as it is without first talking about the game that makes this series itself what it is...Dark Souls. Not 2, not 3, not even Demon's Souls (In my opinion, and I still love the hell out of that game). Just Dark Souls. Where to even begin? This game is HUGE, yet very compact. It nails level design, weapons/armor, enemies/bosses, and the lore especially. I'm still to this day, trying to uncover its secrets, and speculating on all manner of things within this universe. Odds are, the developers themselves don't even know the answers to a lot of my questions, but you know what? I'm fine with that. Sometimes it's better to be able to craft my own theories and formulate my own opinions about certain characters or places based off of what I *think* is true or untrue about them. It makes it feel like I'm played a gigantic, epic campaign in D&D, and I love every moment of it. Sure Dark Souls 3 is a better game from a gameplay and storytelling (but not story itself) prespective, and it's surely the game I would suggest someone play if they wanted to get into the series, as it's a much better representation of how great the series is for this modern age of gaming, there is no denying that Dark Souls 1 is where the true heart of the series lies.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												DARK SOULS™: Prepare To Cry Edition, like someone called it, i totally agree with this name cause i was close to cry many times, specially at beginning...Another way i would like to call it is DARK SOULS™: Prepare To Fall Edition or shorter, Pitfalls, yes, because i'm pretty sure i've died much more times by falling in some dark pit than killed by enemies/Bosses.....What is good so in this game ? Let's try to find it out...The story ? It's good but not so good to be able to say it's epic, it's interesting and capture your attention so that you want to know what will happens afterward, but at the end it's not so special.What is really good in this game is the graphic art, the enemies and bosses are very well painted, loved them, the combat system is at beginning very complicated but once you manage to master it it's well rewarding.I never had one single crash in all the time i spent over this game so we can say that devs did a good job about that..So overall we can say that this is a GOOD game but then, why we are not going to give to it a 100% ? Let's see which are the factors that forced me to cut points on the road.....-4 points for the insane difficulty of the game, at beginning, a new player find himself in a very hostile world, enemies are from the very first minutes very strong for an unprepared adventurer and the first bosses you'll meet will challenge your skills, patience and perseverance at the limits, so much that i fear that many players would quit this game before being able to kill the first 2 bosses, killed the second, one can take a little breath and recover a bit of hope.....The ones who will not surrender and will continue will face their worst nightmares in Anor Londo, a place with a very difficult point to pass and, after that, they'll have to face what in my opinion is the most difficult boss of the whole game, a strange decision  by the devs to put a such fight in the first 35%-40% of the game, instead of leaving it for the last boss like many other games do.....-2 points for the fact that this game not tell you anything on what to do, i had to read tons of wikia game pages to learn everything i needed otherwise probably i would have missed most important things.-2 point for the targeting system and autoswitching camera, basically, if you have only one enemy in front of you, all fine, but if there are at least 2 or more, once you taget lock one, the camera will move automatically between them all making your life a nightmare, cause, will happens that you'll give your shoulders to one of them who will backstab you or you'll end falling down to death while the enemy jump in a dangerous direction...I would have totally preferred if, once i target lock one enemy, that would have been the only one enemy targeted and not all together...:(-1 point for the terrible interface of the PC port, it has a mouse cursor wandering for your screen and you can't do anything to get rid of that, altough exist an external software that fix this, being a purist i generally refuse to install external software and like to play games like they're offered by the software house, so a minor bug for many but i can't forgive devs for not having fixed this one.-1 point for the really too many zones where you risk to fall to death, come on devs, this is a RPG, not a platform.....-1 point for the way the coop/multiplayer is implemented in this game, let's talk a little about it....In this game you can wander as a ghoul (not human) and this way your single player experience will never be broken by other players, you'll be fine, but.....There is some points n this game where is better (or much better) being in human form, so, you will be able to return a normal human if you desire do so, but, once human, you'll be vulnerable to invasions that simply are the other players who will be able to enter in your world and attack you and beware, this can happens in any zone you are and in any moment, this means that if you're doing delicate things and fighting some dangerous enemies, you can be invaded and you'll be forced to fight TOGETHER the enemies you're already fighting and the player ho invaded you, specially the first times, this will most likely end up in your death.....Multiplayer can also be useful to defeat Bosses with other players but the mechanics are made this way, you can leave a summoning sign so that other players will be able to enter in your world and help you, but only if the players are in your same range and that means, if you're level 20, that only players between level 10 and 30 will be able to assist you, this means also that if you're too low level or too high level, according of the day time or luck could happen that you'll not find any player who can assist you, so, if you have a friend you want he help you be sure he's of your same level or very close to that.In conclusion, Dark Souls is an epic game, legendary for sure, but is thinked and made not for everyone, just for the hardcore players, casual ones is better stay away from this game if they not want to feel infinite frustration and pain.My Final Score is 89 /100

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												Dark Souls One is my most beloved game of all time, even beating Ultimate DOOM and Metroid Prime which were among the first and greatest games I ever played. It's a Dark Fantasty styled RPG that doesn't hold your hand through the game, hell not even the story, leaving you to fill in the blanks which created one of the biggest lore communities for a video game that's ever been made. It's easily my favorite game of all time, and is a godly title, throwing you into a dark curse world that'll tear you apart over and over and is heavily inspired by my favorite book/comic series ever made, Berserk, and if you know what Berserk is then you'll see all the inspiration and love for it in this game. While you'll need the DSFix mod to even make the game playable in terms of frame rate and bugs, and another mod for the online connection and PVP to even be close to stable, it's the greatest game I've ever played. The huge variety of enemies, the level design, the soundtrack, the characters, the lore, the story, everything besides the games sadly unstable fps and bugginess is damn near perfect, and is one of the very, very few games I'd ever give a 10/10 rating too (There's only 6 others out of every game I've ever played) and the replayability for this game is at a high level as well, and that's not even including the still very active community in the PVP part of the game. The Souls series itself is a beautiful collection, and this is simply the greatest of all of them, and my favorite RPG I've ever played.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Everything there is to say about Dark Souls has been said. If you stumble on this little review, just know that it's renowned for a reason. Deep mechanics, gameplay that never gets tiresome, endless replayability, innovative multiplayer, and a story that isn't forcefed to you. The only game I cared enough about to get all the achievements, the only game I've enjoyed enough to play through more than once, and the only game I'd recommend to anyone who likes games.My only gripe is that the PvP mechanics are so much different than the PvE mechanics. When you're ready to try and take on other players online, throw out what you learned about fighting from the computer. It's a shame because PvE has a well-defined set of rules, but PvP has an entirely different tempo and features a lot of bugs and exploits (dead angling, for instance), especially with experienced players. Don't get me wrong, it's learnable, and rewarding in its own right, but it's very different than the rest of the game.If you're just starting you should know two things about the legendary difficulty of the game. 1. Combat is unforgiving - learn the controls and the tempo (button mashers won't win at DS).  2. Game mechanics are obtuse and not explained very well in game - avoid spoilers but learn the mechanics from a wiki (at minimum, understand how poise works and how endurance/encumbrance works). You'll have a much better time. It doesn't come easy but when it does, it's more rewarding than any other game you'll play.

												The best souls game (IMO) to date.This game started it all, while demon souls was good succes Dark Souls made the media jump out and say: "Hey, that's pretty good!" (Probaply also because Xbox360 and PC now could play too..)The game has lots of amazing views and looks extremely pretty despite it's old graphics. It's often critisied for being too hard but it just take patience and knowledge to get your♥♥♥♥♥to next area or defeat that boss. The replayablity is BIG, while 100% the game can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥it's still a fun thing to do. Also doing challenge runs can be great new experience. The online play in the vannila game is a tad bit tedious, it doesnt work well and it has lots of problems.  With mods you can fix that problem which can make the game a lot more fun (altough I think you should always do your first playtrough alone as it could possibly ruin your experience)  The PvP isn't the best but it works... If I kept going I'd ruin many suprises and possibly spoil too much. One of my favourite games ever, 9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Everything there is to say about Dark Souls has been said. If you stumble on this little review, just know that it's renowned for a reason. Deep mechanics, gameplay that never gets tiresome, endless replayability, innovative multiplayer, and a story that isn't forcefed to you. The only game I cared enough about to get all the achievements, the only game I've enjoyed enough to play through more than once, and the only game I'd recommend to anyone who likes games.My only gripe is that the PvP mechanics are so much different than the PvE mechanics. When you're ready to try and take on other players online, throw out what you learned about fighting from the computer. It's a shame because PvE has a well-defined set of rules, but PvP has an entirely different tempo and features a lot of bugs and exploits (dead angling, for instance), especially with experienced players. Don't get me wrong, it's learnable, and rewarding in its own right, but it's very different than the rest of the game.If you're just starting you should know two things about the legendary difficulty of the game. 1. Combat is unforgiving - learn the controls and the tempo (button mashers won't win at DS).  2. Game mechanics are obtuse and not explained very well in game - avoid spoilers but learn the mechanics from a wiki (at minimum, understand how poise works and how endurance/encumbrance works). You'll have a much better time. It doesn't come easy but when it does, it's more rewarding than any other game you'll play.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Dark Souls One is my most beloved game of all time, even beating Ultimate DOOM and Metroid Prime which were among the first and greatest games I ever played. It's a Dark Fantasty styled RPG that doesn't hold your hand through the game, hell not even the story, leaving you to fill in the blanks which created one of the biggest lore communities for a video game that's ever been made. It's easily my favorite game of all time, and is a godly title, throwing you into a dark curse world that'll tear you apart over and over and is heavily inspired by my favorite book/comic series ever made, Berserk, and if you know what Berserk is then you'll see all the inspiration and love for it in this game. While you'll need the DSFix mod to even make the game playable in terms of frame rate and bugs, and another mod for the online connection and PVP to even be close to stable, it's the greatest game I've ever played. The huge variety of enemies, the level design, the soundtrack, the characters, the lore, the story, everything besides the games sadly unstable fps and bugginess is damn near perfect, and is one of the very, very few games I'd ever give a 10/10 rating too (There's only 6 others out of every game I've ever played) and the replayability for this game is at a high level as well, and that's not even including the still very active community in the PVP part of the game. The Souls series itself is a beautiful collection, and this is simply the greatest of all of them, and my favorite RPG I've ever played.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												I decided to review this game without much hours played because I have finished this game on Xbox 360. Let's get straight off to the review.Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition is a role-playing, difficult game developed by From Software (best known for their difficult games, Dark Souls series, Bloodborne and Demon Souls). This game was a spiritual successor to its predecessor, Demon Souls on PS3 exclusively. You have been started off as a customised undead character, you can play as 10 starting classes. The synopsis is purely minimalistic, so you have to interpret the whole story of the game. Prepare to Die Edition includes the DLC, Artorias of the Abyss. The gameplay mechanics and combat system are simple. Combat system is what this game is known for. Controller is the essential for this game or else you will die,a lot. This game is not a gung ho fest, you need a strategy for every single enemies you encounter. Reading attack patterns, when to use the item and most likely how to use stamina effectively. Co-Op system is kind of complex because you need a specific item that your friend summons you to their world to defeat their boss at any place (Jolly Cooperation yay!). The PvP in this game is great but I keep getting destroyed by Dark Souls veterans (I suck at dueling). Downside in this game? Yes, a big one. Poor PC optimization is the issue because it locks at 30fps and keyboard and mouse controls are terrible. Thankfully, you can download the 60fps mod. But it's not only the PC port issue, sorcerer class is OP because the damage is just broken and you can defeat every boss fight even without a hitch if you know how to build a sorcerer. Also, this game is not for everyone. The game suits for anyone who wants to conquer the hardship of the game or getting better at it.Pros+10 different classes+ Replayability (New Game Plus)+ Hidden Rooms and Secrets+ Amazing atmosphere and cryptic loreCons- Horrendous PC Port- Clunky controls for keyboard and mouse users (Controller, duh)- Sorcerer class is brokenI am wrapping this review up. The great; combat, atmosphere, combat system, cryptic lore, classes. The not-so-great; PC port, clunky controls for keyboard and mouse users and sorcerer class beyond OP (it's such a stupid complaint ever from me). I am giving this game a 9 out of 10, a solid recommendation. Even though, this game is not everyone, I highly recommended for gamers who are determined to play the game.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												After 70 total hours of gameplay I finally managed to finish Dark Souls. I started it over several times, often getting bored after reaching a certain turning point in the story, too intimidated to face "the big guys". Thus the first few areas of the game became very familiar to me and I couldn't resist the temptation to aggressively wiki the rest. In certain fashion, so, I had beaten the game long before I actually beat it.I usually don't have the stamina to replay any game, sometimes playing it through once is too much. Dark Souls, however, is one that never ceases to capture my attention. I'm pretty sure everything has been said concerning its polished combat system and deep, not-straight-in-your-face story, so these points don't need too much repeating. Those, however, are exactly the points that keep inviting me back again and again. It's not too often when a game dares to be difficult but fair, deep and intricate but modest and secretive at the same. It's not lightly that I consider the Souls series one of the best franchises we've had, perhaps for all time.It's actually pretty difficult to find anything to criticize. You could of course compare Demon's Souls to Dark Souls and find something to nitpick about, or compate Dark Souls 2 to Dark Souls and find something you are unhappy with. Personally I think it's very difficult to find anything meaningful to criticize. Each game does its own thing as it sees fit and I've never seen anyone denounce any of these games as totally unplayable. For me Dark Souls acts as a first encounter with a certain type of gameplay and storytelling that is practically impossible to top anymore. After 70 hours of playing and nearly the same amount watching speedruns, lore videos, let's plays and reading the Wikis, Dark Souls has embedded itself in my consciousness perhaps irreversably. It's said that you never forget your first love and it's pretty much guaranteed in my case, with this game.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												I'll start off the review by saying that this is best action RPG I've ever played.  It easily has some of the best combat in any game I've played.  The game is at times frustratingly fun to play but also immensely rewarding when you achieve victory.  This is a game that doesn't hold your hand.  Nothing is given to you, everything has to be found and fought for.  Even going for what seems to be the simplest item can sometimes lead to death.  If you want to learn the lore you have to look for it, even a conversation with an NPC can have negative consequences if you rush through it.  If you do want some help the game has allowed for other players to leave tips/hints around the map.  It was really neat to read some of the tips and they were helpful, but they are great because they are optional, if you don't want any help/spoilers you can skip them entirely.One of the best parts about this game is the amount of character customization it offers.  You have the ability to almost fully make the charcter how you want.  Picking a starting class doesn't force you to go down a specific route or path and you have to follow a certain skill tree.  Instead you can spec your character how you want, put points into the way you want to play the game.  At the same time the combination of weapons/armour/rings/items also lets your further how you want to play.  It makes it really feel like your character and should you choose to play through multiple times your character can be completely different from a previous play through.I only have two small complaints about the game.  The first is about the camera.  At tiimes the camera was just outright frustrating with no fun attatched.  The lock on/camera system would at times ignore the enemy I looking at and pick an enemy clear across the room.  Or there was times I would try to lock on to an enemy only to have my camera just spin around and I didn't lock onto anything.  Also the lock on system seemed to be a little inconsistent in the distance it takes to lock on to some enemies.  Some enemies I could lock on clear across a room while others needed to be right in my face before I could get locked on.  It was annoying but happened so infrequently that it's not a big complaint.Only other complaint was about a particular area later in the game.  The game does a good job of punishing you vs the enemies you fight, or presents a challenge in a particular area that you can overcome with having some smart item or weapon/armour usage.  However that last area didn't seem to fit that mold and felt out of place.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Pretty good. I've put over 500 hours into this game on PS3 alone and I still come back to it sometimes. A lot of variety with weapons and how you can level up your character over time, and many ways to challenge yourself when you get bored. I also recommend going into this game as blind as possible. Guides, wikis, and videos will ruin your first experience.extra thing from the future:In the past, I may have recommended the console version over this one just because of how terrible Games for Windows Live was, but thankfully, in the past year or so some brave souls from bamco and/or fromsoft decided to completely transfer the online service from GFWL to Steamworks and remove region locking, eliminating any problems I had with this version of the game. This is the definitive version of Dark Souls; even without DSfix installed.Also, you've probably already heard this if you've looked into the game at all, but you will need to use DSfix if you want to get rid of the cap on the framerate and make the game look a little prettier, but installation and configuration of the tool is relatively quick and painless in most cases.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												I'll start off the review by saying that this is best action RPG I've ever played.  It easily has some of the best combat in any game I've played.  The game is at times frustratingly fun to play but also immensely rewarding when you achieve victory.  This is a game that doesn't hold your hand.  Nothing is given to you, everything has to be found and fought for.  Even going for what seems to be the simplest item can sometimes lead to death.  If you want to learn the lore you have to look for it, even a conversation with an NPC can have negative consequences if you rush through it.  If you do want some help the game has allowed for other players to leave tips/hints around the map.  It was really neat to read some of the tips and they were helpful, but they are great because they are optional, if you don't want any help/spoilers you can skip them entirely.One of the best parts about this game is the amount of character customization it offers.  You have the ability to almost fully make the charcter how you want.  Picking a starting class doesn't force you to go down a specific route or path and you have to follow a certain skill tree.  Instead you can spec your character how you want, put points into the way you want to play the game.  At the same time the combination of weapons/armour/rings/items also lets your further how you want to play.  It makes it really feel like your character and should you choose to play through multiple times your character can be completely different from a previous play through.I only have two small complaints about the game.  The first is about the camera.  At tiimes the camera was just outright frustrating with no fun attatched.  The lock on/camera system would at times ignore the enemy I looking at and pick an enemy clear across the room.  Or there was times I would try to lock on to an enemy only to have my camera just spin around and I didn't lock onto anything.  Also the lock on system seemed to be a little inconsistent in the distance it takes to lock on to some enemies.  Some enemies I could lock on clear across a room while others needed to be right in my face before I could get locked on.  It was annoying but happened so infrequently that it's not a big complaint.Only other complaint was about a particular area later in the game.  The game does a good job of punishing you vs the enemies you fight, or presents a challenge in a particular area that you can overcome with having some smart item or weapon/armour usage.  However that last area didn't seem to fit that mold and felt out of place.

												Excellent game, but requires a mod to fix the horrible port. It also requires a mod to fix multiplayer and requires a mod to fix button prompts for those who don't use controllers. The story isn't that great, but people buy this game just to kill stuff and not care about the story, right? The game can be challenging at first, but you'll (probably) adapt to it in no time. Buy it at 20$ if you wish, but I strongly recommend buying this on sale. It can go as low as 5$, probably even lower. Have fun invading, getting invaded, and engaging in jolly cooperation!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Too many modern games hold your hand while you play. Dark Souls doesn't like that fact. This game's sole purpose is to remind you that you are not an unstoppable juggernaut. Every enemy can kill you, and believe me they will try their hardest to make it happen. Each victory in this game is backed by a hundred failures, but that just makes success a hundred times sweeter. You will fight, you will lose, you will respawn, you will try again, and you will not give up. Why? Because every attempt brings you one step closer to the inevitable outcome:  you will win. Welcome to Dark Souls. Prepare to Die.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												In a surprising turn of events, Dark Souls puts any and all responsibility of failure on the player.Got killed by an enemy? You did something wrong.Fell into a pit? You did something wrong.Died from poison? You did something wrong.But there's no limit to how many attempts you get at making it through a hurdle. And, if you learn from every mistake, you will make it through said hurdle, every hurdle. You do not need luck, only determination and the ability to learn.The game itself is a third-person Action RPG minus most of the loot casino. There are some random drops, but it's only to get early access to specific weapons (black knight ones, iirc). You progress through an area, talk to people, fight monsters, challenge bosses, and upgrade your equipment and/or character. Some weapons will be better for some players and/or characters, but there's plenty to choose from, and most of them are good enough to see you through the game.The setting is gothic dark fantasy, reinforced by the state of ruin and/or abandonment you find most things in, and NPCs are generally a grim lot. Genuinely nice and/or jolly people are few and far between.Multiplayer is different than what you'd expect, and requires some adjustment to fully use. Player-written messages are a great feature, but be wary of ruses. You really think someone would do that? Just go on the internet and tell lies? Yes.Due to this being a console port, it is highly recommended to play the game with a controller. Xbox360 controller behaves flawlessly. And you'll probably want to get DSFix to help bring the game up to a more visually pleasant standard (above 30fps framerate as well as texture quality).All in all, it's a great game, and you should give it a go. Just keep trying and you'll make it through.Don't you dare go hollow.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												From my own experience, the real enjoyment of the game wasn't just the challenge of the game, but how dynamic the combat is and how interesting it is to see how different playstyles, weapons, spells, items, armor interact against certain enemies and players.The game does not hold you back on anything, it has a relatively fast tutorial and its areas are can be open. Although certain situations can become "linear", and may lack some options, the game itself shines in the fact that almost any situation is possible to complete even with the worst kind of gear, it will just take skill, and a bit of luck.I should warn the game can be incredibly vague, and that there are some gameplay aspects that are never explained (poise damage, humanity counter 'XP')Because the game was rushed, some things might feel a bit 'lacking' and there are some design issues that may show this.play cautiously, but play to die, because that's the entire point of the game.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												This game is one of my favourites for this decade. Dark Souls is a harsh, unforgiving but still such a rewarding game. So first im going to tell you the fact that you are going to die.....alot. But the feeling when you kill a boss that you've been struggling with for many hours is  incredibly satisfying. The game is meant for people who are not afraid of spending alot of time and for people that have very good nerves. I've found myself throwing my controller to the wall but I've also found myself kissing the controller when I get through a really hard area of the game. But this game isn't perfect, sometimes it takes 30-50 minutes to find yourself a co-op partner due to Dark Souls not having it's own servers for multiplayer. But for me, that's the only negative thing about this game. Also if you're planning to play on a keyboard,, it might overhelm you due to it's weird  default key-bindings. But that problem can be easily solved by re-binding the keys to whatever you desire. But after all the game is a wonderful piece of art with it's unique world and it's sometimes ridiculously hard boss fights. I can't wait for DS2!  "Praise the Sun!" ~|Edu|10/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Dark Souls is like a slow, strategic, punishing, survival horror hack n slash story and multiplayer hybrid game.For starters, It has engaging enemies and bosses that have interesting design. Secondly, immersive exploration and great level design as the whole world is cleverly interconnected and the shortcuts are well placed and can surprise you .To add to that, there is a huge variety of play styles and weapons/magic/miracles to choose from and it's an added bonus that you can not only forge weapons from bosses, but also forge them from tails of certain bosses if you manage to cut their tails off.Last but not least, the ambiguous lore really adds to the experience as well since it's intriguing not quite knowing the answers but having to imagine yourself what's really going on. You're given fragments of information through item descriptions and and clues through all sorts of details when you're playing. There are barely any cutscenes. Nevertheless, there are some problems - level design starts to suffer in the second half, one boss sucks so much A S S that you'll question if you want to touch this game ever again (but makes up for having some of the best and most intense at least), and poor framerate at times. Overall, this is one of my favourite games of all time and I'm glad I got to play this. You'll die a lot and at times question why you're playing a game where you die so much. But trust me, it's worth it. Overcoming the challenges of certain areas and bosses or even discovering things yourself are incredible sensations of joy that Dark Souls emulates so well.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												                                                    This game is wonderful if you have the patience for it.       Your first run is going to be garbage. Now I can't say that for a lot of games, but this one really holds true to that. I put fifty hours into my first character, only to figure out that my build was♥♥♥♥♥♥ the combat was lacking, and overall my experience was flaccid. Instead of playing it safe with a simple sword and shield, I made a new character with a strength-focused build. Shoving all my points into strength and endurance, I tanked out every enemy in the game, and you know what? That wasn't enough. I was constantly wondering, "Man, I wonder how this♥♥♥♥♥♥would run if I had a dex build..." or "This♥♥♥♥♥♥would be easy as ♥♥♥♥ if I was using a mage." Thoughts like that are what makes this game so damn re-playable.        The dialogue in this game (albeit limited), is pretty involving. Just about every npc can be killed, and the reward for killing them can be tempting (sorry Priscilla). Lore is aplenty in Lordran, but you'll probably not catch it all on your first run. You're the chosen undead on a quest to either rule the world of dark, or keep the age of light alive a bit longer. Items found throughout the game give lead to this lore via their description, however some can be cryptic unless some though is put into them.      The budget of this game is very apparent. Some areas are masterly done and nigh perfect, while others are SO garbage, that despite my love for this game I can't help but call out their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I won't spoil it for you, but god you'll know it when you see it (I'm looking at YOU, Lost Izalith).      Combat is extremely satisfying, and the move style for many weapons are very unique. Of course, you can't have every sword swing in some ridiculous special way, but you can still feel the difference between each one.      PVP is mostly dead at this point, but there's still the chance that you can be invaded by other players. Not much else to say besides that.      The difficulty of the game isn't nearly as much as it's acclaimed to be. Maybe I'm just fantastic at this game (har har), but as long as you're patient and accustomed to the combat, it's a breeze. I'm not saying it's easy, but rather that it's fair.      This is one of my favorite games, and despite having so many hours in, I'm sure I can squeeze an easy hundred more out of it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I loved this game more than I imagined I would, but I want to stress something: the game is a great game overall regardless of its difficulty.  This game is not just noteworthy for being unforgiving at times: it is an amazingly well-designed game in general.  My friend had been trying to get me to play it for years and I finally got around to it.The level design is possibly the best I have seen in any game.  Other games like the Metroid series may have done it first but it is absolutely delightful how so many of the areas interconnect, and opening a shortcut to find out it led back to somewhere I had been in a way I never expected was always extremely rewarding.  Aside from two instances in which you get rings to survive in certain areas the progression itself is not like Metroid, but the level design most definitely is.  It's disappointing to hear the second and third games do not have such a complex interconnected layout, but this game set the bar so high it would be very difficult to match it.That leads me to another thing about the level design: This is a game that takes place in a three dimensional world.  Too many games treat the world as mostly 2D with perhaps a couple floors of height. This game is absolutely massive, and that includes the use of vertical space.The difficulty was not as bad as I expected.  One particular fight did take four hours of attempts to beat, but the game overall was not as consistently difficult as I had expected.  While bonfire (checkpoint) placement can be moderately far from a boss battle sometimes, without exception you can learn to run past most of the enemies to get back to a boss battle fairly quickly.  I am sure unforgiving difficulty ramps up considerably in New Game+, but I am talking about just a normal run of the game.  Fighting bosses in this game is very much akin to the Mega Man series.  You learn the moves they can do and how to deal with them, and eventually you take less damage than they do and you win.  I am not someone that is into tough games, but it is still very satisfying finally beating a touch foe.  My friend put it well: he said the game has a high learning curve and people mistakenly think that means it is very difficult all the way through.  The game has tough moments, but most of all I think it is a very fun and satisfying experience.In short, this game is among the best because it is so incredibly well-designed.  That it can be unforgiving at times is not

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												If you like instant gratification, this game is not for you, however, if you have the tendency to put your genitals into the blender just to see what happens... This game might just be what you want. (Disclaimer: don't put your genitals, or any bodyparts for that matter, into the blender.Dark Souls is hard, it is as hard as you've heard it would be and then some. But boy does it feel goed when you finaly kill that one enemy, usualy only to find out there's actually two more around the corner. The game gives you little to go on for that matter; if you die, you're propably not on the right track, yet. Either that or you have to step up your game a little.But where the game itself doesn't tell you to much, the other players actually help quite a lot; with information scrabbled on the floor or as a spirit against a boss. When they are not helping you however, prepare for some prison shower♥♥♥♥♥♥invasions in which you will definatly get the worst of it. But that might just be my bad luck talking.The short version of  real review would be:Do you like to level up against foes you cannot beat? Do you like to see yourself die, a lot? Do you want to pummel your low level enemies into the ground when revisiting an area? Do you want the most awome stuff?Yeah? buy this game.If you do not want to try and try and try again, just so you can die 5 feet further, play farmville.And don't forget: praise the sun.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Bixo, vou te contar uma história sobre esse jogo. É que nem você sair por aí tentando achar a mulher que é o amor da sua vida. Vou começar comparando com uma festa. Você começa conversando com aquelas mulheres que não são tão lindas, aquelas que você vê que são menos confiantes mesmo só pra esquentar. Aí você vê uma linda e fica meio nervoso... Mas ♥♥♥♥-se, sempre vai ter mulher por aí né? Você esquentou e ralou pra se sentir confiante, aí a rainha com rosto reluzente, cabelos brilhantes, olhos azuis que nem as águas do Caribe e com corpo de Deusa Grega do Olímpo te dá a maior patada que você já tomou. A conversa não durou nem 5 segundos. Você sai♥♥♥♥♥♥e frustrado achando que ela é uma vadia de♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Reclama pro seu amigo que toda mulher é uma vadia que não presta.Você vai esfriando enquanto tenta dançar um pouco, conversa com mais umas mulheres, faz umas amizades com uns brother no meio do nada e decide chegar em outra mina linda. Talvez na mesma. Você toma outro tapa emocional que arranca sua alma fora.Você não desiste e começa até a se divertir tomando esses tapas. Uma hora você taca o ♥♥♥♥-se e decide que nessa festa você não vai conseguir arranjar uma aspirante à modelo da Playboy.Aí acontece.Você tenta mais uma vez, depois de se ♥♥♥♥♥ x0 vezes seguidas e sempre tentando diferente, mas dessa vez você percebe alguma coisa a mais, algum bagulho diferente que você não tinha notado antes. Do nada a mulher tá te agarrando como se você fosse Zeus em pele e osso. Você não tá acreditando. Sua mão ta tremendo pra♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ você não sabe direito o que fazer, mas aconteceu e você tá em êxtase. Você sabe que valeu a pena se ♥♥♥♥♥ todas aquelas vezes pra chegar aonde você chegou. E bixo, daí em diante você só melhora. Passam alguns anos e quase toda modelo de bíquini com quem você conversa tá na sua mão. Você já tá confiante pra♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥e sabe que provavelmente vai dar tudo certo, e também tem certeza de que se você se ♥♥♥♥♥ é muuuuito fácil tentar de novo. Você entende que se ♥♥♥♥♥ na verdade não é se ♥♥♥♥♥, mas sim uma chance de tentar diferente. E♥♥♥♥♥♥que pariu, sentir isso é um sentimento do caraaaalho.Agora velho, quando já se pensou que a ♥♥♥♥♥ de um jogo virtual seria exatamente assim? Dark Souls. Tu só se fode, fica♥♥♥♥♥♥pra♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ aí enquanto voce tá no pico da fúria, como se fosse Deus tacando um meteoro no Brasil porque ele tá♥♥♥♥♥♥pra♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥por causa do Fluminense ter caído pra segundona, do nada você mata o Boss.♥♥♥♥♥♥que pariu, tu não acredita, treme, entra em nirvana e é como se fosse uma explosão de emoção dentro de você.Compra, joga e não desiste. 10/10

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												*IMPORTANT*If you do not have a gamepad hooked up to your computer, Dark Souls has an incredibly difficult control scheme using IJKL for your right hand, as the mouse does NOTHING. Buy a cheap wired controller for the X Box (or similar) at minimum, else you will not enjoy Dark Souls to its fullest.*Review/ Why is this game impossible?!?!*Dark Souls has some of the best combat mechanics of any RPG. Each of the plethora of weapons has its own distinct style of fighting, with different styles being more useful in certain situations than in others. Whilst the massive learning curve at the beginning of the game seems brutal, mastering the basic controls will take you far. Whilst the game may seem impossible in some situations, it's only really difficult because you're trying to achieve something in the least effective way. Swinging a sword around in cramped tunnels is far less effective than stabbing enemies with spears, but the sword is more useful on an open field against multiple opponents, while a slow and more powerful weapon (such as a great sword) will be more useful against bosses. Also, be observant of your environment, as it will save you from some nasty deaths. Find a bridge which is scorched, has parts of it on fire still and has multiple dead scorched bodies on it? It probably means that something burnt it all to a crisp and it may still be around, so be careful.Also, think about what type of build you want to make. A jack-of-all trades who does magic and uses miracles (like magic, but more focussed on buffing yourself via healing and similar) whilst wielding heavy swords and wearing armour will mean that you will spend a lot of time trying to grind levels, which is incredibly tedious. So instead, before you begin, ask yourself "What type of style do I want to play as?" Once you have a general idea, poke around on the internet to see what stats are relevant to that class/ style before you start. If you don't get it right immediately, that's OK. I personally had gotten a fair way into the game and realised that my person wasn't what I wanted, as I was struggling due to running out of health potions constantly. I switched from an un-optimised warrior to a cleric with miracles to heal myself, and it made my first full run through a lot easier than it would have been otherwise.One of the most useful things one can do once you arrive in Lordran (a message telling you that you are in Lordran will appear up the top) is to look at a route telling you where you should be going. Whenever you enter a new area, a message will appear up the top informing you so. Using a guide such as this one ( http://darksoulswiki.wikispaces.com/Game+Progress+Route ) will help you know what you should be looking for.So all in all, after being told how to make the game seem less impossible, should you buy it? If any part of the above interested you, then yes, you should buy it. If you're looking for a new game to play with fantastic fighting mechanics with awesome boss battles interspaced, then yes. If you're simply looking for a new game to play and invest some time in, then yes. And if you really want to understand why people are excited for a Dark Souls II, then buy it.

												If you like instant gratification, this game is not for you, however, if you have the tendency to put your genitals into the blender just to see what happens... This game might just be what you want. (Disclaimer: don't put your genitals, or any bodyparts for that matter, into the blender.Dark Souls is hard, it is as hard as you've heard it would be and then some. But boy does it feel goed when you finaly kill that one enemy, usualy only to find out there's actually two more around the corner. The game gives you little to go on for that matter; if you die, you're propably not on the right track, yet. Either that or you have to step up your game a little.But where the game itself doesn't tell you to much, the other players actually help quite a lot; with information scrabbled on the floor or as a spirit against a boss. When they are not helping you however, prepare for some prison shower♥♥♥♥♥♥invasions in which you will definatly get the worst of it. But that might just be my bad luck talking.The short version of  real review would be:Do you like to level up against foes you cannot beat? Do you like to see yourself die, a lot? Do you want to pummel your low level enemies into the ground when revisiting an area? Do you want the most awome stuff?Yeah? buy this game.If you do not want to try and try and try again, just so you can die 5 feet further, play farmville.And don't forget: praise the sun.

												TL:DRIf Dark Souls was a person, it'd be a dominatrix girlfriend. It will abuse you, make you feel worthless, like you're less than nothing, but you stay with it because every now and then, it gives you the night of your life, where it makes all of your messed-up fantasies come true.EDIT: I beat the game recently (a week or two ago since this edit) and while I really enjoyed it, I found it to be REALLY unfair quite a few times. *Cough* Sen's Fortress and the Tomb of The Giants *cough* I still pretty much agree with my initial review of the game, although that first dungeon I was talking about was actually one of the last you're supposed to go to. (Oops on my part, and dickish on the developers'. I mean come on, a little hint in the right direction would've been nice, especially since it's damn near impossible to find your way out of said dungeon) Nevertheless, if you're up to a quite intense and brutal challenge with many deaths, swear words, ragequits and sleepless nights, then I definitely recommend this to you.Kept this part because people thought it was funny or something:Do you hate your life but not have the guts to end it? Well, worry no more! If you buy this game, you'll have COUNTLESS more reasons to hate yourself, and it'll give you the push you need to kick that bucket just as hard as I kicked my computer after trying to beat the first dungeon with a MAX LEVEL character. (Hint: I failed) Seriously, I like my games challenging, but I also like them possible. I'm beginning to think that the developers of this game only made it so difficult because they were too lazy to program anything past the first 9001+ hours of the game. (Which is to say, the first dungeon) In the time you could beat the first dungeon, you could've beaten the Water Temple from the Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time approximately 98,432,753,985,476,219,743,057,239,764,396,329,743,765,964,329,746,975,649,762,197,265,976,493^85,749,938,938,659x10^9001(Omg^bbq/wtf) times with your eyes closed.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												If classic video games have equivalents in the realm of literature, I'd argue that "Dark Souls" is video gaming's very own "Paradise Lost" or "Divine Comedy."  It's basically a big, brilliant, video game rendering of hell.  Not so much in its setting, although it is set in a land populated by undead, but more so in its game mechanics.  “Dark Souls” is a game all about suffering in the pursuit of perpetually unfulfilled and unfulfillable desires.  Such an approach to gameplay certainly isn’t new to video games. Many MMO’s have made an endless progression of “carrots on a stick” into a business model.  What’s unique about “Dark Souls,” however, is its hostility to the player in obtaining these carrots.  It goes out of its way to make sure that players suffer in pursuit of the desire to beat the next boss, get the better armor, or level up one more time.  Not only will you die and die repeatedly, but once you accomplish one desire, there’s always something new to replace it (another boss! another set of armor!  higher stats!, New Game +!, New Game ++!, etc, etc, etc).  Indeed, upon completing the game, in the “good” ending your avatar’s body is burned off into nothingness, perhaps being freed from its perpetual cycles of unfulfillable desire, yet you yourself are spit right back into the start of the game, repeating everything once more only with harder enemies and the devious promise of greater rewards.The conception of hell as being existence dominated by perpetually repeating cycles of unfullfillable desire probably has more relationship to eastern religious traditions than western (no surprise that the game is Japanese). In other words, in its gameplay mechanics, it could be argued that “Dark Souls” is basically “Paradise Lost: Buddhist edition.”  There are western analogies too, though. CS Lewis outlined a similar conception of hell from a Christian perspective in "The Great Divorce," arguing that hell is ultimately nothing more than a mindset characterized by endlessly and obsessively repeated cycles of thought.  And for the atheists among us, Sartre's "No Exit" might be another literary analogy, not only because Sartre defined human existence as the mind’s impossible desire to be both being “in itself” and “for itself” at once, but also because the ability for players in "Dark Souls" to "invade" your single player game and kill you at inopportune times makes the famous statement in "No Exit" that "hell is other people" completely apt.In case it isn't clear, though, saying that playing “Dark Souls” is like being in hell is maybe one of the nicest things I’ve ever said about a game.  "Dark Souls" is not just one of the leanest, meanest, and best ARPGS I've ever played, but one of the best video games I've played, period.  It’s a game where everything it has to say is reduced entirely to the language of its own game mechanics.  It’s not trying to tell a story, or create compelling characters, or be a movie or a book.  It’s simply a game and any meaning that you could potentially derive from this comes almost entirely from its status as a game.  This makes it, if not one of the best RPGs ever, definitely the most honest.  It's just simple, unadorned, brilliantly designed, and entirely compelling gameplay. An RPG boiled down to its absolute essence of dying, developing combat skills, and dying again in the endless pursuit of more loot and more power.  The lack of trappings such as plot or character that might distract from what it actually is, gives the game the odd and entirely unique effect of deconstructing itself as you play it.  You quickly realize that any goal you obtain will inevitably be replaced by another goal that’s further away, so you actively start to question the point of pursuing those goals....in the same heartbeat that you willingly spend 2 more hours grinding souls for armor that you don’t need (because it will raise my physical defense stats by 5 points, damn it, so I have to have it!).  No game has made me question my own motives and reasons for playing it, and, indeed, actively dared me not to play it, more than “Dark Souls.”  Which I think is kind of brilliant in its way.  “Dark Soul’s” ultimate lesson, if it has one, is that in games, as in life, the only way to truly beat the “hellish” cycle of perpetual desire is to quit playing entirely.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I loved this game more than I imagined I would, but I want to stress something: the game is a great game overall regardless of its difficulty.  This game is not just noteworthy for being unforgiving at times: it is an amazingly well-designed game in general.  My friend had been trying to get me to play it for years and I finally got around to it.The level design is possibly the best I have seen in any game.  Other games like the Metroid series may have done it first but it is absolutely delightful how so many of the areas interconnect, and opening a shortcut to find out it led back to somewhere I had been in a way I never expected was always extremely rewarding.  Aside from two instances in which you get rings to survive in certain areas the progression itself is not like Metroid, but the level design most definitely is.  It's disappointing to hear the second and third games do not have such a complex interconnected layout, but this game set the bar so high it would be very difficult to match it.That leads me to another thing about the level design: This is a game that takes place in a three dimensional world.  Too many games treat the world as mostly 2D with perhaps a couple floors of height. This game is absolutely massive, and that includes the use of vertical space.The difficulty was not as bad as I expected.  One particular fight did take four hours of attempts to beat, but the game overall was not as consistently difficult as I had expected.  While bonfire (checkpoint) placement can be moderately far from a boss battle sometimes, without exception you can learn to run past most of the enemies to get back to a boss battle fairly quickly.  I am sure unforgiving difficulty ramps up considerably in New Game+, but I am talking about just a normal run of the game.  Fighting bosses in this game is very much akin to the Mega Man series.  You learn the moves they can do and how to deal with them, and eventually you take less damage than they do and you win.  I am not someone that is into tough games, but it is still very satisfying finally beating a touch foe.  My friend put it well: he said the game has a high learning curve and people mistakenly think that means it is very difficult all the way through.  The game has tough moments, but most of all I think it is a very fun and satisfying experience.In short, this game is among the best because it is so incredibly well-designed.  That it can be unforgiving at times is not

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Personal Rating: 6 of 10If you ever thought of sinking your grubby hands into this game, you must remember that winning isn't the goal of the game; dying is. I play RPGs like Skyrim, Risen, Witcher, well you get the idea. Some might classifiy those games as amateur stuff but trust me, Dark Souls takes RPG difficulty right to the next dimension. I basically got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked by a bunch of common low level skeletons. This game requires tonnes of patients to play so be warned. Also the controls are horrendeous even with a controller (yes I do own one) so I don't blame the port. To give a little insight on the difficulty level:- Game is open world where there are no quests or story to guide you so you simply explore and pray you are in the area that suits your level.- Puzzles are challenging (I consider finding exits as puzzle) because there are no indication and some places are well hidden.- Since there are no map you need to memorise the location.- Enemies are tough and can easily kill you. They sometimes spawn in a group that consists of range, melee and tank so you really need to plan. Potions are limited and it takes time to consume so imagine the mini boss and boss fights.- I really doubt that there is anyone who can win in an encounter with a mini boss or a boss the first time even with the clues given in game as you really need to study the behaviour. I once encounter a gigantic minataur and it charges at me non stop. During me second reload,  I saw arrows raining behind and notice a tower which I can climb. I thought well there it is the place where I can snipe this brute. Third attempt I climb the tower and dispose of the 2 skeletons and begin my genius plan. The minataur was just below the tower and he leaped onto the tower behind me and charge towards me knocking me down and I died. - I don't really understand the story since the opening cinematic and the beginning of the story has no relation but then again, I gave up on the game before even progressing 5% maybe? This may cause confusion since you have absolutely no clue on what to do or where to go.- There are no quick save or save point I dare say unless you progress till quite the next area. In order to recover your health you can rest at bonfires but this will cause all minions to respawn as well. This can be good since you need to grind for souls to upgrade youself or buy some items.- You need to figure out the system in the game since tutorial is close to nothing in this game.- Exploring is really rewarding as you can get powerful items you need to keep your eyes peeled and question every damned thing.Configuration options are kept at minimal since console don't have much to configure but there is a resolution option. The graphics is relatively nice but I am rather satisfied with the voice acting. Overall Dark Souls is a decent RPG game and it is meant for real hardcore RPG fans with passion, wit and wisdom. The reason for the 6 is not because of what it is lacking because I'd assume it is what makes the game and that it was planned this way. But I think the port is really bad even though there are some mods to compensate for but I generally think it should be the developers responsibility to bear.So unless you are in for some frustrating death and repetition, Risen and The Witcher isn't really such a bad game.
