content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #39 - Dark Souls: Prepare to Die EditionI like that they called this Prepare to Die Edition, as a not so subtle warning about the difficulty of the game.  My first death was pretty hilarious.  I went through this portal and ended up on a ledge above a huge Asylum Demon.  I'm looking down on this guy thinking to myself that he is going to kick my♥♥♥♥♥ and trying to figure out a strategy.  I thought to myself, at least I am safe up on this ledge, and no sooner than I thought that, the demon smashes the ledge with his ridiculously sized hammer, and I fall to my death.The game doesn't start off immediately hard.  Instead it gives a tutorial to ease you into things.  In the first area, you'll run across a series of messages which will introduce you to the different controls in the game.  So you get some time to get a feel for things before you are thrown in the grinder.I thought the graphics were okay, but it's pretty obvious that this is a console port.  I also found it much easier to play with a controller rather than the mouse and keyboard.  I wouldn't go so far as to call it a bad port, it's just more of a straight port without any graphical enhancements for the PC.  This may be a turn off for some, but it didn't really bother me any.As difficult as the game is, dying doesn't really have much of a consequence other than having to restart from the last checkpoint.  There's no permadeath or anything like that.  The game expects you to die many many times, and to experiment with different combat strategies.  If you are easilly frustrated, this game may not be the right one for you, but for me the combat was a lot of fun and outweighed the frustration of dying.  For $20 I definitely think it's worth the buy, just heed the title and be prepared to die.

Posted: May 10, 2016
												About two years ago, I stopped playing this game because Blighttown frustrated me to no end. It came to the point that I gave up, never touched it again, but liked it enough that I bought its sequel. The same thing happened to Dark Souls II; I got tired of dying a lot that I gave up on it after 25 hours. With the surging popularity of the series once again with the release of Dark Souls III I decided to give this game another shot. As of now, I've finished my Thief playthrough and began playing through New Game 1, and at the same time started on another character, a Cleric. It's a terrible port, even with DSFix it's still runs slowly, but it's now my favorite game of all time. No other game gives such satisfaction from defeating a boss. So if you're tired of playing modern games that hold your hand too much, give this game a try.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
nukes-viewHi all, nukes here.Dark Souls: Prepare to Die is a action role playing third person style game, a spiritual successor of Demon's Souls. Based on "Don't make the same mistake twice philosophy this game is definitely challenging and not for the weak minded. I honestly cannot count how many times I died on Dark Souls, it says it in the title but still doesn't prepare you. So Dark Souls, a fantastic game which will make your blood boil when you die, but brilliant none the less. The combat mechanics based around medieval weapons, levelling system and exploration of this game are what sold it. I really enjoyed the different style of play to most games. If you have heard or enjoyed any of the Dark Souls series this is where the heart is, I strongly recommend playing it.The Game PlayBefore you start on your journey you are able to create a character. By choosing a class you are presented with various options and choices related to a point based skill system.I chose a deprived class which lets you start off as pretty much a blank slate. Possibly one of the more challenging characters to play, but one that you can shape, from the get go.After character creation you play a cursed undead (Hollow), locked away from the world. Which needs to escape, on the way out you face up to some nasty enemies and other things.Killing said things will give you lovely souls which is in game currency for everything. When I say everything, I mean everything.Killing is done in a variety of ways, with different weapons to magic.Dying means you drop those lovely souls you have acquired, giving you one chance to redeem those souls from where you died. Failing at this chance means you lose those preciously saved souls forever. Hint: Don't die.... Right?DifficultyThere is no difficulty setting in this game, yes this game is truly unforgiving but practice makes perfect. Once you get used to dying and possibly loosing many souls. From either running into a the wrong room with lots of enemies. Going through the dreaded mist, completely unprepared with only a broken sword to between you and a huge demon. Or just falling off a ledge due to bad timing or bad player habits.This game is as difficult, as you make it.Once the game is completed the games difficulty increases, with a new game plus mode, this will happen every time you complete the game if you can stomach it.Controls & InterfaceI strongly recommend using a controller for this game as playing with a keyboard is like giving the monsters a bigger advantage, why anyone would want to do that, is like crazy.AchievementsThis game has steam achievements. Which increased my enjoyment and challenge of the game and one day I will get 100%.... one day. Hurray I have done this now!StoryThe plot of Dark Souls is minimalistic which I found interesting as it made me want to find out more about the game (Dark Souls Wiki). With so much to do and not much direction other than your weapon of choice as the guide, I soon found myself exploring and reading. A great way to find new and interesting items, enemies or ways to die.If you truly love this game like I do, check out the wiki page story and lore is absolutely brilliant and even some of the fan theories based on in game descriptions are fantastic. The developers really know how to tell a story, with each character you meet they all have their own goal and agenda which is so well put together.If you are unsure what I mean and are thinking to yourself that story was crap.Please check out some of the YouTube (personal favourite) summaries and theories.Combat System Combat is based on swords, axes, hammers, spears, shields and bows etc... The weapons mostly have different swing sets,  different movements, ranges and speeds. Which increase your choice of killing weapon and replayability.Not only do you get vast arsenal of weapons to choose from but you can also train and learn pyromancies, sorceries and miracles.The combat is fast pasted and real time so thinking quick and being ready to roll can save your life.I loved that Dark Souls combat keeps you on your toes, as pretty much every distinct enemy that you encounter will move and attack in different ways depending on the weapons they hold, especially the bosses.Levelling Stats & SpellsAs before I mentioned acquired souls are currency, you spend souls to level up at a kindled fire place, any unspent soul is a potential lost soul.Spending souls to level will increase a variety of stats and also let you equip bigger heavy weapons or better spells.Sounds  & EffectsThe game sounds are really decent and fitting for the gloomy world which was once ruled by dragons.Although I am sure you will get annoyed by the blacksmiths constant hammering.GraphicsThe graphics although now possibly seen as dated to some, I still feel they are done excellently.I have always found Dark Souls games to have lovely designs, views and imagination from the level designers.Cut ScenesWithout spoiling anything I found all cut scenes epic, increasing my immersion into the game.Humour & TriviaDark Souls has a surprisingly lot of background information supported by communities. I spent hours on the wiki page looking up weapons strategies and different things about the game.A well known fact that Dark Souls is a spiritual successor of Demon's Soul, but both are actual successors of a game called King's Field.Also if you ring either of the bells it can be heard in other peoples games. Pretty cool although as of late fewer and fewer people are playing due to the latest releases of Dark Souls genre.Game UtilitiesThe game offers auto save feature, where ever you log out or leave your character. He/she will be right where left off.This is to stop anyone trying to back track to avoid boss rooms and losing all their souls, which works brilliantly in my opinion as there is no escaping death.Kindled fires offer sanctuary, but resets all slain monsters (except bosses) so be wise when you go to rest.MultiplayerThis game is mainly single player but with some interesting multiplayer features.Players may use summon signs to be summoned by other players to aid them with area bosses. This also works vice versa, but you need to be human to be able to summon (Human Effigy).Players may also invade others in player versus player style combat fighting to the death to retain all the glory, finishing with a gesture of course.Keep in mind you may also join, in-game covenants that give special benefits or that suit your play style.Bugs - ImportantI didn't encounter any game breaking bugs on this game, although trying to play co operatively with a friend is tricky and may need a bit of prior research into how it works before you can do it easily.As there are a few things regarding same steam download server region. Not only that but you must be in the similar level range, plus the area boss has not been defeated for summoning host.If you are playing this solely offline then you are able to summon non player characters to help with boss fights, you must be human to see summon signs.ConclusionOverall I found this game extremely fun to play and enjoyed every ounce of it, even if you decide to get this game and only get to the Belfry Tower Gargoyles I'll be impressed.I personally think this is a fantastic game I will always remember killing my first boss, it was a good feeling even if it was with a broken short sword and many deaths later.Still felt like I missed so much out.You Died.... All to often.Hope I helped, good luck.ηυĸєΜ266

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												THE PROS:Dark souls is known for its difficulty, its teeth grinding, controller breaking difficulty. But to me it is much, much more. Dark souls is a game that takes years to master, and has been part of my gaming history for years and I cant stop coming back to it. The game has the most depth in its lore I have ever seen and I am doubtful I will see a more complex story then this one. There is a story behind every room, item, and character, and quite frankly I am in love with it. The way the story is told is just fantastic. You are dropped in a universe you know nothing about, right at the beginning you can go one way with enemies that are suitable for a new player, or you could take the wrong turn down a dark shadowy path to a group of enemies that one shot you. Thats what I love, you see something too hard for you, progress in another area only to come back and best that enemy. It is insanely satisfying. I love the fact that while progressing at any time you can be invaded by another player who will utterly destroy you. It adds so much unpredicatability to the game that you are on the edge of your seat when you see that invasion notification. The pvp is also insanely in depth and has many different ways to play it. Not only this but I have never seen such a strong community. Players are always sharing stories and things they find in the world. With a wide range of fan art, it shows the true appreciation the players have for the art style of the game and themes the game holds.THE CONS: The only cons I can find in this game is the port. To be blunt about it, the game was literally copy and pasted from the xbox 360 version. That being said you need to use mods online to fix up the game to be playable if you are not using a controller.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
DARK SOULS: PREPARE TO DIE EDITIONDark Souls. Where to begin?HARDEST GAEM EVURIf you've never played this game, you are likely here because you heard it is the hardest game in the world. This is not true. Dark Souls is not hard, but it requires a dedicated player. The game is unforgiving, and wants you to quit, it wants you to refund it, it wants to annoy you and frustrate you in as many ways as it can. But it does this without ever being unfair. You may throw your controller accross the room screaming about the BS death you just went through, but that is how the game will teach you. It's likely that you will be required to lay off a boss the first time you meet it, purely to learn how to approach it, or how to dodge it.WHAT'S UH... THE DEAL?The story is not told at all, if you want to learn what the hell is going on, you'll need to study one of the thousand or so lore items that hint towards things. A good example of this being that until recently, we didn't know the entire story of the Blacksmith God was written on the image of the Titanite Slab in an old gaelic language. You know you have some amazing and detailed story when it's taken 6 years for someone to find that out. I won't spoil anything, all I'll say is you'll be questionning "why?" alot, because you won't know what is going on, or why you are in the middle of a giant fetid underground waste city, but if you actually look into the location details and item details, you may find it out, or through tidbits of dialogue you get from the depressed and mostly ignorant characters.MASTER OF KARATEThis game is heavily focussed on combat. It is the thing you will be doing most aside item farming. The combat system is recognisable as one of the most intuitive and well designed out there, prompting games with similar actions to be branded "Soulslikes". Of the hundreds of weapons in the game, everyone is as viable as the next. I know what you are thinking... So, a small sword is just as viable as a 20 foot long axe made from dead demons? Well, yes. And no. Dark Souls lets you build your own character from scratch, you can level up what you like when you like and wield what you like.RATINGOverall, Dark Souls is a fantastic RPG experience, with masterful silent narrative, oustanding combat, and that edge that kicks you in the butt and tells you to keep on going. Not only is it the best in the series, but it is in competition for the best video game of all time. For that, it earns an easy 9.9/10.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Dark Souls easily gave me the most unique and indescribable gaming experience I have ever had. Yeah, you're going to die a million times but it will never be the game's fault, you will learn from every mistake you made. Dark Souls teaches you by its gameplay and not by its non-existant casual tutorials. Dying is not a frustrating thing in this journey, but the essence which makes this game so unique and outstanding. Sometimes you will get punished so hard even after you died, but you'll just want to keep playing. The gameplay is so simple at first glance, but in fact, it's deeper than the depression I felt in when I got cursed by those freaking frogs. I just can't tell how many secrets the game has, it's mind-blowing. And jeez, that level design... I have NEVER seen such genial, fluid and complex level design in any game, EVER, and at the same time it's so easy to memorize every inch of Lordran's amazing world. This universe is vital and thanks to its amazing community, Dark Souls is still a living, full of life experience.After all, I thought I've seen everything in the gaming industry, then I did give a try to this masterpiece. Dark Souls is easily the best *game* I have played in my life and I only saw the tip of its nearly heightless iceberg. 10/10, would lose my soul(s) again.

												Probably one of the best action adventure games since The Legend of Zelda. There is so much to explore that you will get immersed in the game's moody and dark atmosphere. The game is, to the core, Nintendo Hard of the best kind. Difficult gameplay that will keep beating you down but then standing right back up and trying again. It's the kind of difficulty that gives you the sense of accomplishment and happiness when overcoming the most troubling of obstacles. The world is also very interconnected so you can either co-op with strangers to defeated bosses or invade other online players for that feel of hunting your prey. Get this game, it's so damn worth it.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Dark Souls: Rustle Your Jimmies Edition can be played one of three ways. It’s either that you spend hours tenaciously fighting in a nonsensical world, you spend days training for the quickest speed-run through a still nonsensical world, or you spend months learning character motifs/ reading item descriptions/ observing architecture/ and even research why a certain item was found in a certain place. For a 2011 release by a company primarily known for an exceptional PS2 series, this was undoubtedly a gamble. Their budget is apparent in the repeating textures, copy-paste mob placement, and cut dialogue that would have made interesting additions to the game. Yet despite all this undeniable laziness, the game makes up for it in clever use of map design, unique weapon and armor design, and a lore deep enough for things to still be discovered 5 years later. Essential themes of the game are comparable to Maslowian self-actualization psychology, the cyclic nature of Uzumaki by Junji Ito, and many other hipster sources. In all seriousness, Dark Souls: Fiddle Your Diddle Edition is not a perfect game, it’s not nearly as hard as youtubers will make it seem, but it’s not nearly as easy as speed runners will make it seem either. If you're still debating whether you should get it 5 years later, you should, and beat the game at least once. No matter which of the three ways you choose to play it, have fun and good luck.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
Famoso por ser um jogo difícil, Dark Souls também surpreende pela sua sombria e curiosa história.Nota: 9/10Você joga como o Chosen Undead, desenvolvendo um papel determinante na profecia sobre o fim da Era do Fogo. Durante sua jornada em busca de almas que permitarão o alcance do seus objetivos, você explora diferentes áreas do reino de Lordran, como castelos, esgotos, florestas, cavernas e muita outras áreas, todas com uma pesada atmosfera erma e soturna que cria uma sensação de tensão e isolamento que marca a franquia.Um grande motivo que me fez gostar do jogo, não é apenas apenas o desenvolvimento da história em si, mas como ela é transmitida ao jogador. Como sua jornada é relativamente solitária, salvo alguns poucos NPCs, única forma de compreedê-la é pelas breves conversas com os personagens, descrição dos itens e mesmo pela observação do ambiente, e aos poucos você monta o quadro do que levou o reino a ruínas, assim o que parecia simples se torna uma rica história.Não tem como fazer um review desse jogo sem abordar os problemas de port, a FromSoftware cometeu um erro gravíssimo em deixar um jogo desse calibre chegar ao PC com essa qualidade. Porém, existem patches e fixes não-oficiais que habilitam recursos gráficos ociosos e consertam problemas, como as texturas e fontes do jogo estarem em terríveis resoluções, alguns problemas ao se jogar com teclado+mouse e outros erros menores. Depois de aplicá-los, o jogo se torna muito bonito, com paisagens únicas e belos lugares com ótimas qualidades gráficas.Apesar da produtora ser japonesa, o gameplay é um clássico dungeon crawler ocidental, todos os elementos de RPG estão presentes no título, como a criação de personagem bem flexível, possuindo magias, armas corpo a corpo, arcos e bestas disponíveis para sua escolha de combate preferida, upar seu personagem como você quiser, fortalecendo uma das formas de combate descritas ou usar um pouco de cada contra inimigos e bosses cada um mais forte e bizarro que o outro. Cautela ao se jogar é muito recomendado, porque além dos inimigos serem muito fortes, existem inúmeras armadilhas e falcatruas que garantem ao jogador uma morte certa. É bem possível que você morra várias vezes tentando vencer um boss ou tentando passar de alguma área, mas isso faz parte da experiência, o jogo não tem como subtítulo Prepare to Die por nenhuma razão, mas é altamente recompensador vencê-los.O áudio geral do jogo é também muito bom, a trilha sonora realiza seu papel de criar e reforçar a atmosfera proposta pelo jogo.Reforço o que está avisado na página da Store, controle Microsoft Xbox 360 é altamente recomendado para jogar, eu testei o do PlayStation 3 e mesmo ele apresenta problemas que atrapalham a jogabilidade.História: 10/10Gráficos: 8/10Áudio: 8/10Gameplay: 9/10

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Introducing: "Dark Souls: Prepare to Die" PC edition!New features include:-Some free DLC-Controller compatibility (only for the weak)-A whole new difficulty setting"New difficulty?" you ask.Yes, it is called "Mouse and Keyboard/PC Gamer Mode." It is approximately 217 times harder than the base (controller played) version of Dark Souls.Some players (the weak) believe this to be the result of a poor port from console. However, this was actually done on purpose. This mode negates any and all complaints that the game is "not hard enough".Just unplug your weakling controller and try beating the game using only mouse and keyboard, I promise that, if you want difficulty, you won't be disappointedThere are only 4 endings to this mode-"I can't even navigate the menu this way, I'm calling my mom to cry" (Pleb)-"This is♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can't even get out of the Asylum, I'm starting a complaint forum to express my frustration" (Weakling)-"It took me 6 hours, but I finally beat the Aslyum and I'm now in therapy to cope. I'm plugging in a controller" (Veteran)-"If I had a dollar for every time I died from falling or because I couldn't turn and fight the thing attacking me; I could pay off the entirety of the United States' debt. I only got to the top of Blight Town." (Expert)-"Once I made it to Anor Londo I collapsed; I couldn't take it any more after that. I no longer remember my real name. I feel as though I have lived and died thousands of times. I have frequent hallucinations in which I become disoriented before being crushed by giant boulders or attacked by red-glowing nudists with massive swords. The sight of balancing beams, churches, snake-men, bridges, emaciated persons, and many other seemingly harmless entities all trigger violent and horrifying flashbacks. I am now in a mental institution. I can hear the demon lumbering, breathing, and growling under the floor. I think it is getting restless. I just need to wait for the key so that I may finally escape. The Crow will be here soon, it must be, I know it will be." (Godlike)

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												If you want more reviews for TV shows, movies, games across all platforms, and more, come check out my blog!http://gandhigaming.wordpress.com/Also, be sure to use this link below if you do purchase this game, otherwise it WILL NOT work. http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/864980153227392683/Thanks to my friend Shadow for sending me this link before I purchased this game!To be honest, I meant to do this review earlier because it would take too long for me to beat the game, as the average playthrough is about 60 hours long. To add on to that, my crave to review games is pretty hard to contain. So, here's my review of Dark Souls, arguably the best RPG of last gen to many.Dark Souls has been highly praised by gamers and critics and was a solid GOTY contender, but it was overshadowed by Skyrim, which got all the attention. It's true, I am a Skyrim fanboy and I love everything to it, but this game still deserved a lot more recognition than it got. Plus, now that I got a handy Xbox 360 wireless controller, I wanted this game bad. However, I still was worrried due to GFWL ruining my experience. Thanks to one of my awesome friends though, he gave me a link that would fix that annoying problem. But, I don't want to provide negatives because of GFWL and all of that, Enough of my nonsense, to the review!GraphicsThe visuals look outstanding yet bland at the same time, depending on how you look at it. The world of Lordran is beautiful about 70% of the time, while the 30% is the more dull part of the game. The dull parts of the game though are harder to explain, and half the time you won't even realize the bad parts to the visuals. The atmosphere is thrilling, dark, and epic. Not much to say for the visuals, heck, even the character models aren't too bad, but there's nothing too great about it.GameplayThe gameplay is easily the strong point to the game, no doubt. Everyone says the game is hard, and that's certainly true, but when someone describes the gameplay to Dark Souls, they always just say "Wow, this game is HARD! Did I also mention it's hard?" and whatnot. I'll give you an unbiased non-hard mentioning gameplay review here. The combat is smooth and actually pretty realistic. Your supplies are actually LIMITED for once, and also the combat is nice and slow because you aren't some kind of MGR Raiden or DMC Dante. You're a regular warrior/sorcerer/knight/pyromancer/whatever else there is. And plus your stamina actually is important unlike other games. Because of the realism in the combat, this game can be very slow at times. Therefore, Dark Souls is for the most patient of gamers. They don't mind repeating the same part over and over again while discovering new ways to get to the next point in the game. The successful realism and well paced gameplay makes Dark Souls have some of the best Action-RPG gameplay seen in years. Phew, check it out, no mentioning of the difficulty! Woohoo!StoryThe story may seem vague at first, but then you realize it's basically a puzzle- find the pieces and put them together to make one big picture. It isn't straightforward at all. It wants you to talk to the NPCs and all of that, which makes Dark Souls pretty heavy in lore when you know where to look. You're no god or some kind of super prophecized legend or anything (although in a way you are) and yet Dark Souls successfully does that. The story is what most dark fantasy games should have. There's also Solaire of Astora (Praise the Sun!) on the "bright" side of things and he is known to be a very enjoyable character in the game. I also made a song I'm still working on, but let's not get off topic.AudioDark Souls' audio is among the best I've seen when it comes to sound effects. Again, Dark Souls successfully captures some of the realism intended into the game. The knight, more specifically, sounds amazing with the sound effects instead of listening to the normal quiet footsteps even the most armored of people have in other games. As for the voice acting, everyone seems dark and grim, a major pro to a game that's trying to have a dark theme to it. And for the music, the songs don't really play that much, but when they do, you know you're in big trouble or you're in a safe place. The soundtrack actually is a guide in this game, providing signals to you when traveling throughout Lordran.ReplayabilityThe replayability is pretty strong I hear. Like I said, I never had the time to beat this game yet, but I hear there's new game+ and you can also make multiple characters. Based off of what I seen, the people who stay to enjoy this game get an easy 120 hours. VerdictIn the end, Dark Souls is an outstanding RPG no one should miss, given you don't mind a challenge. Dark Souls is what dark fantasy games should be like. The atmosphere is perfect, the sound effects realistic, and the gameplay smooth. In fact, sometimes when I play Skyrim, I view myself as if I was in the world of Lordran, traversing through the beautiful undead world. If Skyrim could make me do THAT, something is going right with Dark Souls. Even if it isn't my favorite RPG, Dark Souls is one outstanding, dark adventure other Action-RPGs should be looking at.Graphics- 6.5/10Gameplay- 10/10Story- 8.5/10Audio- 9.5/10Replayability- 9.0/10.:9.1/10:.+Smooth gameplay+Strategically placed lore+Amazing sound effects+Brilliant atmosphere (No game has been that good with atmosphere since Bioshock)+Lots of realism for a fantasy game+Solid replayability-Mediocre to above average visuals

content:
Posted: February 26
												Dark Souls is the infamous action RPG that you've already heard about. You've probably heard about how difficult and punishing it can be, but it can actually be quite easy if you learn how stats and equipment work. GameplayYou CAN get through the game by learning enemy attacks, baiting out certain moves and punishing them, all of which can be very fun if you like action games; however, this game is an RPG to it's core with a slew of different damage types and armor resistances, meaning some damage types will work better depending on the enemies' armor. These basic RPG elements impact the game rather heavily, meaning you can simply change weapons/armor and turn a difficult boss fight into something trivial, even though you still need to know the fighting basics.Because of this focus on damage types and stats, you might assume that your starting class will determine what bosses you find difficult, but in Dark Souls your equipment changes your gameplay more than other factors. While playing Dark Souls you can often just change equipment, dynamically changing your build as you find out what works against certain enemies. With all of that said, luckily the foundational RPG elements aren't completely enforced, you can always just learn the boss's patterns and win with a build completely ineffective against the boss. Or you can just use Havel's set, the Black Knight Halberd, and chug like a scrub winning no matter what.Art DesignAlthough Dark Souls is a rather solid gameplay experience, Dark Souls shines best when you can appreciate the art design. I'm happy to say with this game the marketing is pretty much spot on, so if the marketing materials interest you, you won't be dissapointed.Final ThoughtsIf you like the idea of an action RPG with a focus on RPG elements, you'll enjoy the gameplay. If you like a dark, gritty, atmosphere with lots of dangerous creatures, you will like the art design.Even if you just think the marketing looks cool, the game is 5 bucks on sale, so might as well pick it up.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												Dark Souls is a game I will never forget. I don't really know what to say about this game, I personally think it is a masterpiece. I've put well over 1,000 hours on Dark Souls on console. If you have not played this game, you need to.I do want to bring up the problems with the PC version though. Basically it's broken. You have to download mods to be able to get the game to work. Also you have to play this game at 30FPS in order for it to work properly otherwise your jumps and everything will be messed up. I personally spent around 4 hours setting up this game, but this game was worth all those hours.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2012
												По-моему игра просто великолепна! Но всё-же 9,5 из 10!Это РПГ с чисто японским подходом к созданию игр, то есть "Всё не как у всех"! Ты начинаешь играть и понимаешь, что ничего не понимаешь! В ней нету никакого обучения, ты должен всему сам учиться! Для меня это огромный плюс, т.к. устал от игр, в которых тебя ведут за ручку, press x to win и т.д.Прекраснейший дизайн локаций, отличный геймплей (да ещё и хардкорный, который заставляет "попотеть"), одновременно жуткие и прекрасные боссы и враги, притягивающая атмосфера, необычные рпг составляющие и ещё многое! Обязательно попробуйте поиграть!P.S.: Ах да! Чуть не забыл! В игре есть офигительный "мультиплеер" - PvP и PvE режимы! Оставляют хорошие впечатления)

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Dark Souls... Where do you start?It's a game that'll punish you for YOUR mistakes. Not it's own. It's a game that requires skill to learn and play. It's a game that will take you 50+ hours your first time around then you can beat it in <5. The game never gets old because of how open it is, you can do things in so many different ways. Required bosses only? Why not. All bosses? Go for it. Fist Weapons only? Whatever. It's your choice. You don't even have to know the story, you can just fight enemies and not care, or you can go into the lore that each item gives you. It's very open-ended.The multiplayer in the game might be a bit confusing at first, but it's much worth it. The PVP and PVE Co-op just make the game have so much more replayabilty to it. You could get invaded by someone while doing jolly co-operation with your friends through Anor Londo, or walk into the forest and fight off the constant invaders protecting it. You can place your summon sign down outside a boss gate and help people fight the boss over and over, and it won't get boring. The combat just is so fluid and transfers so well to this.Dark Souls is one of the few games I will consider Perfect. It's buggy at times, but really, the game itself past that is a complete masterpice. I recommend it to ANYONE. It'll make you rage at first, but you'll love it soon after once you get that first boss dead.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Dark Souls is an extremely rewarding JRPG with 100+ hours of content, and plenty of challenge and secrets. Dark Souls's strengths come from its exploration, in-depth RPG elements and challenge, which many might find rewarding when it seems difficult modern games are becoming harder and harder to find. The game on its own is fantastic with the exception of some cheap level design, however the port is ♥♥♥♥ing lazy and horrible, and needs a download of DSfix to be truly playable, and it utilizing Games for Windows can make playing the game, especially PVP very frustrating. Dont bother buying the game if you don't have a gamepad, but the game is definitely worth your money if you have one on hand. Dark Souls is a step in the right direction for video games not becoming interactive movies, and is an especially rewarding video game experience worth anyone's time. Buy it.

Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam groupFew words about the gameFirst thing i wanted to say about the game itself, it's the hardest masterpiece I have ever played. For me it's really difficult game, maybe I wasn't "devoted" to it enough or something but still, didn't got as far as I'd like to get because it really takes time. Besides screams, broken controllers and rage quits, game offers us a really interesting way of telling us bits of story (i recommend reading everything, it's really interesting but easy to skip) and many breathtaking views. Hope that one day I'll be able to finish this game ^^Advantages - Unique graphics that provide us with lots of beautiful views - Truly epic atmosphere, not only during boss fights - Astonishing and diverse level design, surprising how everything is connected (yeah, whole game is accually one, connected in various ways level) - While leveling, player get more and more skilled together with character - Creative multiplayer in game that merges into singleplayer - Overally good sound effects and soundtrack - Nice ammount of armory to choose from, player easily can match it to his own playstyle - High replay value as here, every step mattersDisadvantages - Horrible PC port, practically unplayable without controller - 30fps lock, if you wish to you can unlock it with some mods but it might result in some errors - Many multiplayer issues - Lacks a little bit of tutorial for new playersIf you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Dark Souls is, to put it briefly, a masterpiece with minor flaws.It's an incredible game, with an entrancing setting that can be both beautiful and haunting.As you guessed from the title, it is very dark, in terms of both setting and themes. However, it's not pitch black. There's always some hope, or some beauty, or some light that keeps this game from being nothing more than a depressing march from start to finish. The game feels more like 'Purgatory' than 'Hell', if that makes sense. Hope is frail in Dark Souls, but this game will never leave you feeling completely hopeless. There is ALWAYS a way.Finally, the big question everyone asks: Difficulty?Honestly, Dark Souls is not the brutally difficult game everyone tells you it is. Aside from two or three actually tough bosses, Dark Souls is only as hard as you allow it to be, as cliched as that sounds. If you appreciate learning, can think laterally and can adapt to meet changing situations, Dark Souls is a very enjoyable challenge. If you allow yourself to get easily frustrated, insist on blindly rushing things, and stubbornly refuse to change tactics if required, the game will punish you, and rightly so, because you're stupid. There is no "one-size-fits-all" plan. Dark Souls doesn't punish "unskilled" people, it punishes stupid people. In the first hour I couldn't even kill a pair of skeletons, now I've finished the game. Perseverance is critical. If you're going to think like a loser, you're going to be a loser, it's as simple as that. There will be times when you'll want to throw your hands up in the air. Don't do it. Never give up.Dark Souls is honestly not a brutally tough game. For any Brood War players out there, if you could beat "To Slay The Beast", you can beat this whole game,  Dark Souls is much easier than that was.So don't be afraid, don't hesistate, do something positive for yourself, and experience Dark Souls. When you make it to the end, you won't regret it. Also, get DSFix. It's a painless five minute install, and is absolutely necessary for a good experience.PS - No spoilers, but there's this thing called a "Purging Stone". You might want to have at least one of those on you at all times. That's all I'm saying.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Dark Souls changed the gaming world for me. Its unique atmosphere and playstyle is what caught me and I consider it an ideal gaming world. There are no other RPGs that have the vibe that Dark Souls has, and because it is so unique; I keep returning to it. With that written, I can say that I can spend 1000+ hours on playing this game without getting bored.Ofcourse you die a LOT of times and thus it could not actually be considered ideal; However, the atmosphere really seals the deal. We all have our dark moments and Dark Souls is a great release.I have played this game using my keyboard and mouse. Although it was not recommended by friends and reviews; I did manage to finish it (and I probably took longer than I could have with a controller). The controls take a bit of getting used to, and there are some moves that you might miss out on, like kicking.These missing moves will not stop you from being capable of finishing the game and they will not stop you from enjoying the game (once you have gotten used to the controls).The story of the game is kind of unclear. This could be because:I didn't spend enough time on reading;I spent too much time between dialogues.Either way, I do think that I am not the only one. Why else would there be videos about Dark Souls lore? I definitely recommend keeping up with the story. A story of tragedy, a story of the 'light' against the dark. Prepare to cry, some say.It indeed has a great lore.Last but not least, the atmosphere and story are greatly complimented by awesome soundtracks. Once one has looked into the Dark Souls lore, one will understand how the music dramatically affects the game. This results in some soundtracks being filled with epicness and some soundtracks being filled with pain and sorrow.This review is probably not complete, I can keep on praising Dark Souls. Praise the sun! My fellow sinners!UPDATE: I will add more details to this review and I will make it into a whole when I feel like I have added everything.When starting a new game in Dark Souls, you start off at the character creation menu. So this provides the player with the opportunity to build his/her own character. There are 2 options when creating a character. You can either pick a developer made look or you can go into some of the tiniest details and build your own entirely new and unique look. There is also a lot of gear to pick from in Dark Souls. There is a big variety of weapons and armor sets (including the gear that bosses wear).

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Dark Souls... Where to start?  You've heard about it, I know,  and all the hype about it being such a hard game.  "It doesn't dumb down anything!" "The definition of Hardcore!" "Other games insult our intellegence, but not Dark Souls!"Those are the types of things I read about it prior to buying it, and now, after playing a little of it, I can say that I don't agree with any of those statements.Let me explain why:So imagine you got a  Belgium Waffle Maker from a old lady's yardsale.  You are excited to try it, but its just so clunky, it doesn't do what you want, and after some time of trying to use it, it only brought you frustration.         Now replace the waffle maker with Dark Soul's controls  and understand that the hardest part of this game       are the ♥♥♥♥ing keybinds.The gameplay is supposed to not hold any hands with the style of the game, but the first tip was how to use the Left Joystick...I tried a few classes out, starting with pyromancer, and the first thing I noticed was that you aim with your nose... and you cant turn your head, so that leaves you trying to turn your body with the waffle controls, just to throw a damn fireball in the tutorial.I'm done ranting for now, but I wish I never bought this game, even when it was only 5 dollars.                                                         --------------EDIT-------------                                           I see that my review seems to mislead people                                    into thinking I was playing with a keyboard, and a                                     controller would fix everything, but understand that                                    I was playing exactly as recommended I should and                                     it still led me to this conclusion.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												when it comes to game titles there has never been such a truth worthy title than darksouls. when playing this game you really do have to prepare to die. however it is still one of the most addicting games ever i mean beside pokemon. Why is Dark Souls so addictive? We play and we die. We die and we die some more. Just when we think we're out of danger, we die. Right when we start the game, we die. There's a lot of dying in Dark Souls; the PC re-release is even called the "Prepare to Die Edition!" Any normal person would have abandoned this frustration a long time ago...so why can't we?It's because when we're not dying, Dark Souls is an excellent action RPG. Building our character is great, the dangerous world we're fighting in is fun to explore, and when we do actually finish the quest without dying, the satisfaction is unmatched. Yes, sometimes you make us want to bash our heads against the wall...but we love you Dark Souls. Don't ever change.

I can't even go far into the game without it kicking me back to the title screen because of a low framerate, not to mention having to log into GFWL.Buy the console version and avoid this one at all costs (unless you have a great PC).EDIT:  By pure virtue (and Google) did I find fixes for this, so I'm able to play it a bit better, but that doesn't excuse it from being a very bad PC port in all. content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Nope, sorry, I just can't go on with this game. I'm sure many love this game-style, but I have neither the time nor the patience for it. That doesn't mean it is a bad game, it just isn't for me. (Let's see how many unhelpful reviews I'll get for not liking someone's favourite game... it kind of seems people mostly rate unhelpful only because of different opinions, not because the review was truly helpful or not. I mean a review can be helpful even though it doesn't approve of the game - another discussion though...)The good:Great style and atmosphere. Great art design. Dark intriguing (albeit not very obvious) lore. Even though graphics are not amazing it still creates interesting, sometimes beautiful vistas and locations - It fits the style of the game. Great fighting mechanics, and animation. Unique game mechanics and approach to fighting. Lots of exploration. No handholding. Kind of a great "community game" since you need other people's help in order to progress - it certainly makes it easier.The bad:Unless you have a controller you might as well forget playing this game. Port is truly awful and requires modding (that is thankfully not too hard to implement). Clunky interface. 30 fps... No handlholding. You need to look up how to progress the game. Ridiculously difficult, and ultra hard bosses. If you easily get frustrated, don't buy this game. A lot of repeating the same over and over and over and over in order to progress.If you are into a challenge that takes time, requiring lots of patience and hard work - you'll love it, If you can get over the sluggish game engine and the fact you must have a controller of course. Otherwise, it probably isn't for you even though many love the series. I know many who have excitedly started one of the games in the dark souls series (because of the hype and the fact so many talk about these truly unique games, that are also sometimes truly beautiful and special, like for example bloodborn), only to have given up a few hours later, cause the game will eat you for breakfast with no mercy whatsoever.Just not for me though.  If you are uncertain get it on a sale.Cheers!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												At the very start of Dark Souls past the introduction, Descending a granite staircase early in Dark Souls, you find a Black Knight obstructing the corridor below. He stands with his back turned, oblivious to your approach. A white loot orb glows cheekily at the far end of the passage. Lesser games might telegraph this enemy’s difficulty by showing it rear its head back and screech, flecking the camera lens with spittle shaking the screen and taking the controller away from you and saying "Look at this scary thing". But no Dark Souls does it different. The mere outline of the knight’s horned helmet  instantly recognisable from the game’s box art sets your pulse galloping! The game does not come with a warning other than "Prepair to die" And you will often be matched with red text across your screen saying "You Died" Just in case when you saw your lifeless corpes flop to the ground it wasn't asma or an cardiac arrest. But the deaths in this game does not mean you failed, Dark Souls has a brillant way of teaching the one playing. Learn from your mistakes alright...some times it's just ♥♥♥♥en bull♥♥♥♥♥♥when you press b to roll and it doesn't roll then the sword comes do-...Anyway. Though from the amount of deaths you rally up it only adds up on the sheer sence of accomplishment you get when you over come it. You might hear that alot when reading other reveiws about this game. Mainly because it's true once you've masterd the blade, The Magic, The Miricles you'll wonder how you got stuck before you'll breeze right through the game until new game pluss.My main positive about Dark Souls is it will last a long time. Packed with gameplay that will leave you wanted to re-roll and experience new ways of slaying! From slamming your foe into the dirt to a well placed strike! Dark Souls having the right amount of difficulty that just makes you say "Maybe this time. I'll do it this time." It offers you what you want but puts it on the highiest shelf. While the same that shelf looks wonderful the enviroment in Dark Souls is always different from the dirty depths of a sewer to the high polished walls of a city for gods.The PC port though is baaad. And is highly reccomended a 360 pad in order to play, keyboard just don't even... In conclusion get Dark Souls. It's wonderful. A work of art and brilliant to play.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												What can be said about Dark Souls that hasn't already been said? The game is hard as hell and it will make you want to cry. But if you can get over that, you will see that it's not just a hard game, but one that tests your ability to learn and adapt. Once you get over one challenge, another one is thrown right into the players face, and you will probably die. But you learned how to over come the first challenge so it will be easy the second, or thrid, or fourth time around. The game is not for the faint of heart, I am 6 hours into the game and I still haven't finished the first part after the tutorial. The key to Dark Souls is to stay calm, take a deep breath and carry on, because the only way for you to beat the game is to stay sane, and outsmart the game.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Be warned, you are going to hate this game so much that you love it. Dark Souls brings brutal, unforgiving difficulty that comes out of nowhere in a non-linear open-rpg environment. Only through specific tactics can enemies be conquered, or you will be crushed, sometimes in a single swift blow. One mistake will lead you to death, where you will lose all of your experience until you go back to where you died to retrieve it. Die again before reaching it, and it is lost forever, making you lose precious power. Trial and error is hit or miss. Risk may bring reward or agonizing failure. You will die over and over, and you will love it.

												One of the best RPGs I've played. If you like challenging gameplay which is really rewarding, Dark Souls is for you. As of right now I've played it for almost 300 hours.But.It is very recommended to use a gamepad. Either an xbox controller or a controller which can be emulated as one. Like the PS3 or PS4 controller. ( http://forums.pcsx2.net/Thread-XInput-Wrapper-for-DS3-and-Play-com-USB-Dual-DS2-Controller I recommend this emulator. Especially over MotionInJoy.)It is also recommended to install DSfix ( http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix ) in order to unlock the fps and resolution in order for the game to look a lot better.In short, the game is quite tough. I can't deny that. But it isn't at all as hard as I thought it would be. I would in a heartbeat recommend this game to anyone and everyone who enjoys being challenged.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Ah.. Dark Souls.. You have given me my highest and lowest times in my gaming history. With every moment of joy, you will punish me in ways I never knew could happen. After finally killing that boss.. to being pushed off a cliff by a weak hollow.You will get angry, you will die but you will push on.Dark Souls drops you off into a strange land with very little to go on and sends you on your way. The open world allows you to wander into areas far beyond your skill but as you master the game these areas will allow you to choose how you tackle the start of the game in new and challenging ways.The depth of the story is a bit hard to take in on your first few playthroughs but as you listen more and more you will start to see the world unfold before you.The npcs add a nice and manic flare to the atmosphere, often mocking you or giving you vague information on what you could be doing next. They don't treat you like a hero, you are just some other hollow, passing through, like the rest of them.The amount of gear you can aquire allows for very unique character development and style choice  Meta aside , making it so no 2 characters are the same.This is one of the best games I have ever played and I would recommend it to anyone who is willing to take a hit to their ego.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Dark Souls still remains my all time favorite game.And no, this game isnt hard. As long as you dont try something, fail at the strategy you used, then try it again and again and again 1235435 times. If it doesnt work, try a different strategy. For the most part, its pretty balanced. The only thing they didnt nerf and shouldve nerfed was ♥♥♥♥in wrath of the gods. It stuns most builds, and people are allowed to spam it in PvP, because thats how the spell works. Even with decent armor on, it still takes chunks out of my life. Anyways, everything else is pretty good. Theres so much weapon variety, and nearly every weapon has its own moveset. They all have different attack properties. One sword may have normal attack, and piercing. A scimitar has slashing damage. A rapier has piercing. A mace will have blunt/strike damage. A spiked mace will do piercing damage. And every armor has different strengths and weaknesses to each of these attack properties. Typically lighter armored enemies are weaker to slash damage, most heavy armored enemies are weaker to piercing. I like all this depth because not many RPG games even have this sort of thing thought out. A mace may do the same type of damage as a curved sword, or a dagger used for thrusting. Theres also 3 different types of magic you can add to your character. Pyromancy, which is kinda close range magic. Sorcery, which is more long range. And then theres Clerics. People also do 3 typical different types of weapon builds:Dexterity, strength, and "quality". No, it doesnt mean its a real quality build.Dexterity is typically for character builds to use fast, quick attacking weapons.Strength for the heavy hitters, typically the slower weaponsQuality is used for people who want both.Now take all these different build possibilities, and you get a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of replay value. Theres also the many many different weapons to expirement with, and different upgrading paths to expirement with. The story isnt presented like most games are today. With fancy cutscenes, dialogue, etc. A lot of it is through lore. Lore that you must piece together yourself through reading and speculation. If you're too lazy like me, there are many lore videos going over everything.Yes, this game was an extremely lazy port by FromSoft, its evident with the optimization issues and the xbox buttons being displayed for actions.Without mods, this only runs at 30 FPS. But honestly, it looks fine. Not as fluid as other games running at 60 FPS, but you get used to it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Reviewing this game purely on it's merits as a game and not a PC port, it's fantastic, easily one of my favorite games of all time, possibly my favorite RPG of all time. With one of the best combat systems of any game, you make a mistake, you'll probably end up dying, it's extremely punishing and thus not for everyone but if you put in the time it's VERY rewarding.The world and level design is in my opinion unmatched in any RPG, there's all sorts of secrets to be found in the game by jumping from ledges and rolling onto different platforms to get to secret areas, the game is rife with secrets.The story is incredibly deep, complex and compelling but is told subtly in item descriptions, random observations around the world and NPC dialogue.PvP is great fun but likely will be laggy, it's entirely optional, as is CO-OP, some people love to play the game with friends, some love to solo it, I'm in the latter category but there is something here for everyone.The enemy design and voice acting are top notch, I honestly cannot say enough good things about this game, but I stress, if you do not enjoy a challenge (that's fine) then Dark Souls is likely not for you, oh, and the PC port is a barebones straight console port, but is easily fixed by using Durante's "DSFix" Mod.In my opinion, one of the greatest games ever made.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												So this game came up on the Steam Winter Sale, and at the price point I thought it worth checking out. I had, after all, heard so much about its bone-crushing difficulty and ridiculous levels of '♥♥♥♥ you, player' that I couldn't help but to be intrigued. There had to be something to it, right?So I bought it, installed it, installed the resolution fixes, added mouse capability to it, and started playing.That is when I discovered that Dark Souls is not a 'hard' game. It is simply unforgiving.The last few years of gaming had trained me to be lazy and dare I say entitled. To regenerating health, hand-holding, steamroller protagonists, all the various watered down populist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that has been focus-tested and brute-forced through the mainstream system. Dark Souls stripped all that away without telling me, and I have to say that at first I was furious. How was the starting area enemy such a threat, and why did he remain a threat hours into the game? Losing resources for good due to a single mistake? No map or guidance on where to go or what to do? No teleport pads? What the hell kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t was all this?Then, I had a realization. Those things happened because of me. My mistake. My haste, my lack of care, my poor choice of equipment, whatever. It wasn't because the AI was cheating like a rubberband racer, or a glitch in the game - it all came down to my decisions, for good or for ill. Dark Souls didn't just hand me success, or elevate me without merit, but instead challenged me to rise to the occasion. In that challenge, I found a real sense of triumph in a game that I haven't felt in some time.In a way, this is because Dark Souls puts the PC on much the same or lesser footing than the NPCs. Even the weakest of them can kill a PC in a few combos, even when the PC can one-shot them. There are many more of them, and they coordinate, with the same toolbox of weapons and attacks that the PC has. The only advantages the PC has are the minor improvements to his stats and equipment, which can never make him invincible, and the human judgement behind its actions. Dark Souls demands that the player learn to succeed.Suffice it to say, I am a fan.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Dark Souls is a game that doesn't hold your hand, and doesn't want you to want it to. It's a game you learn from experience(read trial and error), or you learn from the community.Myself? I mainly got it from the community. A couple of buddies and some wiki-ing made this game that was once an intimidating cliff into an invigorating hike through the hills. It's not a way to ruin the game, to get others to help you (be it through "how do I beat this boss?" or reading a wiki about how to find a certain crafting item); it's simply a different way to play it and enjoy it.This game has the most satisfying combat, one of the most compelling subtle worlds, some seriously cool loot, and an unconventional and interesting multiplayer system.It has it's negatives, certainly; the PC port was not good (DSFix is practically mandatory), Games for Windows Live is not a selling point, the camera can be temperamental, and when you're not progressing it can feel a bit hopeless. BUT; all these things are really a testament to how good the game is because despite all these flaws the game shines through - it's truly grossly incandescant.Bring on Dark Souls 2!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												If you want to feel pain, anger, depression and sadness, you did the right thing in buying this game. You will die. No way you gonna survive this game with one life (some pros might). You get beaten to death, you fall, you get poised, you get cursed, you got burned to death and so on and so forth. There are so many ways you will die in this game you won't believe it. Nonetheless you will realize quick that dying is a part of this game like running and fighting. The good thing is that you as a player improve pretty quick. Not only because of the improving equipment you find but also because you improve as a player yourself. You learn how to dodge, when to parry, when to strike. I personally think that Dark Souls shows more than most other games how you improve and learn the game. This is a cool reward.The game has a few problems tho. Without a mod it has only 30 fps. The menus are clumsy and a gamepad is HIGHLY recommended because the Keyboard+Mouse controls are horrible. So you have been warned :)That few concerns aside the game offers a lot of fun. You choose from 4 different attacks. 2 for each hand. It depends what weaponry you have equipped. A heavy axe has a different attack style than a light sword.  The armors influence your speed and how far you can jump and also your dodging speed. The heavier armors really feel like a heavy armor. You can basically feel it on your character. Really well done. The saving system is automatic and if you rest on a bonfire. A bonfire offers regeneration of most effects. It also refills your health potions. So no need to buy one. You have only a certain amount of them but as soon as you rest on a bonfire you get new ones. Be warned tho. If you rest the enemies will respawn. If you die you will be respawn at the last bonfire rested on. As said above your only currency are souls. You earn them from defeating enemies and bosses. No matter if you want to level up your strength or buy arrows or weapons, you use souls. If you die it gets tense. You have to fight your way back to where you died. If you die on the way, every soul you collected and didn't spend for something is lost. That is a hard mechanic and can make you mad, but it is definitely a thrill to get back, especially if you have lost a huge amount of souls.The controls are good. You have to use a gamepad tho. They are pretty darn accurate. You have a lock on system which helps you fighting most enemies. Some huge bosses are better fought without it, especially the ones that fill the whole screen ;)The weaponry and armors are medieval like. Some enchantments here and there for weapons some magic. The basic stuff. A lot to test out and a lot of ways to replay the game.There are so many ways you can play. As a rogue or a flamethrowing knight. Everything is possible.The story is pretty confusing. You don't get that much background. Especially if you don#t listen or meet some characters. So you either listen closely or you check out the wiki on the internet. They are very well written and offer strategies for bosses if you really don't know how to beat them.Well, the bosses. They are great. A large variety. Each with unique moves and appearance. YOu need for each a different strategy, which makes the game even more challenging. The multiplayer is extensive. A big community of pvp players awaits you. Sadly you can't deactivate the pvp completely. So you can be invaded on certain occasions by people that might be way stronger than you and get killed. But those aren't the only ones. People can set markings in certain areas so you can summon them to help you fighting bosses or areas. This is a cool feature, but it is a shame that you can't really play it in singleplayer. Tip. Stay hollow. Nobody can invade you then. Only problem is you don't get some bonuses you would get as human. Well that is enough i guess. Hope you have a little idea what awaits you. I really enjoyed playing it. It was very challenging, but when you beat it. You feel like badass ;)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I'm a big fan of the Souls series (and Bloodborne of course).This is a game all about sperimentation: try, die, change accordingly to your mistakes (or you will die again). You try out what build best suits you, what weapon is best for your build, and so on. The gameplay is nearly perfect, but in my opinion what makes this game shine is the lore. Miyazaki's way of storytelling is at first glance incosistent. But, like many gameplay and design details, this is a deceive. Try out a YouTube channel that discuss the lore (ENB, TerraMantis, VaatiVidya and many others), and you will find hours of awesome stories. This is a great added value: even if you are not playing the game you are enjoying it.This is the best of the Souls series, don't miss it!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I've played this game more on the PS3, but the experience NEVER gets old. This game is indeed challenging and if you get really stressed out in games, then I won't recommend this to you. Great RPG elements, with the gameplay somewhat like the modern Legend of Zelda games. Even though the lore is hidden within the game, after you learn what happened in the land that you are in, you'll get into the game even more than before. Great characters, great story, great gameplay. 10/10.Edit: Well, after getting all achievements and playing 110 (or so) hours of this game, I've come with the conclusion that this game is my favorite game of ALL time, beating Team Fortress 2 and New Vegas. Graphics: For a game from 2011, the graphics looks alright. Art style is great, as it shows a world where it's meek and honestly depressing. Story: As mentioned in my earlier review, the full understanding of the story doesn't come to you automatically as you play throughout. You need to read item descriptions, go through dialogue, and use the ol' speculation route to learn what happened within the world of Dark Souls. Characters are great, with good development for almost all of them. Controls: Oh boy. This one is questionable in terms of scoring. Simply, the controls for this game just sucks if you use keyboard and mouse. As the store page of this game suggested, it is HIGHLY recommended to play this game with a controller. Especially an Xbox controllerAs my conclusion, this game is a fantastic piece to have in your library and it is an experience that you won't soon forget and with that, it's time to put it back on the shelf. Time to play some Dark Souls II now. ;)WARNING: If you are buying Dark Souls II after playing Dark Souls, DO NOT BUY DARK SOULS II! From Software is going to release Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin, which is the "next-gen" version of Dark Souls II. It includes improved multiplayer, DirectX 11 compatibility, and improved item descriptions and some other stuff. It will also include all DLCs. More information at the Dark Souls II store page and discussion board.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I'm going to have a hard time describing what's so great about this game. I did not expect the SCALE, SCOPE, and DEPTH that it has. The game is big.SCALE: You can see really far, see objects really high up, and paths and obstacles in the depths below. You feel like you're part of something really big. It doesn't seem like there's an engine limitation that a lot of other games have. Enter a giant mountain, fight your way up, come out the top and see that path from which you entered waaaaay down below. It's teeny-tiny down there! Amazing feeling of heights. Also there's a ♥♥♥♥ing huge dragon not too far into the game.SCOPE: This game is huge and covers way more area than I thought it would.DEPTH: The inventory system is big, and the weapons system and fighting system is big. It's straight-forward so you won't feel overwhelmed, but big enough to give you lots of options as you work your way through the game and discover ways to exploit the weaknesses of your enemies.Overall, this ranks somewhere in the top 15 of games I've ever played. I've been playing video games for 31 years now, having started on a Commodore 64 when I was 7 years old. I just didn't expect this at all.Notes to picky PC enthusiasts: To get the PC version past the graphics-related criticisms I'd have otherwise had, I used DSFix. I read the readme very carefully and brought it up to 1080p (using recommended guidelines for the game-specific settings I didn't understand) and 60 fps. I encountered two ladders in the game where the enhanced framerate would interfere with the collision detection, causing my character to fall through the floor and die. It's just those two ladders, and only happens when doing the "ladder slide" move. So for these ladders, simply walk down them normally. I died so often anyway, that this discovery was not an inconvenience. Aside from those two minor instances in the FPS unlocker, DSFix is excellent, so it's worth it to install!

												This is a terrible port, but thanks to the community it's decent now. DSFix is a must to fix the screen resolution issue, google it. And you could pick up some texture mods from the nexus site. This game sucks on keyboard and mouse, I'd really take the controller required disclamer serious. The game is brilliant, it pretty much has alot of old school gaming to it. It's difficulty is a bit exaggerated, and is purely difficult as the game doesn't spoonfeed the player and leaves everything from combat to the story up to his/her interpretation. There is alot of trial and error on your first play. The online play is cute, however not GFWL that is tied to it.The art direction, sound, animation and combat is very good. To me art direction is more important than "graphics". Because I'd take Bioshock or this over a Crysis Game.The only weird thing about this game is that it really starts off with a steep difficulty curve, right up to the bell gargoyle fight. This has pretty much made it into my list of favorite games. Just make sure you get DSfix first for this game, and also a controller.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I can't even begin to describe how good this game is, but, i'll try.Basically, it has everything a gamer could possibly want:-It's challenging to the point of frustration (which only makes winning more satisfying)-It has a large array of gear and loot to keep the collectors and completionists busy for a long while-It has a very in depth, delicate and extremely profound and complicated storyline and lore-Your character has a number of different attributes with a number of different combat paths to take-The combat system is one of the best i've seen in a long while, and while it is hard it is very fun to learn-Almost every weapon has its own unique fighting style-It has Co-op-It has PvP-It has Shops and NPC's and sub-plots of different characters woven into the main storyAll in all, this game is almost flawless. But be warned, the learning curve for the first 10 or so hours of gameplay can be unforgiving, so if you do intend on playing this game, make sure that you have cleared your calendar so you can get to the more enjoyable parts of the game. And if you get stuck, try to think outside the box, or just look it up. Some parts are so complex you can be left wondering how anyone ever figured them out at all. It's small wonder that this game was put in the top 20 games ever. I would recommend that everyone play at least the first 3 or 4 bosses of this game to get the true feel of it. It is utterly fantastic.Also, if you figure out how, SAVE SOLAIRE. He is a true bro.

At 55 FPS I felt like Neo at the end of the first Matrix, just owning everything I came across. So if your coming over from PS3 or XBOX; Parry, Repost, and Back Stabs are much easier at 55 fps... and Blight Town can actually be appreciated.The downside is that the community is smaller, so there isn't as much activity in the multiplayer aspect. Also, with GFWL shutting down soon, Dark Souls "may" become a single player experience. Which will not be so bad for new comers, but for the veterans... that will be most unpleasant. However for now you can use DSCFix, which makes it easier to connect to people.Important NOTES: From "my" experience, the DSFix mod does not help for PCs using native graphics. You need a dedicated GPU, and or video card. I shelled out $150 on my NVIDIA GeForce GTX 650, and it runs so smooth. You Will Need-------------------------------------->A game controler (360 or equivelent)DSFix For frame rate and other graphical settingshttp://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/19/?DSCFix For online conectivity with other playershttp://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/334/?----------------------------------------------------------->A Note On My credability: I have already scored 400+ hours, and aquired the platinum for the PS3 version of Dark Souls before playing the PC version, (PSN: Liam_Eibach).

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I remember when this game came out. I remember a lot of people discussing how difficult this game is. I don't remember much else talk as I didn't venture to the game's specific message boards. I shrugged this off. "Why buy a game simply because it's challenging? It can't really be that hard."As it turns out, this game can be quite challenging at times. For the most part, it gets gradually more difficult, allowing for one of the best learning curves I have seen in a game. At the beginning, I could hardly do anything except spam a basic attack or strong attack. By the time I reached the end of the game, I really felt like I had learned a lot about how to play this game better, and I do feel it has made me better at games. I ran into combat with confidence in my ability to outclass an opponent rather than achieving victory because of the enemy being weak. It definitely rejuvenated some of the patience I had lost due to the ease of, well, every other game I have played in years. These feelings were cemented in my mind as I began a second playthrough and laughably passed the first of the bosses that really tried me on my first adventure.Yes, this game can be pretty tough, but there is so much more to it than that.There isn't much dialogue like your typical RPG. Don't expect sequence after sequence of cutscenes. Each item has well-written descriptions along with it that help bring out lore in this world of Lordran. As you progress through the game, the few conversations with NPCs that are related to the story are quite informative despite their brief nature. This is fantastic. There are other NPCs not related to the main story that you meet multiple times throughout your adventure. This game can feel quite desolate and lonely much of the time. But when you meet these recurring NPCs, it fosters a feeling of safety and camaraderie. For such little dialogue, it's incredible how developed one of these characters in particular became.The environments do look dated, but they are crafted in such a way that they are still nice to look at while doing an exceptional job providing an atmosphere unique to the area and design.The combat has a surprising amount of depth by using different moves with different combinations of inputs on a controller or keyboard. Each weapon also creates for itself a unique play style which allows the player to play the game in drastically different manners between characters or, if skilled enough, on just one character.This truly is one of the best games I have played. If you have any interest in an RPG, I urge you to purchase this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Dark Souls is a special game.  Like that one album that made radio hard to listen to, this game raised the bar for millions and created a hunger that, to date, only From Software has been able to satiate.I would encourage everyone to not be discouraged by the legends of its punishing difficulty.  While the learning curve is steep at first, once the player attains fluid control over their character they will enjoy one of the most satisfying combat systems in any game ever made.  The timing windows are somewhat tight, but there's a sublime feeling that comes with perfect dodging, parrying and riposting.  Once you learn the Soulsborne combat system, it can tough to go back to other games.The combat is just one facet of this gem of a game.  The world design is top-notch - there's a delicate sense of beauty to be found within the desolate and oppressive game world.  The level design (especially the first half of the game) is fantastic - not only are the environments varied but there are shortcuts to reward exploration.  Sound design and music are excellent and immersive.  The lore of the game is deep and interesting, but is only hinted at through various dialogues, item descriptions and corpse locations.  The DLC that's included with the PTDE is some of the best DLC ever released.  Both new areas are interesting and at least 3 of the best and most difficult boss fights are found there.This game gets my highest recommendation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Arguably the greatest game ever made, Dark Souls is atmospheric, complex and beautiful.Your story begins in an asylum where the undead are locked up, never to be seen again, to await the end of the world. That was the plan anyway, but a mysterious figure drops a key into your cage, allowing you to leave the asylum. This marks you as the chosen undead, fated to undertake a pilgrimage to Lordran, land of the ancient Lords.And Lordran is one of the best fantasy worlds ever represented in a video game. Once a magnificent kingdom ruled by gods, Lordran has been overrun by the undead. Yet it still retains its amazing variety, as your quest will take you to forests, swamps, castles, towns, blazing infernos and silent primordial lakes. Lordran's incredibly detailed verticality (indeed you are always travelling up or down) means that the game feels beautifully interconnected and coherent, as you seamlessly walk from one area to the next, uncovering shortcuts that connect to earlier and later locations along the way.Lordran is also a perilous place, and every single enemy is capable of killing you with ease if you're not being careful. In spite of this, the game seldom feels unfair: you lose all your stuff when you die, but if you get back to the place where you were killed - without dying again - you can get it back. This is to say nothing of the bosses. Dark Souls' legendary bosses are in many ways the souls of the areas they inhabit. Every boss fight (ok, Pinwheel excepted...) requires a careful study of the boss' movements and the arena where you're fighting to build up, over the course of many deaths, a strategy to take down the boss. And there are myriad strategies you could construct to take down any given obstacle, since the game mostly rewards all playstyles and equipment choices equally: it is very possible to beat the game using the very first weapon by upgrading it as you go along.All of this is backed up by a story and lore that are revealed slowly, and only when you go looking for them, in conversations with NPCs, description text for items, and the enemies and locations themselves. Nor is the lore ever revealed completely, so the game always feels compellingly shrouded in mystery.Brilliant, right?
