content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												There really isn't a game like Dark Souls. It takes (mostly) melee combat and makes it its central piece. It's visceral, it requires careful timing and quick thinking from the player. Landing hits is oh so satisfying. Knowing when to block, dodge or attack is paramount, as a few, unforgiving (but often well-deserved) hits are all that separates the chosen undead from killing an enemy to having to restart from the checkpoint and risking losing all their souls (in-game currency), as they'll disappear from your death spot if you don't pick them up before dying again. Tension buildup is inevitable when you're exploring a new area or trying not to die to recover your 100000+ souls you dropped on your last death. This is the same reason why slaying bosses tastes so much sweeter than in any other game, since there's so much at stake. Multiplayer is also a strong component of the game, in which through diverse items and covenants you can invade (enter someone else’s game) another chosen undead and either help him get through an area and slay the boss or simply engage the invaded player and take his souls and humanity. Again, this plays very well into the whole tension-buildup setup the game goes for. No game is perfect, and Dark Souls does have a few issues: On the game side, the second half of the game (approximately) feels unfinished and rushed, with uninspired areas and bosses; the game’s leveling system lets players with high-end gear invade new players who are in the starting areas, which makes an unfair fight (but really, who hasn’t given in to becoming a level 1 darkwraith?). Technically, this is one of the worst console ports ever made, with locked in-game resolution and framerate (which can be solved with 3rd party patches like dsfix); and of course the networking code, invasions are based on a peer-to-peer system, so running into laggers is inevitable (that is if you manage to invade/get invaded in the first place, since Games For Windows Live does far more harm than good, requiring fiddling with router ports and more 3rd party patches like dscfix). At the end of the day, if you give the game and chance, it will “click” with you, and then you’ll become another victim from the dark curse, discussing and planning character builds and thinking why most other melee-focused combat games just don’t feel right anymore.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
using a controller with this game is highly recommendedPros:+ Excellent level design and overall atmosphere+ Loads of weapons, armors and items+ Simple yet deep combat system+ Deep, interesting lore (usually given by snippets of dialogue from NPCs or item descriptions)+ Challenging without being too unfair; which, for the most part, can lead to a great sense of accomplishment+ Leveling up one stat at a time (that affect Health, Stamina, Strength and so on) allows for a deep character customization, and along with a NG+ feature, ultimately welcomes multiple playthroughsMiddle Ground:~ Optimization: I'm placing this as a middle ground simply because it is difficult for me to blame FromSoftware for this port, or even have that much to complain about in all honesty.  If you are someone who cannot stand playing a game at 30fps (even if the game is designed around that framerate) or prefer to have a higher resolution experience, or even perhaps just want to tweak with some of the in-game effects, you'll want to Google search something called DSfix.Cons:- Matchmaking: (I suppose this could be linked to optimization as well, yet I am unsure if the console versions of this title use the same method) - I rarely was able to spot a player phantom sign during my first playthrough; in fact, most of that time the servers were not working at all.  So aside from a few NPC summons here and there for boss fights I rarely had the chance to play with other people (that includes invaders).  This personally is not a deal breaker for me as I enjoyed my time nonetheless, however, many gamers nowadays tend to be turned off if a game like this doesn't include proper multiplayer features.  I believe there is a program that improves the matchmaking experience - using your favorite search engine can lead you to the "fix" if you're willing to try it out.Conclusion:It's fairly difficult for me to find many faults with this game as I have only played through it once so far, along with messing around with a couple of different early game builds.  I'm probably what this community would call a "filthy casual" as I am not a walking encyclopedia of every aspect of the game's mechanics, so, again, it's hard for me to critique something I'm not yet aware of.  All I can say is, even with this title's downfalls, I very much enjoyed my time in Lordran and still to this day do not regret spending the current full price ($20) on what will probably go down as one of the greatest Action-RPG pinnacles of gaming history.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												(I'm largely going to skip the talk about GFWL (Games for Windows Live) and the required mods due to cruddy porting. Yes, GFWL is bad. Yes, it has just been replaced (Woo!). Yes, the porting is bad. Yes, it is entirely negligible with the DSfix and even made 100% playable with keyboard and mouse with DSmfix (setups which I'd be right happy to share.)I will probably have to start this review off by saying what everyone says; yes, this game is hard, and it will undoubtedly test you if you're new to the series.However, it will also reward you and your skill (or your exploring), over and over if you're willing to press on, not just with shiny items or souls, but also sometimes with breathtaking atmosphere, stunning landscape views (which in 99% of the cases, are places you'll end up later on, the level design is genius) and heaps of lore if you're into that sort of thing. Even I, who is 450 hours in, and now pushing for 100% completion, get well rewarded for some of the things I go through.Now, after all these hours, I know I can't say this game is completely flawless (aside from GFWL and port issues). I know the flaws. I've seen the flaws. I've talked to parts of the community about the flaws. But I did not see them the first playthrough, or the second, probably not before the third time or so, and honestly I'd say that's a lot better than most games still.I'd like to say that Dark Souls is a rather lonely experience and I'll suggest it should be played as such, at least the first playthrough. In my opinion this contributes to making some of the encounters more atmospheric, more lively, more depressive.As a last word, I wholeheartedly recommend this game, for there are few like it, and hopefully someone dare take the step to try it and falls as much in love with it as I have.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I simply cannot recommend this game enough.It's a refreshing take on the RPG genre. It doesn't hold your hand through anything. The story flows organically through dialog with no quest markers or logs - just the player and the world, which can be traversed from top to bottom.The difficulty is not artificial in any way; it is simply what you make of it. Learn the mechanics, master them and you will get the most satisfying gameplay experience you've had in a long time. Boss fights are just challenging enough to truly make you feel like you've earned the victory and make it that much sweeter when it comes.The multiplayer component is seamlessly weaved into the single player experience, something more and more games have been doing ever since Dark Souls proved it to be quite the viable mechanic. 10/10 would die again!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Generally, I play games on normal difficulty. Sometimes I drop it down to easy, because I'm a filthy casual. I didn't think I'd enjoy this game but I haven't been able to stop thinking about it since I started.The world is beautiful (once you get DSfix) in a run down way. It starts out with fairly typical undead ruins but gets weirder from there. The lore is largely unspoken, it is relayed through descriptions on items and how the world works. This is similar to the database in the first Mass Effect and I love it here just as much.The gameplay is tough. My first learning experience was near the start of the game. I had amassed a sizable amount of Humanity (a resource used in the game for various things) and because it increases item find I thought it'd be good to use it all. This means that I could lose it if I died, but I figured I'd have no problem getting to my bloodstain (which restores your lost Humanity and Souls). Then I met the first boss. He killed me. A lot. And then I died on the way back before I could get my bloodstain. All those Souls and Humanity - gone. I got mad. I stopped playing for the night. But I came back with an altered mindset: the only thing you lose by dying is whatever you choose to risk. Once I got into that mindset death doesn't bother me as much, although I am still cautious. I can see the effects of getting better at the game mechanics. I can see the benefit of my improved arms and armor. I "broke through the wall".It was worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Dark Souls is widly known as a game that causes undying rage in many of its players as well as being an awful pc port. These may be true, however there are allot of things that the people who dont play it because of this lose out on. Dark Souls is an incredible game overall. The story is amazingly deep and with all of the lore that exists in the game, it creates a world that you truly feel has existed long before you came around and long after you leave. Every character that you see on screen and even allot that you don't see on screen. All have huge impacts on the world around you and allot of people overlook this because of the games dificulty. For example you could find a body with some armor on it and not think twice. But if you look into it more you may find that the person who's armor it was had a huge impact on where you are and where the world is now and you had the misfortune/fortune to run into their grave.The gameplay itself works smoothly enough though a controller is strongly reccommended because of the pc ported controls being bad and not well explained. Most all of the movements in the game are very smooth, everything from parries to backstabs are all pleasing to the eye as well as very satisfying when you land them. You will die allot in this game, thats a given and something even mentioned in the title "Prepare to Die". But the greatest part of this game and why I personally find the dieing acceptable is because of the sense of acomplisment you get when you succeed. Killing a boss in this game is more than something you can just shrug off, its a huge acomplisment to kill a boss after dieing to it ten times before. To finally see on the screen "Boss Defeated" is a huge thing and can bring giant smiles and cheers to some. The sheer acomplisment alone makes this game worth while. The entire way you craft your character is very different to normal rpg's. You start with the regular builds, but as you go through the game your able to work towards whatever you want. You can start out a mage and end as a tank with the heaviest weapons and armor in the game if you'd like. This "Class system" makes gameplay allot different from other rpg's. Even better in my opinion is the opressive feeling you get when you have allot of souls (The ingame xp and currency) and are walking back to a bonfire, anything can happen and it gives you a very nervous feeling because you just killed a boss to get all of these and you dont want to lose them to a small enemy before you get to use them. So the atmosphere can change rapidly, and because of the soul system allot of people get turned off because that is what is rage inducing about the game. But getting past it makes you feel like you have truly acomplished something.As far as multiplayer however this game comes up a little short. The ability to see other people as translucient phantoms is amazing, getting to see the blood stains of other players in real time and seeing how they died is great. Or even sitting at a bonfire and seeing someone else sitting with you is good because it all makes you feel much less alone and lets you know others are going through what you are too. As far as the match making system for the party and invasions system is concerned however is another story. If you were hoping to co-op with a friend in this game, you will have a rough time. The game uses a peer to peer match making system which is a little flawed because of the time it can take for you to see a friends summon sign. Even more annoying can be the invasion system which allows others to invade your world when you are a human and slay you for your souls and humanity. Because you need to be human to summon others into your world for the boss fights, this can clash against the invasion system and allot of the time you will get invaded before you can even see your friends summon sign to bring them to your world.Overall this game is extremely well thought out in lore, setting a perfectly dark tone which suits the game and the atmosphere. The way the game has you interacting with other players is creative and inovative but the co-op aspect is slightly lacking. The Third Person RPG style gameplay is amazing and will keep you coming back for more every time along with the amazing boss fights (Save for 2 of them) that make you feel great when you finally defeat them. This is an amazing game which allot of people pass up for fear of its reputation as either a bad port or as a terribly difficult game. But, id reccomend this game to anyone who likes dark and very deep story lines, the very strong gameplay and "Class system" or lack there of and who want a little more challenge than the average game. Personally I give dark souls a 10/10 but that could be just me.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This game has the soul of an old-school ARPG with modern AAA production values.  This game puts fresh spins on mechanics that went out of style 10-15 years ago and puts them at the core of its gameplay.  Every enemy is a threat, bosses will brutalize you until you figure them out, there's zero hand-holding, and dying hurts.  And you will die.  A lot, actually.And it's awesome.  Don't wait for years like I did thinking it's all overblown hype.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												A modern day masterpiece.Im not new to the series having previously done everything possible in Demon Souls....I'd went several NG+ deep, held every weapon, reached well in excess of SL250 and farmed souls to the point where losing 4 million souls meant absolutely nothing, all as part of a 15-20 hour search just for the ever elusive Pure Bladestone. Dark Souls does everything Demon Souls did but on a grander scale. The nexus is a thing of the past with more traditional progression through the area making it feel more like a world than a series of selectable areas / levels. There's a heavy covenant theme throughout the game, many are easily missable as there well off the beaten track. There are NPCs which will sporadically pop up during your playthrough provided you fulfill very specific conditions and for the most part meet them at a set point during progression through the game.What is retained is the outstanding sense of atmosphere. Blighttown & The Depths are Dark Souls equivalent of the Valley of Defilement from Demon Souls, an area where early game you'll spend most of your time either poisoned, toxic, cursed or all three. Tomb of the Giants with its almost complete darkness hiding oversized skeletons up until the point where they attack, Darkroot Basin & Darkroot Garden with Alvina the Forest Covenant leader looking like a nod to something from Alice in Wonderland. The Crystal Cave, Demon Ruins, Lost Izalith, The Catacombs, The Painted World of Ariamis, Anor Londo....there all fantastic, so unique and defined in the game world with completely unforgettable mini bosses / bosses.The gameplay mechanics are generally as was in Demon Souls, load created by equipped items and stamina / strength stats still play a huge part, go over 50% and you fat roll, go even higher and your character will just squirm on the spot when you tap roll, mobility as before is key. If you can get to them the game throws high level armour sets and weapons at you very early on, there so high though you're unable to use them effectively. During my initial playthrough I fealt like I barely scratched the game, I used several weapons out of more than likely 50+ which reside in my inventory, used 3 or 4 armour sets, used 3 or 4 rings predominantly chosen specifically for boss fights or locations. I believe I used one spell out of a vast amount, that being Iron Flesh to tank the Sanctuary Garden boss - the scope to play the game in your own way is almost overwhelming.To touch on the multiplayer, its still active, people still drop the old troll signs telling you to jump off cliff faces to fantastic treasure etc, for the best example of how unique the multiplayer is googling "Dark Souls The Wall" leaves nothing to the imagination.Very few games nowadays keep me compelled to the point where I can't put them down, Dark Souls is one of them.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												BEST GAME EVERI own this game on Xbox360, and have beaten it more times than I could keep track of. I died more times than I could count. This game went from, one of THE most frustrating experiences in my life. To one of the most rewarding experiences. I think I purchased it a couple (2) of years after it came out. Now you could watch a bunch of YouTube videos. However it took me years of grueling and triumphant effort to master this game.Although I own Demon's Souls (PS3), Dark Souls II (360, PC), Scholar of the First Sin (PC), Bloodborne (PS4), and Dark Souls III (PS4,PC)....I cannot stop playing the first "Dark Souls". Years later and I am playing like it's an addiction.I paid $15 to the expansion content on console. Yet I picked up this Steam version, with DLC. For like $2.99. This was even after a sale I missed. I was crushed. The price then, was $4.99. Even at what, 20 bucks? This game is a STEAL.Casual gamers; this game IS for you, because you deserve the aggravation. Hardcore gamers already know about this game and don't need to be sold on the value.Not only is the story a mystery, but the lore is a matter of opinion. You MUST read item descriptions, talk to anyone that will speak, and play through to decide for yourself. Will you follow the Sun, link the Bonfires, become a Darkwraith, or simply become Crestfallen....and give up.Ah haha haha Ha hahahaCome on then. It's only a game, and it won't be THAT difficult for you. Will it!?

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Product received for free
												Its more fair than real life.Seriously tho. If you find modern day AAA games to be a cakewalk at default and padded with artificial difficulty at higher levels (bullet sponges, 2 hit kills.... you name it) then you will like this game. It doesnt BS you with some fake difficulty and catapults you into the game world whose history you will likely not understand until NG+2.GameplayDont get the wrong impression and run away now though. The actual PvE combat mechanics is very well balanced. The mobs will die few whacks and so will you. So once you learn the mechanics and patterns of the enemies. The game becomes considerably easier to manage and you'll likely not die at all provided you're careful.The area can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥to navigate and there's hidden nooks and crannies(ph4tloots included) everywhere.So its a nightmare for the forgetful gamer. Getting lost mid-map is mandatory. You might wanna skip to a guide if you dont really have the time. I cant say much about the PVP but be prepared to face laggers and cheap strat "meta" no lifers taunt-after-every-killers. The connection is P2P. Theres no dedicated server. (more lag yaayyyyy)[PC Port troubles]What can I say? This is a console game ported to PC by popular demand so the interface sucks big goblin donger and gets crammy really quick. The default mouse+kb control is unusable(mod fix) If you want to play at 60fps 1080p you will also need to dl a mod.In the end you will get frustrated. You will forget that frustration once you rekt that a-hole boss after 10 deaths. You will get frustrated again...etc...But is the feeling at the end worth? DefinitelyPraise/10

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I simply cannot recommend this game enough.It's a refreshing take on the RPG genre. It doesn't hold your hand through anything. The story flows organically through dialog with no quest markers or logs - just the player and the world, which can be traversed from top to bottom.The difficulty is not artificial in any way; it is simply what you make of it. Learn the mechanics, master them and you will get the most satisfying gameplay experience you've had in a long time. Boss fights are just challenging enough to truly make you feel like you've earned the victory and make it that much sweeter when it comes.The multiplayer component is seamlessly weaved into the single player experience, something more and more games have been doing ever since Dark Souls proved it to be quite the viable mechanic. 10/10 would die again!

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												Now, let's just preface this with the obvious.You'll die. A lot. Okay, now with the obvious♥♥♥♥♥♥done and dusted, this game is a masterpiece. The way the lore is (or rather, isn't) told, the combat mechanics forcing you to adapt and reflect on each and every death, the at times skeletal but driving soundtrack, it all fits together like a well-crafted jigsaw. Add to that the massive scale of the replayability be it via NG+ or a new build, and the graphics (which are very pleasing even for an 'older' game) being what they are, this game is a solid rec in my opinion. Finally I'd like to add that the online playerbase is thriving still. It's not as active as DS3 per se but considering that at this point in time we've already got two sequels, the fact that people are still regularly engaging in jolly cooperation is heartwarming.Now to be fair, the game is far from perfect. The later areas suffer from either dips in budget, time or creativity, a prime example being the bed of chaos. Or as the community's dubbed it, the bed of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Some parts of the game feel barren, and a few of the bosses really could have benefited from some extra zest to them. However, this is just nitpicking.All in all this game is sure to keep you entertained and challenged, from the moment ms big booty jumps you until the point where you beat old ashbeard.P.S.: don't skip out on the DLC, it contains some of the best boss battles and scenery in the game.P.P.S.: don't level RES. Just don't.P.P.P.S.: \[T]/ praise the sun \[T]/

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Dark Souls is an action RPG that originally came out on the PS3 back in 2011 and later ported to PC. In order to get the best experience out of it you'll need to get DSfix and use that (nexus mods has it or just google it). You'll also need a controller. Keyboard & Mouse controls are absolute garbage and even customizing them is worthless.  It's a game that's most famous for it's challenge, although fair, takes skill and trial & error to complete. There's many different playstyles to start from, Warrior, Pyromancer, Sorceror, Cleric etc. With all types of weapons ranging from swords, clubs, hammers, axes, spells, bows, crossbows and so on. As you progress in the game you will find bonfires that you can use to level up your character with souls collected from fallen foes. Bonfires are by far the most useful object in the game. They're needed to repair weapons & armor, store your items, level up and eventually fast travel. Everytime you use a bonfire though all the enemies (except bosses and important monsters) will respawn which means you'll have to plan your route and battle strategy accordingly since distance between bonfires can be quite far.It's not a game I'd call frustratingly hard but it is fair and will punish you for every mistake. Every encounter serves a purpose and the level design which at times can be a bit confusing but still brilliantly constructed to tie the world together is one of my favorite things about the game. The story isn't straightforward and the world building & lore is done mostly through reading item descriptions. If you head into a direction and the enemies totally destroy you, that's the game's way of telling you not to go that way yet.All in all, this game is one of my favorites. Get Dark Souls. Get good.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												It is what it is, one of the best and most unforgiving RPG's there is, gameplay-wise.In my opinion though the STORY isn't all too great, don't get me wrong, the lore of the game is amazingly unique and magnificent, but I don't really feel the story of the main character, the Chosen Undead.You really have to get into this game to understand it, both regarding story and gameplay, but once you're in it, it's an amazing experience.It's awesome both co-op and single player. Although the game is meant to be played purely single player or co-op with strangers, I've played with one of my best friends (Trigger) practically the whole game except some little annoying or unimportant parts.If you like getting both your patience and skill pushed to its limits, this is the game for you.And if you like shaping your own character the way YOU want, in this game nothing is stopping you. You choose a main class at the beginning, determining your starting skillpoints and standard equip, but then you're free to do what you want.Example: I started off as the class Sorcerer. Theoretically, I would be blasting enemies away with spells called "Soul Arrows", but along the game I also put points into strength and dexterity, so now I also sometimes use a Falchion or a huge Dragonhunter Bow. Ever seen a mage use a bow that's too big to even hold? If you're into shaping your own character in an environment where you aren't sure if enemies will jump out of walls, THIS is THE game for you.9/10

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Some games try to scare you with bump-in-the-night shocks and far-off howls, but Dark Souls doesn't require such predictable methods of terror. Its terrors emanate from its very core, each step bringing you closer to another inevitable death. How amazing that such a terrible place could be so inviting. The game's world is so memorable, and its action so thrilling, that it might invade your thoughts even when you aren't playing, silently urging you to escape the real world and return to this far more treacherous one. Dark Souls doesn't just surpass other dungeon crawlers; it skewers them with a razor-sharp halberd and leaves behind their soulless corpses.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												Dark Souls is what more games would be if the industry didn't try so hard to mimic Hollywood. It's what games used to be: challenging, creative, and most importantly; it unobtrusively tells a story about you, the player. It doesn't dwell on side characters or lavish cutscenes; this is all about your journey, as painful or rewarding as it may be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Reviewing this game purely on it's merits as a game and not a PC port, it's fantastic, easily one of my favorite games of all time, possibly my favorite RPG of all time. With one of the best combat systems of any game, you make a mistake, you'll probably end up dying, it's extremely punishing and thus not for everyone but if you put in the time it's VERY rewarding.The world and level design is in my opinion unmatched in any RPG, there's all sorts of secrets to be found in the game by jumping from ledges and rolling onto different platforms to get to secret areas, the game is rife with secrets.The story is incredibly deep, complex and compelling but is told subtly in item descriptions, random observations around the world and NPC dialogue.PvP is great fun but likely will be laggy, it's entirely optional, as is CO-OP, some people love to play the game with friends, some love to solo it, I'm in the latter category but there is something here for everyone.The enemy design and voice acting are top notch, I honestly cannot say enough good things about this game, but I stress, if you do not enjoy a challenge (that's fine) then Dark Souls is likely not for you, oh, and the PC port is a barebones straight console port, but is easily fixed by using Durante's "DSFix" Mod.In my opinion, one of the greatest games ever made.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												What to say about Dark Souls...Dark Souls is amazing in every way. The gameplay, the story, the lore, and the atmosphere. The atmosphere plays a huge roll in Dark Souls, making you feel alone and hopeless through much of the game, considering that almost everyone around you is going insane. Dark Souls has a very original way of intergrating multiplayer into the singleplayer. Around the land of Lordran, you will find these Humanity Sprites. With Humanity, you have the ability to become "Human". When you become "Human", You are able to summon other players by finding their White Soapstone. This allows you to engage in jolly cooperation! However, be warned. Becoming "Human" makes you suspectible to invasions. Invasions are random, and are forced upon you. The invaders sole purpose is to hunt you down and kill you for your humanity, so be cautious whenever you get invaded! Hands down, Dark Souls is one of the best games of 2011-2013, and it has shown it's worth the phrase "Prepare to Die".

												Bequeathed be upon thee the Darkened Soul, which thou shalt forever regret and rejoice... Dark Souls easily rivals every game in unforgivingness as even the simplest of enemies provide a challenging experience. The difficulty does not adjust to your level, rather it forces you to adapt and improve; that is, unless you want to get stuck in the game. However, it also comes with a stunning storyline, various roleplay elements and possibly one of the most well made settings in gaming history. Dark Souls will exhaust and enrage you as well as it will draw your breath from excitement and thrill. And if that is not enough: Try holding it with both hands.PS: Since the release of the Steam beta Games for Windows Live is no longer required. Still though, a game controler is a must have for this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												While Dark Souls has a few technical issues this is the closest any video game has come to perfection. Every element of the game (graphics, sound, story, setting, gameplay, difficulty) serves to reinforce the theme of one speck of humanity fighting against the indifferent dying universe. Removing or changing any of the core elements would result in a worse experience. While the game is more difficult than other modern games, it's never unfair. It has no hand-holding tutorials, minimaps, and quest markers because it trusts the player to be intelligent and intrigued enough to try and figure out things on his/her own. It helps that the level design is amazing and unforgettable. There's a reason that the Internet is still harping on about this game, and that its influences can still be seen in other newer games. If not the best than certainly the most important video game of the decade.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Despite the incredible rushjob/absolutely no effort port from the 360 version this is, The game itself makes getting though the initial problems very much worth it. There isn't much I can say that hasen't been said many times already about it.They litteraly took the 360 version, added some new areas and did little else, resulting in a game that has a forced internal resoultion that is the same as the 360 version (1024x720), no graphics options and locked at 30fps. They did infact add an option to change the resolution ingame, but this just upscales it.Just grab DSfix and that's 1 major problem gone. (The lack of graphical options and the 30 fps cap, nothing you can do about the internal resolution though) The games still very much alive and well multiplayer elements are in the process of being transfered to steamworks so no more GFWL soon (Problem 2). On that topic, one thing I will say about this game is it has one of the most unique, creative and seamless approches to multiplayer anywhere. While its mostly the same as this games spiritual predecessor demons souls, it was hardly in need of change anyway. It almost entirely forgos direct interaction, with gestures being your only means of communication outside of friending and msging them. Anyone can leave hints on the ground for players new to the area to read. You can place a summon sign or find one someone else has placed to summon them for help (Jolly cooperation!) Whenever someone else dies you can see a bloodstain on the ground, touching it will show the last few seconds of there life possibly helping you avoid the same fate. And lastly at any place at any time outside of most bonfires while you are in human form you can be invaded by other players and find yourself in PvP. At. Any. Moment. *Paranoia intensifies*. If you have sin points (Gained from killing npcs or getting indicted by a player whose world you invaded) you could find youself getting invaded by a player from the darkmoon covenent whom delever GREAT JUSTICE to those players. These can even all happen at once and you can still be invaded with a summoned player or invaded by more than one person at a time (If you get darkmooned and invaded by a regular darkwraith at the same time or go to the darkroot forest or as I call it: PvP paradise) giving you group pvp. Its not without its problems, mostly from its use of P2P for invasions resulting in some really bad desync at times.This leaves just the horrible controls (Game shows 360 controller buttons regardless if you are using one or not) on keyboard which can be fixed eather by using a controler or using a mouse fix so the lockon at least doesn't swich targets over the SMALLEST mouse movments.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Dark Souls is the perfect mix of old-school Japanese game design with Western RPG mechanics.It's a love letter to a time when games challenged you, demanded you to make a damned effort; and then rewarded you handsomely with an overwhelming, addictive sense of accomplishment.It's a no-nonsense, pure gameplay game. There are barely any cutscenes. The story (which is rather deep and nicely layered) is told in minute pieces you need to pick up and put together on your own. There are a handful of spoken lines and there's not even any form of lipsynch --every resource was devoted to the *game* part of the game.In a time when everyone goes for the everything-and-the-kitchen-sink school of game design, Dark Souls takes a theme and a gameplay mechanic, and decides to just focus on that. Instead of trying to implement 15 different kinds of games at once and half-assing them all (at best), Dark Souls simply aims to be a game about hitting skeletons with a sword --but then it sets out to be the deepest, most complex title on the subject.The world is large, interconnected, it offers a myriad of ways to go about it, it holds gigantic secret areas, and it just drips with atmosphere. In a whole bunch on non-trivial ways, Dark Souls might just be the one true metroidvania of the 21st century.Dark Souls is one of those things that will be talked about in gaming history books.Do I recommend this game? There is no "thumbs up" big enough \[T]/

content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												THIS GAME HAS GRAND AND BEAUTIFUL SCENERY (love those environments), AS WELL AS VERY DETAILED AND AMAZING ARTWORK (shout out to that monster art), ALL WRAPPED UP INTO A VAST AND GRITTY STYLED WORLD THAT CONTAINS THE STUFF OF LEGENDS (Hydras, dragons, basalisks, giant clams with tiny legs & hidden lore are included).Many people hate this game, say its impossible & there's nothing worth a look. 'They' probably have anger management problems and no patience. The game starts in a cage, they die, get angry, die faster and more frequently-seeing nothing but stone walls and dangerous enemies at first, they soon rage and quit."If you try it you might like it""But i tried it mama!""Did you really try it? Or did you just eat the slightly burnt crust of THAT GODLIKE PIZZA BAKED BY ODINS VALKYRIES THEMSELVES?!?!?""GET SOME HAIR ON YOUR CHEST BOY!!!!!" your mother screams like a drill instructor & slaps uYou will see grand scenery, you will reap treasure beyond imagining, you will FEEL the reward!But only after you trawl through sewers, slay the dealiest enemies, hunt the strangest of creatures, defend yourself from disgusting abominations, to scour the world.This game rewards those who keep cool under pressure & persevere. Get angry, then u get reckless & then you die being reckless. Be smart, learn to properly utilize your arsenal (which can be massive), learn different techniques and tactics, attack effectively and counter appropriately-you'll be the victor. Different weapons and/or different approaches all have their strengths & weaknesses depending upon the situation.THE GRITIf you make a mistake & don't die, then it's a good outcome.If you don't look for openings and attack immediately instead, the enemy may do the same, so you both stab each other & die clutching your stomach-assuming the enemy doesn't have armour enough to endure your hit that is.If you dodge a heavy weapon, before it's lifted back up you can stab that insolent fool in the back if your fast enough-but if you don't dodge it... Your body will be pulverized into the ground.However adept you become, a single mistake or a single random occurence that catches you off-guard, can mean your death.THE PVP & CO-OP IS VERY GOODAlthough there are a few bugs-like the small online delay when receving backstabs from other players (which there are quite a few methods to prevent), it is fairly balanced (there are a few exceptions that are unfairly harder to counter then others to the extreme, but there are ways).I MUST STRESSThat if you like a proper challenge, a first playthrough while summoning phantoms to help may spoil your experience & transform u into a dependant cherub.There are optional areas & hidden weapons-don't miss em! The Great Hollow is a favourite of mine.Bare chest & WARRIOR class for versatity is recommended IMO. 16 strength and 12-14 dexterity for great weapon choice and range.Unless u wanna crush things, then go BANDIT.26-28 strength for 99% of your enemy crushing needs.Barechest is no longer recommended, but rather a necessity.Sorcerer for easier mode, the class starts off wth lazors.25 minimum intelligence to rub crystals on your weapons.Wear a skirt.But if you wanna be a baus, but you also want to fire your lazors, then complete the game without increasing vitality or endurance.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I have just finished my second playthrough of this Dark Souls PtD Edition and damn, that game is a fine piece of art and entertainment. There is a reason why it receives so much acclamation and it's not about it's difficulty per se. The game actually grows on you as an experience, and make no mistake, dying is part of the experience.TL;DR: 1) bad port but with modders help can achieve optimal funcionality; 2) great visual art, with lots of inspiring moments and gorgeous views; 3) goodt soundtrack and an "ok" voice acting; 4) exceptional level design; 5) ingenious multiplayer component; 6) deeply satisfying combat, especially because of the high skill curve; 7) a beautiful minimalistic story that you unravel by yourself.First off a fair warning: this is a great game, but a very bad PC port, so to enhance your experience the most you should search for a mod called"DSFix" and another one called "PvP Watchdog". If your rig can take it, you should also download a mod for HD texures, as it improves the visual quality a lot. Second warning: play this game with a controller, seriously, it is hard enough as it is without struggling with a keyboard and mouse in combat.Dark Souls is unique in the sense that it lets you, the player, experience the feelings of desolation, ignorance, fear, persistence, bravery, and last but not least... hope. This game weighs heavily on the atmosphere of an "Undead" (that which you are) in a journey that begins almost as serendipity, and develops into influencing the face of the land of Lordran. To accomplish this feat, the game is very minimalistic about its story, and there are almost no evnts that directly robs the player's agency. Hell, besides a few instructions i nthe first level of the game and the DLC, the game actually almost never tells you directly anything at all! Yet, this is amazing, there is a distinct feeling of awe by discovering th story and feeling, yourself, as disposessed and yer tencaious as your "Undead"character. By talking to the NPCs and by sheer power of observation you can, piece by piece, unravel this purposedly öpen"story and the background of this mysterious land.In that regard, there is also a great component to this game, which is it's multiplayer approach. Make no mistake: Dark Souls is a single-player game, albeit different from others. If you remain in the "Human" state you will seamlessly cross paths with other players in their own Undead Journey, wether py directly interactin wit them or seeing them as phantoms from another "age", as time flows in a very strange manner in this land of Lordran. You can leave hem messages to help other players or trick them, and vice-versa, while also being able to invade other players realities or be summoned by them for help. It is a genious concept, really, and one that works very well asides some few connectivity issues.The world itself is connected like early metroidvanias, in a sense that almost all areas fit into each other seamlessly, with shortcuts nd hidden paths to each of them. It is also a neat RPG where you have a relative freedom to build your character as you see fit, and mix might with magic and so on. The combat is very good and the gameplay is polished, with the caveat that you will have to discover by yourself or with the help of others how everything works (or get a guide in the internet), especially the tidbits of combat mechanics. This game is very hard, but that is a good thing, because the difficult is tied to your skill as a player (your equipment and stats realy come into play later, but the breaking point if you will keep dying a lot will be your skill) as it blends well the gameplay and story of the game. It has no pause button, it does not teach you the advanced mechanics of the game, and if you are not careful, Dark Souls will punish you for your mistakes, because even the lowest of minions can pose a considerable threat. There are very few moments when the game warrants cruel sudden kills, all of it are tied to navigating the land (pitfalls, etc.), but you will learn to avoid these. Dying, I repeat, is part of the experience, and you will die A LOT playing this game.So, I fully recommend this game (with mods to fix the bad port)... go buy it and prepare to die!

The only negative points I've found in the game are the hackers and how long it takes to summon a specific someone: It's getting a tad ridiculous all the people that seem to be level 1 with everything maxed out or worse, with infinite health. About summoning a friend, it is really tricky sometimes, but also depends of luck: One day you can summon your friend just fine and another day... you won't be able to summon your friend no matter what, or the summon will fail over 20 times (yes, 20 or even more) before it will finally work.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Dark Souls is a truly gritty, patience defying, inventive, and unique hack and slash role playing game. As someone who normally is not even remotely interested in the genre, I find this game to be breath of fresh air. Extremely challenging and downright rage inducing at times, prepare yourself for a steep learning curve. However, once you beat a boss, clear an area, or finally get that coveted item the satisfaction is immense. It really helps if you have a friend to show you the ropes and help you with boss fights. (Thanks Jason!) Most importantly, this game would be unplayable without a controller.I highly recommend this wonderfully dark and gloomy game if you are looking to test your mettle and your patience.

												This is a terrible port, but thanks to the community it's decent now. DSFix is a must to fix the screen resolution issue, google it. And you could pick up some texture mods from the nexus site. This game sucks on keyboard and mouse, I'd really take the controller required disclamer serious. The game is brilliant, it pretty much has alot of old school gaming to it. It's difficulty is a bit exaggerated, and is purely difficult as the game doesn't spoonfeed the player and leaves everything from combat to the story up to his/her interpretation. There is alot of trial and error on your first play. The online play is cute, however not GFWL that is tied to it.The art direction, sound, animation and combat is very good. To me art direction is more important than "graphics". Because I'd take Bioshock or this over a Crysis Game.The only weird thing about this game is that it really starts off with a steep difficulty curve, right up to the bell gargoyle fight. This has pretty much made it into my list of favorite games. Just make sure you get DSfix first for this game, and also a controller.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												So I'm pretty sure what happened here is Japan decided it wanted make a Skyrim game. But, what they can't understand is that a true RPG makes you feel like a hero. In this, you die all the time. And, as all basic game development tells you, every time you allow the player to die it devalues the player character as a world power. By the time you've died 17 times on the same enemy, nothing is left of playing as a hero.No one wants to play some game where a rat is a threat. People want to play games where they can kill dragons by pressing RT four times. One thing that I will hand to this game though, is that it has some truly stellar loot progression. I started with nothing more that a simple broken sword, but then after much ado I found my first true blade. That was a truely monumental moment of experience, but the rest of the game failed to meet up to the standards of that moment.Also, this game is run by the Nazis, because you in fact DO lose your XP. I can't count the amount of times I was moments away from reaching a new level of power required to use a mighty weapon, only to fall to my death due to the game's pisspoor collision detection.That brings me nicely to quite possibly the games biggest problem, you can use a spell a limited amout between resting. this essentially removes spellcasting as a viable combat option. The game fails again by failing to implement a score, in fact most of the game is silent. Overall, I give Dark Souls : Prepare to Die Edition a dissapointing 7/10.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												First of all, despite how many people tote the frustration brought on by playing it, this game is by no means exceptionally difficult. Though that's not to say that it isn't challenging, because it certainly is. What makes it seem so daunting the first time around is the contrast to the sheer, often insulting, amount of nanny hand-holding that we're used to seeing from major release titles, which makes Dark Souls feel very refreshing to play and I keep finding myself coming back for more.This lack of handholding is similarly reflected in the storytelling. This game certainly has a story, but unlike many other games it is not told to you outright. Instead, it is subtly told through elements in the world, primarily through item descriptions, but also through NPC dialogue and small details in the world. It is therefore up to you as a player to pay careful attention and to go out of your way to piece the story together yourself, which, I can promise you, is rewarding. Personally, I love this as this means that I don't have to sit through the several minutes of cutscenes and NPC dialogue which seriously cripple the replayability of other games (*COUGH* mass effect *COUGH*).My favourite aspect of the game is its combat which is, above all, exceptionally fluid. The controls are well calibrated, and can best be described as tight. It should be noted that the controls are, by default, severely marred by an atrocious port BUT, thankfully, there exists a mod called DSFix which resolves most of the issues. Even with the fix, I strongly reccomend using some kind of controller over the old faithful mouse+keyboard. Combat in and of itself is governed by only a few simple mechanics, but, together, these make for a great experience requiring the use of tactical thinking.This game is also renowned for its innovative multiplayer. Instead of seperate single-player and multi-player experiences, there are means by which other players can traverse the gap to your world as phantoms, or you can enter theirs. You may either summon other players to help you defeat enemies in the area, including the boss, for which they will recieve a small bounty of souls, or they can forcibly enter your world with the objective of mercilessly preying upon you and claiming your humanity. For the invader, entering your world is random, which is, to say the least, exciting due to the resulting unpredictability. Have you invaded an inexperienced player which you will effortlessly smear into the ground or a grizzled veteran accompanied by multiple phantoms, more than ready to recieve you or a lone host lying in deadly ambush?Unfortunately, while I love this game, there are some unfortunate flaws. As mentioned before, this is one of the most abysmal PC ports that I have ever experienced. DO NOT attempt to play this game until you have installed DSFix! While this will resolve the majority of the issues, the game still lacks optimization for PC hardware and therefore does not perform as well as other games which have possess similar graphical quality. Once again, I highly reccomend a controller (I use a PS3 controller), but this is up to your personal taste.Another objectively bad issue is the poor networking. Dark Souls is strictly peer-to-peer in its multiplayer and also features bad programming in terms of managing it. Consequently, attempting to summon other players into your world or attempting to invade to PvP will often fail. Additionally, this game features highly unusual lag. This is inconsequential in PvE, but during PvP combat, expect to see other players teleporting around the screen occasionally or even appearing behind you suddenly, stabbing you in the back, despite appearing in front of you moments before.My final gripes with the game are with the community. Unfortunately, the nature of the PC means that it is much easier than on consoles to cheat. As someone who frequently engages on PvP, I encounter people on a daily basis with hacked health, modded weapons, infinite stamina, cheated in items, and much more. The best sollution when you discover that someone is cheating is to immediately disconnect from the game. NEVER continue to engage them, as this allows them to take advantage of the cheats they're using and gain the satisfaction from using them.This is not my only complaint. Due to how this game renowned for its difficulty, the community is rife with players who are often condescending, if not downright smug. Whenever someone asks something like "Hey, can anyone give me advice on defeating X boss?", there will often be several people with offers of advice, but you can usually expect one person to reply with "Oh, X boss is really easy. I defeated X boss on my first try!". This also translates to PvP: "I hate it when people use Y in pvp! It's so overpowered!" often incites a reply like "Y is so easy to counter. I almost never lose to people who use Y."Complaints aside, I do really love this game. In fact, I would wholeheartedly state that this is my absolute favourite game of all time.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I'm a big fan of the Souls series (and Bloodborne of course).This is a game all about sperimentation: try, die, change accordingly to your mistakes (or you will die again). You try out what build best suits you, what weapon is best for your build, and so on. The gameplay is nearly perfect, but in my opinion what makes this game shine is the lore. Miyazaki's way of storytelling is at first glance incosistent. But, like many gameplay and design details, this is a deceive. Try out a YouTube channel that discuss the lore (ENB, TerraMantis, VaatiVidya and many others), and you will find hours of awesome stories. This is a great added value: even if you are not playing the game you are enjoying it.This is the best of the Souls series, don't miss it!

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This game is awesome, the only negative aspect about it is that you NEED to use a controller, xbox or play station, it doesn't matter, as long as you have one. As soon as you leave that bad aspect of the game behind, everything else is flawless, beatiful game, very enjoyable, i didn't even finish it yet after playing for more than 100 hours because of all the fun i'm having in darkroot forest doing pvp. I played Dark Souls II before this one, and i loved it, but honestly i liked this one even more, the only thing i missed was the option to reset your skill points, or however you wanna call them, because for any new player it would be a nightmare to play this game without even knowing how to level up properly. If you buy Dark Souls, you'll get a challenging, exciting and beatiful game with an amazing combat system, Every area is different, you'll never get the feeling that you are doing the exact same thing, you have a lot of freedom to choose how to fight your enemies, an open world where you can choose where to go, and when to do so. It has an amazing storyline, most characters you'll find in this game have more backstory than some of the main characters of other games. The world is so well designed that everything is connected, as soon as you finish an area you can activate shortcuts so if you feel like going back there's no need to clear the whole place once again, This game is art, it's like a Van Gogh, only difference is that you'll probably have to fight van gogh, cut his ear, and then slap him with that same ear!!! So, what are you waiting for? time to GIT GUDSpanish:Este juego es genial, el único aspecto negativo que tiene es que TENES que usar un control, ya sea de Xbox o play station es irrelevante, mientras tengas uno… Dejando de lado ese aspecto negativo del juego, todo lo demás es perfecto. No lo termine después de haber jugado más de 100 horas debido a que estoy cagandome de risa, y divirtiéndome haciendo pvp en Darkroot Forest, jugué la secuela antes que este juego, (Dark souls II) y me encantó, pero este me gustó incluso más, Lo único que extrañe del 2, es que, en este juego no tenes la opción de resetear tus puntos (los que adquirís por cada nivel que subís y definen a tu personaje) lo cual puede ser pésimo para alguien nuevo en el juego, ya que bueno… si no sabes cómo invertir bien los puntos, la paliza que te van a dar, ni te la olvidas…. Si compras el juego, vas a tener  esto: Un juego difícil, que te va a costar ganar, y te vas a excitar cada vez que le rompas el orto a un boss, porque el seguro te lo rompe 20 veces antes.  Si estás acostumbrado a los juegos de acción y aventura actuales, seguro que los npc normales te parecen jefes, porque te van a partir, Dejando eso de lado, el juego es bellísimo, es increíblemente creativo, la imaginación de los creadores realmente voló porque cada área que visitas es única, y el juego nunca te deja esa sensación de que haces las cosas de forma repetida, o que los enemigos son los mismos porque ese no es el caso, hay un millón de lugares, un millón de enemigos, un millón de armas, un millón de jefes para partirte el orto, una hidra de 100 metros es considerada un mini jefe, así que ya sabes lo que te espera. Los personajes que se suponen que son secundarios, tienen más historia que varios de los personajes principales de otros juegos, pero no te confundas, no te vas a comer diálogos o escenas que no puedas adelantar, toda la historia del mundo está ahí para que vos la busques, no te fuerzan a conocerla en ningún momento. El mundo está todo conectado, cuando terminas un área podes activar atajos y volver cuando quieras sin tener que despejar todos los bichos que habían, Este juego es arte, es como un Van Gogh, la única diferencia siendo es que, probablemente tengas que pelear contra Van Gogh, cortarle vos la oreja, y darle cachetazos con esa misma oreja. No esperes más, comprate el juego.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												Do I recommend this game? hell yeahDark Souls gave me lots of pleasure and very unique experience.At first I heard of this game on 9gag and decided to try. I played lots of RPGs and ARPGs. The last one I played was Skyrim. Oh boy, Dark Souls seemed to be very hard in comparison to Skyrim. I made a lot of mistakes and Dark Souls doesn't forgive them. The first character was ruined. With the second character I finished the game and it wasn't easy. But after playing DS3 I learned a bit more and now DS1 doesn't feel very difficult or unfair. Zero. You will need a gamepad, DSFix and other mods that you can find on nexus mods to make this purchase worthwhile on PC. The online isn't great nowadays, but if you manage to get some jolly cooperation, or get to invade or be invaded, you'll get some of this unique Souls experience. First of all you have to understand that Dark Souls is more a puzzle game, than simple hack and slash. You need to read every clue you can find about the world and mechanics, because nothing is explained. Forget anything you knew about ARPG games. And don't be afraid to die - this is part of the gameplay. The game is about perseverance and overcoming the obstacles. Second, understand the combat mechanics. This includes dodging, blocking, parrying and backstabbing. Also understand how weapon enhancement, ascension and stat scaling work - this is very important, because you need to level up your weapons as you level up your character.Third, understand how your stats work. Resistance is absolutely useless. Str and Agl don't give a lot of damage boost if your weapon is not upgraded, so at the beginning consider investing in HP and Endurance. Watch for your weight limit, armor defense properties and poise that defines if your attacks can be interrupted. Match your equipment to your enemies’ weakness. Fourth, don't sell or dispose your items, as a lot of them are hard to obtain and are available only once in a playthrough.And the last one. Don't rush. Observe your enemies, observe your surroundings, observe the world. The plot is pretty solid, but you will probably miss it, because you need to piece together a lot of things - the intro, the dialogs (which are in old English), the item descriptions, the location you find these items at and the design of the enemies. There are no definite answers, so you have to use your imagination.  If you finished reading this review, you are probably ready to take on this masterpiece. I envy you.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												This game comes with a laundry list of great features: an exceptionally well-built world (both in terms of level design and backstory), great controls (in a game where this is very important), good balancing, an enticing story that makes you feel both very important and very small at the same time, and some of the best sense of accomplishment you can get from a video game (which comes both from the gameplay and from finding the story, as much of it is not told directly to you but learned from inference). Also of note is the great soundtrack, which I occasionally still listen to outside of the game. Something that must be mentioned the reputation this game has for its difficulty...and it's somewhat deserved. For the first few hours you will likely struggle. The fun comes when you get the hang of it, understand that you're not superman (like you are in many games), and get that sense of accomplishment. Not for the faint of heart or someone looking for a game to breeze through, but totally worth the time investment needed to improve. This is one of the few games where killing the first area enemies still feels satisfying after many hours played (since they were so difficult when you first begin the game). If you enjoy action-RPGs, a sense of improvement and accomplishment, and games with fantastic story, worlds, mood, and music, or if you just enjoy a challenge, pick this up. No other game will ever feel quite the same as it did before you played Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Don't let the "Dark Souls is hard" hype scare you away. There's a few different types of difficulty in games: the kind that tests your skill and dexterity with the controller, the kind that tests your brain and makes you figure things out, and the "arcade hard" that just screws you over randomly and takes your money. Dark Souls is the perfect balance of all three, so even if you're not very good at hard games (like me), the design and balance makes it accessible to anyone who's willing to get in the right "mode" and put in the effort.Every combat encounter requires some strategizing, some practice, and a little bit of luck. It is punishing, you lose "souls" and "humanity" whenever you die, but you do have a chance to get it back, and if it's gone forever, it's not the end of the world. Just accept your losses and, if you can't bring yourself to try that path again, there's usually some other nook to explore in this game's well-designed and wonderful looking world. And stuff will occasionally come out of nowhere and kill you randomly, which if you're in the right mindset just makes the game more hilarious and enjoyable.This game is well worth playing. If you're willing to take it slow, learn the tricks, and trudge your way through, you'll discover a varied and wonderful-looking world with many excellent surprises, some of which throw you off a cliff.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												It is what it is, one of the best and most unforgiving RPG's there is, gameplay-wise.In my opinion though the STORY isn't all too great, don't get me wrong, the lore of the game is amazingly unique and magnificent, but I don't really feel the story of the main character, the Chosen Undead.You really have to get into this game to understand it, both regarding story and gameplay, but once you're in it, it's an amazing experience.It's awesome both co-op and single player. Although the game is meant to be played purely single player or co-op with strangers, I've played with one of my best friends (Trigger) practically the whole game except some little annoying or unimportant parts.If you like getting both your patience and skill pushed to its limits, this is the game for you.And if you like shaping your own character the way YOU want, in this game nothing is stopping you. You choose a main class at the beginning, determining your starting skillpoints and standard equip, but then you're free to do what you want.Example: I started off as the class Sorcerer. Theoretically, I would be blasting enemies away with spells called "Soul Arrows", but along the game I also put points into strength and dexterity, so now I also sometimes use a Falchion or a huge Dragonhunter Bow. Ever seen a mage use a bow that's too big to even hold? If you're into shaping your own character in an environment where you aren't sure if enemies will jump out of walls, THIS is THE game for you.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												10/10 would praise the sunFirst of all, you will die, there's no way around it and without help you will die a multitude of times. Yes, you will get mad. Yes, you will want to punch a hole through your screen. This is all on solo with no guides. I know because I used to feel the same ways. BUT when you do complete boss levels, certain goals and parts you were stuck on you tend to get such an amazing sense of accomplisment and relief, only then to die again of course. However, these things will not come easily so don't think they will, unlike other games, the storyline and objectives aren't handed to you on a silver plate; in fact you get roughly one decent hint about objectives in the game made by directors. The other hints all come from messages on the ground which means you'll have to trust in the "kindness" of other, be scrupulous don't trust messages as some are indeed trolls. The storyline is also immensely deep and you really have to search for clues, the reason it's not too clear is because the creators wanted each person to imagine it in their own way but there is a wiki which displays what the storylines main ideas are if you want to use that.Basically, yes I recommend this game and will continue to recommend this game. Forever. This is one of the only games that I enjoy replaying over and Over and OVER again not only on New Game+ but with new characters.Although, bear in mind, this game is far from perfect in the eyes of others. There are graphical fixes and online fixes if you want to play with your friends, here is the link...if you do this, follow the instructions CAREFULLY, when I did this I messed up STEP 3 as I editted the wrong file:http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/828935269278734403/Also, if you plan on using the keyboard I WISH YOU THE MOST LUCK as this was rushed for pc porting as the developers really only assumed it would be wanted on console so therefore made a crappy PC port, so to get the full experience use a controller and a gamepad. Good luck and PRAISE THE SUN!

												I've nominated this game for having stood the "Test of Time" award, and here's why.Even if the story goes all over your head because the activity of "dying" has distracted you. There's still that great feeling of victory over the game, and a victory of improving yourself as you advance. Yes it is difficult, and harsh at times... but the payoff of pushing forward is beautiful in so many ways.For all the beautiful places you'll visit, all the dreary stories you'll read, and the hardships you experience. This game has left me with memories I will likely never forget. And if you're willing to dive into reading the item descriptions, and the community discussions. You'll find there are some great stories hidden throughout the world, and everything's been placed and designed for a reason... and what a wet dream of a design this game is!

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Reviewing this game purely on it's merits as a game and not a PC port, it's fantastic, easily one of my favorite games of all time, possibly my favorite RPG of all time. With one of the best combat systems of any game, you make a mistake, you'll probably end up dying, it's extremely punishing and thus not for everyone but if you put in the time it's VERY rewarding.The world and level design is in my opinion unmatched in any RPG, there's all sorts of secrets to be found in the game by jumping from ledges and rolling onto different platforms to get to secret areas, the game is rife with secrets.The story is incredibly deep, complex and compelling but is told subtly in item descriptions, random observations around the world and NPC dialogue.PvP is great fun but likely will be laggy, it's entirely optional, as is CO-OP, some people love to play the game with friends, some love to solo it, I'm in the latter category but there is something here for everyone.The enemy design and voice acting are top notch, I honestly cannot say enough good things about this game, but I stress, if you do not enjoy a challenge (that's fine) then Dark Souls is likely not for you, oh, and the PC port is a barebones straight console port, but is easily fixed by using Durante's "DSFix" Mod.In my opinion, one of the greatest games ever made.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Dark Souls is definitely a game of great difficulty for a player who is not well prepared or familiar with the game. The game offers a very interesting storyline packed with lore and incredible detail as well as an addictive urge to come back for more. In all likelihood, most of your first playthrough of the game will be spent learning and questioning where you have gone wrong but usually its the simple mistakes the game tricks you into making.  Majority of the time will also be spent screaming and raging at the countless amount of deaths you'll be facing, as death is inevitable with this game (YOU DIED). Dark Souls becomes less difficult once you become familiar with the games concept, item locations and build combinations. Either way it will always provide you with a decent challenge so dont expect any less! The game was created as a masterpiece overall and it deserves all the praise and reputation it has. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who awaits a challenge, loves a story driven adventure and has the time to sink a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of hours into it!Dark Souls 1 in my opinion is the best of the the 3 due to its amazing lore, gameplay and the land of Lordran as its simply stunning. Also mentioning the amazing DLC which easily stands out as the best dlc of the franchise. Out of the 3 it is the game i can get to ng ++++ and still look forward to more and more gameplay. Bandai Namco should be proud of what they created because i know i am as well as thousands of others.   I give the game a 9.9 out of 10 for all reasons listed above, so dont hesitate to buy it! Oh and dont forget to always praise the sun!

content:
Posted: February 2
												Do I recommend this game? hell yeahDark Souls gave me lots of pleasure and very unique experience.At first I heard of this game on 9gag and decided to try. I played lots of RPGs and ARPGs. The last one I played was Skyrim. Oh boy, Dark Souls seemed to be very hard in comparison to Skyrim. I made a lot of mistakes and Dark Souls doesn't forgive them. The first character was ruined. With the second character I finished the game and it wasn't easy. But after playing DS3 I learned a bit more and now DS1 doesn't feel very difficult or unfair. Zero. You will need a gamepad, DSFix and other mods that you can find on nexus mods to make this purchase worthwhile on PC. The online isn't great nowadays, but if you manage to get some jolly cooperation, or get to invade or be invaded, you'll get some of this unique Souls experience. First of all you have to understand that Dark Souls is more a puzzle game, than simple hack and slash. You need to read every clue you can find about the world and mechanics, because nothing is explained. Forget anything you knew about ARPG games. And don't be afraid to die - this is part of the gameplay. The game is about perseverance and overcoming the obstacles. Second, understand the combat mechanics. This includes dodging, blocking, parrying and backstabbing. Also understand how weapon enhancement, ascension and stat scaling work - this is very important, because you need to level up your weapons as you level up your character.Third, understand how your stats work. Resistance is absolutely useless. Str and Agl don't give a lot of damage boost if your weapon is not upgraded, so at the beginning consider investing in HP and Endurance. Watch for your weight limit, armor defense properties and poise that defines if your attacks can be interrupted. Match your equipment to your enemies’ weakness. Fourth, don't sell or dispose your items, as a lot of them are hard to obtain and are available only once in a playthrough.And the last one. Don't rush. Observe your enemies, observe your surroundings, observe the world. The plot is pretty solid, but you will probably miss it, because you need to piece together a lot of things - the intro, the dialogs (which are in old English), the item descriptions, the location you find these items at and the design of the enemies. There are no definite answers, so you have to use your imagination.  If you finished reading this review, you are probably ready to take on this masterpiece. I envy you.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Game: Dark Souls: Prepare to Die EditionScore: 9/10Recommended? YESWorth a buy at full price? YESThis game is one of my all time favorites (and let's just say I've played hundreds of games).With punishing gameplay that gives you an adrenaline rush (I'm not kidding you) and a storyline so complicated most people don't even understand what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on, Dark Souls is the one of best games you can possibly play.Many consider it to be one of, if not, THE HARDEST game ever created for a reason. However, this game is by no means "unfair" (well... sort of... *cough* ornstein and smough *cough). When you die (and you WILL) it is entirely YOUR fault. You slowly learn how to play the game after a time, and when you win you will *literally* cry tears of joy.This game is not for everyone. If you lack patience and/or the ability to persevere, this game is NOT for you.Keep in mind: the PC port of the game is LOUSY... install a mod called "DSfix" to improve graphics and performance.Conclusion:Overall, 'tis the one of the best games money can buy. With a unique and difficult combat system that has you at the edge of your seat every minute of playtime, and a cryptic story so complex you'll want to look into it some more, Dark Souls is a masterpiece to be remembered by any player for many years to come.Score: 9/10Worth a buy at full price? YES

												Incredibly immersive and engaging with its ambience, atmosphere, and lore. Equipment is diverse; equipment mechanics are well-designed and highly customizable (minimal restrictions), where any equipment set is viable. Combat system is incredible and allows for diversity of playstyles and weapon combinations.This game rewards the player for playing smart, exploring and discovering all aspects of the game, and adapting to the environment, of which the level designs are well-thought-out and interesting to play through. Steep learning curve, but game difficulty is fair, challenging, and immensely rewarding once overcome.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I can't even begin to describe how good this game is, but, i'll try.Basically, it has everything a gamer could possibly want:-It's challenging to the point of frustration (which only makes winning more satisfying)-It has a large array of gear and loot to keep the collectors and completionists busy for a long while-It has a very in depth, delicate and extremely profound and complicated storyline and lore-Your character has a number of different attributes with a number of different combat paths to take-The combat system is one of the best i've seen in a long while, and while it is hard it is very fun to learn-Almost every weapon has its own unique fighting style-It has Co-op-It has PvP-It has Shops and NPC's and sub-plots of different characters woven into the main storyAll in all, this game is almost flawless. But be warned, the learning curve for the first 10 or so hours of gameplay can be unforgiving, so if you do intend on playing this game, make sure that you have cleared your calendar so you can get to the more enjoyable parts of the game. And if you get stuck, try to think outside the box, or just look it up. Some parts are so complex you can be left wondering how anyone ever figured them out at all. It's small wonder that this game was put in the top 20 games ever. I would recommend that everyone play at least the first 3 or 4 bosses of this game to get the true feel of it. It is utterly fantastic.Also, if you figure out how, SAVE SOLAIRE. He is a true bro.
