number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												This game comes with a laundry list of great features: an exceptionally well-built world (both in terms of level design and backstory), great controls (in a game where this is very important), good balancing, an enticing story that makes you feel both very important and very small at the same time, and some of the best sense of accomplishment you can get from a video game (which comes both from the gameplay and from finding the story, as much of it is not told directly to you but learned from inference). Also of note is the great soundtrack, which I occasionally still listen to outside of the game. Something that must be mentioned the reputation this game has for its difficulty...and it's somewhat deserved. For the first few hours you will likely struggle. The fun comes when you get the hang of it, understand that you're not superman (like you are in many games), and get that sense of accomplishment. Not for the faint of heart or someone looking for a game to breeze through, but totally worth the time investment needed to improve. This is one of the few games where killing the first area enemies still feels satisfying after many hours played (since they were so difficult when you first begin the game). If you enjoy action-RPGs, a sense of improvement and accomplishment, and games with fantastic story, worlds, mood, and music, or if you just enjoy a challenge, pick this up. No other game will ever feel quite the same as it did before you played Dark Souls.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												If you want to feel pain, anger, depression and sadness, you did the right thing in buying this game. You will die. No way you gonna survive this game with one life (some pros might). You get beaten to death, you fall, you get poised, you get cursed, you got burned to death and so on and so forth. There are so many ways you will die in this game you won't believe it. Nonetheless you will realize quick that dying is a part of this game like running and fighting. The good thing is that you as a player improve pretty quick. Not only because of the improving equipment you find but also because you improve as a player yourself. You learn how to dodge, when to parry, when to strike. I personally think that Dark Souls shows more than most other games how you improve and learn the game. This is a cool reward.The game has a few problems tho. Without a mod it has only 30 fps. The menus are clumsy and a gamepad is HIGHLY recommended because the Keyboard+Mouse controls are horrible. So you have been warned :)That few concerns aside the game offers a lot of fun. You choose from 4 different attacks. 2 for each hand. It depends what weaponry you have equipped. A heavy axe has a different attack style than a light sword.  The armors influence your speed and how far you can jump and also your dodging speed. The heavier armors really feel like a heavy armor. You can basically feel it on your character. Really well done. The saving system is automatic and if you rest on a bonfire. A bonfire offers regeneration of most effects. It also refills your health potions. So no need to buy one. You have only a certain amount of them but as soon as you rest on a bonfire you get new ones. Be warned tho. If you rest the enemies will respawn. If you die you will be respawn at the last bonfire rested on. As said above your only currency are souls. You earn them from defeating enemies and bosses. No matter if you want to level up your strength or buy arrows or weapons, you use souls. If you die it gets tense. You have to fight your way back to where you died. If you die on the way, every soul you collected and didn't spend for something is lost. That is a hard mechanic and can make you mad, but it is definitely a thrill to get back, especially if you have lost a huge amount of souls.The controls are good. You have to use a gamepad tho. They are pretty darn accurate. You have a lock on system which helps you fighting most enemies. Some huge bosses are better fought without it, especially the ones that fill the whole screen ;)The weaponry and armors are medieval like. Some enchantments here and there for weapons some magic. The basic stuff. A lot to test out and a lot of ways to replay the game.There are so many ways you can play. As a rogue or a flamethrowing knight. Everything is possible.The story is pretty confusing. You don't get that much background. Especially if you don#t listen or meet some characters. So you either listen closely or you check out the wiki on the internet. They are very well written and offer strategies for bosses if you really don't know how to beat them.Well, the bosses. They are great. A large variety. Each with unique moves and appearance. YOu need for each a different strategy, which makes the game even more challenging. The multiplayer is extensive. A big community of pvp players awaits you. Sadly you can't deactivate the pvp completely. So you can be invaded on certain occasions by people that might be way stronger than you and get killed. But those aren't the only ones. People can set markings in certain areas so you can summon them to help you fighting bosses or areas. This is a cool feature, but it is a shame that you can't really play it in singleplayer. Tip. Stay hollow. Nobody can invade you then. Only problem is you don't get some bonuses you would get as human. Well that is enough i guess. Hope you have a little idea what awaits you. I really enjoyed playing it. It was very challenging, but when you beat it. You feel like badass ;)

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Dark Souls is a game that doesn't hold your hand, and doesn't want you to want it to. It's a game you learn from experience(read trial and error), or you learn from the community.Myself? I mainly got it from the community. A couple of buddies and some wiki-ing made this game that was once an intimidating cliff into an invigorating hike through the hills. It's not a way to ruin the game, to get others to help you (be it through "how do I beat this boss?" or reading a wiki about how to find a certain crafting item); it's simply a different way to play it and enjoy it.This game has the most satisfying combat, one of the most compelling subtle worlds, some seriously cool loot, and an unconventional and interesting multiplayer system.It has it's negatives, certainly; the PC port was not good (DSFix is practically mandatory), Games for Windows Live is not a selling point, the camera can be temperamental, and when you're not progressing it can feel a bit hopeless. BUT; all these things are really a testament to how good the game is because despite all these flaws the game shines through - it's truly grossly incandescant.Bring on Dark Souls 2!

content:
Posted: September 20, 2013
												Let me start off by saying that Dark Souls isn't a game for everyone. It can be extremely hard and frustrating at times. Also, playing this game with a gamepad is STRONLY recommended. The PC controls are clunky and poorly optimized, and.. well let's just say that this game won't like that..  With that said, let's move on.Dark Souls is an open-world RPG, that won't hold your hand throughout the game like most games do these days (looking at you, Skyrim). The combat is fantastic, but can be complex at times. It's defenitely not the 2 button-mashing system that other games use. (Still looking..) The game will require your full attention, every single second. Losing your concentration will result in death 9 out of 10 times. But even if the game has your full concentration, there is a great chance that you'll die (especially on your first playthrough). But dying is normal in Dark Souls. Because dying will teach you a lesson. And that's what  Dark Souls is about. Trial and error. The first time you meet a boss and you die you'll think it was an unfair battle, you didn't know what to do. The second time though, you'll know better. And once you figure out you're own perfect strategy and you beat the boss, you'll be rewarded greatly by the game. And you'll feel fantastic. That's a feeling not many games can give you these days. So if you take some of your time to master this game, it will feel like a breath of fresh air. Just try it, if you dare.(Apologies for possible grammar mistakes, English isn't my main language)

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I simply cannot recommend this game enough.It's a refreshing take on the RPG genre. It doesn't hold your hand through anything. The story flows organically through dialog with no quest markers or logs - just the player and the world, which can be traversed from top to bottom.The difficulty is not artificial in any way; it is simply what you make of it. Learn the mechanics, master them and you will get the most satisfying gameplay experience you've had in a long time. Boss fights are just challenging enough to truly make you feel like you've earned the victory and make it that much sweeter when it comes.The multiplayer component is seamlessly weaved into the single player experience, something more and more games have been doing ever since Dark Souls proved it to be quite the viable mechanic. 10/10 would die again!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I remember when this game came out. I remember a lot of people discussing how difficult this game is. I don't remember much else talk as I didn't venture to the game's specific message boards. I shrugged this off. "Why buy a game simply because it's challenging? It can't really be that hard."As it turns out, this game can be quite challenging at times. For the most part, it gets gradually more difficult, allowing for one of the best learning curves I have seen in a game. At the beginning, I could hardly do anything except spam a basic attack or strong attack. By the time I reached the end of the game, I really felt like I had learned a lot about how to play this game better, and I do feel it has made me better at games. I ran into combat with confidence in my ability to outclass an opponent rather than achieving victory because of the enemy being weak. It definitely rejuvenated some of the patience I had lost due to the ease of, well, every other game I have played in years. These feelings were cemented in my mind as I began a second playthrough and laughably passed the first of the bosses that really tried me on my first adventure.Yes, this game can be pretty tough, but there is so much more to it than that.There isn't much dialogue like your typical RPG. Don't expect sequence after sequence of cutscenes. Each item has well-written descriptions along with it that help bring out lore in this world of Lordran. As you progress through the game, the few conversations with NPCs that are related to the story are quite informative despite their brief nature. This is fantastic. There are other NPCs not related to the main story that you meet multiple times throughout your adventure. This game can feel quite desolate and lonely much of the time. But when you meet these recurring NPCs, it fosters a feeling of safety and camaraderie. For such little dialogue, it's incredible how developed one of these characters in particular became.The environments do look dated, but they are crafted in such a way that they are still nice to look at while doing an exceptional job providing an atmosphere unique to the area and design.The combat has a surprising amount of depth by using different moves with different combinations of inputs on a controller or keyboard. Each weapon also creates for itself a unique play style which allows the player to play the game in drastically different manners between characters or, if skilled enough, on just one character.This truly is one of the best games I have played. If you have any interest in an RPG, I urge you to purchase this.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Dark Souls is a special game.  Like that one album that made radio hard to listen to, this game raised the bar for millions and created a hunger that, to date, only From Software has been able to satiate.I would encourage everyone to not be discouraged by the legends of its punishing difficulty.  While the learning curve is steep at first, once the player attains fluid control over their character they will enjoy one of the most satisfying combat systems in any game ever made.  The timing windows are somewhat tight, but there's a sublime feeling that comes with perfect dodging, parrying and riposting.  Once you learn the Soulsborne combat system, it can tough to go back to other games.The combat is just one facet of this gem of a game.  The world design is top-notch - there's a delicate sense of beauty to be found within the desolate and oppressive game world.  The level design (especially the first half of the game) is fantastic - not only are the environments varied but there are shortcuts to reward exploration.  Sound design and music are excellent and immersive.  The lore of the game is deep and interesting, but is only hinted at through various dialogues, item descriptions and corpse locations.  The DLC that's included with the PTDE is some of the best DLC ever released.  Both new areas are interesting and at least 3 of the best and most difficult boss fights are found there.This game gets my highest recommendation.

Posted: May 26, 2016
												Arguably the greatest game ever made, Dark Souls is atmospheric, complex and beautiful.Your story begins in an asylum where the undead are locked up, never to be seen again, to await the end of the world. That was the plan anyway, but a mysterious figure drops a key into your cage, allowing you to leave the asylum. This marks you as the chosen undead, fated to undertake a pilgrimage to Lordran, land of the ancient Lords.And Lordran is one of the best fantasy worlds ever represented in a video game. Once a magnificent kingdom ruled by gods, Lordran has been overrun by the undead. Yet it still retains its amazing variety, as your quest will take you to forests, swamps, castles, towns, blazing infernos and silent primordial lakes. Lordran's incredibly detailed verticality (indeed you are always travelling up or down) means that the game feels beautifully interconnected and coherent, as you seamlessly walk from one area to the next, uncovering shortcuts that connect to earlier and later locations along the way.Lordran is also a perilous place, and every single enemy is capable of killing you with ease if you're not being careful. In spite of this, the game seldom feels unfair: you lose all your stuff when you die, but if you get back to the place where you were killed - without dying again - you can get it back. This is to say nothing of the bosses. Dark Souls' legendary bosses are in many ways the souls of the areas they inhabit. Every boss fight (ok, Pinwheel excepted...) requires a careful study of the boss' movements and the arena where you're fighting to build up, over the course of many deaths, a strategy to take down the boss. And there are myriad strategies you could construct to take down any given obstacle, since the game mostly rewards all playstyles and equipment choices equally: it is very possible to beat the game using the very first weapon by upgrading it as you go along.All of this is backed up by a story and lore that are revealed slowly, and only when you go looking for them, in conversations with NPCs, description text for items, and the enemies and locations themselves. Nor is the lore ever revealed completely, so the game always feels compellingly shrouded in mystery.Brilliant, right?

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Dark Souls is an action RPG that originally came out on the PS3 back in 2011 and later ported to PC. In order to get the best experience out of it you'll need to get DSfix and use that (nexus mods has it or just google it). You'll also need a controller. Keyboard & Mouse controls are absolute garbage and even customizing them is worthless.  It's a game that's most famous for it's challenge, although fair, takes skill and trial & error to complete. There's many different playstyles to start from, Warrior, Pyromancer, Sorceror, Cleric etc. With all types of weapons ranging from swords, clubs, hammers, axes, spells, bows, crossbows and so on. As you progress in the game you will find bonfires that you can use to level up your character with souls collected from fallen foes. Bonfires are by far the most useful object in the game. They're needed to repair weapons & armor, store your items, level up and eventually fast travel. Everytime you use a bonfire though all the enemies (except bosses and important monsters) will respawn which means you'll have to plan your route and battle strategy accordingly since distance between bonfires can be quite far.It's not a game I'd call frustratingly hard but it is fair and will punish you for every mistake. Every encounter serves a purpose and the level design which at times can be a bit confusing but still brilliantly constructed to tie the world together is one of my favorite things about the game. The story isn't straightforward and the world building & lore is done mostly through reading item descriptions. If you head into a direction and the enemies totally destroy you, that's the game's way of telling you not to go that way yet.All in all, this game is one of my favorites. Get Dark Souls. Get good.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Beating the boss of the Tutorial is just as satisfying as beating the final boss.Game feels like an "Adventure and Exploration" type RPG. You explore and kill things to gain EXP and get better.~ Levelling system is entirely open and your "Class" is more just your starting stats and equipment. There are no restrictions on gear other than stats. (So, unlike in D&D, your Cleric can wield more than blunt weapons. [This statement was generalized for simplicity's sake.])~ Solid graphics and audio mesh well to create an immersive world.~ Combat system is solid ~ plenty of weapon styles and combat maneuvers with a fluid control system~ Co-op/pvp system is workable, I have few complaints other than an occassional case of lag-stabs and 1 in 20 encounters are with hackers~ Open world allows for you to choose which area to tackle next. Both a blessing and a curse, as new players can go down the "wrong" path (read: the 'less easy' path. reminds me of playing Ocarina of Time... But more depressing)~ Story is relatively straight-forward, but the world has a rich history that can be found in item descriptions and encounters with NPCs.~ Game is "difficult" but relatively scripted... Feels sort of like playing Super Mario... Things will kick your♥♥♥♥♥until you learn where things are and how they behave.~ Game /can/ be beaten without ever levelling up your character.9/10 ~ Would ragequit another thousand times.\|T|/

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												  I bought this game on my birthday (shortly after it's release) on a friends recommendation and I thought it was pretty cool not even knowing what I was about to embark upon.  I cautiously traversed through the "tutorial" level and yes still managed to die frequently still not knowing this is how it was meant to be.  After many deaths and hours later I started to get a feel for the game but still felt completely lost.  Not wanting to look things up, I wandered aimlessly searching for other ways to progress.  I can't remember too much after that but I do remember the rage and fury and swearing profusely at this game.  I stopped playing for about 3 months before my friend intervened and saved my joy.  Fast forward some time, the bosses are difficult, the terrain is difficult, hell even the mobs are difficult.  But learning how to overcome these challenges made this game my favorite game since it's release date and thereafter.   Frank GFX:          pretty good but smooth and awe inspiring with DSFix (and some other friendly mods)Sound:      the FX of weapons and misc things fit in well in the atmostphere and the music is elegantly composedControls:   natural with controller(360), M&K for those who like a challengeStory:        subtle and amazing (item descriptions helps)Difficulty:  Legendary for newcomers, challenging to say the leastReplay:      Yes because of new game plus and wanting to try new builds

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												So, I got into this game pretty late on, and when I say that, I mean that I got this game AFTER Dark Souls III came out. Dark Souls III was the game that spurred me into buying this game, and let me tell you, this has to be one of my favorite games out there. This is one of those games that I could pick up and play casually all over again. I love this game. Is it a♥♥♥♥♥♥port from console? Well, yes, but that's what the dsfix is for. Does the game cap you at about 40-45 frames and when you unlock the frames, there's a chance that it could make your frames even worse than it was to begin with? Yes. Is Co-Op literally impossible without a mod of the game? Yeah. This game is by no means perfect, no game really is. But, the combat feels fluid, the various characters are memorable and likeable, there's always something fun or stupid to try out in PvP, and (as we are all aware) Praise the Sun! This game is so flexible with the various styles of play, that anyone can really play it if they know what they want to do. I have played this game with multiple different builds and have had one hell of a time while doing so. Fast builds that don't hit that hard? Yeah, we've got that. Slow builds that hit like a truck? ♥♥♥♥ yeah, you can. Somewhere in the middle of those two? You want it? You got it. As long as you know how to micromanage, you will do fine in this game. I have put over 100 hours into a singleplayer/co-op game from playing it by myself to playing it with one of my best friends. This game was so much fun, and there wasn't many times where I could consider it boring. This game will forever be in my heart, and I look forward to playing Dark Souls III when I get a new graphics card (because it runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥right now, and Dark Souls II is not my favorite in the series by any means). The only complaint that I have is that the ending is slightly bland. I won't go into detail as to why because I don't want it to spoil it for anyone that hasn't yet completed the game. You'll just have to see for yourself. But, I digress; I would definitely recommend the game to anyone who is even remotely interesting in Dark Souls. It is definitely worth the $20.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Dark Souls is like a parent. When you do something wrong (fall off of a cliff, get ambushed, roll into a boss's attack, etc), you will be punished. However you aren't being punished because you are disliked or to discourage you, in fact quite the opposite. Dark Souls punishes you so that you will learn, so that you will grow. You will get better at the game, you will triumph, and you will have fought through the pain and the heartache to become a better player. Half of the game is PVE, half of the game is PVP. You don't have to interact with other players, but given the opportunity, you have different options on how you can. Help, or destroy. Give hope or terrorize. How you decide to be around other people is entirely in your hands.Also there's Blighttown. Google "♥♥♥♥ Blighttown."Buy the game.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												To put it simply, this is one of the worst ports I have ever seen. The developers literally took the X-Box version of the game, and slapped it onto PC. Hear me out, I like the game and brings an interesting challenge, but the problems created by this bad port outweigh any redeeming qualities.The fact that this edition is labeled 'Prepare To Die' should be taken quite seriously. You will die, but not because of the difficulty. I found it strange that they took the original version of the game, put on the label, and didn't bother to fix any issues.I can definitley recommend this game, but not this port. If you want to play, you need to go pick up the PS3 or 360 version rather than this abomination.Edit: After fiddling about with some community mods, the experience of this port has improved greatly. Both DS Fix and DS Mouse Fix work great together and fine tune some of the biggest issues. I'd also recommend some mods to upscale the graphics to be higher resolution but remain otherwise unchanged.Overall I now find this game for enjoyable, although a challenge. I would now recommend this game to any avid RPG fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												There really isn't a game like Dark Souls. It takes (mostly) melee combat and makes it its central piece. It's visceral, it requires careful timing and quick thinking from the player. Landing hits is oh so satisfying. Knowing when to block, dodge or attack is paramount, as a few, unforgiving (but often well-deserved) hits are all that separates the chosen undead from killing an enemy to having to restart from the checkpoint and risking losing all their souls (in-game currency), as they'll disappear from your death spot if you don't pick them up before dying again. Tension buildup is inevitable when you're exploring a new area or trying not to die to recover your 100000+ souls you dropped on your last death. This is the same reason why slaying bosses tastes so much sweeter than in any other game, since there's so much at stake. Multiplayer is also a strong component of the game, in which through diverse items and covenants you can invade (enter someone else’s game) another chosen undead and either help him get through an area and slay the boss or simply engage the invaded player and take his souls and humanity. Again, this plays very well into the whole tension-buildup setup the game goes for. No game is perfect, and Dark Souls does have a few issues: On the game side, the second half of the game (approximately) feels unfinished and rushed, with uninspired areas and bosses; the game’s leveling system lets players with high-end gear invade new players who are in the starting areas, which makes an unfair fight (but really, who hasn’t given in to becoming a level 1 darkwraith?). Technically, this is one of the worst console ports ever made, with locked in-game resolution and framerate (which can be solved with 3rd party patches like dsfix); and of course the networking code, invasions are based on a peer-to-peer system, so running into laggers is inevitable (that is if you manage to invade/get invaded in the first place, since Games For Windows Live does far more harm than good, requiring fiddling with router ports and more 3rd party patches like dscfix). At the end of the day, if you give the game and chance, it will “click” with you, and then you’ll become another victim from the dark curse, discussing and planning character builds and thinking why most other melee-focused combat games just don’t feel right anymore.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												(I'm largely going to skip the talk about GFWL (Games for Windows Live) and the required mods due to cruddy porting. Yes, GFWL is bad. Yes, it has just been replaced (Woo!). Yes, the porting is bad. Yes, it is entirely negligible with the DSfix and even made 100% playable with keyboard and mouse with DSmfix (setups which I'd be right happy to share.)I will probably have to start this review off by saying what everyone says; yes, this game is hard, and it will undoubtedly test you if you're new to the series.However, it will also reward you and your skill (or your exploring), over and over if you're willing to press on, not just with shiny items or souls, but also sometimes with breathtaking atmosphere, stunning landscape views (which in 99% of the cases, are places you'll end up later on, the level design is genius) and heaps of lore if you're into that sort of thing. Even I, who is 450 hours in, and now pushing for 100% completion, get well rewarded for some of the things I go through.Now, after all these hours, I know I can't say this game is completely flawless (aside from GFWL and port issues). I know the flaws. I've seen the flaws. I've talked to parts of the community about the flaws. But I did not see them the first playthrough, or the second, probably not before the third time or so, and honestly I'd say that's a lot better than most games still.I'd like to say that Dark Souls is a rather lonely experience and I'll suggest it should be played as such, at least the first playthrough. In my opinion this contributes to making some of the encounters more atmospheric, more lively, more depressive.As a last word, I wholeheartedly recommend this game, for there are few like it, and hopefully someone dare take the step to try it and falls as much in love with it as I have.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												Dark Souls is what more games would be if the industry didn't try so hard to mimic Hollywood. It's what games used to be: challenging, creative, and most importantly; it unobtrusively tells a story about you, the player. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												This is a tricky one to review because the game is simultaneously excellent and terrible.  So let's start with the bad:- It's obtuse.  Fans will claim it's just deep or something you have to learn, but it's not true, the initial learning curve and player training is very poorly handled and will have driven off a lot of new players.- The story.  I have no idea what it was all about, who I was, where I was, what I was doing, or why everyone kept talking in the very, very worst of thee-thou-thine speak.- The voicework is terrible.  Like am-dram into a tape-recorder terrible.- The PC port.  It's perfectly stable and runs fine, but sadly they put the bare minimum effort in and you're stuck using a controller.  With proper mouse control they could have got rid of the locking-on nonsense and with proper keyboard control you could have hotkeyed multiple spells.- There's a few very badly tuned fights where you'll die a lot through no fault of your own.And now the good:- It's challenging in a satisfying way.  It's like an anti-button-masher in that almost every enemy poses a danger if you're not paying attention and instead of elaborate combo attacks you never use, you just have a few basic abilities and it's all about using them at the right time in the right way.- The story.  I know this was also in the Bad List, but one aspect of the story that is good is how it's presented.  A lot of CRPGs force you to sit through page after page after page of turgid dialogue of fan-fic quality fantasy twaddle instead of using the medium they're in to SHOW me the story.  Dark Souls lets you experience the story, it doesn't tell you it.- The world and the art.  It's pretty enough, but most of all it's inventive and some of the locations and monsters are hugely imaginative.  There's more creativity here than in a thousand tedious Dragon Age games.- The mimic chests are excellent.  Right out of a Tim Burton movie.

												This is the kind of game you love to hate.This is probably one of my favorite games of all time, and yet whenever I stop to think about it, I realize that I absolutely hate playing through at least three quarters of it. There are areas in the game I simply loathe. And yet, I can't stop playing this. Dark Souls hooks you in and when you're in, there's no going out. Once your soul goes Dark it never goes back.That being said, a good controller and a ton of patience are required. It is possible to go through without either, but why would you? The game is designed for controller, so play it on controller. And the game is designed through trial and error, so be patient. Anyone can beat it if they try hard enough. Just don't give up and praise the sun! \[T]/

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Dark Souls is a special game.  Like that one album that made radio hard to listen to, this game raised the bar for millions and created a hunger that, to date, only From Software has been able to satiate.I would encourage everyone to not be discouraged by the legends of its punishing difficulty.  While the learning curve is steep at first, once the player attains fluid control over their character they will enjoy one of the most satisfying combat systems in any game ever made.  The timing windows are somewhat tight, but there's a sublime feeling that comes with perfect dodging, parrying and riposting.  Once you learn the Soulsborne combat system, it can tough to go back to other games.The combat is just one facet of this gem of a game.  The world design is top-notch - there's a delicate sense of beauty to be found within the desolate and oppressive game world.  The level design (especially the first half of the game) is fantastic - not only are the environments varied but there are shortcuts to reward exploration.  Sound design and music are excellent and immersive.  The lore of the game is deep and interesting, but is only hinted at through various dialogues, item descriptions and corpse locations.  The DLC that's included with the PTDE is some of the best DLC ever released.  Both new areas are interesting and at least 3 of the best and most difficult boss fights are found there.This game gets my highest recommendation.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												What can I say that hasn't already been said?  I love this game, but...Dark Souls requires patience.The game requires caution when confronting enemies, practice when learning the controls, reckless exploration when learning the world, and careful consideration when learning (yes, learning) the story.  There is absolutely no hand holding.There are no objectives.  There are barely even any NPCs saying, "You should go this way, hint hint."  When you start, you just broke out of prison and a giant crow drops you off in front of a dude that says you should go ring some bells.  He mentions two, which is actually the game's third cruel joke on the player.  If you don't know where to go, the only way to learn is to visit places that you should not, get killed instantly, and wonder if you'll ever be able to go there again.  This is why so many people visit the graveyard, get slashed to pieces, and quit the game forever.But honestly, once you figure out the correct direction (up), the game is actually kind of forgiving in it's own way.  You're slowly introduced to the easiest mobs in the game, and every new encounter introduces you to a new mechanic.  By the end of the Undead Burg, you've almost seen every attack strategy in the game.  This a great time to learn how to step back and find openings.But I digress.  This is also indicative of one of the major issues with Dark Souls.  Too much energy has been spent by folks explaining the first part of the game because it's a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  The lack of guidance is *so* unforgiving that the internet has had to fight to get people not to quit right away.  "No, seriously.  The game is awesome.  Just stick with it!  Please!  What are you doing?  Stop beating me with your controller!"Yes, we've all heard the same thing.  "Once you improve at the game, you'll see it for how beautiful it is!"Though this is true, I totally understand why people quit, and I think it ultimately is a subtle but crippling design flaw.  Yes, the game attempts to prepare you for its difficulty but it also intentionally disregards the player's likely prior experience with third-person action games.We don't only expect to be able to hack and slash at enemies, we expect that when we do, we will lock to the enemy.  Then, we can hit the same button (usually a thumb button) over and over again until we've exhausted our animations.  Not only that, but we expect to be relatively invincible during this flurry.  Then we can dodge, right?  All over the place!  Run from here to there; make sure that we can't be hit.  Healing?  That should be instant.  At the very least, it should stop the rest of the game until it completes.Nope.I believe the game could have been greatly improved if it would have put a little bit more content in that was intended to help the player unlearn bad habits from previous game mechanics.  Players should go into this game knowing that movement and combat are extremely precise and deliberate.  Precise.  Collisions are as they appear.  If you swing your sword and it diagonally misses the left ear of the skeleton you're fighting:  Sorry, no, you didn't actually hit it.  Prepare for punishment.But oh well.  It was awesome once I got it down.  I'm on my third play through.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Arguably the greatest game ever made, Dark Souls is atmospheric, complex and beautiful.Your story begins in an asylum where the undead are locked up, never to be seen again, to await the end of the world. That was the plan anyway, but a mysterious figure drops a key into your cage, allowing you to leave the asylum. This marks you as the chosen undead, fated to undertake a pilgrimage to Lordran, land of the ancient Lords.And Lordran is one of the best fantasy worlds ever represented in a video game. Once a magnificent kingdom ruled by gods, Lordran has been overrun by the undead. Yet it still retains its amazing variety, as your quest will take you to forests, swamps, castles, towns, blazing infernos and silent primordial lakes. Lordran's incredibly detailed verticality (indeed you are always travelling up or down) means that the game feels beautifully interconnected and coherent, as you seamlessly walk from one area to the next, uncovering shortcuts that connect to earlier and later locations along the way.Lordran is also a perilous place, and every single enemy is capable of killing you with ease if you're not being careful. In spite of this, the game seldom feels unfair: you lose all your stuff when you die, but if you get back to the place where you were killed - without dying again - you can get it back. This is to say nothing of the bosses. Dark Souls' legendary bosses are in many ways the souls of the areas they inhabit. Every boss fight (ok, Pinwheel excepted...) requires a careful study of the boss' movements and the arena where you're fighting to build up, over the course of many deaths, a strategy to take down the boss. And there are myriad strategies you could construct to take down any given obstacle, since the game mostly rewards all playstyles and equipment choices equally: it is very possible to beat the game using the very first weapon by upgrading it as you go along.All of this is backed up by a story and lore that are revealed slowly, and only when you go looking for them, in conversations with NPCs, description text for items, and the enemies and locations themselves. Nor is the lore ever revealed completely, so the game always feels compellingly shrouded in mystery.Brilliant, right?

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Product received for free
												Its more fair than real life.Seriously tho. If you find modern day AAA games to be a cakewalk at default and padded with artificial difficulty at higher levels (bullet sponges, 2 hit kills.... you name it) then you will like this game. It doesnt BS you with some fake difficulty and catapults you into the game world whose history you will likely not understand until NG+2.GameplayDont get the wrong impression and run away now though. The actual PvE combat mechanics is very well balanced. The mobs will die few whacks and so will you. So once you learn the mechanics and patterns of the enemies. The game becomes considerably easier to manage and you'll likely not die at all provided you're careful.The area can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥to navigate and there's hidden nooks and crannies(ph4tloots included) everywhere.So its a nightmare for the forgetful gamer. Getting lost mid-map is mandatory. You might wanna skip to a guide if you dont really have the time. I cant say much about the PVP but be prepared to face laggers and cheap strat "meta" no lifers taunt-after-every-killers. The connection is P2P. Theres no dedicated server. (more lag yaayyyyy)[PC Port troubles]What can I say? This is a console game ported to PC by popular demand so the interface sucks big goblin donger and gets crammy really quick. The default mouse+kb control is unusable(mod fix) If you want to play at 60fps 1080p you will also need to dl a mod.In the end you will get frustrated. You will forget that frustration once you rekt that a-hole boss after 10 deaths. You will get frustrated again...etc...But is the feeling at the end worth? DefinitelyPraise/10

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												You will die, repeatedly, and then some. The game never tells you where to go, what to do or how you should do something. This is simply leant by your death, over and over. Everything seems like an achievement from finding a new area, a hidden item or learning how to upgrade your weapon. Dying warrants the respawn of mostly everything you’ve just painstakingly killed. The combat mechanics can be cumbersome at times. You can kill the NPCs...permanently. This game is not perfect by any means, but it is simply one of the best games you will ever play. Every complexity\difficulty\flaw somehow seems to add a characteristic you will learn to love. The game becomes manageable only by your improvement as a player and not by the game getting any easier. This is truly an amazing game, one of the best ever made.

												Pre-review note: I have actually beaten Dark Souls but only on the PS3Pros:- A good RPG system that reflects your fight style- Strategy is definitely needed when fighting groups or boss fights- Summoning AI when offline- Saving AI actually benefits you very well- Fantastic story- online community is really good, perhaps the best Ive ever seenCons:- Glitches in combat such as enemies being able to attack through structures- Online invasions can be really cheap sometimesOver all amazing game and its one of my favorite series. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Ah.. Dark Souls.. You have given me my highest and lowest times in my gaming history. With every moment of joy, you will punish me in ways I never knew could happen. After finally killing that boss.. to being pushed off a cliff by a weak hollow.You will get angry, you will die but you will push on.Dark Souls drops you off into a strange land with very little to go on and sends you on your way. The open world allows you to wander into areas far beyond your skill but as you master the game these areas will allow you to choose how you tackle the start of the game in new and challenging ways.The depth of the story is a bit hard to take in on your first few playthroughs but as you listen more and more you will start to see the world unfold before you.The npcs add a nice and manic flare to the atmosphere, often mocking you or giving you vague information on what you could be doing next. They don't treat you like a hero, you are just some other hollow, passing through, like the rest of them.The amount of gear you can aquire allows for very unique character development and style choice  Meta aside , making it so no 2 characters are the same.This is one of the best games I have ever played and I would recommend it to anyone who is willing to take a hit to their ego.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												Mechanics: Mysterious at first but once you figure them out you can become unstopable. Parrying and backstabs are essential to success but it felt like you needed to rely to much on them. The combat is fluid, the difficulty is good, and the areas are amazing.Story: It's story isn't clear yet it is amazing. The game tells you the premise and reason you are there and then lets you piece the rest out by your self. You will find characters that you will learn to love and help or learn to destroy and kill.Pacing: First you have your typical tutorial level but it isn't as easy as most tutorials. After that you are left in an open world and told to ring 2 bells. 1 above and another below. It's your decision to which to ring first though many chose the top side. After finding secrets, obtaining weapons, and hacking away at enemys you are met with a new boss to over come. Whether it be a demon or animal, you shall overcome it.Summary: The game is with flaws but they don't detract for what you will be expirencing. You shall face the invicible and the strong but they will not stop you from fulfilling your destiny. Just don't go hollow...PvP: I left this for last because it's extremly diffrent. In human form you may summon and get invaded by people. Being human gives you no real buffs except for summons. Having humanity in your counter though can give you some buffs like loot drop chance and curse resistance. Being human is both bad and good. You can get invaded by people 10+ of your level and some below your level. Some area, like the forest, have none to little PvP restrictions, so a 150 SL and invade a 120 SL. Covenants exist to enhance the PvP like the darkmoons (Police), Darkwraith (Hunter of humanity), Gravelords (MESS YOU UPers), and Forest Hunters (Guardians of the forest). What you use in PvE is used in PvP but some weapons are better for one or the other. When it comes to weapons it's really just what you like and succeed with. The PvP is fun and fast paced but has some problems with lag and gankers (People who summon 2 people who all gang up on an invader). You will occasionally encounter some of these problems but they are few and far between.9/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2012
												Difficulty is not to be the major point of this game, for it is unjust to see it as only that.Dark Souls is a lore-driven set piece, new to the addition of the Souls series, without major additions, save for gameplay variables and community accumulation to where popularity is at an all time high.The story is well written, but the majority of NPC's greatly drive force from Demon's Souls, to where they're even a direct copy set in a new reality, as it is. However well the backstory is for them, and how enjoyable it is to see their reactions upon your actions, much of the lore is told throughout item descriptions, which is primarily shoe-horned in, save for a quick explanation of nothing more than, "You had a history before the Asylum!"The game is great, and the graphical department impresses me even to this day, but it is clearly blantantly copying what has gotten them far with Demon's Souls, with putting forth something else simply because.That does not make it less enjoyable, however. The gameplay still makes me have fun, throughout all the circumstances that I've gone through, and overall, I find myself coming back to it, again and again. If you wish to buy this game and haven't played Demon's, then by all means. You shall have a fresh experience, one which I hope you enjoy. Welcome to Dark Souls, for losing is fun here.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2013
												Let me start off by saying that Dark Souls isn't a game for everyone. It can be extremely hard and frustrating at times. Also, playing this game with a gamepad is STRONLY recommended. The PC controls are clunky and poorly optimized, and.. well let's just say that this game won't like that..  With that said, let's move on.Dark Souls is an open-world RPG, that won't hold your hand throughout the game like most games do these days (looking at you, Skyrim). The combat is fantastic, but can be complex at times. It's defenitely not the 2 button-mashing system that other games use. (Still looking..) The game will require your full attention, every single second. Losing your concentration will result in death 9 out of 10 times. But even if the game has your full concentration, there is a great chance that you'll die (especially on your first playthrough). But dying is normal in Dark Souls. Because dying will teach you a lesson. And that's what  Dark Souls is about. Trial and error. The first time you meet a boss and you die you'll think it was an unfair battle, you didn't know what to do. The second time though, you'll know better. And once you figure out you're own perfect strategy and you beat the boss, you'll be rewarded greatly by the game. And you'll feel fantastic. That's a feeling not many games can give you these days. So if you take some of your time to master this game, it will feel like a breath of fresh air. Just try it, if you dare.(Apologies for possible grammar mistakes, English isn't my main language)

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Dark Souls is a game that doesn't hold your hand, and doesn't want you to want it to. It's a game you learn from experience(read trial and error), or you learn from the community.Myself? I mainly got it from the community. A couple of buddies and some wiki-ing made this game that was once an intimidating cliff into an invigorating hike through the hills. It's not a way to ruin the game, to get others to help you (be it through "how do I beat this boss?" or reading a wiki about how to find a certain crafting item); it's simply a different way to play it and enjoy it.This game has the most satisfying combat, one of the most compelling subtle worlds, some seriously cool loot, and an unconventional and interesting multiplayer system.It has it's negatives, certainly; the PC port was not good (DSFix is practically mandatory), Games for Windows Live is not a selling point, the camera can be temperamental, and when you're not progressing it can feel a bit hopeless. BUT; all these things are really a testament to how good the game is because despite all these flaws the game shines through - it's truly grossly incandescant.Bring on Dark Souls 2!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												You will play this game and you will hate it. You will call it clumsy and unfair and rage quit at the first possible opportunity, but then you'll decide to pick it back up and try again. Why? Because you don't want the game to have the last laugh, and that drive pushes you through hell and back while you slowly improve.It's got solid combat that can best be described, as cliche as it sounds, tough but fair. It rewards patience, knowledge of your weapon and enemies, and skill. Once you understand how everything works the combat is a lot of fun. On top of that you have a lot of options in terms of builds and playstyle, and while some are better than others you have a lot of flexibility to be viable.Once you've gotten past the difficulty of the game you begin to rage less and really enjoy yourself. You start to really appreciate the world, level design, NPCs, and subtle story that makes Lordran so captivating to explore time and time again. Don't give up on this game so easily, it's one of the most rewarding experiences I've ever had in a video game.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												A modern day masterpiece.Im not new to the series having previously done everything possible in Demon Souls....I'd went several NG+ deep, held every weapon, reached well in excess of SL250 and farmed souls to the point where losing 4 million souls meant absolutely nothing, all as part of a 15-20 hour search just for the ever elusive Pure Bladestone. Dark Souls does everything Demon Souls did but on a grander scale. The nexus is a thing of the past with more traditional progression through the area making it feel more like a world than a series of selectable areas / levels. There's a heavy covenant theme throughout the game, many are easily missable as there well off the beaten track. There are NPCs which will sporadically pop up during your playthrough provided you fulfill very specific conditions and for the most part meet them at a set point during progression through the game.What is retained is the outstanding sense of atmosphere. Blighttown & The Depths are Dark Souls equivalent of the Valley of Defilement from Demon Souls, an area where early game you'll spend most of your time either poisoned, toxic, cursed or all three. Tomb of the Giants with its almost complete darkness hiding oversized skeletons up until the point where they attack, Darkroot Basin & Darkroot Garden with Alvina the Forest Covenant leader looking like a nod to something from Alice in Wonderland. The Crystal Cave, Demon Ruins, Lost Izalith, The Catacombs, The Painted World of Ariamis, Anor Londo....there all fantastic, so unique and defined in the game world with completely unforgettable mini bosses / bosses.The gameplay mechanics are generally as was in Demon Souls, load created by equipped items and stamina / strength stats still play a huge part, go over 50% and you fat roll, go even higher and your character will just squirm on the spot when you tap roll, mobility as before is key. If you can get to them the game throws high level armour sets and weapons at you very early on, there so high though you're unable to use them effectively. During my initial playthrough I fealt like I barely scratched the game, I used several weapons out of more than likely 50+ which reside in my inventory, used 3 or 4 armour sets, used 3 or 4 rings predominantly chosen specifically for boss fights or locations. I believe I used one spell out of a vast amount, that being Iron Flesh to tank the Sanctuary Garden boss - the scope to play the game in your own way is almost overwhelming.To touch on the multiplayer, its still active, people still drop the old troll signs telling you to jump off cliff faces to fantastic treasure etc, for the best example of how unique the multiplayer is googling "Dark Souls The Wall" leaves nothing to the imagination.Very few games nowadays keep me compelled to the point where I can't put them down, Dark Souls is one of them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Dark Souls is widly known as a game that causes undying rage in many of its players as well as being an awful pc port. These may be true, however there are allot of things that the people who dont play it because of this lose out on. Dark Souls is an incredible game overall. The story is amazingly deep and with all of the lore that exists in the game, it creates a world that you truly feel has existed long before you came around and long after you leave. Every character that you see on screen and even allot that you don't see on screen. All have huge impacts on the world around you and allot of people overlook this because of the games dificulty. For example you could find a body with some armor on it and not think twice. But if you look into it more you may find that the person who's armor it was had a huge impact on where you are and where the world is now and you had the misfortune/fortune to run into their grave.The gameplay itself works smoothly enough though a controller is strongly reccommended because of the pc ported controls being bad and not well explained. Most all of the movements in the game are very smooth, everything from parries to backstabs are all pleasing to the eye as well as very satisfying when you land them. You will die allot in this game, thats a given and something even mentioned in the title "Prepare to Die". But the greatest part of this game and why I personally find the dieing acceptable is because of the sense of acomplisment you get when you succeed. Killing a boss in this game is more than something you can just shrug off, its a huge acomplisment to kill a boss after dieing to it ten times before. To finally see on the screen "Boss Defeated" is a huge thing and can bring giant smiles and cheers to some. The sheer acomplisment alone makes this game worth while. The entire way you craft your character is very different to normal rpg's. You start with the regular builds, but as you go through the game your able to work towards whatever you want. You can start out a mage and end as a tank with the heaviest weapons and armor in the game if you'd like. This "Class system" makes gameplay allot different from other rpg's. Even better in my opinion is the opressive feeling you get when you have allot of souls (The ingame xp and currency) and are walking back to a bonfire, anything can happen and it gives you a very nervous feeling because you just killed a boss to get all of these and you dont want to lose them to a small enemy before you get to use them. So the atmosphere can change rapidly, and because of the soul system allot of people get turned off because that is what is rage inducing about the game. But getting past it makes you feel like you have truly acomplished something.As far as multiplayer however this game comes up a little short. The ability to see other people as translucient phantoms is amazing, getting to see the blood stains of other players in real time and seeing how they died is great. Or even sitting at a bonfire and seeing someone else sitting with you is good because it all makes you feel much less alone and lets you know others are going through what you are too. As far as the match making system for the party and invasions system is concerned however is another story. If you were hoping to co-op with a friend in this game, you will have a rough time. The game uses a peer to peer match making system which is a little flawed because of the time it can take for you to see a friends summon sign. Even more annoying can be the invasion system which allows others to invade your world when you are a human and slay you for your souls and humanity. Because you need to be human to summon others into your world for the boss fights, this can clash against the invasion system and allot of the time you will get invaded before you can even see your friends summon sign to bring them to your world.Overall this game is extremely well thought out in lore, setting a perfectly dark tone which suits the game and the atmosphere. The way the game has you interacting with other players is creative and inovative but the co-op aspect is slightly lacking. The Third Person RPG style gameplay is amazing and will keep you coming back for more every time along with the amazing boss fights (Save for 2 of them) that make you feel great when you finally defeat them. This is an amazing game which allot of people pass up for fear of its reputation as either a bad port or as a terribly difficult game. But, id reccomend this game to anyone who likes dark and very deep story lines, the very strong gameplay and "Class system" or lack there of and who want a little more challenge than the average game. Personally I give dark souls a 10/10 but that could be just me.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Generally, I play games on normal difficulty. Sometimes I drop it down to easy, because I'm a filthy casual. I didn't think I'd enjoy this game but I haven't been able to stop thinking about it since I started.The world is beautiful (once you get DSfix) in a run down way. It starts out with fairly typical undead ruins but gets weirder from there. The lore is largely unspoken, it is relayed through descriptions on items and how the world works. This is similar to the database in the first Mass Effect and I love it here just as much.The gameplay is tough. My first learning experience was near the start of the game. I had amassed a sizable amount of Humanity (a resource used in the game for various things) and because it increases item find I thought it'd be good to use it all. This means that I could lose it if I died, but I figured I'd have no problem getting to my bloodstain (which restores your lost Humanity and Souls). Then I met the first boss. He killed me. A lot. And then I died on the way back before I could get my bloodstain. All those Souls and Humanity - gone. I got mad. I stopped playing for the night. But I came back with an altered mindset: the only thing you lose by dying is whatever you choose to risk. Once I got into that mindset death doesn't bother me as much, although I am still cautious. I can see the effects of getting better at the game mechanics. I can see the benefit of my improved arms and armor. I "broke through the wall".It was worth it.

content:
Posted: April 6
												This game took me 90 hours to get into. It was mostly false starts before my brain got distracted, which it often does. That said; started replaying this a few weeks ago, and something just clicked. All the prior trial and error attempts had sunk much of the gameplay into my brain; where early items were, what to do in general. It all was ingrained somewhere along the way and this time around, I found myself able to dive in.There is a great deal to take in for this game, and honestly without a lot of help from a good friend and some very detailed wikis (which I only look up after roughly...5 failed attempts at a spot), not sure I'd get as far as I have.  Much of the legendary difficulty of this game is learning about...well, everything. What makes pyromancy different from sorcery, what it means to "fat roll", what damage type is good against which enemy, ect. These are things that have to be beaten into you. And once that all settles, or you know how to figure it out; it just becomes being able to make it through the other side of the battle. The only thing that will stop you, it seems, is you.The online scene at this point seems to have simmered down to a mostly good natured lot; from my experiances anyways. I got invaded at one point, the person and I bowed and then they threw lightening spears in my face. Good fight. And then I ended up summoning them to help with Orenstien and Smough. One of those experiences that I can't say I'd get from any other game. So if you've been on the fence about this franchise, please at least give it a try if you see it on sale. It may take time for it to click, it may frustrate the hell out of you for a while. But when it does click, when you begin to see how it works, you'll be rewarded with one of the richest and fulfilling gaming experiances in recent memory.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This game.Let me tell you some things.First of all, yes it is challenging (especially at first), yes it will make you rage at times (more often than not) and yes you probably will die (quite often). As it says on the tin: Prepare To Die. Even if you really don't want to :)Now you may ask, "But why would I want to play a rage-inducing, unforgiving game like this?". Simple. Again and again, it washes away the tears, sweat and pain that you accumulate on your treacherous journey and delivers an incredible experience through a combination of incredible surroundings, enemy designs and a highly rewarding gameplay.Honestly, this game looks absolutely beautiful. I have found myself exploring areas for hours while discovering the odd treasure or secret pathway. The scenery has a great amount of detail and looking towards the horizon from an elevated position will always be incredible in this game. The only loading screens that you will ever see will be mostly the ones after you die, the others cut-scenes while moving to different worlds or encountering a boss. Most of the areas are seamlessly connected and really give out the feeling of an open world.Dark Souls' gameplay is very satisfying and rewarding. The feeling you get when you do your first backstab, your first parry, finally killing that boss that mocked you for hours on end, etc... There is a real sense of accomplishment in this game. Every fight can cost you your life, and if you get too careless doing crazy rolls you might just accidentally end up diving off of a cliff. Then comes the facepalm, the mourning of your lost souls and the quest to get back to the place where they were dropped, swearing that you won't die stupidly like that again... again.The only background music you'll find is during boss fights. That doesn't mean there isn't any background noise. The atmosphere and ambient sounds clearly change with your surroundings, from cursed underground cities to sunny ruins. You are deeply immersed in whichever location you find yourself in, allowing you to hear every movement around you. The music while fighting a boss contributes to the intensity of the moment, filling you with epic despair as you try to maintain your focus.NPC characters will prove to be few and invaluable, although their lives will always be in your hands. Kill them and they are gone until you get to new game+. Your choices in who you help and who you kill or betray will have an impact on your progression, which items/spells will be available to you, who will help you out in times of need and who will turn on you. These are all people with their own story, fighting for a cause... or not. Just like you. So what will you do?The leveling system is different from most RPGs. You basically upgrade your character's stats with the souls that you amass, which are also used as currency for items and upgrading your equipment. Upgrading strength enough for example will allow you to wield heavy weapons such as great-swords while intelligence will make you able to cast a wide range of powerful sorceries.The story has a lot of depth, though that may not be apparent at first as it leaves much to speculation, blurring the lines between good and evil in this world and who is right or wrong. There is a great amount of lore in this game and the NPCs stories will often intertwine with eachother and your own. I would highly recommend reading about the story and lore of the Dark Souls universe if you get into it, otherwise you are missing out on some amazing stuff and theories that will blow your mind.I don't want to spoil any of this amazing game, so let's go on to the technical aspects:As the notice says, I would recommend using a controller while playing Dark Souls. It was made for consoles only initially and we all know the PC port was rushed. The resolution on PC is only 32bit. Aside from that, having a friend join you for some jolly co-operation is great fun.All in all, this is probably one of my favourite games of all time and I eagerly await more from the Dark Souls series. 10/10 would die again. And again. And again.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												"I was given HIV at a young age due to rampant child prostitution in my native country. Thankfully, I was able to escape, and have since lived out my day-to-day life in poverty in the slums of Hoboken, NJ, barely able to afford my AIDS treatment. However, one day, while perusing this website at my local internet cafe (they luckily accept government cheese as payment) I happened across Dark Souls. The cover, bearing an American flag and a zesty-looking cheeseburger piqued my interest immediately, partially due to the fact that I hadn't eaten in days. I purchased the game using a stolen credit card I found in a fat man's asscrack, and began to play.Almost instantly, I felt my cavernous ♥♥♥♥♥♥ begin to tighten--the open sores on my face and neck ruptured and healed almost instantly. I was transformed into a gorgeous, curvaceous woman--my breasts growing to double the size they were before. From Software's brilliant storytelling and stunningly accurate political commentary not only cured my AIDS, it cured my soul. Now I'm dating a man with a♥♥♥♥♥♥the size of an aircraft carrier, who owns several yachts and a mariachi band. Life is good, and I have this game to thank.So, Miyazaki, if you can read this from your throne amongst the gods, I'd like to offer you my sincere gratitude. Let this glowing review remain on Steam eternally, a undying testament to this game's infinite glory. Thank you." - Jeff.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E17 Dark Souls 

			Views: 101		

			The dark fantasy world of Dark Souls is rich with intriguing lore and atmosphere, if you can make it past the unique take on controls and take a special interest in learning the game and its...		

Dark Souls: Dark Souls is like that date that went decently well, maybe you said some dumb things but, you felt pretty good about the date overall. Then the date ignores you outright and, never returns your calls. Do you stop pursuing altogether or, make a more concentrated effort and maybe change up your game to try and score another date, maybe, a better one. Dark Souls is the game series that is infamous for its unforgiving gameplay and dark setting with the main point being you dying over, and over, and over. A refreshing take on the action roleplaying formula, dark souls is a unique mix of role-playing, exploration and anger management. Told next to nothing about practically anything, you are dropped in the world of dark souls, given a brief tutorial on the controls and expected to march forth and succeed. There is something to be said for gameplay over story and Dark Souls definitely capitalizes on the gameplay and mechanic aspect and fails badly at the story aspect. Dark Souls’ combat mechanics is simple to grasp but has a hidden layer of depth and strategy that you learn all on your own. Combining magic, different armors, weapons and so forth you will easily come up with a variety of different builds of characters that all are fully capable of succeeding in the world of Dark Souls. Gameplay and the combat mechanics as well as a superb level design makes learning Dark Souls the challenge it has been cracked up to be but, one that is fair and rewarding. The lore and atmosphere is also worth noting and it makes exploring this world a treat and getting further into the game very rewarding. The main games fault is its vagueness; Instead of igniting mystery and intrigue it often leaves you with more questions to ask than answer and when the game fails to mention basic game mechanics (such as jumping) there is something to be said for being a challenge and just flat out not telling you anything. Unfortunately, a lot can be gleaned it great detail from the awesome wiki sites, however, video games shouldn’t rely on the fan wikis to tell you critical information. Overall, Dark Souls is a challenge, one I find to be harsh at times but, fair and always part of the overall experience. The PC port is pretty awful, don’t buy the game without having a controller on hand to use or you will suffer the wrath of terrible key binding, limited video and audio options and much more. Also the vagueness of basic game mechanics as well as background and story can also lead to frustration and can be hard to find reason to continue on when you are unsure of why you are even there in the first place. However, if you are remotely intrigued by Dark Souls and are up for a challenge then it is easily worth the $20.00 USD. Keep your convictions strong and with a little bit of patience and determination you too can join the ranks of the Dark Souls. -Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												I believe that this game tries to aspire to be an "Nintendo Hard" game; a game with a learning curve that will punish the player until they 'learn' how the game, locations, and bosses funcion. Due to this, it turns off many people who arn't familiar with the 'souls-borne' series of games. This game isn't going to hold your hand, it's not going to be nice to you, it will kick you in the face as hard as it can and you will learn to dodge that kick given time. The very nature of dark souls is to teach the player how to compleate a task without really ever directly telling them how to do said task; Every boss, location, and enemy is basically a puzzle, a puzzle with no instructions that expects you to pick up the pieces each time you make a mistake. Do yourself a solid, DON'T spoil the game for yourself, the first playthrough is always the one that sticks with you.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Now, I've only just bought this game after achieving The Dark Soul achievement on Xbox 360. That's how good it is - I've 100% completed it on one platform after experiencing it and, after countless death after death after falling off of a bridge or ledge countless times eventually learnt this game how it's meant to be learnt; through the game force feeding you until you figure it out because until then you will just be a lone sheep amongst a pack of wolves. I want that again. I want the thrill of relearning the game because of the new controls and reachieving that unique feeling of "OHMYGODHOWTHEHELLDIDIJUSTWIN" after beating a seemingly impossible area boss because you applied attributes that you'd learnt over trial and error what works against that particular boss. Well there's my personal praise to the game, now for the actual review (even though that was a review):Despite what SO many people say, this game has an incredibly deep story and lore behind it. You just need to really want to know it and look for it because you're literally thrown from your nice little asylum of safety into a world where you're alone, and not many people are friendly. Take away what little you find out from NPC's (which is probably where all those people stopped at with their search) and you need to read through item descriptions or pay close attention to little details in the game and afterwards you'll be sitting there in awe of the lore of it all. If you're here, then no doubt you've already heard how hard this game is. The thing is, it's only hard until you apply the skills it teaches you and then it gets relatively easy. Not "oh I won't die again" easy because it's literally impossible to go through this game without dying, and everyone can be overwhelmed by numbers or make simple mistakes that will cost you your experience until you recover it.Anyway, as I've shown I absolutely love this game and recommend it to anyone wanting a good thrill10/10
