content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Difficulty:Most people who review Dark Souls start with praising the difficulty (or the sun :D), and I will be no exception. While the game is really challenging compared to most games of the newer generations, it's not impossibly hard, as some people make it seem. If you're an old-school player, you could probably instantly name a bunch of DOS games that are harder. Anyway, Dark Souls is a difficult game and it will test your skills and patience.General gameplay:The game plays in a fictional world, called Lordran. After the initial tutorial, you have a huge open world to explore. While the game hints, where you should go next, you are completly free to ignore it. Something that really shines out, is the absolutely wonderful level-design. There are many secret places, and you can find entire maps hidden behind illusionary walls! It's just awesome!Enemies are greatly varied and even include such super awesome mobs as mimics. Bosses are all completly unique both in appearance and mechanics.Combat and controlls:Combat in Dark Souls is complex and slowpaced. It requires you to think strategically, be patient and execute attacks carefully. Often, you're pitted against multiple enemies, each stronger than you. A single mistake can mean death, yet you are able to overcome it. That is the beauty of Dark Souls. You can wield many types of weapons, including all kinds of swords, spears, maces, halberds, knives, bows, crossbows and shields. Something that I've found very cool, is that you can wield any weapon one-handed or two-handed, and switch between the two modes with a click of a button. There are also several spells that you can use (and these work in a D&D style "limited number of spell casts per rest, instead of regenerating mana" fashion).Controlls are well designed, but using an XBox 360 controller is a must.Character development:When the game begins, you can create your own character. The options here are rather limited. You can choose your starting class (more on that later), name, gender, face, body and a special item you start with, called gift.Rather than limiting you to one particular class, Dark Souls allows you to develop your character in any way you want. When you level up, you can increase any of the stats you desire. Since the starting classes only differ in starting stats and starting equipment (and lore), you are free to create a build that matches your playstyle. Items are not limited to certain classes either. One can equip any weapon/armor, provided he or she has the neccessary stats.Lore & Story:The game has quite rich lore behind it, but the general story is not put simply in front of you. Most of the lore is found only as item descriptions; the number of cutscenes and dialogs is few. Choices through dialogs are limited, meaning yes/no. There are two endings, but you only choose one or the other at the very end of the game.Online features:Dark Souls is a very special game when it comes to deciding whether it is a multiplayer or a singleplayer game. Most of the time you play alone. However, you can interact with other players. You can summon other players to help you defeat a boss (though soloing one is way more epic :) ), or you can be invaded by other players who will try to kill you (for those who worry about this: you can be invaded only if certain criterias are met). One thing that I really like though, is that even when you play alone, you feel the online elements. Sometimes you can see the ghosts of other players doing their stuff around you. Sometimes you can see the blood of a player who died there; and if you touch the pool of blood, the game will replay how that character had died. My favourite though, is that instead of players annoying each other in some kind of global chat, every player can write short messages on the ground. Now imagine going down in a dark spiral staircase and reading messages like "Good luck!", or "Tears ahead". It just really adds to the mood.Players can also join so called covenants. These focus on various ascpects of the game, including cooperation, lore, invading other players or punishing those who sinned. There are leaderboards for each covenant for the competative minded.Graphics & Sounds:I usually don't really care about the graphics of a good game, so my opinion may not matter too much. Anyway, I think the graphics are nice. It doesn't pop out of the crowd, like Skyrim that was released around the same time, but it certainly looks good and detailed. One thing to note though, is that the graphicsal settings are very limited without external mods. I mean so limited, that you can't even change the display resolution (it defaults to 720p, 30 fps). Anyone playing this should download the mod called DSFix, where you can freely tweak the rendering settings (along with some neat stuff for those without a controller).Sound effects are detailed and believable. The music is good and goes really well with the setting. Some boss musics are especially memorable. That being said, I still don't consider the soundtrack to be exceptional. I would say, it's about on pair with the graphics (if one can compare two such things as music and graphics).To sum it up:If you like games that challange you, then Dark Souls is certainly a must buy for you. Again, the level design is truly fantastic, and it will definiately take some time for you to beat the game.UPDATE:Now that I've beaten the game I'd like to offer some more info about it.First, while the PvE part of the game is amazing, do not buy it for the PvP, because it sucks. The only thing that matters in PvP is who backstabs who, and that's totally random. Due to the utter-crap network code, you can be backstabbed even while you are meters away, facing the enemy.Second, leveling is implemented in a poor way, as you can become overpowered easily, making the challange go away instantly. There are actually videos about people one-hit-killing bosses. Obviously, this isn't a deal-breaker, but I it's pain to see that even when you meet a new boss for the first time, you can beat it without any trouble. Instead of becomming harder, the game becomes relativly easy after you are roughly half through it. Playthroughs on increased difficulties are easier than expected aswell.

content:
Posted: April 9
												Dark Souls 1 is the once-in-a-generation action RPG title that returned to the values of firm-but-fair combat (which, to us candy-arsed gamers of the last decade would be considered insanely difficult) and presented this concept through an incredible world with eclectic enemies and numerous fun ways to stay alive in it. I will make a mandatory plug that you will get the most out of this game by using a modification called DSfix, which allows for more resolution options and fixes frame rate issues. Most die-hard players wouldn't play without it.It should not be understated that this game is an experience in sadism, self-accountability and perseverance. The mechanics of the game are meant to break you to the point where you have to think about timing, patience, and smart  attacks instead of the hack and slash games you might be used to. Aside from the odd enemy attack whacking you through walls, you are taught through its logical composition that your deaths are a direct result of your own actions. Rarely does a game teach you such accountability. I started the game constantly complaining about how the game isn't fair, and ended up just getting mad at myself for poorly reading enemy attacks. And because bosses are unavoidable, you will keep coming back to hand them your♥♥♥♥♥until you finally take theirs. And when you do, it will be one of the greatest accomplishments you will ever feel from a video game.Here is a short list of the best things about this game that should either make you buy it, or replay it: Outstanding sound design. Crystal clear and unique voice acting. Chilling ambience. Full orchestral accompaniments for almost every boss fight to amp up how monumental each fight is for the nourishment of your bruised ego.  Despite a rather esoteric story, the character lines and voice acting is quite memorable. They all have neat storylines that are as bizarre as they are fascinating. Plus they'll usually do great things for you, or you can kill everyone for the cool items they have (that's what new game plus is for!) The covenant system has a host of benefits and unique ways of levelling up in them. They all serve their own purpose, and sweet loot is always a guarantee. The level-up system that encourages the player to find their sweet spot with respect to magical traits and melee combat. It doesn't hurt to learn about what the stats mean before hand, and if it's worth levelling certain stats past a certain point due to diminishing returns to your play style. Gorgeous views. Dark Souls has one of the nicest open world layouts that was well-planned and genius in its execution. The slickest array of weapons, shields, armour sets, and magic spells for you to obsess over, which is owed to comprehensive statistical breakdowns, a sweet weapon upgrade system, unique abilities that are auxiliary to the amount of damage it does or blocks, and just cool-looking stuff. There's a sub community dedicated to the fashion element of the franchise for a reason. Enemies and bosses that will make you laugh, yell, cry, and maybe even aroused. They're all difficult, but hey - that's par for the course. The player base. Whether it's player versus player battles, summoning people to help you through a zone or a boss, or messages on the ground that mix deceit, helpfulness, and hilarity, you have to hand it to the community that makes Dark Souls unlike any other game you've ever played. Overall, just genius level design, and loot stashing. I felt like there were hilarious joke scenarios that the developers put within the game just to mess with you. You'll know it when it happens.The minor things that weren't so great, but in no way detracts from how sweet the game is: So many sweet rings, so few slots for them. You'll occasionally get nicked by attacks through walls and things that weapons shouldn't clip through. But you can exploit it to your own advantage, too. Bonfires you cannot sit at because there are no keepers.On sale, the value is phenomenal - regardless of your skill level, your first play through is going to net you 30-50 hours. The Prepare to Die addition adds some picturesque new zones and three incredibly challenging bosses that will have you banging your desks in delight and rage. Be warned that once the game ends that you will automatically jump into playing the game all over again, so it's important to look up the two things you have to do to unlock the DLC worlds in your first playthrough - otherwise you'll end up playing the game all over again.In the 76 games I've reviewed so far, I have never felt so strongly about  making sure that every person I know who plays video games to give this game a try. It's smart, will ruin your life for a period of time with how much to the game that you can get involved in, and has an original premise and world that you will lose yourself in (in the most delightful of ways). And the best part is that they were able to do it without cramming a story down your throat. Buy it, beat it, and never forget the feeling of true simulated accomplishment as you watch the credits roll as you think about doing it all over again in a different way.

												For those looking for a punishing game of amazing RPG goodness, it doesnt come much better than Dark Souls.This is a very large game, with alot of gameplay to keep you busy. The game is extremely punishing and WHEN you die, oh yes you will die, its because you have made a mistake. But when you get it right the feeling of pure euphoria washes over you, carrrying you onwards towards your next epic win.Never have i felt such extreme rage and extreme happiness in a single title.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Now, I've only just bought this game after achieving The Dark Soul achievement on Xbox 360. That's how good it is - I've 100% completed it on one platform after experiencing it and, after countless death after death after falling off of a bridge or ledge countless times eventually learnt this game how it's meant to be learnt; through the game force feeding you until you figure it out because until then you will just be a lone sheep amongst a pack of wolves. I want that again. I want the thrill of relearning the game because of the new controls and reachieving that unique feeling of "OHMYGODHOWTHEHELLDIDIJUSTWIN" after beating a seemingly impossible area boss because you applied attributes that you'd learnt over trial and error what works against that particular boss. Well there's my personal praise to the game, now for the actual review (even though that was a review):Despite what SO many people say, this game has an incredibly deep story and lore behind it. You just need to really want to know it and look for it because you're literally thrown from your nice little asylum of safety into a world where you're alone, and not many people are friendly. Take away what little you find out from NPC's (which is probably where all those people stopped at with their search) and you need to read through item descriptions or pay close attention to little details in the game and afterwards you'll be sitting there in awe of the lore of it all. If you're here, then no doubt you've already heard how hard this game is. The thing is, it's only hard until you apply the skills it teaches you and then it gets relatively easy. Not "oh I won't die again" easy because it's literally impossible to go through this game without dying, and everyone can be overwhelmed by numbers or make simple mistakes that will cost you your experience until you recover it.Anyway, as I've shown I absolutely love this game and recommend it to anyone wanting a good thrill10/10

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												exelent game, excels in almost every aspect, however it has some flaws, the port is awful, you have to download mods and optimizations to get it running right, GFWL gives a lot of trouble to most people, but when you get past this, you have ensured at least 100 hours of fun, i've been playing this game for 250+ hours and i can't get enought of it, i love dark soulsthe combat:this game has literally the best combat system ever, different moves, parry-riposte, backstabs, bleed, poison... etc. this makes the game worth it just because of the combatenemies:varied, fun and fair, yes, most enemies will kill you, but they'll never 1 hit ko you and they're revealed first, alone, then many and then mixed (pretty mutch like megaman games)Bosses:GREAT boss battles, and here is where the music quicks in, most bosses have their own theme (stray demon - firesage demon - centipede demon , capra demon and taurus demon have repeated themes) and they're awesome, fitting the boss and capture the distress that you have when fighting for your life! However some bosses are flawled, yes, some are frustrating, but in general, they're pretty good fightsAreas:wow the areas in this game, fit the lore and the theme of the game perfectly, most of them dark, but when the light comes in, its perfectly executed, beautiful places to be in, with enemies fitting the areamultiplayer:can be a shore to get it to work, and pvp its a bit flawled, backstabs tend to lag and cause minor frustration, but once you learn how to counter them, you'll have a blast with pvp now, talking about co-op , sometimes is kinda hard to summon someone, but some bossfights are extremely fun to do with a friendconclussion: extremely good game, fun , engaging, hard, visually apealing, it, has almost everything, could use some optimization, defenitely recommended, you won't find a game like dark souls, ever
